DOC.HEAD: Government Says No Extradition for Drug Lords Who Surrender
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS background, details, minor editing. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Accused drug traffickers who turn themselves in to Colombian authorities will not be extradited to the United States, President Cesar Gaviria said Wednesday in an official decree. Gaviria said the policy, a notable departure from the past, forms part of the government's plan to end drug-related terrorism in Colombia. ``Those who have been in crime and who have repented, and who voluntarily turn themselves in to judges in order to freely confess their crimes may be tried by our judges based on our judicial order,'' Gaviria said in a nationwide televised speech. During the past year, the Medellin cocaine cartel has been demanding an end to extradition, the fate drug traffickers fear most. The cartel in July declared a unilateral ceasefire in its terrorist attacks, apparantly hoping that the new administration would end extraditions. Gaviria was inaugurated Aug. 7. He said in his speech Wednesday that criminals who turn themselves in will face lighter sentences. ``Judges will be given the capacity to reduce sentences ... of those who turn themselves in, confess their crimes, lay down weapons and other goods linked to their crimes and cooperate with investigations,'' Gaviria said. In repeated communiques, drug traffickers using the pseudonym ``The Extraditables'' offered to turn themselves in to Colombian judges, in an apparant attempt to convince the government to end extraditions. The Extraditable's communiques bore the letterhead, ``We prefer a tomb in Colombia to a jail cell in the United States.'' Gaviria's predecessor, Virgilio Barco, reinitiated extraditions a year ago after drug traffickers declared war on the state. Twenty-two Colombians accused of drug trafficking have been extradited to the United States since then. Violence meanwhile has soared, with policemen in particular singled out as targets of hitmen hired by drug traffickers. A domestic airliner in addition was blown out of the sky this year outside Bogota, killing more than 100 people. The government has blamem the Medellin cartel for killing more than 500 people, including three presidential candidates. Thousands of others have died in fighting between rival drug gangs and violence by right-wing death squads financed by cocaine smugglers. In his speech Wednesday, Gaviria said three Colombians currently awaiting extradition will be sent to the United States. He said three other extradition requests by the United States have been rejected. There are 14 people held in Colombian jails awaiting extradition.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim Who Took Struggle Public Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jennifer Folsom, who went public with her family's struggle against AIDS, died at her home Wednesday. Her husband, Doug, shot himself in June when, overcome by the strain of having his wife and young daughter infected with the deadly virus. A second daughter so far hasn't tested positive for the virus. ``This afternoon she smiled, and that was the end of it,'' said Jim Leith, a family friend in Duxbury, where Folsom lived. ``She was a super lady,'' he said. ``She was a gutsy thing. You could take a good example from her. She knew exactly how to handle herself.'' In an interview with the Associated Press in July, Folsom, 29, said she wanted people to know she had AIDS because she wanted to ``live with dignity and not have people whispering behind my back. I'm not ashamed of who I am. (AIDS) invaded my home without permission.'' A blood transfusion during an emergency appendectomy in a Massachusetts hospital in 1979 _ before blood supplies were tested and purged of the virus _ probably carried the AIDS virus into her body. She was diagnosed in February 1988. The doctor gave her the test results in his empty office after closing; he was concerned, she said, about how his staff would react to an AIDS patient. Angela, Folsom's 3-year-old daughter, also has withered from acquired immune deficiency syndrome and requires round-the-clock nursing. ``It's not over,'' Leith said. ``They have to take a deep breath and come out of this, and deal with that too.'' Angela and 4-year-old Nicolette, who is tested for the virus every six months, will live with grandparents, Leith said. Folsom initially told friends and neighbors that she had cancer. But then went public with her story because she wanted people to know that rural Vermont hasn't escaped AIDS. ``Here I am, this white, middle-class housewife living in Vermont, trying to make a living,'' she said. ``How dare this disease come into my home? It's AIDS. I eat and drink and sleep AIDS. But I'm not afraid of it anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets With Iraqi Foreign Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Tass report on Gorbachev meeting with Aziz, EDITS throughout to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will maintain diplomatic ties with Iraq for now but still demands that Iraq end its occupation of Kuwait, Tass reported Wednesday following President Mikhail Gorbachev's meeting with the Iraqi foreign minister. U.S. Sen. Bob Dole said he believed the minister, Tareq Aziz, was carrying a message for Gorbachev to give to President Bush at the superpower summit in Helsinki. The Kansas Republican, the minority leader in the Senate, spoke to reporters after his own meeting with the Soviet president in the Kremlin. Aziz met with Gorbachev later in the day. Tass said the meeting was held at the request of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and that the two held a frank discussion on the gulf crisis. It said Soviet officials emphasised that they want, ``for the moment at least, to maintain permanent diplomatic contact with Iraqi leaders.'' ``Until now, however, no political or diplomatic contacts between Moscow and Baghdad have produced the desired result _ the immediate withdrawal of all Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the restoration of that country's independence and sovereignty,'' Tass said. Dole said he thought Aziz was ``coming here, hopefully, to pass some message on to Gorbachev that might be passed on to President Bush.'' ``Maybe it will provide some breakthrough, maybe some little ray of hope. Maybe Saddam Hussein now realizes he made a big, big mistake'' by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, Dole told an airport news conference minutes before leaving for Washington. Bush and Gorbachev meet in the Finnish capital Sunday. The crisis following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was expected to rank high on their agenda. Aziz was to address a news conference Thursday at the Soviet Foreign Ministry, and was expected to discuss the message he was believed to have carried. Dole said he and six other Republican senators winding up a trip to the Soviet Union ``just had a very good visit with President Gorbachev. ... We talked about a number of issues, particularly the upcoming summit. ``We indicated ... none of us want armed conflict. We hope there will be a peaceable solution. ... My impression is that Gorbachev is in almost total agreement on this point.'' ``He indicated it was a turning point that was very important for both countries,'' Dole said. ``He sees it as a very important meeting, when you think about this being the two superpowers meeting now for the first time with reference to a conflict where they are both on the same side.'' Gorbachev told the senators his meeting with Aziz was ``initiated at the request of the Iraqis,'' Dole reported. ``He said in effect, `I am prepared to hear them out and of course I will be reporting to President Bush on what was said and what transpired.''' In an interview broadcast on Soviet television Wednesday night, Gorbachev described Dole as ``close to President Bush'' and said ``the conversation was important for me in connection with the forthcoming meeting in Helsinki.'' During the interview, Gorbachev dwelt almost exclusively with an economic program he is expected to announce next week to move the Soviet Union closer to a market economy, away from the current central planning system. Dole replied when pressed on what proposals Gorbachev and Bush might make to end the gulf crisis, ``I wouldn't even speculate'' on what would transpire. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said he asked Gorbachev ``to clarify this question of the Soviets there in the capacity of advisers and experts,'' referring to 193 Soviet employees affiliated with Iraq's military. According to Warner, Gorbachev ``said right away, `They're not advisers. They have not been involved in the hostilities. They are simply contractors there to work on the equipment. We would like to bring them back. But if we were to break those contracts and bring them back home, it could well jeopardize the 6,000-8,000 Soviets there''' on construction contracts. Warner, ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Gorbachev also wanted to sign treaties with the United States and other Western nations to cut conventional and long-range nuclear arms by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern European Anti-Semitism Discussed
DOC.TEXT: Jewish and Roman Catholic leaders from 16 countries have agreed that a major inititiative is needed to combat anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe, the New York Times reported in Thursday editions. The agreement came in Prague, Czechoslovakia, at the first formal meeting in five years of the Vatican Commission on Religious Relations with the Jews and the International Jewish Committee on Interreligious Consultations. The four-day meeting was scheduled to end Thursday. Archbishop William H. Keeler of Baltimore told the Times the conference's closing statement would call for Catholic repentance and stress that anti-Semitism ``is a sin against God and humanity.'' It also will recognize ``the special problems of anti-Semitism in Eastern and Central Europe,'' said Rabbi Jack Bemporad, chairman of the Interreligious Affairs Office of the Synagogue Council of America. Open anti-Semitism is said to be on the rise in the region, as the fall of totalitarian Communist regimes allows people to express their views more freely. Participants at the meeting recommended that other Eastern European countries follow the lead of Poland and Czechoslovakia in setting up Catholic-Jewish liaison committees. It also urged rapid translation and dissemination of recent Vatican statements on Catholic-Jewish relations. Eastern European churches lacked either permission or resources to publish these documents. Also recommended by participants are systematic efforts rid textbooks of religiously or racially divisive material, establishment of seminary courses and training programs for priests to counter anti-Semitism, and new efforts to defend religious liberty and monitor any outbreaks of anti-Semitism. Vatican officials also reaffirmed their intention to prepare a major document on the church and the Holocaust, a project pledged in 1987 but delayed. Catholic-Jewish relations are ``back on track,'' Seymour Reich, chairman of the Jewish committee, told The Times. The Jewish committee was established in 1967 as an umbrella group for discussions with the Vatican. Its membership includes the Synagogue Council of America, B'nai Brith International and the World Jewish Congress.

DOC.HEAD: CNN to Cover Space Shuttle Lift-Off Live
With AM-Space Shuttle, PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK _ None of the major broadcast TV networks will carry live coverage of the liftoff of the space Shuttle Columbia, scheduled for 1:20 a.m. Thursday, but Cable News Network plans live coverage. CNN will broadcast the liftoff live and will update its coverage throughout the day, a spokeswoman said. An NBC spokeswoman said the network would not itself broadcast the space shuttle launch live, but would offer a live feed to its affiliates to carry if they wish. Representatives of CBS and ABC said they had no plans for live coverage of the liftoff, which is NASA's third attempt to send Columbia on an astronomy mission and its first shuttle flight in months.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Semitism: Old Demon Haunts New Polish Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Four months ago, someone painted a small, rusty-red swastika on a stone pillar a few steps from the Israeli ambassador's home. He drives by it every day, neighbors walk dogs past it, children play nearby. No one has tried to obliterate the ugly symbol. Graffiti and other signs of anti-Semitism are being seen again in Poland, even though it is nearly bereft of Jews, and the prejudice of the streets has begun to infiltrate politics. Some rightist politicians are fanning nationalist emotions and, with a seeming inevitability, anti-Semitism. On the other side, prominent anti-Communist figures like Adam Michnik, editor of the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, and Zbigniew Bujak _ both leaders of the pro-government Democratic Action party _ have been sounding the alarm. Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa, indignant at suggestions of bigotry on the part of himself or some of his followers, declared: ``Lech Walesa is not and will not be anti-Semitic.'' In a resolution July 29, Walesa's national Citizens Committee condemned both prejudice and the use of unfounded charges of anti-Semitism to smear political opponents. Members of the committee have accused foreign journalists of exaggerating the extent of anti-Semitism in Poland. The late sociologist Aleksander Hertz, a Polish Jew, said anti-Semitism grew in the 19th century in response to Poland's humiliating partitions, Russian influences and the prosperity of a burgeoning Jewish population, which both the declining aristocracy and impoverished peasants resented. In politics, anti-Semitism peaked just before World War II, when it was a major tenet of the popular National Democrats. University students hounded Jewish colleagues and anti-Semites organized boycotts of Jewish businesses. Three million Polish Jews were killed by the Nazis. Some of the half-million who survived owed their lives to Poles who hid them, but others were betrayed by Polish acquaintances. Polish Jews who lived through the Holocaust were traumatized by it and feared trying to reclaim homes and property from Christians, particularly after a pogrom in 1946 that took 48 lives in Kielce. Most of them emigrated to Israel or the United States. An official Communist purge of ``Zionists'' prompted the last big wave of emigration in 1968, reducing the number of Jews to 5,000-15,000 in a nation of 38 million people. For the first time in centuries, Poland is without a large Jewish population, and profound changes have resulted. Before the war, Jews were about 10 percent of the population, concentrated in towns and cities, and made up a large part of the middle class. The landed aristocracy disdained commerce and peasants stuck to their farms, so much of the small business, trade and industry were left to Jews. Half a century after Nazi occupation, Poland still has not come to grips with the loss of its Jewish population. Any discussion of Jews is likely to provoke strong emotions, often defensive. Poland's only rabbi, Pinchas Menachem Joskowicz, said he had noticed more anti-Semitism recently. He used to find respect and friendliness when he walked the streets in his traditional orthodox garb, Joskowicz said, but now encounters hostility. ``Two weeks ago, I had guests from Israel and we went for a walk,'' he said in an interview. ``Then youths, maybe 21, maybe younger, started shouting `Jews to Palestine' and other slogans, too. I did not pay any attention, let them shout. ``But when we walked a few meters they approached us and started hitting one of the guests.'' Joskowicz said he now avoids walking at night and does not know what to tell Jews from abroad when they ask him if it is safe to visit Poland. There is a tendency to blame Jews for the nation's troubles. ``I keep hearing that a gang has gotten to the feeding trough, they are probably Jews and they are destroying us,'' Walesa told a meeting of his national Citizens Committee on June 24. He said such remarks do not mean anti-Semitism is increasing, but that the government must do a better job of explaining itself to the people. Farmers who occupied the Agriculture Ministry in June, demanding guaranteed prices, were heard muttering about the ``Jewish government.'' That government is led by a devout Roman Catholic, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who identifies with Christian-Democratic politics and sometimes is accused of being too solicitous of the church. Allegations that Jews run the government rest on the fact that some prominent Solidarity politicians are Jews. Two examples are Michnik and Parliament member Bronislaw Geremek, leader of the Citizens Parliamentary Club, who are of Jewish descent but do not practice the religion. Communist functionaries used such information in the past in the vain hope of discrediting Solidarity. In August, the National Party, a far-right group based in the southern city of Krakow, said it was unfair for an ethnic minority to have dominance in the government. The Grunwald Society, created by nationalistic Communists, contended recently that ``German and Jewish chauvinists'' were the greatest threats to Polish sovereignty. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska, who wrote a book on the remaining Jews in Poland with her husband, a photographer, said anti-Semitism is coming to the surface in the more liberal atmosphere since Communist rule. ``Now everything is free,'' she said. ``Many good things have come out, but also some bad things.'' Some anti-Semitism is present in all countries, she said, and ``I hope it will be marginal in Poland too for the future. Because it's visible, it can be fought.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Sun And Sand Take Toll On U.S. Gear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto of Sept. 4.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: EAGLE FORWARD BASE CAMP, Saudi Arabia (AP)
DOC.TEXT: The harsh conditions of the Saudi desert are taking a toll on U.S. military equipment, affecting simple mechanical gear as well as sensitive high-tech equipment, from M-16 rifles to weapons guidance systems. The warships patrolling the waters around the Arabian peninsula are also have problems, officers and maintenance crews said. ``When you buy a stereo, what do the instructions say?'' Marine Gunnery Sgt. Tate Ingles of Miami asked during a recent interview. ``They say you should keep it away from heat, dust and vibration. You put the same electrical gear in the Saudi desert, and, well, there you have it.'' Because of the heat and sand, weapons systems that rely on sensitive electronics and computers could be troublesome to operate if extended hostilities broke out, technicians say. At Eagle Forward, a base camp for Apache gunships and other helicopters of the 101st Airborne Division's air assault brigade, the soft Saudi sand blown by the desert wind is the big headache. ``It's unbelievable. It gets everywhere,'' a maintenance crew member said. Crews are flushing out the Apache engines with water every day to rid them of the sand. The powdery sand also finds its way into transmissions and gears that turn the rotors, forcing more frequent maintenance on those systems as well. ``Hovering around in the desert is going to be very hard on the engines,' said Maj. Greg Maisel, of Laredo, Texas, the executive officer of a Marine attack squadron. Helicopters are being fitted with radiator filters much like the black wraps often seen on fronts of sports cars. ``We were having a lot of overheating problems because of sand clogging the radiators,'' squadron leader Lt. Col. Don Cody said. ``We think the filters have fixed that.'' The sand scours the paint from rotor blades, exposing metal that glints in the sun, making the helicopters easier to spot. Sand is the reason the Air Force is cutting the time between its routine maintenance. Tests and routine adjustments made every 100 hours are now being done every 60-75 hours, an air force official said. One persistent problem is sand clogging air-intake valves of jet engines. Much like the Apaches, the engines of Air Force and Navy planes, on the ground and aboard carriers, are being flushed with water daily. A Marine sergeant cleaning his automatic rifle noted: ``Sometimes I'm not sure it would fire if I needed it to. We train in the desert, but I've never seen anything like this.'' Tanks need more frequent filter cleanings and track flushing and higher viscosity oil. Radiators need to be checked constantly to prevent overheating. The sand cakes on headlights and windshields and can get into the fuel supply if proper care is not taken. Weapons systems protected from the sand can't escape the scorching sun. Within days of arriving here, 82nd Airborne units were reporting dead radios because wires were burned out or fused by the heat. One officer in the division said Monday that parts for the radios and other equipment being damaged are getting hard to come by. ``We're short quite a few things,'' said the officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I'm sure we'll get them eventually.'' Meantime, ingenuity is helping. On Tuesday, two 82nd soldiers were at a Safeway supermarket in a Saudi town, cleaning it out of sponges and cloth. A vehicle containing several TOW anti-tank missiles and other weapons exploded at an 82nd motor pool Monday and the men suspect heat was a factor. The equipment problems are frustrating, but the maintenance crews try to keep a sense of humor. ``Some officer says, `Hey, my radio don't work,''' Ingles said. ``I tell him: `Sir, if you'd been sitting out here under a magnifying glass in 130-degree temperatures all day, you wouldn't work either.'''

DOC.HEAD: Monet Stars at Royal Academy, Which Rejected Him in 1871
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Academy of Arts in Piccadilly opens an exhibition of 94 works by Monet on Friday, hoping to draw at least a half million visitors over three months _ more than for any other show in its 222-year history. Receipts at that level would bring in up to $5.6 million, which could be used for its current huge renovation. The works in the new exhibition, ``Monet in the '90s: The Series Paintings,'' are among the most beautiful and intriguing that Monet did in his long life. He was 86 when he died in 1926 at his home in Giverny near Paris. In the 1890s, he created series of paintings of the same subjects in different weather and light, exhibiting each group as it was completed. Among the subjects in the show are 11 views of grainstacks, 20 of poplar trees, 10 of Rouen cathedral, seven of misty mornings on the Seine river, 15 of the Normandy coast, four of the Thames and five of the Japanese-style bridge over Monet's waterlily pond. Ten paintings of the Creuse valley in central France include one loaned by Britain's Queen Mother Elizabeth. Paul Hayes Tucker, associate professor of art at the University of Massachusetts, spent four years assembling the exhibition from five continents and said Monet's paintings of the 1890s were ``perhaps the grandest incarnation of his art.'' ``They have been collected from all over the world with immense difficulties and I believe we won't be able to see them together again in our lifetime,'' said academy president Roger de Grey. The show, with some changes, opened at Boston Museum of Fine Arts in February and was later seen at the Art Institute of Chicago. London is its only venue in Europe. In 1872, Monet's style was dubbed ``impressionism'' by a derisive critic who saw in Paris his painting of Le Havre called ``Impression: Sunrise.'' Monet subsequently became rich and famous as the father of impressionism, the most popular art movement the world has ever known. Ironically, the academy in 1871 turned down three Monet paintings of London: canvases of Hyde Park, Green Park and the Thames river at Westminster. The academy is the first gallery in Britain to adopt the European and American system of selling tickets in advance and has already sold 16,000 at 5 pounds ($9.35) each. The show is open daily through Dec. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarket Cuts Beef Prices, Blames Persian Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A supermarket chain has slashed retail beef prices by as much as 50 percent, and says it's partly because the Persian Gulf crisis has cut off the Iraqi market for Irish meat. Superquinn, which has 12 outlets in the greater Dublin area, has reduced the price of boneless rib steak from $3.20 to $1.70 per pound. ``The whole thing is a cynical advertising ploy to grab a bit of the market,'' William Smith, president of the Irish Master Butchers Association, complained on Tuesday. He contended that wholesale prices had held steady. ``There is an element of a special offer in it,'' said Fergal Quinn, owner of Superquinn, but he insisted it was a legitimate reaction to the gulf crisis. ``It's influenced by the fact that there is surplus of beef in the market place,' he said. Iraq had been a major buyer of Irish beef, but the market was cut off by a U.N.-ordered trade embargo following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Quinn added that the drop in demand was largely for hindquarter cuts, and he had no plans to mark down the price of sirloin.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Intends to Aid Gorbachev, Not Hem Him in at Summit
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Grateful for Soviet backing in the Persian Gulf, President Bush is unlikely to try to push President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beyond his political limits when they meet Sunday in Finland. At the same time, Bush will try to help Gorbachev where he needs it the most _ his ailing economy. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher will take some 15 chiefs of American corporations to Moscow to begin discussions on large-scale technical cooperation. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, will discuss with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze U.S. offers to help improve areas such as banking, housing, the tax system and distribution networks. Baker delivered a list of nine projects to Shevardnadze in Paris in mid-July. This followed an initial discussion between Bush and Gorbachev at the Malta summit last December, and Bush intends to pursue the subject at Helsinki, provided the Persian Gulf crisis does not take up all their time. A leader of the Communist Party's traditionalist wing told 2,500 delegates at a Russian party congress Tuesday that Gorbachev's reform program is ``on the brink of collapse.'' Ivan K. Polozkov, first secretary of the Communist Party in the Russian Republic, drew vigorous applause from the delegates. The group includes many generals and career party officials who are believed to harbor reservations about Gorbachev's policies _ on both the economic and Persian Gulf fronts. Many of those same conservatives do not seem to agree with the Soviet leader and Shevardnadze, his chief interlocutor with the U.S. administration, that the Cold War is over. Gen. Vladimir Lobov, the military chief of the Warsaw Pact, was quoted last week as expressing grave doubts about the U.S. military buildup in the gulf area. According to Tass, the Soviet news agency, he warned that it ``drastically changes the strategic balance in the region.'' Fighting to keep his reforms going, Gorbachev cannot risk it all by going much further than he has to accommodate Bush in his campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. After some initial hesitation, the Soviets voted Aug. 6 in the U.N. Security Council for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq and then, on Aug. 25, after more hesitation, to use force to implement it. In both instances, the Soviets could have killed the U.S. moves with their veto. Gorbachev chose instead to support Bush in what is the most dramatic gesture of superpower cooperation since the waning of the Cold War. ``I don't know where we would be with this effort if it were not for the cooperation and enlightened new thinking of the Soviet leadership,'' Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday. And yet, to keep peace with their political foes, Gorbachev and Shevardnadze also are stressing the explosive nature of the situation in the gulf and urging a speedy political settlement. It is a view endorsed last weekend in Beijing by Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen after three hours of talks with Shevardnadze. If Bush could have his way, the Soviets would yank the 193 military advisers and some 1,000 other Soviet nationals involved in training, maintenance and other military-related tasks in Iraq. They are remnants of the Kremlin's long-term close military ties to the Saddam government. ``We think, quite frankly, it is inappropriate to be providing any military assistance to Iraq at the present time and we will continue to talk to the Soviets about the 193,'' Baker told the House committee. But he said it was not clear the Soviet advisers are free to leave. Some 8,000 Soviet nationals are in Iraq and Kuwait. So, as Bush's Helsinki summit with Gorbachev shapes up, the president will emphasize the cooperation he is getting from the Kremlin and not haggle over the bumps in the road. ``We want to keep them on the reservation,'' a senior U.S. official told The Associated Press on Tuesday. ``We are not asking for anything specific at the moment.'' A key U.S. objective, he said, is to assure the Soviets that the military operation in the Persian Gulf is not directed against Moscow. In all, 26 countries have sent in military forces, many of them token contributions. While the West and Japan rely far more than the Soviet Union on gulf petroleum, the Soviets are a superpower with close ties to a number of Arab countries and clearly do not want the area dominated by the United States. Bush is bound to make the point to Gorbachev repeatedly that the U.S. objective is to force Iraq to reverse its annexation of Kuwait _ and no more than that.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid heads the AP's State Department staff.

DOC.HEAD: US Working on Developing Mideast Security Alliance
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Baker testimony scheduled for 10 a.m. EDT; Will be topped
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The United States is working to develop a long-term alliance to stabilize the Middle East in much the way that NATO was used to contain Soviet expansion after World War II, Secretary of State James A. Baker III says. At a hearing Tuesday before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Baker described the alliance as ``a new security structure'' for the region. He told a reporter later that it could be military in nature, or diplomatic and political. The U.S. role remains to be defined, but the new entity would include ``major Arab participation,'' said Baker, who also was testifying today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``We've still got a lot of work to do,'' Baker said after a three-hour hearing in which he addressed for the first time publicly how the United States ultimately might deal with the continuing threat posed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Addressing the expense of the U.S. military operation in the Persian Gulf, Baker said ``leadership sometimes does cost. It's going to run us probably around $6 billion for the balance of 1990.'' At the same time, some lawmakers reacted coolly to Tuesday's announcement by the White House that President Bush wants to forgive $7 billion in past military loans to Egypt, a reward for President Hosni Mubarak's leadership in marshaling Arab opinion against Saddam. Such a move would require action by Congress. Lawmakers said they valued Egypt's action, but they were wary of the high figure, which is equal to half of next year's total foreign aid budget. ``It's a small price to pay for the level of cooperation we've gotten from Egypt,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, but the price looked a lot larger on Capitol Hill. ``It may be a little premature,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., just back from a four-day trip to the Middle East during which he and other lawmakers met with Mubarak. ``I would like to hear firsthand from the administration the rationale,'' Michel added. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., whose Senate Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee must deal with the request, predicted that other nations _ Israel, Pakistan, Greece and Turkey, for example _ will be lining up for similar favors. ``I know it's going to be necessary to increase some foreign aid dollars as a result of Operation Desert Shield,'' the military and economic drive against Iraq, Leahy said in an interview. But he added, ``It looks like some in the administration are saying let's have a blank check for foreign aid. I want to remind them that my subcommittee's still got the checkbook.'' Baker, in his testimony to the House committee, said creation of a new multilateral security structure is ``likely to be required, even if there is a pullback from Kuwait.'' The new structure would involve ``some continuing U.S. presence,'' he said. ``Maybe it wouldn't be a ground force presence, maybe it would be a naval presence.'' When asked by Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., whether any multinational arrangement could prevent Saddam from developing nuclear weapons, or from using the chemical and biological arsenal he already has, Baker's answer sounded much like Cold War deterrence. ``It is conceivably possible ... to come up with a security structure that would make it so clearly to the detriment of any subsequent leader, or even the present leader, to use or contemplate using any of those weapons that there would be very little risk that they would be used,'' Baker said. In other comments, Baker said: _Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat ``jumped too quick'' in aligning himself with Iraq in the crisis. As money flowing back home to Palestinian families from workers inside Iraq falls off, ``I think there could well be ... some reassessment'' of that commitment, he said. ``You are beginning to see in public comments and in other ways that a reassessment is going on.'' _The United States has added Iraq to its official list of countries sponsoring terrorism. The move, which carries certain automatic trade sanctions, was largely symbolic because Iraq already is under a total economic embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Sheriff, now Congressman, Accused of Coercing Confession
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court panel Tuesday postponed the execution of a convicted murderer after hearing arguments that he was coerced into confessing by a sheriff who now is a congressman. U.S. Rep. Tommy Robinson, has denied allegations he and his Pulaski County deputies beat defendant Barry Lee Fairchild and five other black suspects and urged them to confess to the killing of an Air Force nurse. Fairchild, 36, was scheduled to die by lethal injection at 9 p.m. Wednesday for the 1983 abduction, rape and murder of Marjorie ``Greta'' Mason. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, on a 3-0 vote, ordered the case returned to U.S. District Court for a hearing on the allegations. The state attorney general's office was preparing to petition the U.S. Supreme Court to dissolve the stay and let the execution proceed. Assistant Attorney General Jack Gillean said he would argue in a petition to be filed Wednesday morning that that defense attorneys failed to present a plausible case that Fairchild is innocent. He said that is a requirement this late in the appeals process. Fairchild's attorneys say he is mildly retarded, with an IQ between the 60s and 80s, and contend he was easy prey for authorities seeking to force a confession. He confessed twice, but later said the statements were coerced. His lawyers also contend that someone other than Fairchild confessed to the murder. They said police later dropped the man as a suspect because he provided few details about the crime. ``We are not just dealing with coerced confessions. We are dealing with what appears to be investigative practices that do not depend on collecting evidence,'' Richard Burr of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund told the panel. ``We are dealing with a systematic practice of culling out suspects based on who's the weakest.'' Before the stay was issued, Robinson, the congressman, issued a news release saying: ``The attorneys for Barry Lee Fairchild have lost all credibility. The affidavits filed today are the desperate, last-minute moves of ambulance-chasing, publicity-seeking lawyers who care more about ego gratification and about their own press clippings than they care about our system of justice.'' Robinson was elected as a Democrat but switched to the Republican party. He lost the GOP primary for governor this year and isn't seeking re-election to the House. In recent days, Burr, of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and defense attorney John Wesley Hall, said they got a tip that four other men were beaten. The attorneys and their staffs interviewed Nolan McCoy, Frankie Webb, Donald Lewis and Randy Mitchell concerning the allegations. Three of the four men are state inmates. ``They were beaten _ several were bloodied in the beatings that were inflicted,'' the attorneys said in Tuesday's pleading. ``They were threatened with guns, often thrust into their faces, and they were kicked. All were pushed and shoved and knocked around. They were terrorized racially, threatened with hanging and with being killed and thrown in the river, they were called `nigger,' they had a barrage of pejorative epithets thrown their way. And they were all told, `We know you were involved.''' A spokesman for the lower court said a date for the hearing had yet to be set. The hearing Tuesday was conducted by telephone conference in the Little Rock office of Judge Richard S. Arnold. Judges Donald Ross of Omaha, Neb., and Frank Magill of Fargo, N.D., participated.

DOC.HEAD: Dentist With AIDS Sends Warning Letters to Ex-Patients
DOC.TEXT: A dentist believed to have given a patient AIDS during a tooth extraction has sent others he once treated a warning letter suggesting they get tested for the virus. ``I am sorry I cannot tell you this face to face, but I am dying of this disease,'' wrote Dr. David J. Acer of Stuart. ``I am very close to the end.'' The Centers for Disease Control last month reported that a 21-year-old woman contracted AIDS during a dental visit, the nation's first known instance of a health professional apparently giving the disease to a patient. The agency did not identify the dentist or the patient and said it was not clear how the virus was transmitted. ``I do not understand how such a thing could have happened, and I do not believe it did happen,'' Acer wrote. ``I am a gentle man, and I would never intentionally expose anyone to this disease.'' The dentist sent a copy of the letter to the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, which released it Tuesday. It was unclear how many he sent to former patients. The letter does not say when Acer learned he had AIDS or how long he practiced afterward. He said he stopped when he got AIDS-related cancer. Acer, whose telephone number is unlisted, could not be reached for comment. While HRS never publicly confirmed that the dentist in the CDC report practiced in Florida, the agency said it had the ability to track down patients and urge them to take an AIDS test. But under state confidentiality laws, HRS would be prevented from telling the patients that their connection to the dentist had prompted the advice. Acer said he consulted experts after testing positive for the AIDS virus and was assured he could continue practicing. Among the guidelines he followed were those from the CDC itself such as wearing gloves and a mask, he said. Acer said he did not suffer a puncture wound that could have exposed the patient to infected blood. ``Because I was aware that I had the HIV virus, I was extremely careful in how I practiced dentistry,'' he said. Nevertheless, Acer said he understood that former patients could be frightened and suggested they contact health authorities for testing and counseling. ``I have cared for people all my life, and to infect anyone with this disease would be contrary to everything I have stood for,'' he wrote. ``I am sorry if the news story has caused you fear and worry.'' A 22-year-old woman identified only as K.B. has taken steps to sue a ``Dr. D.A.'' for malpractice in state court in Palm Beach, according to court papers. A motion says the woman went to the dentist in 1987 and contracted AIDS from him. The lawsuit has yet to be filed. The motion asked that the woman be allowed to testify via videotape because she is in the advanced stages of the disease. A judge granted the request last month.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Release Tensions of Gulf Crisis With Gallows Humor
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israelis awoke the other day to a new bumper sticker: ``Come on Saddam, Step on the Gas.'' The slogan was an example of the macabre humor that has cropped up as Israelis try to cope with the tension and uncertainty born of threats from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's to attack them with chemical weapons. Both Saddam and chemical weapons have become sources of gallows humor. A new T-shirt features a picture of Saddam with the legend ``Wanted for murder, jaywalking and armed robbery.'' A popular theme for satirists and cartoonists are the long-snouted gas masks to be distributed to civilians in case of an Iraqi attack. The jokes began after Saddam first issued his threat in April, saying he would annihilate half of Israel with binary chemical weapons if Israel were to attack his country with nuclear weapons. State-controlled television picked up the theme in a skit that also played on the heated political horse-trading going on then to form a new government. It showed several friends wearing gas masks and playing cards. As the camera zoomed in on one of the players, he lifted his mask and said with a sigh of admiration: ``That Saddam is an OK guy. Thanks to him, you can't smell the stink of the politics in this place.'' Saddam's invasion of Kuwait last month, followed by an acrimonious public debate about whether to distribute gas masks at once, provided humorists with fresh material. The mass circulation Maariv newspaper ran a two-page spread of cartoons called ``Gas Masks in Our Daily Lives.'' One of the frames showed an attack dog running away from a mailman wearing a gas mask. A popular prime time television show featured a wife at the dinner table complaining about the husband's noisy eating habits. The camera then turned to the husband, his face covered by a gas mask with strands of spaghetti dangling from the nose filter. ``You try eating through this thing,'' he said angrily. Israelis, surrounded by hostile Arab states and hardened by the wars they endured during the country's four decades, are a responsive audience.

DOC.HEAD: Post Meets with Unions, Sets Sept. 15 Deadline for Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: New York Post management told its unions Tuesday that the paper had to have a cost cutting plan by the end of next week and indicated the continued publication of the nation's oldest daily was at stake. Post Vice President and General Manager Richard T. Nasti said after a meeting with leaders of the paper's 10 unions that the paper has set Sept. 15 as a deadline for reaching agreement. He said he was optimistic the deadline will be met. Nasti didn't say specifically what would happen if the deadline weren't met. Theodore Kheel, a labor mediator and unpaid adviser a union group who attended the meeting, said he understood that management would suspend publication Sept 15 if it couldn't reach agreement with the unions on $17 million in savings. The paper's 900 employees and 10 unions are represented by the Allied Printing Trades Council. The council's president, George McDonald, said management ``told us they are losing money, and they are looking for some relief from the unions.'' The losses have been blamed in part on the city's slumping economy. Publisher Peter Kalikow called the meeting and said through a spokesman the session was ``very cordial, not a hostile meeting, with both sides trying to work it out.'' The Post offered to open its books to its 10 unions, and meetings with individual unions are scheduled throughout Wednesday and Thursday. In a prepared statement, Nasti said management officials would meet with each union ``for lengthy and detailed explanations of their cost saving proposals.'' ``This newspaper has served New York for 190 years and through a cooperative effort between labor and management it will continue to serve New York for another 190 years,'' he said. Kalikow must find $25 million in annual savings to continue publishing the paper, Nasti said. Kheel said the $17 million figure is the amount the Post hopes to save through cost-cutting measures affecting its unions, with the rest to be made up in other ways. Kalikow took over the Post from Rupert Murdoch in 1988 when the paper was losing about $3 million monthly. Concessions from the unions were part of the package that Murdoch had to achieve in order to meet Kalikow's terms. Those same unions are now involved in intense negotiations with the rival Daily News of New York. The News is seeking contracts that would allow management to institute a variety of cost saving measures that the News says are critical to its survival.

DOC.HEAD: Meat Industry Fighting Projected Layoff of USDA Inspectors
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department's food guardians are getting steady pressure from the meat industry to soften the round of inspection layoffs that will occur next month if Congress and the White House fail to reach a budget agreement. But the plan for furloughing thousands of federal meat and poultry inspectors for several days every two-week pay period beginning Oct. 1, the start of fiscal year 1991, is still in effect, officials said Tuesday. ``The die is cast and unless something is done, the furlough will take place,'' said spokesman Jim Greene of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. Last week, the inspection agency notified the nation's 6,300 federally inspected meat and poultry plants that the initial layoff order by President Bush would be for a maximum of 36 hours during the Oct. 1-14 period. Agency Administrator Lester Crawford said the layoffs ``would effectively shut down'' plants during the furlough periods. The White House, meanwhile, said it is willing to listen to proposals for a budget reduction of less than $50 billion, the current target under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. Budget negotiators will resume talks in private at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., in hopes of reaching an agreement by Sunday. Meanwhile, if layoffs take effect on Oct. 1 as currently planned, it could mean hardships for the industry and consumers, said the American Meat Institute, a trade association. ``Furloughs are not the answer,'' said institute President J. Patrick Boyle. ``At best, it would take years for the industry and the economy to recover the losses generated from furloughs of the magnitude being discussed for fiscal 1991.'' The meat and poultry industry asked Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter to find alternative methods of coping with the inspection agency's budget problems, including the possibility of giving inspectors priority status so they could keep production lines moving. ``Closing factory doors has unacceptable costs, not only to plant workers, who would be denied their jobs, but to consumers, who would be denied essential food products, and to the government, which would be denied additional tax revenues,'' the groups told Yeutter. A shutdown of one day would idle 356,000 workers, halt livestock and poultry purchases from producers, and cost nearly $1 billion in lost sales throughout the marketing chain, they said. However, FSIS Administrator Crawford said the industry's request for giving inspectors priority for remaining on the job would not work. ``In plant inspectors, import inspectors and circuit supervisors comprise 82 percent of our work force,'' he said. ``The remaining 18 percent represents laboratory technicians, compliance officers, label reviewers and administrative staff that are essential to carrying out the FSIS label.'' About 88 percent of the agency's budget is salaries, Crawford said. And 4.6 percent of its money is for fixed, non-salary costs that must be paid with or without a furlough.

Spraying chemicals to kill grasshoppers on land set aside under the Conservation Reserve Program is not expected to have significant harmful effects, according to studies by the Agriculture Department. The environmental assessments by USDA involved CRP land in Idaho, western Minnesota and the Dakotas, a region of severe grasshopper infestation, officials said Tuesday. Land in the program is taken from crop production for 10 years and planted to protective grass and trees. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said CRP land ``poses an extremely inviting target to grasshoppers, which can consume all vegetation in an infested area.'' The assessments were made under an assumption that grasshoppers will be controlled through an integrated pest management program using several methods, including spraying with malathion, carbaryl and acephate, as well as using baits containing carbaryl or Nosema locustae. However, Glosser said the use of Nosema, a biological control agent, will not be used on CRP land this year because it ``does not achieve the quick knockdown'' of grasshoppers needed to protect nearby crops. The assessments were said to cover effects on human health, endangered species, other wildlife, water resources, aquatic species, soil, vegetation, air quality, land use, cultural resources and economic concerns.

A new mechanical Big Foot with legs and feet instead of wheels is being developed to prowl forests, the Agriculture Department says. The vehicle ``will soon be strolling about the woods of southwest Virginia'' near Blacksburg, home of Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, one of the machine's developers, the department said Tuesday. Products technologist Robert Koeppen of the Forest Service said the machine could solve some forest management problems while helping protect forest ecosystems. Currently, forest managers depend on rubber-tired vehicles, which can cause soil compaction, rutting or damage to vegetation, the agency said. Wheeled vehicles also are limited by terrain that is too rough, steep, wet or soft. The machine, called ``the robotic walking vehicle,'' may alleviate such problems. For example, it can move sideways, a maneuver Koeppen said may help drastically reduce damage to forest soils and vegetation. A public unveiling of the machine has been scheduled for Sept. 11 at Virginia Tech, with field tests to begin later this month. The tests will include the machine's performance on level, mountainous and simulated low-lying wetland terrain.

DOC.NOTE: For release at noon EDT; time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Study Says Capital Gains Tax Cut Would Favor Wealthy
DOC.TEXT: One percent of American families would save an average $19,599 from a proposed capital gains tax cut while 80 percent would face higher taxes to pay for the benefits, according to a private analysis released today. ``The four-fifths of American families whose incomes are below $61,000 would receive an average capital gains tax benefit of only $30,'' according to the study by Citizens for Tax Justice, a coalition of labor, public interest and citizens groups. ``Since most families own no capital assets other than their homes, most actually would get no capital gains tax break at all,'' it said. These people ``would face higher taxes to pay for the cost of this enormous new loophole for the very wealthy.'' Those whose incomes place them in the top 1 percent would get an average tax cut of $19,599, it said. The Washington-based Citizens for Tax Justice describes itself as a non-profit, non-partisan coalition working for fairer taxes at the federal, state and local levels. Capital gains are profits from the sale of stock, real estate and other investments. They now are taxed at the same rates that apply to wages and other income. President Bush has made cutting the tax a top priority, contending such a reduction is needed to keep the economy growing. His administration has pressed for a reduction during this year's budget negotiations with members of Congress. The talks are due to resume this week. The administration has never denied that the wealthiest taxpayers would be the biggest beneficiaries of a capital gains tax cut. But it contends that the proposed tax cut would spur investment and create jobs. The Treasury has projected the cut would raise tax collections every year and by $12.5 billion over the 1990-95 period. However, the congressional Joint Committee on Taxation forecasts annual revenue losses after the first two years and losses totaling $11.4 billion for 1990-95. The Congressional Budget Office last week said a capital gains tax reduction ``could not be counted on'' to give a significant boost to American economic growth. ``It is unlikely that the increase in income would generate enough additional tax revenue'' to offset losses to the Treasury, it said. Citizens for Tax Justice said middle-class Americans would not benefit from a capital gains tax cut because their incomes come mainly from salaries and wages, not from stock portfolios or real estate holdings. ``The wealthy are the only ones who benefit from reduced taxes on asset sales because they own the lion's share of the assets in the first place,'' it said. The analysis also suggested that because the wealthy in California, New York, Texas, Florida, Illinois and New Jersey are so much richer and more numerous than in other states, more than half of the cuts would go to residents of those six states.

DOC.HEAD: `Ghost' is Top Hit of the Summer
LaserGraphic of Sept. 4
DOC.TEXT: ``Ghost,'' once considered a vanishing act next to the summer blockbusters, outlived all of them to close as the summer's biggest smash and the top hit of the Labor Day weekend. The spectral love story starring Patrick Swayze, Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldberg took in $10 million over the holiday weekend, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Tuesday. The superhero flick ``Darkman'' took second place over the weekend with $7.9 million, followed by the courtroom thriller ``Presumed Innocent,'' which made $5.9 million. ``Ghost'' has made more money than any other film released this summer, grossing $125 million since it opened July 20. Seven films had more lucrative opening weeks: ``Total Recall,'' ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Back to the Future Part III,'' ``Another 48 HRS.,'' ``Days of Thunder'' and ``Bird on a Wire.'' But in the end, business for all seven films declined while ``Ghost'' remained relatively steady. Overall, this summer was the second biggest in Hollywood history, with North American moviegoers spending about $1.85 billion. Box-office analyst A.D. Murphy of Daily Variety said Tuesday that the summer's gross represented a 9 percent decline from last year's record $2.04 billion. Among the more surprising failures this season was ``Days of Thunder,'' which scarcely broke the $80 million mark. Paramount blamed the collapse of the Tom Cruise movie on the historical unpopularity of race-car movies. Disappointing returns were also reported by ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' ``Ghost Dad,'' ``Quick Change,'' ``My Blue Heaven,'' ``Cadillac Man,'' ``Air America,'' ``Fire Birds,'' ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' ``Betsy's Wedding,'' ``The Two Jakes'' and ``RoboCop 2.'' The summer's top 10 films, in order, were ``Ghost,'' $125 million; ``Total Recall,'' $116.7 million; ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' $109.7 million; ``Dick Tracy,'' $103.7 million; ``Back to the Future Part III,'' $84.1 million; ``Days of Thunder,'' $80.6 million; ``Another 48 HRS.,'' $79.1 million; ``Bird on a Wire,'' $70 million; ``Presumed Innocent,'' $67.4 million, and ``Arachnophobia,'' $48.4 million. ``Pretty Woman'' made $59.5 million during the summer but was a spring release, opening March 23. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $10 million, 1,766 screens, $5,636 per screen, $125 million, eight weeks. 2. ``Darkman,'' Universal, $7.9 million, 1,833 screens, $4,330 per screen, $19.2 million, two weeks. 3. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $5.9 million, 1,355 screens, $4,319 per screen, $67.4 million, six weeks. 4. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $5.2 million, 1,479 screens, $3,536 per screen, $40.1 million, four weeks. 5. ``My Blue Heaven,'' Warner Bros., $3.2 million, 1,502 screens, $2,118 per screen, $18 million, three weeks. 6. ``Men at Work,'' Epic-Triumph, $3.1 million, 1,035 screens, $2,974 per screen, $7.7 million, two weeks. 7. ``Taking Care of Business,'' Disney, $2.8 million, 1,176 screens, $2,396 per screen, $13.2 million, three weeks. 8. ``Exorcist III,'' 20th Century Fox, $2.7 million, 1,297 screens, $2,125 per screen, $20.8 million, three weeks. 9. ``Young Guns II,'' 20th Century Fox, $2.4 million, 1,321 screens, $1,812 per screen, $34.3 million, five weeks. 10. ``The Witches,'' Warner Bros., $2.3 million, 879 screens, $2,618 per screen, $5.8 million, two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: North Prosecutor Asks Appellate Panel to Reconsider Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh wants a federal appeals court to reconsider its split decision that set aside three felony convictions against former White House aide Oliver L. North. Calling the 2-1 decision ``unprecedented and unwarranted,'' the independent counsel asked the three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Colombia to rehear the case. Walsh also suggested a rehearing by all 12 members of the court. The tartly worded petition charged that Circuit Judges Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle used faulty logic and ``a plain misreading of the record'' in the case to set aside North's convictions. Over the dissent of Chief Judge Patricia Wald, the two appeals judges ordered a hearing to determine if trial witnesses were influenced by the testimony that North gave Congress under a limited grant of immunity from prosecution. The so-called ``use immunity'' granted by the congressional Iran-Contra committees barred Walsh from using North's televised testimony as evidence or for leads in his investigation. Walsh called the panel's order ``an unwarranted extension of use immunity protection'' that was ``particularly unjustified'' because he took special precautions to make sure that prosecutors were not exposed to North's testimony. Trial witnesses were instructed by U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell to testify only from their personal knowledge. The prohibitions against prosecuting based on North's immunized testimony ``do not extend to the independent conduct of third-party witnesses, particularly witnesses who testify on the basis of personal knowledge,'' Walsh said in the petition. To conduct the hearing according to the appellate panel's instructions, Gesell would have to ``probe the psychological processes of each witness, many of whom are irrelevant to the conviction,'' Walsh said. The standards the appellate court set for a ``witness by witness'' hearing would make ```virtually impossible' the criminal prosecution of a person who provides public immunized testimony,'' Walsh said, quoting from Wald's dissent. North, a former National Security Council aide who coordinated secret support for the Nicaraguan Contras, was convicted of aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress, destruction or alteration of government documents and accepting an illegal gratuity _ the construction of a security fence around his house. North was fined $150,000 and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. If it is allowed to stand, the July 20 appellate court decision could invalidate the five felony convictions of North's old boss, former national security adviser John M. Poindexter, who is appealing his six-month sentence. The retired Navy rear admiral, who was convicted of lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair, also gave immunized testimony on Capitol Hill. Walsh filed the petition Tuesday as prosecutors from his office began trying a tax case against a former CIA agent who participated in the sale of U.S. arms to Iran. Thomas Clines, who assisted retired Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord and arms dealer Albert Hakim, is accused of not fully reporting on his income-tax forms the commissions he earned from the arms deals. Prosecutors claim that Clines earned $875,000 from the arms-for-hostages sales. Both Secord and Hakim, who have pleaded guilty to other Iran-Contra charges, are expected to testify against Clines at the trial in federal court in Baltimore.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Drivers' Strike Benefits Terminated
DOC.TEXT: The Greyhound drivers' union is cutting off $50-a-week strike benefits for those still waging a 6-month-old strike because it says it needs the union's remaining money for legal battles. The halt of benefits for the union's 6,000 drivers ``should not be taken by anyone as a signal that we are abandoning the strike or the campaign we have been waging,'' Amalgamated Transit Union President Jim La Sala said in a letter released Tuesday. The union already has spent more than $6 million on the strike, according the letter to local union leaders. Strike benefits have to be discontinued starting Sept. 13, La Sala said, because the union's so-called ``defense fund'' was about to drop below $2 million. Remaining resources are needed for legal fights, the union's involvement in bankruptcy proceedings and its buyout effort, La Sala said. ``I can fully understand that many of our members manning the picket lines may well feel betrayed. ... To the contrary, this union has made a pledge that Greyhound will never operate in a picket-free environment so long as our strike continues,'' La Sala said. Frank Motsay, president of Local 1610 in Washington, said drivers knew the strike benefits eventually would run out and that he did not expect it to affect morale on the picket line. ``I think it's only natural to assume that none of these things have a bottomless pit. Fifty dollars a week is not what's keeping them out on the picket line. ... Our people are out their for a just cause, to improve their working condition and wages,'' Motsay said. Many of the striking drivers have found other jobs since the strike began or are receiving unemployment benefits that exceed the $50-a-week union benefit, La Sala's letter said. Greyhound drivers walked out March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. Since the dispute began, Greyhound has operated a reduced schedule with about 3,000 strikebreakers it hired and has said it has no plans to resume negotiations with union drivers. The bus line, now in the protection of bankruptcy court, has been hurt financially as well. It blames its money troubles on security and legal costs that stem from initial strike violence that it charges was orchestrated by union leaders. La Sala's letter said that if strike benefits were continued, the international union's defense fund would be in jeopardy and forced assessments might cause the ``total destruction'' of some local unions. While the bus line has said the strike is in effect over because Greyhound has continued operations with replacement drivers, the union is hoping for other possible solutions. Those include the possibility that a bankruptcy judge might replace Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey with a trustee willing to resume negotiations with union drivers. Another possible solution would be for a New York investment banking firm, the Blackstone Group, to take over the company. The firm already has said a takeover would include bringing union drivers back and possibly allowing employees to have part ownership. In addition, there's the chance that a National Labor Relations Board administrative law judge in Milwaukee will agree with the board's general counsel and find that Greyhound engaged in unfair labor practices. That would mean the bus line would have to take back the union _ and give drivers back pay amounting to as much as $10 million a month. However, the bus line has already said it would appeal such a decision, which could mean court battles for years. Greyhound contends its financial problems will be resolved with a reorganization plan that streamlines the company's operations.

DOC.HEAD: Some in Washington Say a Single Bullet Could Resolve the Problem
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is the latest administration official to suggest that the United States would welcome Saddam Hussein's departure from office. In Iraq, such leavetakings ordinarily come by way of the assassin's bullet. The idea of ending the Persian Gulf crisis by having Saddam killed is much discussed in Washington. Some see it as an alternative to a brutal war that would kill thousands of Iraqis and Americans alike to achieve the same end. As might be expected, no one in the executive branch is openly advocating Saddam's murder. For one thing, assassinations are a violation of American policy, first enunciated in writing by President Ford 14 years ago in response to suspicions that Americans had a hand in the murder of the leftist president of Chile, Salvadore Allende. For another, the experts _ including three former CIA directors _ say it would be extremely difficult to arrange. Saddam is on guard. He has survived dozens of assassinations attempts. He came to office through that route. That's how leaders normally rise in his country. The Wall Street Journal quoted Sahib al-Hakin, an Iraqi dissident in London, as saying that removing Saddam would not make much difference because those around him who might take over are as ruthless. Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday that it would not make the administration ``terribly unhappy if the people of Iraq decided they wanted a new leader.'' But, he added, that's ``up to the people of Iraq ....'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., is as forthright as anyone in saying the U.S. goal should be Saddam's removal. ``It seems to me important that Saddam Hussein must either leave or be removed,'' he said. President Bush, asked about Lugar's view, said last week that he had ``great respect for Dick Lugar'' but added that he had not altered his ``publicly stated'' objectives, of which Saddam's removal is not one. Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has written that ``any outcome that leaves Saddam Hussein in place and his military machine unimpaired might turn out to be only an interlude between aggressions.'' Early in the crisis, Bush himself said he hoped the Iraqi people would ``do something'' unless Saddam ``changes his spots.'' But former CIA Director Stansfield Turner said assassinations offend American morality and can backfire. ``I don't think an American could possibly kill Saddam Hussein and survive, so you'd end up hiring someone else and who knows what they might do,'' Turner said. ``They might kill 5,000 people to get Hussein. It's a very chancy thing.'' Richard Helms, another ex-CIA chief, said, ``When push comes to shove, Americans don't believe in having America assassinate foreign leaders. They want somebody else to pull the trigger.'' And William Colby, who also once ran the agency, said that Bush clearly hopes the economic squeeze on Iraq will become so severe that within the country ``people will get the idea, `we've got to get rid of this guy.''' Once before _ in the Panama invasion that resulted in the arrest of Manuel Noriega _ Bush suggested that the people themselves remove his antagonist. But when Panamanian military leaders plotted a coup and sought American help, signals got crossed and the attempt failed. Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla. a member of the House Intelligence Committee, was asked as he was leaving on a trip to visit U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia last week about Saddam's removal. ``The future of Saddam Hussein is of concern to everyone, the potential power and resources he would have available,'' the congressman said. ``You fear his ability to regroup.'' But as far as an assassination, McCurdy said simply, ``That's out of our hands.'' Shirheen T. Hunter, a Mideast expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said she did not think U.S. intelligence forces ``have the kind of network inside Iraq that we can pull this kind of thing.'' Saddam, she said, ``is extremely heavily guarded. His security forces are loyal _ mostly his relatives or members of his village. ... I don't think it is a serious policy option.'' The Ford executive order directs that no one ``employed by or acting on behalf of the United States government shall engage in, or conspire to engage in, assassination.'' Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan renewed the order. Bush has not, but it remains in effect. It is a policy, not a law, however, and carries no penalty. Bush could revoke it, publicly or secretly, or simply override it by ordering an assassination effort.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Is Both a Demon and a Hero to Non-Arab Moslems
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: To the hundreds of millions of Moslems who live outside the Arab world, Saddam Hussein is generally considered either a demon or a ``champion of Islam.'' Some perceive the Iraqi president a hero. Others call him a tyrant and fear he will bring disaster to the Persian Gulf, cradle of the Moslem faith. Nearly two-thirds of the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems are non-Arabs. They live in a crescent that reaches from the sands and jungles of black Africa to the steppes of Central Asia and juts out to islands in the Pacific Ocean. The non-Arab Moslems, like their co-religionists in the Middle East, are divided in their opinion of Saddam and the presence of U.S. troops in the gulf. Some despise him. Some have given him a new name _ ``Saddma'' Hussein. ``Saddma'' means sorrow in the Urdu language spoken by many Moslems in India and Pakistan. Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait has brought misery and fears of greater poverty to a half-million South Asians who worked there. Some revere him. In Bangladesh, where Moslems account for 90 percent of the 110 million people, the government has promised to send 1,200 soldiers to Saudi Arabia to guard against further Iraqi aggression. But at least 5,500 civilians have volunteered to fight on the Iraqi side if war breaks out. ``I have offered to fight for Iraq because President Saddam Hussein is a champion of Islamic revivalism,'' said Mohammad Faisal, a businessman in Dhaka, Bangladesh's capital. In predominantly Hindu India, whose 105 million Moslems give it the second-largest Moslem population of any country in the world, the Iraqi consul general in Bombay has compiled a list of Moslem volunteers, the Sunday Mail newspaper reported. ``We intend to call up these reserves if and when the need arises,'' Amer Naji, the consul general, said. In New Delhi, hundreds of Moslems emerging from their weekly prayers on Friday burned an effigy of President Bush to protest the American deployment in Saudi Arabia. In Jakarta, capital of Indonesia, the Islamic Council for the Defense of the Holy Land called a rally to deplore the Iraqi invasion. The 2,000 demonstrators also called on the United States to withdraw from the gulf. Indonesia, with 162 million Moslems, is the largest Moslem country in the world. The country's largest Moslem organization, Muhannadiyah, has urged the Americans not to take any arbitrary action. ``The U.S. presence is not genuinely aimed at defending the interest of an invaded country,'' said Yuwono Subarsong, dean of the political faculty of the Indonesian University. He said Washington only wants to ensure its oil supply ``to maintain the American way of life.'' In Pakistan, a Moslem state with 103 million adherents of the religion, a poll of 700 people showed 74 percent supported the government's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia while 11 percent opposed it. But the same poll showed 62 percent opposed the presence of American forces in Saudi Arabia, home of the Moslem world's most sacred shrines. In the past two weeks, Moslem fundamentalists have staged noisy but non-violent anti-American protests in Islamabad, Karachi and other cities. In India, the government avoided direct criticism of Saddam and thanked him for helping some of the 180,000 Indian workers in Kuwait and Iraq return home. But posters have appeared in the Jama Masjid, a New Delhi mosque that is one of the world's largest, asking Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. In Malaysia, where 45 percent of the country's 17.8 million people are Moslem, the government has backed the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. But the opposition Pan Islamic Party held a demonstration calling for U.S. withdrawal. Most West African nations with large Moslem populations have either remained silent or criticized Iraq initially and then kept quiet. Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation with 119 million people, half of them Moslem, has said very little about the invasion. But it has defied Saddam's orders to close its embassy in Kuwait. In Uganda, Moslem leaders have criticised Hussein. Umar Kaggwa, a Kampala businessman, said he thought Saddam should have learned a lesson from former Ugandan leader Gen. Idi Amin, who invaded Tanzania and precipitatated his own downfall in 1978. ``I think Saddam is mad,'' Kaggwa said.

DOC.HEAD: Guardsman Complete Gas Warfare Training
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

A silent semicircle of men stood in a room with dirt floors and unfinished walls. At their center, a candle heated a coffee can holding five tear gas tablets. One by one, as if in some initiation ceremony, the men drank from hoses in cumbersome gas masks, then took them off, counted to 10, spelled their last name and recited their Social Security numbers. Voices cracked halfway through the litany. This mild torture suffered by the 14 members of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment is part of regular training for all U.S. soldiers. But for the water purification unit of the South Carolina National Guard, the session in the post's gas chamber had added significance. It marked the end of chemical warfare training meant to prepare the unit for Mideast duty. Mobilized for deployment last week, the Allendale, S.C., unit had spent four of six training days brushing up on NBC _ nuclear, biological and chemical warfare. The men heard lectures and watched movies about the effects of nerve agents, choking gases and blister gas. They walked in 90-degree heat wearing gas masks, hoods, overboots and bulky chemical warfare suits. The gas chamber was a final stop to show the men their equipment worked. With masks on, the tear gas had little effect. When masks came off, the air in the dim room felt red hot, as if the candle's heat was everywhere. The exposed faces went through escalating degrees of pain, from the sensation of a slight sunburn to that of flayed flesh. A quick walk into the outside breeze and a splash of water from a canteen cleared it away. ``Stings a little, but it wasn't so bad,'' said Mark Rooker, at 20 the youngest member of the unit. To celebrate the 265th's graduation, 2nd Army commander Lt. Gen. James Crysel came by the chamber. Crysel, whose command includes the federalized 265th, stood downwind from the chamber, impervious to its fumes. He spoke to several of the men about their unit and their families. The men, looking like mole people in their chemical warfare mufti, gave muffled answers. The 265th's men were assured all through training that the equipment can save their lives. The bigger problem is functioning as a soldier in the claustrophobia of the mask and overgarments that quickly leave a man soaked through with sweat and smeared with the charcoal from the suit's liner. ``Some people get an attitude in the mask,'' said Sgt. Van Toliver, a post instructor, warned the group. ``It makes you angry.'' Before the gas chamber session, the men spent an hour in suits and masks, practicing the frustrating task of swapping contaminated protective clothes for fresh ones. When the sweat-drenched men finally removed their masks the anger Sgt. Toliver warned of was obvious. ``They throw gas at us when we're over there and we're going to die,'' said Ulysses Calhoun, one of the unit's younger members. ``Might as well take off the mask and get it over with.'' Not everyone agreed. ``I'll stay with the mask,'' said Sgt. Hullie Cohen, a guardsman for 16 years. ``I plan to do what I can to survive.'' Cohen, a burly 40-year-old brick mason, often breaks a moment of tension with a joke. He is equally deliberate on the basketball court, choosing his shots while the unit's younger members gun for impossible baskets. It seems he rarely misses. It was Cohen's first time in the gas chamber. He was one of the few who volunteered to go through again, this time without a mask. ``I just wanted to see what I could stand,'' he said. The gas temporarily blinded him; he had to be led out.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Cranston's Popularity Sinking
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Alan Cranston's popularity is plummeting amid a Senate ethics committee probe of his intervention with federal thrift regulators, a poll shows. A California Poll published in Tuesday's editions of the San Francisco Chronicle found the 76-year-old Democrat was supported for re-election by only 13 percent of those surveyed. Cranston's current term ends in 1992 and he has said he plans to seek re-election. Cranston was viewed unfavorably by 67 percent of those surveyed, compared to 10 months ago when a similar survey showed he was viewed favorably by 64 percent, according to the poll. Among Democrats, 65 percent said they were not inclined to support Cranston, while 84 percent of Republicans and 74 percent of those with no party affiliation said they were disinclined to vote for him again. The poll questioned 468 registered voters from August 17-27. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points. Cranston, along with four other U.S. senators, is being investigated by the ethics committee for intervening with federal regulators on behalf of savings and loan operator Charles Keating. Keating made large contributions to all the senators, including nearly $1 million to Cranston campaigns and causes. Cranston has maintained the ethics committee probe will clear him of any wrongdoing.
DOC.HEAD: Nunn Changes His Position on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia is changing his position on the government's role in regulating abortion, saying the decision should be left ``to the informed conscience of the mother'' in most cases. Nunn, a conservative Democrat, previously had supported proposed constitutional amendments to overturn the Supreme Court's 1973 decision legalizing abortion. But he now favors ``leaving the decision prior to viability (of the fetus) to the informed conscience of the mother,'' Nunn wrote in a letter to constituents.
