He favors prohibiting abortions after viability ``except in cases where the life of the mother is threatened,'' the letter added. ``While Roe vs. Wade was a questionable constitutional decision, the viability standard it established may now be the best legislative policy on abortion,'' said Nunn. Nunn is regarded as a potential presidential candidate in 1992. He began rethinking the abortion question after it became apparent that changes in the makeup of the Supreme Court could force Congress to decide when the government should intervene in the abortion decision, said his press secretary, Scott Williams. In the letter, Nunn said he still considers abortion ``a tragedy and an act of great moral consequence that should be strongly discouraged except in cases of rape or incest, or when the life of the mother is endangered.'' But he said he concluded that laws prohibiting early abortions cannot be enforced because legalized abortion has been the law of the land since the 1973 Supreme Court decision.
DOC.HEAD: Quayle Calls Governors Races `Brass Ring' for Redistricting
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle gave a boost to Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt's re-election bid and declared that governors' races around the country are ``the brass rings'' that hold the key to redistricting. Alabama has ``led America in economic progress'' during the Hunt administration, Quayle said Tuesday after attending a $5,000-a-plate lunch to raise money for Hunt's campaign. Quayle said the gubernatorial races in Georgia, Alabama and Texas are ``key races in the South.'' ``With reapportionment coming up, the governorships are the brass rings this year,'' the vice president said at a news conference. ``They are the ones who are going to have a lot to say about redistricting.'' Hunt is the first Republican governor in Alabama since Reconstruction. Hunt's Democratic challenger is teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert. Former President Reagan will visit Birmingham, Ala., Sept. 29 to campaign for Hunt.
DOC.HEAD: Fenwick Chairing Congressional Campaign in New Jersey
DOC.TEXT: Former Rep. Millicent Fenwick is now the head of a GOP state senator's campaign for a U.S. House seat that includes much of her old congressional district. Mrs. Fenwick, 80, was too ill to attend a news conference Tuesday where she had planned to announce her involvement with the campaign of state Sen. Dick Zimmer. ``As you may know, I am not taking on many public responsibilities these days,'' Mrs. Fenwick said in a prepared statement. ``Nevertheless, I have agreed to become chairperson of Sen. Dick Zimmer's campaign for Congress from the 12th District, which includes much of my old congressional district.'' She gave up her seat in 1982 to run for the Senate. After losing to Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., she served as the first American ambassador to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome. Zimmer is facing Democrat Marguerite Chandler in a general election bid to succeed retiring Republican Rep. James Courter in the GOP-dominated district.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find Gene Related To Primary Arthritis, NIH Says
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio family in which nine members developed a potentially crippling form of arthritis has helped researchers isolate a gene that may be responsible for the degenerative disease. Researchers led by Dr. Darwin J. Prockop of Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia and Dr. Roland W. Moskowitz of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland surveyed the genetic pattern of three generations of the family and found a faulty gene that produces a protein mutation. The genetic flaw changes a single amino acid in the structure of a component in cartilage and this leads to an early onset of arthritis, Prockop said at a news conference Tuesday. ``We now know that a gene can cause the problem,'' said Prockop. Moskowitz said the gene apparently is not responsible for osteoarthritis in all families where the disease is common. ``We think it is likely that other genes are involved,'' he said. The cause of primary osteoarthritis has long eluded science even though it is one of the most common complaints among people past the age of 55, affecting about 16 million Americans. The disease causes a breakdown or erosion of cartilage that covers and cushions joints. It can affect any joint, but most commonly the hands, ankles, knees and hips. Severe cases can lead to crippling that can be corrected only by replacing the diseased joint with an artificial one. Currently, treatment consists only of treating symptoms and relieving inflammation. Prockop said that with the arthritis gene identified, scientists now have a research target that could lead to drugs to prevent or arrest the disease process. However, such drugs will take years to develop, he said. In the family that was studied, Prockop said, the researchers found that there was one defective gene and one good gene for the production of collagen II, a protein that is the primary component in cartilage. The defective gene substitutes an amino acid called cysteine for one called arginine, he said. The result is an altered and weaken collagen, and this leads to an early onset of arthritis. ``With this discovery, we hope to find ways to make the good gene work better and the bad gene work less well,'' said Prockop. Researchers started studying the Ohio family, which was not identified, after a physician referred them to Moskowitz. Three generations of the family, starting with the father in the first generation, suffer from osteoarthritis. In the second generation, three brothers and one sister out of seven children had the disease. Three in this group underwent joint replacement surgery. And in the third generation, there were five with arthritis. For some in the family, the disease symptoms appeared at age 16. Using a tissue sample from one family member with arthritis, the scientists isolated the collagen II gene and found that it was mutated. They then checked that gene in the other family members and found it was defective in the nine who were affected with arthritis, but not in 10 others. Tests were conducted on 57 unrelated individuals without arthritis and the defective gene was not found. Prockop said it is now possible to identify the gene from tissue samples within four weeks and his laboratory hopes to develop tests that can make a genetic diagnosis within two days. This would enable members of a family where arthritis is common to determine if they are susceptible to the disease. Moskowitz said that in expanded studies 10 families with several generations of arthritis have been examined and the faulty gene has been found in three of the groups. This suggests that the gene found in the Ohio family is not the only one underlying arthritis. John D. Stobo, a Johns Hopkins University medical professor who is president of the American College of Rheumatologists, said the discovery ``provides real hope that a cure will be forthcoming.'' Dr. Arthur I. Grayzel, senior vice president of the Arthritis Foundation, said the new research ``has the potential for helping change the concept of osteoarthritis from a disease that is the inevitable consequence of aging to a disease that has a specific cause in different people.'' The research was supported in part by National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases, one of the National Institutes of Health.

DOC.HEAD: For US Troops, Coke and Rambo, USO Shows and Devil's Food Cake
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rambo and Coca-Cola have made their way to U.S. troops in the Saudi Arabian desert. And USO shows should be coming soon. For news and entertainment-starved troops, a night at the movies, no matter how old the movie, is a big deal. The treat came this past week for members of the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing, who set up a movie tent to watch ``Rambo'' after the unit secured a copy of the film. ``It was really great, we had popcorn and everything,'' said Becky Colaw, the public information officer for the 354th, which is based in Myrtle Beach, S.C. Cold Coke has been making its way to the troops over the past several days as part of a $2 million corporate service and entertainment campaign organized by the USO. The non-profit organization hopes to bring live entertainment to the troops in the coming months. The Coke delivery effort has not been without snafus. The company arranged a media trip Tuesday for its delivery to the 18th Airborne Corps but didn't tell unit commanders they were coming. ``Let's just say they weren't too pleased,'' said an Army officer who escorted the media to the site.

Feeding the burgeoning American military force is a formidable task. Early in the deployment, Saudi fast-food chains and other outlets were contracted for some of the meals. And the troops always had their high-calorie field rations _ Meals Ready to Eat _ to fall back on. But as time drags on the services are establishing more and more field kitchens, with supplies flowing in daily. A walk past a row of pallets at an air base the other day provided a menu preview: Elbow macaroni, cranberry sauce, applesauce, dehydrated egg mix and nonfat dry milk. And for dessert? Devil's food cake with artificial vanilla icing.

For the past three weeks, American military spokesmen and the first reporters allowed into Saudi Arabia have been staying in a hotel that also is the temporary home of dozens of Kuwaiti refugees. The Kuwaiti children, who play in the halls all day and well into the morning hours, in the past few days have begun playing with toy guns in the halls, often springing out from behind doors and curtains to surprise hotel patrons. A Navy captain was walking down the hall with a reporter the other day when one Kuwaiti boy jumped out from behind a pole and fired a toy air gun in the direction of the captain. The captain then admonished the boy, telling him not to aim the gun at anyone. When he was done speaking, the captain stood for a second, smiling at the boy. The boy re-cocked the air gun and fired a shot at the captain's chest. ``He'll learn,'' said the captain, shaking his head as he walked away.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Taking Off in New Air Force One
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has flown the equivalent of eight times around the globe in his 20 months as president. Starting this week, he'll be able to make the circuit without even having to stop. The president who has traveled farther and more frequently than any other chief executives at comparable points in their terms _ 17 countries and 40 states as president so far _ will get the ideal accompanying piece of hardware. A plane capable of staying aloft a week or more through midair refueling. Although nearly two years behind schedule, the new Air Force One takes flight this week. Bush, a former Navy pilot, is expected to take his maiden flight on the new plane _ a converted jumbo Boeing 747 _ on Thursday when he gives speeches for Republican candidates in Topeka, Kan., and Tallahassee, Fla. Then, he will use it this weekend when he flies to Helsinki, Finland, for his one-day summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. While midair refueling is an option to be reserved for an emergency, the new plane can fly 7,140 miles without refueling. That's 1,400 miles farther than the present Air Force One, a 20-year-old Boeing 707. It also carries state-of-the-art communications systems, an anti-missile system, collision-avoidance equipment and is designed to protect electronic systems after a nuclear explosion. The new plane also has: _ Eighty-five telephones. _ Twin beds in the president's stateroom, a changing room and a shower. _ A built-in movie screen and projection systems. _ Refrigerator-freezers that can hold a week's supply of food for 70 passengers and 23 crew members. _ A private office for the president with eight large chairs and a sofa. _ Seven lavatories. _ A medical emergency room. _ Two copying machines and television, videocassette and stereo systems. Although the plane originally was intended to be ready for President Reagan's return trip to California in January 1989, it seems more made-to-order for Bush. What other president would expect to take in both Kansas and Florida and call it a day trip, for instance? Or fly to Finland for lunch? ``Look out world, here we come,'' Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said in announcing that the new plane was ready. The new Air Force One _ and an identical backup plane to be delivered in June 1991 _ were built by Boeing at Everett, Wash., and spent most of the past three years at Boeing's plant in Wichita, Kan., for outfitting. Boeing officials are expected to be on hand when the plane touches down in Topeka on Thursday on its inaugural flight. Barring any unforeseen complications that would delay use of the plane, its maiden flight will be ``a kind of triumphant return to Kansas, its birthplace,'' Fitzwater said. Progress on the planes was delayed nearly two years primarily by Boeing's efforts to equip the plane with wiring that could withstand a nuclear blast, Boeing officials have said. The new plane has about twice as much wiring _ 1.26 million feet _ as a commercial 747. Boeing signed a fixed-cost contract with the U.S. Air Force to deliver both planes for $250 million, although the price later was revised to about $266 million. Actual costs rose to close to $400 million, Air Force officials have said, with much of the overrun being absorbed by Boeing. The larger planes also required construction of a new hangar at Andrews Air Force Base, in the Maryland suburbs of Washington. The designation ``Air Force One'' does not relate to a specific plane, but rather to whatever plane the president is riding on. When he takes a small Gulfstream, as he sometimes does on the way to Camp David, Md., that becomes ``Air Force One.'' The first ``Air Force One'' was a four-engine piston-powered DC-4 flown by Franklin Roosevelt in 1942 and dubbed ``Sacred Cow.'' The new 747 will replace the current 707, Air Force No. 2700, that is primarily used as Air Force One. The second plane will replace the backup 707 now used for presidential travel, Air Force No. 2600, on which Lyndon Johnson took the oath of office on Nov. 22, 1963. That plane, which Bush uses occasionally, is the first jet ever used by a president.

DOC.HEAD: Reserve Call-Up Continues
With PM-Gulf-Reserves
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon says more than 650 reservists from the Air Force, Army, and Navy have been called up since Saturday to support Operation Desert Shield in the Persian Gulf. According to a Pentagon announcement Tuesday, the secretary of the Air Force has called: _709th Military Airlift Squadron, Dover Air Force Base, Del., to support C-5A transport planes with 239 reservists. _312th Military Airlift Squadron, Travis Air Force Base, Calif., to support C-5A and C-5B transports, with 230 reservists. The secretary of the Army has ordered 20 reservists to active duty, linguists from the 337th Military Intelligence Battalion. The reservists are in three companies: B Co., East Point, Ga.; C Co., Melbourne, Fla., and D Co., Charlotte, N.C. The Navy has called 189 individual reservists to serve with various units that have been called to active duty, the Pentagon said. Through Aug. 31, 8,871 reservists were called to active duty. The Army called 4,292 reservists; the Navy, 2,584; the Air Force, 1,723; and the Coast Guard, 272, a spokesman said. In addition, Air National Guard units announced the pending departure of 100 members of Missouri's 139th Tactical Airlift Group, 60 members of Delaware's 166th Tactical Airlift Group and 100 members of Rhode Island's 143rd Tactical Airlift Group to overseas bases to support the buildup in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Payola Case Against Record Promoter Isgro
DOC.TEXT: The biggest payola case since the scandal that ruined the careers of some of rock 'n' roll's top disc jockeys 30 years ago has been thrown out by a judge who ruled prosecutors deliberately withheld evidence. U.S. District Judge James Ideman on Tuesday dismissed payola and racketeering charges against independent record promoter Joseph Isgro, 43, citing ``outrageous government misconduct.'' The trial began Aug. 21. Assistant U.S. Attorney William Lynch said he will appeal. Isgro was on trial on 57 counts of tax fraud, racketeering and other charges. He was accused of paying cash and cocaine to radio stations in Texas and California in return for playing certain songs. The trial had featured testimony about cash and drugs stuffed into album jackets and audio cassette cases delivered to radio station executives. Ideman said prosecutors deliberately withheld from the defense contradictory statements by a key witness, Dennis Di Ricco, a former Internal Revenue Service agent convicted of tax conspiracy and obstruction in 1989. Prosecutors had earlier denied hiding the testimony. ``Having been caught with a smoking pistol, the government, which denied it had a pistol, then denied that the pistol smoked,'' the judge said. He declared a mistrial and dismissed the indictment. He also threw out the case against Isgro's co-defendants, cocaine dealer Jeffrey Monka, 32, and former Columbia Records executive Raymond Anderson, 50. ``The government was willing to win at all costs and it got its hand caught in the cookie jar,'' said defense attorney Don Re. The defense had discovered that Di Ricco, at his trial, denied involvement in payola with Isgro, contradicting what he told the grand jury that indicted Isgro. Isgro said he was ``relieved and happy'' the trial was over. Isgro's clients included Columbia, MCA, Warner Brothers, RCA and Polygram Records. A 1960 federal law made it a crime punishable by a $10,000 fine and up to a year in prison to offer money or other inducements to give records airplay. The law followed a scandal that rocked the music industry in the late 1950s and early '60s. The scandal led to congressional hearings into the then-widespread practice of offering DJs inducements to give certain records airplay. Among those called to testify were Dick Clark of ``American Bandstand'' and Alan Freed, who is credited with inventing the term rock 'n' roll. The investigation cost the careers of several top disc jockeys of the era.

DOC.HEAD: Cars and Other Vehicles Recalled for Too Much Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motors Corp. is recalling about 92,000 cars and 75,000 trucks and utility vehicles that fail to meet federal exhaust pollution standards. The Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that the cars are 1987 Mitsubishi Mirage and Dodge Colt and Plymouth Colt models equipped with 1.5-liter engines. The other vehicles are 1986 and 1987 models equipped with the 2-liter engine _ 1986 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive and two-wheel-drive Dodge Ram 50 and Mitsubishi trucks, and 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive. The Dodge and Plymouth models concerned are manufactured by Mitsubishi. The agency said routine testing discovered that the cars emit more than the permitted about of carbon monoxide, and the trucks and utility vehicles emit too much carbon monoxide and unburned fuel. Owners will be asked to schedule appointments at Mitsubishi or Dodge and Plymouth dealers for modifications _ installation of a new valve in the pollution control system of the cars and changes in the fuel systems of the trucks and utility vehicles.
DOC.HEAD: Indians Urge Monument to Warriors Who Fell at Little Big Horn in
DOC.TEXT: Montana

American Indian leaders want Congress to approve a memorial to the warriors who fell at Little Big Horn and Virginia officials are urging a national commission to help preserve Civil War battlefields. ``We need to honor our warriors who gave their lives,'' Carol Gipp of the National Congress of American Indians told the House Interior Committee's subcommittee on national parks and public lands. The appeal came Tuesday as Indians, conservationists and others crowded the hearing room to plead for approval of favorite bills before Congress adjourns next month. A memorial to the warriors who fell in the 1876 victory of the Sioux over Lt. Col. George Custer and a detachment of the 7th Cavalry Regiment would cost about $2.1 million, the National Park Service has estimated. The service is supporting the memorial, as yet undesigned. The memorial would be adjacent to the monument to the 7th Cavalry which was erected on Last Stand Hill on the Montana battlefield in 1881. It bears the full names of Custer and each of the 224 other men in his command. Virginia officials and historic preservationists urged approval of a national commission on civil war battlefields to help shield a number of sites from development as the suburbs outside the nation's capital spread southward. Mayor Elizabeth G. Helm of Winchester pointed to estimates that employment in the Dulles Corridor outside Washington would grow more than 1,000 percent and the homes of those joining the labor force most likely would be in central Maryland and the northern Shenandoah Valley. ``This same area is heavily steeped in history and tradition but we have tended to take this heritage for granted,'' she said. ``We have assumed that it will always be with us for future generations.''
DOC.HEAD: White House Pleased Jackson Had Success with Saddam
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's spokesman says the president is pleased that Jesse Jackson was able to get 47 American hostages out of Iraq and Kuwait. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, asked Tuesday about Jackson's endeavor, said Bush ``is pleased by Jesse's success in bringing back Americans and we're grateful that he was able to make those arrangements.'' Jackson, who will be host of his own television show, interviewed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on Friday. He also visited Kuwait City and spoke from outside the gate with U.S. envoys at the embassy, which Hussein has ordered closed. Jackson returned to Washington on Sunday with 47 freed Americans on an Iraqi jetliner. Asked whether the White House had any misgivings about Jackson's trip, Fitzwater said: ``He was successful and that's important. He did get American lives out.'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger spoke several times with Jackson by telephone to arrange permission for the Iraqi plane to land at Dulles International Airport, Fitzwater said. ``We did cooperate. ... Our emphasis is on getting back American citizens,'' Fitzwater said.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Backs Greater Business Role in Improving Education
DOC.TEXT: Businesses should play a greater role in improving schools by investing more dollars and personnel to boost quality and prepare students for the workforce, according to a nationwide poll. The Roper Organization poll was released Tuesday. Commissioned by an affiliate of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, it found 96 percent of Americans with children in public school, as well as 91 percent of all Americans, are concerned about the quality of education in their communities. Three-quarters of those polled agreed that public schools are failing to prepare students for jobs now available. Sixty-three percent said most students will lack skills for jobs in the future. Most of the 1,003 adult Americans polled by telephone last month were receptive to the involvement of business in local public education. Ninety-one percent said it is a good idea for business to provide equipment to schools, while 6 percent thought it was a bad idea and 2 percent didn't know.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,078.34, down 829.30 points, or 3.33 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A congressman and a team of researchers plan to visit Christie Brinkley to see if the cover girl has figured out a way to fight Lyme disease. Brinkley believes the guinea hens she is raising are eating the deer ticks on the Long Island estate she shares with her husband, singer Billy Joel. The ticks carry Lyme disease, which causes a variety of symptoms and can be fatal. Rep. George Hochbrueckner quickly seized the (photo) opportunity when Brinkley told the Democrat the tick population dropped after she let the hens wander. He said researchers will study whether the birds can tell the difference between dog ticks and deer ticks. They will also try to determine if the deer tick population is lower on the celebrity property than at neighbors' homes. The hens are used in Africa to keep ticks out of barnyards, Hochbrueckner said.

Lou Diamond Phillips of ``La Bamba'' and ``Young Guns II'' was hospitalized over the weekend because of bleeding from a tonsillectomy, his spokesman says. The 28-year-old actor was taken by paramedics to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Thursday after losing blood while eating at a restaurant, Eddie Michaels said Tuesday. ``He had a tonsillectomy about two weeks ago, and this was what they call residual bleeding,'' said Michaels. ``He actually lost a lot of blood. But he got a transfusion and is doing fine right now.'' Phillips was released from the hospital Monday.

Seems someone at the Miss America Pageant still can't come to grips with Vanessa Williams. Miss Williams, who was stripped of her 1984 crown after nude photographs of her were published in Penthouse magazine, is named on the back page of this year's program, along with all winners since the first contest in 1921. Her reign from Sept. 17, 1983, to July 23, 1984, is listed, as is runner-up Suzette Charles _ from July 23 to Sept. 15, 1984. But in a separate section detailing the accomplishments of the past 10 winners, the achievements and name of Miss Williams are absent. The singer has met success with such hit songs as ``Dreamin' '' and ``The Right Stuff.''

Gov. Buddy Roemer and his wife, Patti, have divorced. ``Sometimes bad things happen to good people,'' the couple said in a statement. Mrs. Roemer, 36, was in court, but the governor, 46, wasn't when the divorce was granted Tuesday. The Roemers, who have a 10-year-old son, married in 1973 and had been separated for a year. ``Although our marriage of 16 years has ended, we remain friends, viewing each other with respect, love and honor,'' they said.

Italian maestro Claudio Abbado has signed a seven-yaer contract with the Berlin Philharmonic, succeeding the late Herbert von Karajan. Abbado, 57, was picked last October by orchestra members to succeed von Karajan, who died in July 1989. Orchestra spokesman Helge Gruenewald declined to say how much Abbado will be paid under the contract signed Tuesday, but the newspaper Der Tagesspiegel said the maestro will receive salary and benefits totaling $500,000 per year. Abbado, who also directs the Vienna State Opera, led the Berlin Philharmonic in a rehearsal of works by Brahms and Debussy hours before signing.

Jerry Lewis will return to Hollywood next Labor Day with his Muscular Dystrophy Association telethon after raising a record amount in pledges this year. Association officials said the 21{-hour show, which ended Monday, raised $44.1 million to fight 40 neuromuscular diseases that kill and cripple thousands each year, most of them young people. Last year's tally was $42.2 million. The telethon regularly breaks its pledge records, but ratings in recent years have dropped. Viewing figures are to be released in two or three days. Producers moved the 25th annual telethon to Los Angeles after 17 years in Las Vegas to reduce costs and update the show's image.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted Wednesday because of continuing concern about the Middle East situation, traders said. The dollar dropped sharply against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 829.30 points, or 3.33 percent, closing at 24,078.34. The index shed 512.79 points on Tuesday. The dollar closed at 142.30 yen, down 1.75 yen from Tuesday's close. After opening at 143.08 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 142.17 yen and 143.25 yen. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged up to 8.150 percent as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT) from Tuesday's close of 8.130 percent. Their price stood at 82.87 points, down from 82.96 on Tuesday. Securities dealers said the Nikkei index fell because of a lack of buying incentives due to continuing uncertainty over the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Concern about higher interest rates resulting from price increases in crude oil is adversely affecting investors,'' said Yozo Asai, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities. In the currency market, dealers said the dollar's lower start followed a decline in New York, where it fell to 143.40 yen from 143.785 yen late Friday. U.S. financial markets were closed Monday for Labor Day. ``The yen is favored over the dollar and European currencies,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Yoshida said life insurance firms were among those selling dollars. The dollar has slumped in recent weeks because of pessimism about the U.S. economy. Its weakness has been countered, however, by concern over the Persian Gulf situation. The dollar is usually viewed as a safe haven in times of crisis. Other dealers said the markets are awaiting the release Friday of the U.S. employment figures for August. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for November delivery was quoted at $28.05-.15 a barrel in Tokyo, up from its close at $27.92 in London Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Program Unveiled to Slim Iron City
DOC.TEXT: An effort is under way to get people in the Iron City to stop eating like steelworkers. The state has joined 100 companies and two drug store chains in sponsoring the Pittsburgh Community Health Challenge, which will offer some 52,000 workers and other members of the public a 10-week analysis of their eating habits. Organizers hope to turn people away from an artery-clogging legacy of pirogies, kielbasa, gyros and other high-fat ethnic dishes that sustained generations of robust steelworkers. ``Our parents developed high-fat kinds of foods when they were working in the steel mills,'' said Donna Donati, the program's executive director. ``They used to work very hard, burn those calories off. ``But we're eating the same foods they ate when they hung their clothes outside on the line, rather than what we do, sitting around as they dry in the dryer.'' The city, once dependent on steel, has created service, high-tech and medical jobs since the decline of the mills in the early 1980s. Supporters of the program dined on low-fat quiche and cheesecake at a Tuesday lunch to unveil the effort aimed at curbing the city's appetite for foods loaded with saturated fats and cholesterol, both linked to heart disease. Questionnaires about family medical history, smoking, exercise and diet will be handed out the participating companies, including PPG Industries Inc., H.J. Heinz Co. and Allegheny Ludlum Corp., among the area's largest employers. Thrift Drugs and Legend Pharmacies will distribute questionnaires at their stores. A computer analysis will tell respondents how they compare to average Americans in the risk of heart disease. ``It's really personal. It will hit them right on the head,'' Ms. Donati said. Pennsylvania had 266.8 heart disease deaths per 100,000 people in 1986, the most recent year available, said Dr. Lewis Kuller of the University of Pittsburgh's school of public health. The national average was 246.8 deaths per 100,000. Most southwestern Pennsylvania residents are ignorant of the dangers of cholesterol and fat, researchers said. ``Most of them don't have the foggiest idea what they're doing to themselves,'' Kuller said. ``It's so simple, too. People can reduce cholesterol in their food through simple changes and substitutions.'' Organizers said doctors don't tell their patients enough about the importance of diet. ``Most doctors are poorly educated in nutrition,'' said Pitt's Dr. Trevor Orchard. ``They don't have time to spend giving nutrition counseling, even if they did know what they are talking about.'' ``The physicians should be provided with the names of foods that are low in fat or cholesterol, as the drug companies have been doing for years,'' said Christian Chavanne, executive chef at Galaxy Cheese Co. The company makes Formagg, a cheese of skim milk and soybean and canola oils that was featured in pizza, quiche and chicken at Tuesday's lunch. Chavanne said watching fat content ``doesn't mean you can't have that occasional binge or splurge once in awhile, the T-bone steak every three weeks if you've been good.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Last Imperial Power in Gulf, Back In Key Support Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To RESTORE first reference to Saddam, SUB 4th graf, `Mrs. Thatcher ... ``old hag.''' Picks up 5th, ```Thatcher would ...' ^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Middle East empire is long gone, but London's strong political and defense ties in the region have given it a high-profile role in the Persian Gulf crisis. Britain helped draw the current map of the Middle East after World War I and was deeply involved in governing many countries in the region _ including both Iraq and Kuwait. Last month, it was the first power to send weapons in support of the U.S. buildup in the region, and last weekend Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher bore the brunt of Iraqi invective over the West's military challenge to its invasion of Kuwait. Mrs. Thatcher accused President Saddam Hussein of Iraq of having ``hidden behind the skirts of women and children,'' and the Iraqi News Agency denounced her as an ``old hag.'' ``Thatcher would do well to bear in mind that the empire on whose possessions the sun did not go down has long been defunct, and neither she nor any of her allies will be able to set the clock back,'' it said. Dr. Basim Musallam, director of the Center of Mideast Studies at Cambridge University, says the historical background has made Britain's role in the Persian Gulf ``bigger than the number of planes it has sent.'' Britain sells sophisticated military hardware to the gulf states, and British officers help train their soldiers and pilots. In 1988, Britain signed its biggest arms deal ever, to sell Saudi Arabia nearly $20 billion worth of warplanes. ``Britain was the last imperial power to withdraw from the gulf,'' Musallam said in an interview. ``The British know the terrain very well. They have close connections with the local rulers ... much more than the French or Americans.'' Originally Britain needed the Middle East to shut out Russia and Germany and secure its routes to the Orient, and it ruled Arabia from India until after World War I. The seven sheikdoms which now comprise the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait gave Britain control of foreign affairs and defense in the late 19th century. Bahrain was a British protectorate from 1861 until 1971. A romantic Anglo-Arab tradition developed, personified by such figures as Lawrence of Arabia. Oil changed Britain's interest in the Middle East. The Royal Navy switched to oil in 1912 just as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company, which is now British Petroleum, started operations in Persia, now Iran. Having defeated the Ottoman Empire in World War I, Britain and France drew new Mideast boundaries. France got Lebanon and Syria. Britain got Iraq, Transjordan (now Jordan), and Palestine. Britain installed friendly Arab rulers who were ``more or less amenable to British protection, a situation which survived more or less until the late 1930s,'' according to Oxford University historian Alastair Parker. Then came more changes. Oil was struck in Saudi Arabia, and the Americans moved into the Middle East for the first time. Meanwhile, the Jews were demanding a state in Palestine. Britain was torn, and in 1939 it opted for a pro-Arab policy. After World War II, the British Empire began to wane. But London's interests in the Middle East remained paramount. In 1956, it joined France in trying to seize the Suez Canal from the Egyptian nationalist leader Gamal Abdel Nasser. In the early 1960s, it sent troops to ward off threats in the Persian Gulf and Adan (in present-day Yemen). Prof. John Vincent, a Middle East historian at the University of Bristol, says Iraq shouldn't be surprised by Britain's response to the Kuwait invasion. ``We are sticking to precedent,'' he said in an interview. ``This is what we've always done.'' ``Our interest has stayed the same down the ages,'' he said. ``We want a balanced, strong, independent Middle East which isn't under the thumb of any great powers and which isn't under a regional dictator.'' Columnist Robert Harris mused in The Sunday Times at the reversal in U.S. and British roles. ``For half a century after World War I, American foreign policy was dominated by a desire to break up the British empire. That policy succeeded _ perhaps too well,'' he wrote. ``Now, as Washington's gunboats are required to steam along our old imperial routes to the gulf, one cannot help but smile.''

DOC.HEAD: Acting Governor Nominated in Bid for Job He Inherited
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs with Gallaway nominated; PICKS UP 6th graf, `Gallaway, a ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Primaries Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Miller crushed five Democratic challengers Tuesday in his bid for a full term in the job he inherited two years ago. Businessman Jim Gallaway won an eight-way race for the Republican nomination. Miller moved up automatically from the lieutenant governor's post after Gov. Dick Bryan was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1988. With one-third of precincts reporting, Miller had 41,294 votes, or 80 percent; the next most popular choice of voters was ``None of the Above'' _ which appears on all Nevada ballots _ with 4,100 votes or 9 percent. A long-shot hopeful who changed his name to Rhinestone Cowboy was running third with 1,540 votes. In the GOP race, Gallaway had 23,146 votes, or 49 percent, ``None of the Above'' drew 10,585 votes, or 24 percent, and builder Charlie Brown had 9,221 votes. Gallaway, a relative newcomer to the state, said Miller had shown ``a total lack of leadership'' as governor. Gallaway was accused by Brown, of trying to buy the election with slick television ads. Gallaway outspent Brown by 4-to-1. A poll conducted for the Nevada Retailers Association in August looked at the likely matchup in November and found Miller trouncing Gallaway 60 percent to 27 percent. The poll's margin of error was 4 percentage points. But Gallaway hoped to gain support from two issues. He favors abortion rights and opposes a statewide payroll tax plan while Miller is anti-abortion and backs the tax. In a bizarre contest, the name of late Assemblyman Marvin Sedway, a Las Vegas Democrat, was listed on the ballot in the District 15 Assembly contest. He died in July of lung cancer, too late to have his name removed. The ballot also included political unknown Charles Wakefield. Sedway's widow, Kim, expressed interest in the job, but too late to get on the ballot. She hoped Sedway would win the primary and the county Democratic committee would then pick her as its candidate. If so, she would face Republican Bob Wong in November. A plane crash Monday seriously injured two candidates in the GOP primary _ Sue Wagner, running for lieutenant governor, and Bob Seale, who is running for treasurer. Seale's wife, Judy, was killed in the crash, authorities said. Both held substantial leads. Five people were aboard the twin-engine plane that crashed after takeoff from Fallon for a Labor Day parade in Carson City. Two aides to the candidates suffered less serious injuries and were taken to a hospital, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Crowd Witnesses Reburial Of Allende
DOC.TEXT: In an outpouring of emotion, tens of thousands of Chileans lined the streets to view the casket of toppled Marxist President Salvador Allende, whose remains were unearthed from a humble grave for an honorable burial. Tuesday's solemn ceremony, organized by the new democratic government, came 17 years after Allende's death in a bloody military coup. The military was conspicuously absent from the ceremonies. Gen. Augusto Pinochet led the coup against Allende and still heads the armed forces. The day was chosen because it marked 20 years since Allende became the Western hemisphere's first freely elected Marxist president. As the crowd dispersed after the observances, riot police blocked small groups who attempted to march to the city center. Interior Minister Enrique Kraus said 92 people were detained in sporadic clashes with police in Santiago and five in Vina del Mar, but all were released three hours later. Santiago was reported calm at dusk. The official observances were marked by appeals to preserve Chile's newly restored democratic rule. ``We express our will to favor the future of our country, which demands from us to unite beyond the disputes that separated us in the past,'' President Patricio Aylwin said in a speech at the cemetery. Allende's remains, which had been buried outside the capital, were placed in a marble mausoleum at Santiago's main cemetery, where other Chilean presidents and dignitaries are buried. Aylwin, an elected civilian who was a political foe of Allende, succeeded Pinochet in March, putting an end to 16{ years of authoritarian military rule. Allende died during an attack on his presidential palace on Sept. 11, 1973. The military said he committed suicide rather than surrender. Allende's remains were unearthed early in the day from a modest family tomb in Vina del Mar. In Santiago, thousands of people lined the streets to view the flag-draped coffin. The procession drove the presidential palace, the Catholic Cathedral and finally the capital's main cemetery. Right-wing politicians said the ceremony was a bid to gain political advantage for the government and the left. But the government said the reburial was ``repairing an unjustice toward a man who was a legitimate president of Chile.'' Aylwin was booed when he recalled in his speech that he had opposed the Allende government. Raising his voice, the 71-year-old president replied: ``To those who are booing, I say: The only language that will allow us to understand each to other is the language of truth.'' ``The horror and suffering that Chile has gone through should never happen again,'' he continued. ``It's a task for all Chileans to prevent it, and we will be able to do so only if we reject hatred and violence.'' Allende's widow, Hortensia Bussi, said Tuesday's ceremonies ``should be seen as a contribution to reconciliation.'' French Prime Minister Michel Rocard, speaking on behalf of foreign dignitaries attending the ceremony, stressed the importance of preserving democracy. He said restoration of democracy in Chile ``shows that freedom can be momentarily supressed, but it can never be defeated.'' Security around the ceremonies was tight. Four bombs went off overnight in Santiago, causing minor damage to two military monuments and two shops but no injuries. A right-wing group claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Promises More Videotapes in Pay-For-Vote Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A powerful former legislator who once proclaimed he had ``never taken a dime with strings attached'' has pleaded guilty after being captured on videotape taking a wad of $100 bills to help pass a gambling bill. Former state Rep. Robert Brown on Tuesday became the first of five lawmakers indicted in an FBI vote-selling sting to plead guilty. The seven-year lawmaker, a Democrat from Marion, was the most powerful of those charged. Other indicted lawmakers also will be shown on FBI videotape, said U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel. Brown, 34, former chairman of the Labor, Commerce and Industry Committee, admitted taking $2,500 from a lobbyist working to legalize horse and dog racing. The bill was approved by Brown's committee last year but never came up for a full House vote. Brown, who agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, could get up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine on one count of corruption. No sentencing date was set. Prosecutors played a grainy black-and-white videotape of Brown accepting $2,000 in cash from the lobbyist, Ron Cobb, aboard a FBI yacht on April 14. FBI agent Michael Clemens testified Brown also accepted $500 from Cobb in a hotel room in May. Cobb, a former state House member, had turned undercover agent. Shortly after news of the investigation broke in July, Brown denied accepting money in exchange for his services or his vote. He resigned his seat Aug. 23, one day before he was indicted. Another indicted legislator, Rick Lee, is scheduled to appear before a federal judge on Monday. Lee, a Republican, resigned his Senate seat a week ago and has said he intends to plead guilty to accepting a $2,000 bribe. Reps. Robert Kohn, Luther Taylor and Danny Winstead also were indicted under the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts for votes or favors. Winstead also was indicted on an obstruction charge. Kohn, a Republican who has said he will not seek re-election, and Taylor, a Democrat, have been suspended from the House. Winstead, a Republican, resigned Aug. 23.

DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Post Losing Money; Sets Sept. 15 Deadline for Union Concessions
DOC.TEXT: The New York Post is losing $25 million a year and could close unless its unions agree to cost-cutting measures, union and management representatives say. Post general manager Richard T. Nasti said after a meeting with leaders of the paper's 10 unions Tuesday that the paper has set Sept. 15 as a deadline for reaching agreement. He added that he is optimistic the deadline will be met. Nasti said there is ``a $25 million annual gap that must be filled to allow (Publisher) Peter Kalikow to continue publishing the paper.'' But, in a statement, he did not say what would happen if the deadline were not met. Theodore Kheel, a labor mediator and adviser to the unions' Allied Printing Trades Council who was at the meeting, said it was his understanding that ``if they are not able to reach agreement with the unions on savings of some $17 million, they would suspend publication and give employees a 60-day notice.'' Kheel said workers would be paid during the 60 days, but the paper could cease publication immediately on Sept. 15. He said $17 million is the amount the Post hopes to save through cost-cutting measures affecting its unions, with the rest to be made up in other ways. The Allied is an umbrella group for the 10 unions representing 900 employees at the Post, which is the nation's oldest daily. The tabloid, founded in 1801, has a circulation of 505,000, behind the Daily News and The New York Times. The Post offered to open its books to its unions, and meetings were scheduled for today and Thursday to discuss cost-cutting proposals. Kalikow bought the Post from Rupert Murdoch in 1988 when the paper was losing about $3 million a month. Concessions from the unions were part of the package that Murdoch had to achieve to meet Kalikow's terms. The unions also are involved in negotiations with the Daily News over cost-saving measures the newspaper says are crucial to its survival.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Investigators Criticize Blood-Heating Treatment for AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Federal scientists have concluded a controversial blood-heating treatment for AIDS did nothing to help two U.S. patients. The team of researchers from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases also said the hyperthermia treatment, a technique to raise body temperature and kill the AIDS virus, should not be repeated. Dr. Kenneth Alonso, who helped pioneer the technique, charged that the report was ``replete with errors'' and merely an attempt to discredit his work. ``Apparently any work which does not fit your thesis is ignored,'' Alonso said in a letter to Dr. Lawrence Deyton, NIAID assistant director for community and head of the investigative team. The letter was released on Tuesday. A summary of the investigative team's findings released Tuesday by the NIAID said, ``Hyperthermia, as applied in these cases, appears to have offered no clinical, immunologic or virologic benefits to these two patients.'' NIAID reported that the two patients still were infected by the AIDS virus. There does not ``appear any support for further human experimentation in this area at this time,'' the summary concluded. The institute's report is the harshest official criticism yet of the treatment, which offered hope to thousands of AIDS sufferers earlier this year after one patient pronounced himself cured. NIAID researchers visited Alonso at his request July 25 to learn about his technique, which had been performed in the United States on two patients infected with the virus. A third man, reportedly a very ill AIDS patient from New York, received the treatment from Alonso in Mexico and died hours later. The first patient, 33-year-old Carl Crawford, reported dramatic improvements in his Kaposi's sarcoma, a skin cancer afflicting many AIDS patients. He went so far as to tell reporters he had been ``cured of AIDS.'' But tests showed no evidence the man had Kaposi's sarcoma, the NIAID reported. The researchers suggested Crawford's skin problems resulted from an infection from cat scratches that was cleared up by antibiotics. Alonso called that conclusion ``absurd.'' The second patient, a 38-year-old with advanced AIDS whose identity was kept confidential, reported little or no improvement after hyperthermia, according to the NIAID report. Alonso disputed those findings as well. Hyperthermia, commonly used to treat infections before the advent of antibiotics, is still used against some cancers. In the procedure developed by Alonso and his former partner, Dr. William Logan, the patient's blood was run through a heater and back into the body to raise body temperature. The NIAID report, however, noted that some researchers have reported that heat can actually increase the AIDS virus.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Patrol `Twilight Zone'
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Pentagon press rules prohibit giving the exact location of U.S. units.

The U.S. Marines call their patch of the Saudi Arabian desert ``the twilight zone.'' The sector south of the border with occupied Kuwait is home to venomous scorpions, snakes like carpet vipers and heat that's almost unbearable. The men never know the exact temperature, and perhaps that's a blessing. ``We don't know what day, what month, what time it is,'' said Lance Cpl. Eddie Zazueta, 21, of Los Angeles. ``I think maybe I was supposed to get out last year. This is the Twilight Zone.'' Under a pounding sun, Zazueta and his fellow Marines patrol the Martian landscape in their ``heavy gun'' _ a transport vehicle with a 50-caliber machine gun on the roof _ just across from a region that's been bristling with Iraqi troops since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The man on gun watch wakes the others up around 5 a.m. ``You usually just smack them in the legs,'' said Sgt. Thomas Hixson, 23, of Kingston, Tenn., the section leader for two vehicles in the platoon. Riding with him are Zazueta and Lance Cpl. John Doyle, 24, of Tulsa, Okla. Alert for any attack, Hixson sets reveille an hour before the time ordered for the whole 2nd Battalion of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade. Some men have suffered nasty scorpion stings early in the morning as they groped for their toilet kits. A day in the clinic and they are back on the line. The morning ``bath'' is perfunctory but important; a nearby army unit that skipped it came down with body lice and dysentery, Hixson said. Hot showers back at the base come about every 10 days. Breakfast is a banana, apple, orange or an MRE _ ``meal-ready-to-eat.'' Frankfurters are the favorite. By 6 a.m., they've picked up their four gallons of water and are headed for the day's practice battle positions and maneuvers until noon. At 7 a.m. it's 85 degrees. An hour later, it's 97. By noon it's approaching 120 degrees and the heavy guns crawl under camouflage tents until 5 p.m. Sleep at midday is impossible because of the heat. ``We talk about John Wayne-kinda stuff. What to do if we're attacked,'' said Hixson. ``We pray for war,'' said Zazueta. They banter about getting rid of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``We just want to go kick him, get him out and get home,'' said Hixson. Mail is important. ``If we have somebody who doesn't get mail, you can tell. They're down, not motivated, don't talk,'' said Hixson. ``I just got divorced, but I wish my ex would write me. I gotta get a girlfriend.'' While he talked the others whooped over a package he received from his sister, Pam Semezian in Jacksonville, Fla. It included gum, starbursts, Ritz crackers, peanut butter, watermelon flavored Jolly Ranchers and pre-addressed envelopes. Time not spent pouring over letters is spent writing them. Week-old newspapers are devoured, and a major complaint is the lack of world news. Few men brought shortwave radios. When the temperature slides downwards in late afternoon, the heavy gun trio sometimes get up a football game. After 5 p.m. its time for more maneuvers, and then a stop for dinner sometime after the eagerly awaited sunset. It's MREs again _ heavy sealed plastic bags with the menu stamped in black letters on the outside. Hot meals are as rare as showers. The last one came with green eggs. ``If you want a hot meal you just have to put it on a rock and flip it over every 3 seconds,'' said 1st Lt. Ron Ainslie, the platoon commander. ``It gets pretty hot,'' said Ainslie, a 28-year-old from Haslett, Mich. Leaving them in the sun too long can cause problems, though. About 20 men came down with food poisoning. Darkness usually brings the few things the men enjoy: a breeze and the stars. ``But I wish we had a nightclub out here,'' said Hixson. The night includes one hour of guard duty after every three of sleep. Battalion Commander Col. Carl Fulford says he'd like to see everybody home by the Marine Corps' birthday, Nov. 10. Many think it will take longer before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is rolled back. ``I don't expect to be home for Christmas,'' said Hixson.

DOC.HEAD: Six Students Killed in Protests Against Job Quotas; Bus Service Halted
DOC.TEXT: Police fatally shot six students protesting plans to give more jobs to low-caste Hindus, and growing violence prompted the government today to cancel bus service linking New Delhi with state capitals. The buses were canceled to avoid clashes and attacks on state-owned buses during a 50-hour strike beginning Thursday that students have called. They are protesting Prime Minister V.P. Singh's proposal to reserve half of all government jobs for lower castes. Thousands of passengers were stranded at New Delhi's Inter State Bus Terminus today. At least 25,000 people a day normally travel on buses from the station, the largest in India. Said a transport official at the bus terminal: ``We are running only those limited services which can return to the depot by this evening.'' Police in Bihar, India's poorest state, opened fire on students Tuesday, killing at least six people and wounding 50, news reports said. The violence raises to 14 the number of people killed in four weeks of street protests against Singh's decision. The Statesman newspaper said students had set numerous cars on fire and attempted to storm the government secretariat in Patna, the capital of the eastern state of Bihar. Indian Express, a New Delhi-based newspaper, said groups of students planned to block all traffic on the streets of the capital when the strike begins Thursday. An organization of upper-caste farmers that commands wide support in areas around New Delhi has pledged support and said its members will block all roads leading to the city. Prime Minister Singh announced Aug. 7 that 49 percent of government jobs would be reserved on the basis of caste, up from a previous 22 percent. In addition, 5 to 10 percent of jobs would be reserved for poor people regardless of caste and the rest would be awarded on merit, he said. The proposal raised a storm of protest. The government employs 18 million people and a white-collar job is much-sought by graduating students. Opponents said Singh was attempting to buy votes from the lower castes, who form a majority of India's 880 million people. The chief opposition party, the Congress Party of previous Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, has dismissed the proposals as politically motivated. Media criticism has also been fierce. The biweekly India Today magazine said Tuesday that the decision marked ``the descent of Singh from leader to demagogue. ``He has been reduced ... to a vote-hungry power broker shamelessly using the two elements which have ever bloodied and divided this nation _ religion and caste,'' the news magazine said. Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the country's people, are divided into four main castes and hundreds of sub-castes. Discrimination on the basis of caste is legally banned, but in reality the system permeates much of Indian life, especially in rural areas.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Gainesville Slayings Wanted in Sexual Attack
DOC.TEXT: A leading suspect in the stabbing deaths of five college students is wanted on charges he followed a woman, put a knife to her throat and tore her blouse two years ago, authorities said. Investigators on Tuesday also revisited the off-campus sites of last month's killings with a laser device to search for evidence. As most students returned from the Labor Day weekend, police again warned that the killer may still be in their midst. A memorial service for the slain students _ four from the University of Florida and a fifth from Santa Fe Community College _ was scheduled for today at the university. Scholarships in their memories were to be announced. The Indian River County Sheriff's Office filed armed burglary and attempted sexual battery charges Tuesday against Edward Lewis Humphrey after a 27-year-old woman identified him from his newspaper picture as the man who attacked her. Humphrey is in jail on $1 million on charges of beating up his grandmother. Police said he lived briefly this summer at an apartment complex and a dormitory where three of the slaying victims lived and is one of eight suspects. According to the police report on the 1988 incident in Indian County, the woman said a man followed her into her home near Vero Beach, tore her blouse and held a hunting knife to her throat. She said she got away and called police. ``Similarities from the 1988 incident, compiled with the knowledge that Humphrey was being looked at by the task force in Gainesville, prompted the sheriff's office to notify authorities in Gainesville,'' the sheriff's office said. Sheriff's spokeswoman Theresa Woodson did not specify the similarities. Police in Gainesville said the serial killer stalks trim brunettes, slipping into their off-campus apartments through windows or doors. He killed four women and a man in three attacks, mutilating three of the victims. Prosecutors said would fight an effort to lower Humphrey's bail. ``I'm not saying he's the killer, but the fact is that some things have surfaced in that investigation that convince us he is a serious danger to the community,'' said Michael Hunt, assistant state attorney. Investigators have taken Humphrey's fingerprints and footprints, samples of his blood and his psychiatric records. His Gainesville apartment remained sealed as a search continued on the grounds around it. Police have not sought a a search warrant for the apartment. Police confirmed that Stephen Michael Bates, a Lakeland short-order cook, was another suspect. He has been held on $100,500 bail since his Aug. 29 arrest in an unrelated assault case. Polk County authorities said they doubt Bates, 30, is the killer, but his fingerprints have been sent to the task force. Also Tuesday, Michael West, a forensic specialist from Hattiesburg, Miss., arrived with a sophisticated laser device to be used in the investigation. West, whose specialty is matching bite marks to teeth, is a dentist and a deputy coroner. Investigators did not say what they hope the laser will help them find.

DOC.HEAD: Merchant Ship Sails Out Of Kuwait With Refugees
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian-registered cargo vessel left the Kuwaiti port of Shuwaikh today with more than 600 Indian refugees aboard, shipping sources said. The merchant ship, Safeer, is the first to sail out of Kuwait with refugees since Iraq invaded the oil-rich desert kingdom on Aug. 2. The 9,300-ton Safeer was expected to reach the southern Persian Gulf port of Dubai on Thursday, said the sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The voyage from Kuwait to Dubai should take about 30 hours. From Dubai, the evacuees will be flown to India, diplomatic sources said on condition they not be identified. Shipping sources said the Safeer was in Kuwait at the time of the invasion, after arriving from the port of Kantala in western India. There are an estimated 150,000 Indians still trapped in Kuwait awaiting evacuation, diplomats said. Two Indian-registered ships, the Akbar and the Tipu Sultan, are expected to begin evacuation from Kuwait by Monday. The Tibu Sultan can accommodate about 600 passengers. The Akbar can take about 1,500, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Irene Dunne, Star of `I Remember Mama,' Dies at 88
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Irene Dunne, the alluring star of Hollywood tear-jerkers, musicals and screwball comedies in the 1930s and '40s such as ``Showboat'' and ``I Remember Mama,'' has died. She was 88. Miss Dunne, who died of heart failure at her home Tuesday, was among the most sought after and highest paid stars during her Hollywood heyday, appearing opposite such leading men as William Powell, Cary Grant and Charles Boyer. She used her fine comic timing in such comedies as ``The Awful Truth'' and ``My Favorite Wife.'' She sang in such musicals as ``Roberta'' and ``Show Boat'' and acted in the tear-jerkers ``Magnificent Obsession'' and ``Back Street.'' Miss Dunne was nominated for Oscars five times, for ``Cimarron,'' 1930, ``Theodora Goes Wild,'' 1936, ``The Awful Truth,'' 1937, ``Love Affair,'' 1939, and ``I Remember Mama,'' 1948. ``I Remember Mama,'' in which Miss Dune played the mother of a Swedish immigrant family in San Francisco, was her favorite. She generally favored her more dramatic roles. ``Comedy was easy for me but it wasn't rewarding in the same way,'' she said in a 1985 interview. ``But Cary (Grant) paid me one of the loveliest compliments of my life. He said I had the best timing of anyone he ever worked with. ``It must be something that comes naturally to you. My father had a keen sense of humor, which I think is different from having a sense of humor.'' Ginger Rogers, who appeared in ``Roberta'' with Miss Dunne, described her as ``a fine and loving lady,'' but one who was difficult to get to know well. ``She had a very excellent singing voice,'' Miss Rogers said. Irene Marie Dunn _ she added the ``e'' later _ was raised in Louisville, Ky. She trained her lyrical soprano voice at the Chicago College of Music, intending an operatic career. But when she failed an audition at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1920, she turned to musical comedy. The actress was appearing in ``Show Boat'' when she was signed to a contract by RKO Pictures in 1929. Except for ``Cimarron'' and ``Roberta,'' in which she sang ``Smoke Gets in Your Eyes,'' her RKO films were undistinguished. Only when she became a free-lance star in 1936 did her career soar. Her other films included: ``Joy of Living,'' 1938, ``Penny Serenade,'' 1941, ``A Guy Named Joe,'' 1943, ``The White Cliffs of Dover,'' 1944, ``Over 21,'' 1941, ``Anna and the King of Siam,'' 1946, ``Life with Father,'' 1947, ``The Mudlark,'' 1950. Her last film was a mild comedy, ``It Grows on Trees,'' in 1952. She made occasional TV appearances afterward. She was too ill to attend in 1985 when she was scheduled to accept Kennedy Center Honors in Washington along with Bob Hope, Allan J. Lerner and Frederick Loewe, Beverly Sills and Merce Cunningham. Miss Dunne was active in Roman Catholic causes and also worked for the Republican party. President Eisenhower appointed her an alternate delegate to the U.N. 12th General Assembly. Ronald and Nancy Reagan were close friends. Miss Dunne married a dentist, Francis Griffin, in 1920, and remarked after his death in 1965, ``I had the most marvelous husband and it was a great surprise to me to learn that he had kept every letter I had written to him.'' Along with her daughter, Mary Frances Griffin Gage, she is survived by two grandchildren and a niece. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Day Traffic Toll Totals 463
DOC.TEXT: A total of 463 people died in traffic accidents over the holiday weekend, the National Safety Council reported. California had the most deaths, 68. Texas followed with 33. Florida was next with 22, ahead of Mississippi with 18. The National Safety Council had estimated before the Labor Day holiday that between 400 and 500 people would die on the nation's streets and highways. Last year, 431 deaths were recorded during the three-day holiday weekend. Alaska, Hawaii and the District of Columbia reported no holiday traffic deaths this year. Maine, Vermont and North Dakota reported one each.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Group Sues Over Failed Launch
DOC.TEXT: Intelsat, the international satellite consortium, is suing Titan rocket builder Martin Marietta Corp. for $400 million over the botched launch of a $145 million communications satellite now stuck in a useless orbit. In the lawsuit filed Tuesday in federal court in Baltimore, Intelsat charged that Martin Marietta miswired the rocket, then gave false assurances of its quality before the March 14 launch, for which Intelsat paid $115 million. Martin Marietta has said a wiring problem caused failure of the satellite and its attached booster rocket to separate from the Titan when they reached orbit. As a result, the uninsured satellite fell short of its station 22,300 miles above Earth and will be a total loss unless it gets a boost. A shuttle crew will try to rescue it next year at a cost to Intelsat of about $90 million. Intelsat claimed Martin Marietta didn't take proper steps to detect the flaw and failed to properly analyze test data or supervise crews that built the rocket. Elliott Miller, Martin Marietta director of corporate relations, said the lawsuit had no merit and that Intelsat had declined to buy insurance. ``Under the launch services contract between Martin Marietta and Intelsat, the relationship of the parties for risk of loss is clearly set forth,'' he said. ``The contract provides that Martin Marietta is not liable for the satellite failure to achieve orbit.'' Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., built the rocket near Denver. The aerospace company attempted a pre-emptive strike against Intelsat in July, asking the federal court to declare that its only legal responsibility was to provide a replacement launch. Martin Marietta said it might have to go out of the commercial launch business if it were made to pay damages. But in its lawsuit, Intelsat noted that Martin Marietta was considering dropping out anyway.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Northern Plains, Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Cloudy skies prevailed across much of the nation early today, and isolated thunderstorms were over the northern Plains and Northeast. Today's forecast called for late summer heat from the Rockies to the central Appalachians. Scattered thunderstorms were expected from California to the Gulf Coast. Rain fell in upstate New York early today, and thunderstorms were over Buffalo. Early morning thunderstorms also were over central North Dakota at Bismark. Unseasonably high temperatures were spread across the East, Midwest and South on Tuesday. Among them was a record high of 105 degrees in Meridian, Miss., the high temperature for the Lower 48 states. Thunderstorms packing powerful winds damaged trees Tuesday in Brandon, Miss. Hail nearly an inch in diameter fell near Grand Bay, Ala.
