DOC.HEAD: Stranded Asians Fight for Bread, Urgent Appeals For International Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 11th, `Many have ... respective countries' to UPDATE with Philippines planning to step up flights. Picks up 12th pvs, `R.K. Jenny...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM5
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of ragged Asian refugees who fled Iraq and Kuwait are battling for starvation rations in this squalid desert camp. The United Nations is desperately appealing for international help. Thousands pushed and scuffled among themselves Tuesday next to a large trailer truck from which Jordanian officials were trying to distribute food _ a round piece of flat Arab bread, one tomato and one small cucumber per person. The commotion and the disorder was so great that the dozen or so Jordanian soldiers on duty stripped off their belts and started flailing the ragged refugees, yelling at them to stop fighting and get into line. But again and again, as soon as some order was restored, the thousands at the back surged forward, screaming for their share of the meager rations before they ran out. There were slightly less chaotic scenes at scattered points in the vast desert camp when half a dozen tanker trucks arrived to distribute water. ``We are fighting because we are hungry and thirsty. ... Tell the world we are going to die here if we are not helped,'' Ahmed Saed, a white-bearded Pakistani, pleaded with reporters visiting the camp near the Iraqi border. ``It is not easy to control people who are hungry and thirsty,'' said Suleyman Bakr, one of five Jordanian doctors manning a first aid tent. ``We need more food, more water, and better organization. But what's needed more than anything is to get these people to their countries as soon as possible,'' he said. The makeshift camp at Ruweishid is regarded as the most desperate area in Jordan for evacuees who have arrived from Kuwait and Iraq in the month since Iraqi troops overran the oil-rich emirate. It is located at Shaalan, 50 miles inside Jordan, between the Ruweishid border post and the Iraqi border. It houses 40,000 mostly penniless refugees from Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, the Philippines and Thailand. Many have been stranded for the past two weeks awaiting travel arrangements for the journey on to their homelands. Philippine Airlines announced today that it has scheduled 21 flights this month to the Jordanian capital of Amman to speed up the evacuation of stranded Filipinos. R.K. Jenny, a senior U.N. official trying to organize a massive airlift for the Asians, announced Tuesday that the United Nations has launched a world appeal to help Jordan cope with the massive influx. ``This is going to be a gigantic problem calling for a gigantic response,'' he told a news conference in the capital, Amman. Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan said more than 100,000 Asians are stranded in his country _ out of the 420,000 people who have crossed into Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait since Aug. 7. ``The situation may soon become critical,'' he told the news conference. ``The plight of these persons has only evoked the faintest of responses from the world community and from a world press more interested in war scenarios than humanitarian relief.'' Indeed, there has been concern that world attention has been focused instead on the better-off Westerners being held by the Iraqis, and their quest to get out. In Amman later Tuesday, Jordan's American-born Queen Noor embraced and kissed British millionaire Richard Branson when he flew in aboard a 747 jumbo jet of his Virgin Atlantic airline with 30 tons of food for the stranded Asians. ``We are so grateful. We desperately need all this,'' the queen told Branson as she pointed at the sacks of wheat slung on top of the scarlet first class seats of the jet. ``We will get this to the really desperate areas and this action you have done is a tremendous help,'' the queen added. Branson said he was worried more about the plight of the stranded Asian and Arab refugees than of the Westerners trying to leave areas under Iraqi control. ``What we are doing is only a pittance,'' he said. ``Children and old people are dying. We need a massive airlift, and ships. This is something the United Nations should do.'' One Bangladeshi in Ruweishid said his embassy in Kuwait ``advised us to leave after the Iraqi invasion to avoid being killed if war broke out with America. ``But it would have been better to stay in Iraq and face death there, rather than die in this terrible stink hole in the desert.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl To Name Four Top East Germans To His Cabinet, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to name four leading East Germans to his Cabinet to help deal with the massive problems of their people when the two Germanys merge next month, government sources said today. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere is a top candidate for a Cabinet post, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In East Berlin today, officials said the number of East Germans either unemployed or working shorter hours at lower pay jumped to nearly 2 million of the 8.8 million workers last month. The Central Labor Office said 361,286 East Germans were without jobs last month, up by 86,269 from the end of July. The jobless rate went from 3.1 percent to 4.1 percent. That compares with a 1.6 percent rate at the end of June, just before East Germany converted to a free market economy on July 1 after four decades of socialism. Many factories and businesses, no longer subsidized, are having difficulty competing with more efficient Western enterprises that now have access to the East German market. Electronics, textiles, automotive and agricultural industries are among the hardest hit. The number of workers who came under a West German-financed program fighting the rise in unemployment was up to 1,439,412, more than double the 656,277 in July. The workers under this program would have been laid off but are being kept on payrolls at shorter hours and lower pay subsidized by West Germany. Critics say these workers, some of whom are making only a small amount over the unemployment rate and not actually doing any work, should be counted among the jobless. Government sources in Bonn said today that as part of Kohl's plans for an interim government for a united Germany the chancellor will be adding four East German officials to his Cabinet. East Germany and its government will cease to exist on Oct. 3, the chosen day of unity. The four new ministers will help Kohl govern what is now East Germany between the day of unity and Dec. 2, when an all-German Parliament will be elected, said the sources. They said that along with de Maiziere, other top candidates are Guenther Krause, de Maiziere's leading unity negotiatior; Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, president of the East German Parliament; and Rainer Ortleb, head of the East German Free Democrats. The four new Cabinet members would be ministers without portfolios, said the sources. West German radio said the four new ministers would act as intermediaries between Kohl's government and East Germany's five soon-to-be-recreated states. East Germany will also have parliamentary representation in the interim period between unity and all-German elections. The two Germanys have agreed 144 East German lawmakers will have seats in the West German Parliament after unity. The major East German parties are choosing the 144 on the basis of the current balance of power within the East German Parliament, which will be dissolved when unity comes.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Shipment Of 800 Vehicles to Saudi Arabia Held Up By Worried Seamen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with seamen's union holding up departure. Picks up 5th pvs, `Kaifu has...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan loaded a ship with 800 four-wheel-drive vehicles for the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf, but a seamen's union held up today's planned departure because of the war danger. The $11 million in cargo, Japan's first installment of the $1 billion it has promised in aid for the effort against Iraq, also included an unspecified number of water trucks and air conditioners. Negotiations between the government and the All Japan Seamen's Association continued into the evening and it was unclear when the ship would set sail from the central port of Nagoya. The union said its members should not be forced to sail into the tense gulf region. The Panama-registered Sea Venus, owned by Kawasaki Kisen Co. Ltd., would take about three weeks to get to the gulf region, the ship's agent said in a telephone interview. The vehicles are expected to be used by military staff in the multinational forces assembled in Saudi Arabia, said a Foreign Ministry official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The shipment is part of the assistance package announced last week by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. It is to include 100 medical personnel and chartered civil aircraft and ships that will transport food, water and medical supplies ship as well as other non-military goods. Kaifu has ruled out a direct role for Japan's military, citing the constitutional prohibition against the use of force in settling international disputes. The Foreign Ministry official declined to say when further shipments were to be made, but Japan has said prefabricated housing, refrigerators and power generators would likely be sent. Kuwait today joined Washington in urging Japan to make a greater contribution. ``I would have wished Japan to have done more,'' Sheikh Ali al Khalifa al Athbi al-Sabah, finance minister of the Kuwaiti government in exile, told reporters in Tokyo. But he added that persuading Japan to contribute more should be done ``very softly, considering their circumstances.'' U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is to stop briefly in Tokyo on Friday to explain to Kaifu and other Japanese officials what kind of further assistance Washington is seeking. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe on Tuesday dismissed criticism that the aid package did not go far enough, saying it was a ``rather sizable amount.'' He also said Japanese corporations will be asked to divert existing stock to the assistance package and sell their products to the government at cost. Toyota spokesman Yoshiharu Tateishi would not say what losses the company might incur, but said providing vehicles for the Persian Gulf force would delay supplies. ``Our productivity is not capable to cover the losses because the domestic demand is already quite high,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Don't Forget Africa
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II ended his five-day pilgrimage to Tanzania today by celebrating Mass at the foot of Mount Kilimanjaro and imploring rich countries to forge ``a new era of solidarity'' with Africa. ``Let the world not forget the urgent needs of the peoples of Africa,'' the pope said before flying to the central African country of Burundi, the second leg of his 10-day, four-nation tour. John Paul, making his seventh trip to Africa, said he was pleased with the growth of the Roman Catholic Church in Tanzania, but he could not ignore that millions of Africans continue to live in poverty. ``I implore God's gifts of comfort, strength and peace upon those who suffer or are in need on this continent,'' he said in a departure speech. ``In the name of our common humanity I appeal to the more developed nations of the earth to inaugurate a new era of solidarity with Africa, based on justice and respect.'' Earlier today, about 40,000 people attended the pope's Mass in Kilimanjaro Stadium, a former cricket and polo grounds of British rulers. When John Paul arrived, the 19,300-foot snowy peak of Africa's tallest mountain broke through clouds that obscured it much of the morning. In his homily, the pontiff paid tribute to the missionaries who brought Christianity to northern Tanzania 100 years ago. ``The many saints and martyrs of the young African churches show that what has been handed on since apostolic times need not be watered down in order to penetrate the rich soil of Africa,'' he said. ``The heroic response to the demands of conversion and the challenge of martyrdom constitutes a glorious page in the history of your particular churches.'' The pope encouraged his flock to practice their faith in ``an authentically African way'' by incorporating their customs, culture and traditions in the church. ``By illuminating and purifying these elements of local life with the Gospel and bringing them into Catholic unity, the whole church is marvelously enriched,'' he said. The pope has urged Roman Catholics to shun such practices as witchcraft and polygamy, stressing that the basic tenets of the faith cannot be compromised. Among the gifts for the pope was a stuffed lion brought to the edge of the altar on the back of a pickup truck by a Masai Moran, or warrior, dressed in the tribe's traditional toga-like robe of red and blue. To mark the pope's visit, members of the Mount Kilimanjaro Mountain Club scaled the peak and placed a plaque at the summit. ``We pray that this visit will sow the seeds of peace, love, progress and understanding among the people of Tanzania, Africa and the whole world,'' the plaque read. The pope will also travel to Rwanda and the Ivory Coast, where he will end his tour next week by consecrating the massive basilica of Our Lady of Peace.

DOC.HEAD: Mirage Jet Fighter Crashes in Southern France
DOC.TEXT: A French Mirage jet fighter crashed in the sea off a southern French island today, but the pilot ejected and was unharmed, military officials said. The pilot of the Mirage F-1 radioed that a fire had broken out on board before he ejected and the plane crashed into the Mediterranean Sea off the southern coast of Corsica, a French island about 590 miles southeast of Paris, the officials said. The plane was taking part in a firing exercise, the officials said. They said an investigation was opened to determine the cause of the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Named President of Newsday
DOC.TEXT: Douglas B. Fox, a senior vice president for marketing at Newsday, has been named president and chief operating officer at Newsday and New York Newsday, the paper announced today. Fox, who joined Newsday in 1987 as a vice president of marketing, will be responsible for the day-to-day management of the newspaper, publisher and Chief Executive Officer Robert M. Johnston said. ``In his time at Newsday, Doug Fox has shown himself to be not only a great marketing mind, but a genuine team player and natural leader,'' Johnson said in a news release. ``At the same time, Doug's appointment and promotion will allow me to concentrate more on broad issues of policy, strategy, employee concerns and outside community relations both on Long Island and in New York City,'' Johnson said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with students clashing with police. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `South Korean...' Minor editing to trim.
DOC.TEXT: The rival Koreas today held their highest level meeting to date, and North Korea demanded that South Korea immediately release jailed dissidents and halt a joint military exercise with the United States. For its part, South Korea proposed mutual recognition, free travel and gradual arms reduction. The Communist north and capitalist south never formally recognized each other after the division of Korea in 1945. Across town, about 1,000 radical students yelling ``U.S. troops get out!'' hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police who blocked them from marching off the campus at Seoul National University and fired tear gas to disperse them. Several people were injured and at least five students were arrested. South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon, the first to speak at the opening session, had no opportunity to respond directly to the demands of the Communist north. But the Seoul government has already said that the issues are internal matters. The north also demanded that South Korea cease efforts to seek a seat in the United Nations, saying that would perpetuate the division of the peninsula. After each side made its statement, the formal meeting was adjourned, as scheduled. A second meeting was to be held Thursday behind closed doors. It was unclear whether the future of the talks would be jeopardized by the north's demands, but North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk strongly indicated that progress in other areas would be unlikely unless the demands were met. He stopped short of calling them conditions. ``We view these as very urgent, very serious matters ... directly connected with the future fate of this conference,'' the North Korean premier said. The south opened the talks with a proposal based on its conviction that mutual confidence-building measures must precede unification talks. North Korea has taken the view that confidence between the two sides will come only after arms cuts and unification are complete. ``Should the authorities of both sides persist in confrontational and hostile attitudes, inter-Korean relations will never be improved,'' Kang said. The South Korean prime minister said cooperation between the two sides should include free travel across the border during major holidays, economic and trade cooperation, and the reconnection of railroad, highway, mail and telephone service lines. Kang also proposed that the two governments work jointly to locate family members separated by the three-year Korean War in the early 1950s. An estimated 10 million Koreans were separated from family members during the conflict. On arms reduction, Kang said the two sides should agree to equal numbers of troops and weapons. Currently, the north has about 1.1 million troops and the South has 650,000 and the support of 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea. Kang said international safeguards for peace on the peninsula should involve not only the two Koreas, but interested foreign powers, including the Soviet Union, China, Japan and the United States. South Korean observers have been careful to point out that the talks that began today are meant to be a significant first step in a long process of dialogue which eventually may lead to unification. A peace treaty was never signed after the Korean War. The North Korean delegation is only the third to visit the south in more than 40 years. The 90-member delegation crossed the border Tuesday for a four-day visit. The talks opened promptly this morning with the seven-member official delegations of both sides facing one another across a rectangular table. The North Korean premier, wearing a badge depicting North Korean Communist Party leader Kim Il Sung, waved briefly to onlookers and took his seat at the north side of the table. The South Korean premier sat on the south side. The premiers smiled broadly and shook hands across the table. When photographers yelled for them to repeat the action, they stood for about a minute clasping hands. The North Korean delegation was staying at a luxury hotel where they could tune into American television, enjoy a sauna in a posh health club and buy German and French magazines. The South Korean government was picking up the tab.

DOC.HEAD: Videotapes Replace Striking Teachers in Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with tentative strike settlement, vote this morning, change verb tenses throughout. Will be updated after vote scheduled for 11 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Students watched videotaped lessons that a teacher's union official called ``high-tech scabbing'' during a strike that lasted only one day before negotiators reached a tentative settlement early today. Teachers were expected to vote this morning on the settlement offer, which was made about 2:30 a.m. after nearly 6{ hours of talks, said Melanie Mitchell, president of the Yakima Education Association. Ratification was expected to be a formality. Details of the offer were not immediately available. But Mitchell said it gives teachers more say over the method of classroom instruction, sets limits on class size and addresses teacher evaluation concerns. ``I think we've achieved a settlement both parties can be pleased with,'' she said. School administrators defended their use of television instruction in the 12,000-pupil district, but some teachers and students weren't impressed. ``It's a joke,'' said sophomore John Williams, who walked out of an English class Tuesday at Davis High School to find a skiing magazine in the library. ``I'm going home,'' said student Carmen Espinosa. But another student, Brendon Curland, said it was better to go to school because there would be too many distractions trying to work at home. Yakima's 709 teachers walked out Monday night in a dispute over class size, pay for extracurricular activities, teacher evaluations, grievance procedures and use of teacher aides. Administrators had recorded video lessons and on Tuesday, the first day of classes, showed them in every school while teachers walked picket lines outside. Teachers urged parents to keep their children home. At Davis High, more than half the 1,600 students were in class, but many classrooms were empty. Students worked with supervision from teacher aides. Some students talked back to the video teachers; others sipped soft drinks, gazed out windows or talked among themselves. ``This guy looks cool,'' one student sneered as a lecture on the Civil War came on the screen. Carolyn Wallace of the National Education Association called the televised lessons ``high-tech scabbing.'' ``We have never heard of anything like this,'' Ms. Wallace said by telephone from Washington, D.C. Some districts have shown educational films during strikes but never recorded lessons, she said. Striking teachers questioned the value of the tapes. ``It's tough to ask a TV a question,'' said Roger Farnum, an English teacher at Davis. Principal Robert McLaughlin said the video lectures follow regular lesson plans and that teachers would pick right up from them when they return. ``We think this is a quality education. This is not baby-sitting,'' he said. ``But it's not as good as having my instructors here,'' he acknowledged. The tapes were supplemented Tuesday by four pages of advertising in the local newspaper containing lesson plans and assignments for students. The tapes also were shown over two educational cable TV stations controlled by the district, and students could do the work from home for credit, said district spokeswoman Rhonda Stone. The district said it would pay to hook up cable for any family of a student that didn't have the service, and for newspaper subscriptions. Administrators began taping the lessons last week at the district's TV studio and said they hoped to stay one week ahead in the event of a lengthy strike, said McLaughlin, who is teaching economics. Teacher aides, who did not strike, could oversee classrooms but cannot do any teaching, said aide Lisa Baker. ``I make sure they are getting their notes down,'' she said. Ms. Baker said some students asked her to switch channels to MTV. In another class a boy insisted to an aide that Davis students were allowed to have soft drinks during class. McLaughlin said they aren't.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Wary About Writing Off Egyptian Military Debt
With PM-Gulf-Baker Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 4-5, I think..., to UPDATE with further quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are questioning President Bush's decision to forgive $7 billion in debts from Egypt, saying it could trigger pleas for similar relief and push up the federal deficit. House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said Congress would approve Bush's recommendation to reward Egypt for helping in the Persian Gulf operation against Iraq if Egypt's participation saves the United States substantial money. ``If we could avoid spending a substantial amount of money by having Egyptian soldiers in place of American soldiers, there could be a tradeoff there,'' Gingrich told reporters in Atlanta. ``I think we would have to look at the other nations that owe us a lot, also,'' Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said today on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' program. ``There are going to be requests from others if we do this, undoubtedly.'' But he said he thinks there will be a lot of support for forgiving Egypt's debt and it should be considered. ``It's not as expensive if...you evaluate it in terms of the present worth of that debt,'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said on the same program. ``A lot of debt reduction's occurring around the world. You take a look at what the world market is for it. For example, $7 billion is in fact worth five cents on the dollar if you try to sell it on the open market.'' Several members of Congress said that while they support Bush's overall policy of holding the line against further aggression by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, they are concerned about the repercussions of Operation Desert Shield on the already steep federal budget deficit. Growing political pressure for a deal between the White House and Congress to curb federal deficits already had thrown into doubt the notion that money saved by the lessening of East-West tensions could amount to a peace dividend to be applied to domestic needs. In asking Congress to approve a deal to write off $7 billion in Egypt's military debt to the United States, the White House said Bush decided on this course of action as ``a symbol of our appreciation'' for Egypt's assistance in the gulf operations. But House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said the move ``may be a little premature.'' He added, ``I would like to hear firsthand from the administration the rationale'' for the decision. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of a Senate foreign aid panel, said the debt forgiveness would lead to similar requests from other nations that have suffered economically because of an embargo on trade with Iraq. ``I'm not willing to double or triple our foreign aid budget without a lot more understanding of what the United States gets out of it,'' he said. Leahy predicted that such a major step involving Egypt would trigger similar requests from Israel, Turkey, Greece, the Philippines, Morocco, Pakistan and other nations. ``I know it's going to be necessary to increase some foreign aid dollars as a result of Operation Desert Shield,'' Leahy said in an interview. But he added, ``It looks like some in the administration are saying let's have a blank check for foreign aid. I want to remind them that my subcommittee's still got the checkbook.'' Egypt has an additional $6 billion in non-military debt to the United States and that still stands, Fitzwater said. He said forgiving the $7 billion debt would mean the U.S. Treasury would forgo a payment of $750 million this year, which would have contributed to the efforts to reduce the federal deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Monitors Detained
DOC.TEXT: Three Western human rights monitors probing alleged abuses in the restive Kosovo province were detained by police, ordered out of Yugoslavia and barred from the country for the next three years, diplomats said today. The diplomats, who asked not to be identified, said three members of the Vienna-based International Helsinki Federation were detained late Tuesday at their hotel in Prizren, a Kosovo town close to the border with neighboring Albania. The three were ordered out of Yugoslavia within 24 hours and had their passports stamped to bar them from the country for three years, according to the diplomats and Lisa Lotteleicht, a group spokeswoman in Vienna. A Dutchman in the delegation, identified as Barend Cohen, told his embassy in Belgrade the group also had all its work documents confiscated, Lotteleicht said. The police action followed increasingly critical reports by the group on the human rights situation in Kosovo, an ancient Serbian province now dominated by ethnic Albanians. The Serbs have taken full adminstrative control of the province, arguing this is necessary to protect the Slav minority from alleged ethnic Albanian harassment. More than 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with Serb-dominated security forces in the past 18 months as the Albanian majority there struggles to regain autonomy. Serbia's tactics in Kosovo have drawn increasing criticism from visiting Western delegations. Last week, 21 police and dozens of demonstrators were injured in clashes between security forces and thousands of Albanians waiting to greet a U.S. Congressional delegation investigating alleged human rights abuses. The delegation, led by Republican Sen. Robert Dole of Kansas, said later it was ``deeply disturbed ... (by) fresh evidence that Serbian authorities are engaged in a systematic pattern of violating the rights of Albanians.'' The delegation was led by Christine von Kohl, a Danish-born correspondent who now lives in Austria but previously spent several years working in Belgrade. Cohen and an Austrian were the other two detained. Vera Caric, head of the press department of the Yugoslav federal government, said that neither her office nor the Foreign Ministry had official word of the delegation's visit. Serbian authorities were not immediately available for comment. Kosovo is the heartland of Serbia's ancient medieval kingdom and the issue of its autonomy is a highly emotional one in the state, Yugoslavia's largest. Serbs maintain that if given self-government, ethnic Albanians would secede and merge with neighboring Albania.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rocks Southeastern Cuba; No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 5 on the Richter scale caused some damage to buildings in the southeastern Cuban city of Santiago, but no injuries were reported, a Spanish news agency reported today. The state-run Spanish agency EFE cited a Cuban news report as saying Cuban seismologists rated the earthquake as one of the strongest in the quake-prone area in the last 10 years. EFE did not report an exact time for the start of the earthquake, which occurred Tuesday evening. The U.S. National Earthquake Information Center said a quake of magnitude 4.3 was felt Tuesday at Santiago de Cuba and Guantanaomo Bay. The different Richter readings could not immediately be reconciled. Anthony Gordon, a duty officer at the Guantanaomo Bay Naval Station operated by the United States in Eastern Cuba, confirmed the earthquake was felt at the base about 4 a.m. Tuesday. ``It shook me awake,'' Gordon said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake registering 5 on the scale can cause considerable damage. EFE said the Cuban news agency AIN reported the tremor cracked and split walls in some buildings, shattered windows and sent pieces of building adornments flying to the ground. The report said seismologists in Cuba located the earthquake's epicenter at 12.4 miles south of Santiago de Cuba at a depth of 20 kilometers in Santiago Bay.

DOC.HEAD: Adrian Phillips, 91, Former Miss America Pageant President
DOC.TEXT: Adrian Phillips, a former hotel executive and ex-president of the Miss America Pageant who saw every crowning, has died at his home outside Atlantic City. He was 91. He was the last surviving charter member of the pageant organization, and had planned to attend this year's finale on Saturday despite his poor health, his family said in announcing the Tuesday death. Phillips saw the first pageant in 1921, joined the sponsoring organization the following year, and was elected president in 1967. Atlantic City Mayor James Whelan said Phillips, who maintained a collection of resort memorabilia, was ``a walking history of Atlantic City.'' Born in Philadelphia, Phillips spent summers in Atlantic City, learning the hotel business through an uncle and aunt who operated the St. Clare Hotel. He moved to the resort as a teen-ager. In 1922, he began a 60-year career at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, a hotel that became the city's first legal casino, Resorts International, in 1978. He taught hotel management at Cornell University for 20 years, and was a past president of the Hotel Sales Management Association. Phillips and his wife, Emaline, observed their 68th anniversary last month. In addition to his wife, he is survived by four sons, Donald of Lower Bank, Adrian Jr. of Phoenix, Robert of Atlanta, and Steven of Philadelphia. A memorial service is scheduled for 3 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Leaving Iraq, Kuwait in Airlift
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more flights under way today to evacuate Westerners, Iraq says it's doing its best to speed departures; TRIMS pvs; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Western women and children detained in Kuwait and Iraq continued leaving Iraq in small groups today, while hundreds more waited anxiously for the government's permission to leave. A regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight to Amman today brought seven Britons and four Americans, airport officials said, and more Europeans and Americans were expected on a regular afternoon flight. A group of about 175 foreigners, including 24 Americans, flew to London from Amman early today aboard a Virgin Atlantic Airlines Boeing 747. The plane had carried 40 tons of supplies for tens of thousands of desperate Asian evacuees from Kuwait stranded in Jordan. Taleb Subah, an American teen-ager from Davenport, Iowa, was among the Americans who arrived in Jordan on Tuesday and early today. ``Kuwait was living hell,'' he said. ``You go to sleep to bombing, and you wake up to it. It is like living Vietnam all over again. There are lots of dead people. They throw them in the trash.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said last week he will release all women and children but keep Western men at strategic installations to deter any foreign attack. Since then, however, only small groups of Western women and children have been able to leave. In addition to today's regularly scheduled flights, a French-chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 707 was scheduled to fly from Baghdad to Amman with 60 French women and children as well as some Belgians, Italians, Britons, Norwegians and Spaniards, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman said. An Air France jet left Paris for Amman early today to pick up the French detainees, who had reached Baghdad by traveling overland from Kuwait, French Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said in Paris. The morning arrivals refused to talk to reporters as they were hustled by a Jordanian officials through the arrival lounge to a waiting room for flights to Europe and the United States. ``Please leave us alone, you will get us into trouble. We cannot speak to you,'' one of them said. In Baghdad, 306 British women and children who arrived in a seven-bus convoy from Kuwait on Tuesday night were awaiting exit visas today, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The group was expected to leave Baghdad on Thursday or Friday. The Iraqi News Agency today quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying Iraq was doing its best to speed the departure of foreign women and children. ``Iraq endeavors with all possible means to ensure their departure in cooperation with concerned countries,'' the news agency reported. It said ``all border points were open for their departure, and the Iraqi Airways was ready to lease its aircraft for flying them to any capital.'' More than 700 Western detainees _ women, children and a few ailing men _ left aboard two Iraqi Airways flights on Saturday in the first major airlift since Saddam announced they could go. Some evacuees also have traveled across the desert to neighboring countries. But the departures of others have been complicated by Iraq's refusal to allow foreign airlines to land in Baghdad and by long delays in processing exit permits. About 11,000 Westerners are now believed stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Throughout Tuesday and into early today, three Iraqi Airways jets airlifted hundreds of Westerners from Baghdad to Amman and connecting flights home. Most of the evacuees were women, young children and teen-agers, but some elderly and ailing men were also aboard the flights. On Tuesday, 135 foreigners, mostly West Germans, flew into Amman on a charter from Baghdad and then transferred to a Lufthansa flight. British millionaire Richard Branson, owner of Virgin Atlantic, arrived in Amman with one of six jumbo jets he lent at the request of Jordan's American-born Queen Noor. He said he was worried more by the plight of stranded Asian refugees in Jordan than by Westerners, who are oming home. ``What we are doing is only a pittance,'' he said. ``Children and old people are dying. We need a massive airlift and ships. This is something the United Nations should do.'' He urged that all flights coming in to repatriate Asian refugees carry supplies for the more than 100,000 people housed in squalid camps in Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Heads Into Final Hours of Countdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with test director quote, weather outlook. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `An important ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: NASA headed with confidence today into the final hours of Columbia's countdown, which was halted once before by fuel leaks and then by problems with one of four telescopes aboard. Columbia is scheduled to blast off with seven astronauts and the Astro observatory at 1:20 a.m. EDT Thursday. It will be NASA's first shuttle launch in more than four months _ the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. ``We're not tracking any problems at the current time. Everyone's upbeat, ready to go,'' test director Mike Leinbach said today. Air Force meteorologists today were predicting an 80 percent chance of good weather at launch time and expected the outlook to improve as the day wore on. An important test was to come this afternoon, when NASA was to begin fueling the shuttle with a half-million gallons of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen. A hydrogen leak forced NASA to scrub Columbia's first countdown on May 30. The leaky hydrogen lines were later replaced. ``There will be a little apprehension, of course, on all of our parts,'' program manager Bill Huddleston said Tuesday. ``But we have all the confidence in the world that we've got this problem resolved.'' A launch attempt set for the weekend was scrubbed after NASA lost contact with Astro's X-ray telescope, secured alongside three ultraviolet telescopes in Columbia's cargo bay. The problem was corrected, allowing another countdown. The latest delay required a juggling of Astro's observing schedule, said Arthur Davidsen, principal investigator of Johns Hopkins University's ultraviolet telescope. About 150 high-energy objects will be observed during the nine- to 10-day flight, some of them millions of degrees hot. Astronomers now will be able to observe Jupiter, which was too close to the sun last week, Davidsen said. But an important quasar _ the brightest one _ has moved too close to the sun and will not be visible to Astro. The $150 million observatory had been scheduled for a ride on Columbia in 1986, but the Challenger disaster two months earlier put all missions on hold. It will be the first scientific mission in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research. Astro will remain on board and return to Earth for possible re-use. The mission will be the first shuttle flight since April, when Discovery put the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit. The telescope was later found to have a flawed mirror that produces blurry images. That news quickly was followed by the discovery that Atlantis had hydrogen leaks similar to Columbia's. NASA briefly grounded the three-shuttle fleet, and Atlantis' secret military flight was delayed from July to November. NASA has wasted no time getting its shuttle program back on track. While repairing Columbia and Atlantis, the space agency has been preparing Discovery for an October flight with the Ulysses satellite. Discovery was moved out to the other shuttle launch pad Tuesday night. Ulysses is being sent on a five-year journey to explore the sun's poles. NASA has from Oct. 5 to Oct. 23 to launch Discovery because of Earth's alignment with the sun and Jupiter. Otherwise, the mission must wait 13 months.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Rebel Leaders Arrive For Meetings on U.N. Plan
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian government officials and rebel leaders were in Jakarta today for possible meetings on a U.N.-supported peace plan. The talks, scheduled to begin Thursday, may bring together representatives of Premier Hun Sen's Vietnam-backed government and leaders of a three-member guerrilla coalition. But plans for the meetings seemed threatened Tuesday after disputes over who would represent the various groups. Coalition leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk said earlier this week he would be represented by his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh. Hun Sen said he would send a subordinate because Sihanouk would not be in Jakarta. Then the Khmer Rouge said it would boycott the talks because Hun Sen had withdrawn. Son Sann, leader of the third element in the coalition, said he was ``prepared to hold talks on Cambodia despite the absence of Hun Sen.'' ``I hope Hun Sen will be coming soon ... If they are serious, they will come,'' said Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan said after arriving in Jakarta. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas arranged for no more than three days of informal talks on a peace plan adopted Aug. 28 by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. The plan, approved by the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France, calls for a truce and U.N. supervision before elections. It also proposes a Supreme National Council of representatives from the four Cambodian factions. Khieu Samphan said he hoped his arrival would encourage Hun Sen to make an appearance. All three guerrilla factions welcomed the U.N. plan. Phnom Penh, however, expressed support for a major U.N. role, but said it should retain power in the interim period. The peace plan, originally proposed by Australia, appears to offer the best hope to end the decades-old conflict. Millions have been killed in Cambodia since 1970, when a coup ended three decades of rule by Sihanouk. The Khmer Rouge won a civil war in 1975 and ruled the nation for three years. It's blamed for the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of people in efforts to create a new agrarian society. The Soviet-backed Vietnamese invaded in December 1978. Guerrilla combat and near famine in 1979 drove hundreds of thousands of Cambodians to U.N. refugee camps in Thailand. The Hun Sen government comprises largely Khmer Rouge defectors. Sihanouk said from Beijing that he was not coming to Jakarta because Hun Sen should negotiate with Son Sann, who is premier of the resistance coalition. Sihanouk also said he doesn't want bilateral talks with Hun Sen because a solution must be worked out among all four Cambodian factions. The Khmer Rouge receives weapons and supplies from China. Moscow backs the Phnom Penh government and the United States supports the non-communist factions under Sihanouk and Son Sann.

DOC.HEAD: Police to Patrol Jewish Monuments After Defacement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Corrects spelling of graffiti.
DOC.TEXT: The city police chief has ordered regular patrols of Jewish sites after a vandal scrawled hate graffiti on a monument at Umschlagplatz, where Jews were put aboard trains to the Treblinka death camp in World War II. The graffiti, which said ``The only good Jew is a dead Jew,'' was discovered early Monday at the monument, which was dedicated in April 1988 on the 45th anniversary of the Warsaw Jewish Ghetto Uprising. Authorities were alerted by residents, but the graffiti was not removed until Tuesday due to bureaucratic shuffling, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported. ``This deserves contempt. This hurts, wounds, and casts a shadow on the great majority of Poles who consider such an act as sordid,'' said government Minister Aleksander Hall. Hall, representing Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's Cabinet, laid flowers at the monument Tuesday to honor the Jewish victims. ``Not only the church but the whole nation condemns and distances itself from such deeds. They can only be the act of irresponsible and immoral people,'' said Bishop Wladyslaw Miziolek, quoted by Gazeta Wyborcza.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Foresees Increased Gulf Aid From Allies
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs on British response; Brady comments. Deletes outdated 6th graf pvs, From London ... in Tokyo. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The administration ...
DOC.TEXT: Britain today pledged to contribute to a U.S.-organized fund to share costs of the Persian Gulf operation against Iraq, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady called the European portion of his fund-raising tour a success. A spokeswoman for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Mrs. Thatcher promised a contribution but offered no specific amounts, and Brady told reporters after his 45-minute meeting at 10 Downing Street that he was pleased by the response. ``We didn't talk specific amounts, but she was tremendously supportive and indicated that the plan we had outlined to her was one with which she agreed,'' Brady said. Brady left immediately for Seoul, where he was to hold talks with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on Friday before heading to Tokyo, the last stop on his four-nation journey, to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. At a news conference, Brady rejected suggestions that European and Asian leaders might resent being leaned on by the United States to put up more money for the Persian Gulf campaign. ``Quite the contrary, Mrs. Thatcher thought it was exactly the right thing to do,'' Brady said. Earlier, Brady had said he believed increased assistance would be forthcoming once the allies review the details of the American proposal more closely. But he said his four-day fund-raising marathon may not bear fruit until the allies have a chance to study the U.S. proposals and their own economic assessment of the situation in more detail. Brady met with French government officials on Tuesday. The administration is seeking more than $25 billion in economic assistance to defray the military and economic costs of the campaign to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said following his discussions with Brady late Tuesday in Paris that the two had enjoyed a ``very constructive conversation and we will look at these problems in the near future.'' U.S. officials said the French had told Brady that the question of increased European economic assistance would be taken up at a meeting of officials of the 12-nation European Community on Friday. For his part, Brady gave what amounted to a pep talk to the allies, contending that they were close to putting into place the final pieces of a three-part strategy to resolve the Mideast crisis. He said that strategy focused on the trade embargo approved by the United Nations, the military buildup led by the United States and economic assistance to provide ``staying power'' for the first two efforts. ``There is diplomatic support, there is military support and now we have the job of providing economic support,'' Brady said. Brady's globe-girdling jaunt was one of two administration efforts to round up economic support. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was scheduled to leave Washington tonight on a similar mission to oil-rich countries of the Middle East, with later stops planned in West Germany and Italy. The administration has a lot riding on its fund drive. It fears that without a substantial flow of economic assistance Third World nations especially hurt by the loss of trade with Iraq will begin violating the embargo. Officials speaking to reporters aboard Brady's plane said a critical need at present was to get commitments for $10 billion or more to provide assistance to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt, the three countries suffering the most economically from the Persian Gulf crisis. In addition, the Brady mission was discussing allied support to help defray the cost of the huge U.S. military buildup. Japan and West Germany, two economic superpowers who depend on Mideast oil, are being looked to along with Saudi Arabia and the exiled government of Kuwait to help provide perhaps $1.1 billion a month or more to cover such U.S. costs as transportation and housing for military forces. The administration also was discussing raising funds to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe and other countries such as Brazil and the Philippines cope with higher oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Only Nuclear Plant Canceled, 20-Year Energy Policy Outlined
DOC.TEXT: Construction of Poland's only nuclear power plant project has been halted under a new policy stressing coal and other natural energy sources, the official news agency reported today. Work on the four 440-magawatt reactors began in 1983 and the first reactor was scheduled to start producing electricity as early as next year. But concerns about rising costs and environmental dangers have plagued the plant at Zarnowiec on the Baltic coast northwest of Gdansk. Demonstrations against the project intensified following the 1986 nuclear accident at Chernobyl in the Soviet Ukraine. Prime Minster Tadeusz Mazowiecki's Cabinet voted to stop work on the plant and devise a plan to sell off components. ``The costs of the completion of the investment would probably exceed construction costs of a conventional plant of equal performance,'' the Council of Ministers said following its decision Tuesday, the PAP news agency reported. Work was stopped last year on Poland's only other nuclear project, located in Klempicz, about 150 miles west of Warsaw. That plant was to have four 1,000-megawatt reactors, also of Soviet design. Under the new energy policy, development of nuclear power is not envisioned until at least the year 2000, and then only in ``a limited scope,'' according to PAP. The plan, worked out by the Solidarity-led government, urged continued reliance on coal, but supported a shift to more efficient energy sources such as natural gas, crude oil and water power.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ruling Puts PTL Purchase in Question
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge has thrown into jeopardy the $52 million deal by a San Diego evangelist to purchase the assets of the PTL ministry once headed by Jim Bakker. ``This deal is in big, big trouble,'' said Dennis Shedd, the court-appointed trustee overseeing the sale of the defunct religious empire near Fort Mill, 10 miles south of Charlotte, N.C. ``I don't think people are aware of how serious this is, but they should be,'' Shedd said after a bankruptcy court ruling Tuesday. Judge Thurmond Bishop ruled against the preferential right that evangelist Morris Cerullo claimed to negotiate an extension of PTL's contract for satellite time from Home Box Office. HBO officials said they can strike a better deal for their satellite time from someone else. Without the network, Cerullo's plan could crumble. ``We're going to have to regroup and decide whether to appeal or whatever we have to do,'' Shedd said. If Cerullo decides PTL isn't worth buying without the satellite time and backs out of the deal, he stands to lose a $7 million non-refundable deposit for the network and an additional $1 million deposit for the remaining assets of PTL's bankrupt Christian retreat and theme park. The issue Tuesday involved a contract Bakker signed with HBO in 1985 to sublease satellite time that allowed PTL to beam its gospel to cable TV systems serving millions of people. Bakker's Inspirational Satellite Network and broadcast facilities reached about 800 cable systems and 7 million cable households in the United States at its peak. The contract, calling for monthly payments of $242,000, expires in February. Cerullo wanted HBO to approve the transfer of ownership for the few remaining months. He also wanted to negotiate an extension of the contract so he could continue to use HBO's leased satellite capacity. Chicago lawyer James Cherney represented HBO in court Tuesday and argued that Cerullo does not have the right under his agreement to purchase PTL to negotiate with them concerning an extension of Bakker's original contract. Bishop ruled in favor of HBO. If the judge's ruling is not appealed and stands, HBO could sign a contract with anyone for the satellite time. An HBO official told The Herald of Rock Hill on Tuesday it is unlikely they would sign an agreement with Cerullo. ``We got a much better offer from Turner (Broadcasting System) and we'd feel a lot better with him on board than Cerullo,'' he said. Tim Treadwell, attorney for Cerullo, refused to comment after the judge's decision. Earlier this summer, Cerullo received court permission to buy PTL's remaining assets, including the 2,200-acre Heritage USA. The property, closed since Hurricane Hugo struck in September 1989, includes two 500-room luxury hotels, a theme park, five restaurants, a shopping mall, a water park, conference center, housing projects and more than 1,500 acres of undeveloped land. Cerullo announced in August he planned a $15 million facelift for the retreat before reopening it in mid-1991. PTL has been in bankruptcy since June 1987 when Bakker resigned amid a sex-and-money scandal. He is now serving a 45-year-old federal prison sentence for conspiracy and defrauding his followers of millions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Virus Group Linked to Debilitating Disease
DOC.TEXT: Researchers are intrigued by a report linking a virus to chronic fatigue syndrome, but say more study is needed before the cause of the mysterious debilitating illness is known. A study released Tuesday said evidence of a type of virus known as a retrovirus was found in the blood of 23 of 30 victims of the syndrome. Many of their healthy relatives also showed evidence of the virus, suggesting it is contagious, the researchers said. ``It's very interesting and it definitely needs to be followed up,'' said Ann Schluederberg, chief of the virology branch of the National Institutes of Health. She said a more direct cause-and-effect must be established. ``There are things about it that make it not at all implausible _ just more has to be done,'' she said. The findings mean hope for treatment for those who suffer from the syndrome, and vindication for those who were told the symptoms were all in their heads. ``It's very encouraging, very important,'' said Marya Grambs, director of the Chronic Fatigue Immune Dysfunction Syndrome Foundation in San Francisco, ``This is first time anything has been published, but the information and suspicion has been very clear for a while,'' she said. The foundation _ one of four national groups dedicated to the illness _ estimates 3 to 10 million Americans are afflicted. The disease starts with flulike symptoms and can develop into overwhelming fatigue and depression. Other symptoms include muscle and joint pain, headaches, fever, sore throat, memory lapses and depression. Because the symptoms mimic those of many other diseases, it is often misdiagnosed, she said. ``It's so critical that this disease is recognized by the government and medical community so it can be aggressively researched, so people who have it can be validated, and not told they're crazy,'' she said. Because it was widely reported among well-educated women in their 30s and 40s, the syndrome was dubbed ``yuppie flu.'' The new findings were presented Tuesday at a neuropathology conference in Kyoto, Japan, by Elaine DeFreitas of the Wistar Institute in Philadelphia; Dr. Paul Cheney of Charlotte, N.C.; and Dr. David Bell of Lyndonville, N.Y. ``If it turns out to be the agent causing this, then we learn something about treatment and something about prevention,'' said Walter J. Gunn, principal CFS investigator for the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. ``It has the potential to be a very important study.'' But the research must be replicated several times before it is accepted by the scientific and medical community, Gunn said. ``This is an extremely tricky area,'' he said. ``It would not be hard to make a mistake.'' DeFreitas herself told The Charlotte Observer: ``I don't think any of us understands what this thing is, or how it's transmitted or what the role of this agent is in this disease. Certainly the studies have to be replicated.'' Using a new laboratory technique, DeFreitas found that nine of 11 adults and 14 of 19 children had blood cells containing a viral sequence similar to the human T-cell lymphotropic retrovirus, specifically HTLV-II. The HTLV family of retroviruses is linked with leukemia, chronic diseases of the central nervous system and AIDS. DeFreitas also checked 10 healthy adults and 10 healthy babies as controls, and none showed the presence of such virus-positive blood cells. The researchers checked outwardly healthy relatives and close friends of the CFS patients. They found that 43 percent of those exposed to the sick adults tested positively and 29 percent of those exposed to the sick children tested positively. ``Retroviruses are not supposed to be casually transmitted among humans,'' Cheney told the Observer. ``Maybe we found the one that is.'' The CDC is conducting a study to estimate how many people have the disease, Gunn said. The center gets 1,000 to 2,000 phone calls a month from people who suspect they have CFS, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gang Charged in Subway Killing Mugged as an Initiation Rite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with reports that suspect claims stabbing was an accident. Picks up 7th graf, ``If you...'
DOC.TEXT: Eight young men arrested in the stabbing death of a tourist from Utah in a subway station belonged to a gang that required would-be members to mug someone as an initiation rite, it was reported today. Former members said the gang robbed people ``for the hell of it'' and to get money to go dancing, The New York Times reported. The youth suspected of wielding the murder weapon has claimed the victim, Brian Watkins, 22, ran into his knife and the stabbing was accidental, New York Newsday and the New York Post quoted police as saying. Newsday said the suspect, Yull Garry Morales, 18, told investigators: ``There was fighting. I took out my knife to protect myself and the guy turned and it went into him.'' Police said Watkins had come to his family's defense late Sunday when gang members sliced open his father's pants and punched his mother in the mouth as they waited for a subway train. The gang took credit cards and about $200 in cash to go dancing, police said. After the stabbing, the gang headed to a nearby dance club, where five of the suspects were arrested, police said. Three others were arrested later. The Watkins family was in New York on an annual visit to see the U.S. Open tennis tournament. Police said they believe gang founder Morales stabbed Watkins and also imposed the admission requirement. Morales was one of two gang members who did not have a police record, police said. ``If you wanted to be in that gang you had to beat somebody up or mug somebody,'' the Times quoted former gang member Raymond Serrano, 19, as saying. The suspects, in their late teens or early 20s, were charged with murder and robbery and were held without bail. If convicted, they face 15 years to life in prison for murder, and additional time for the other charges. Watkins was the 18th person slain in the subway system this year.

DOC.TEXT: The United States and its allies must plan a new ``regional security structure'' for the Middle East that would not only stop Iraqi aggression but deal with future crises in the region, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today. ``This is not the last crisis of this nature we are likely to face in this region,'' Baker said of Iraq's invasion last month of Kuwait. ``It is worthwhile to begin considering regional security structures ... that would guarantee an equilibrium in this region that will produce peace'' and ``create a more durable order,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Baker cautioned that planning for such a structure has barely begun, and he said it would not necessarily have to be modeled on the Western NATO alliance or involve a leading role for the United States. But on Tuesday, at a similar hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Baker compared the function of such a regional alliance to NATO's role in containing the Soviet Union following World War II. After Tuesday's session, Baker told a reporter that the structure could be military in nature or diplomatic and political. DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Foreign Minister Meets Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister met today with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis just four days before a U.S.-Soviet summit meeting, Tass reported. The meeting between Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and Gorbachev took place in the Kremlin, the official news agency said. It gave no further details. Tass reported that Aziz's visit would be short, and the Iraqi Embassy said he would be in Moscow overnight. His counterpart, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, is in Tokyo. Gorbachev is to meet with President Bush Sunday in Helsinki in a hastily arranged summit. Gorbachev also met today with a group of American senators led by Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan. Dole said Tuesday that they would be discussing Gorbachev's views on the Persian Gulf. In an interview with the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda published today, Iraqi ambassador Ghafil Jassim Hussein said Baghdad hopes the Soviet Union ``will be able to play a role of peacemaker and remain a true friend to the Arabs.'' ``We are keeping in constant contact with the Soviet side,'' he was quoted as saying. ``We have common points of view directed at a peaceful settlement of the conflict.'' Tass said the Soviet Union believes it necessary to maintain ``constant diplomatic contact with the leadership of Iraq.'' It repeated the Soviet policy of using diplomatic means to persuade Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait and restore its independence. In Tokyo, Shevardnadze issued a joint statement with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama condemning the Iraqi invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Opening Arguments Begin in Iran-Contra Tax Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosecutor warned jurors today they would enter a strange world during the trial of an ex-CIA agent accused of not paying taxes on his share of Iran-Contra arms profits and hiding some of it in Switzerland. ``The evidence will take you into a world you are unfamiliar with,'' Stuart E. Abrams told jurors in opening arguments. ``It's a world of international arms deals, secret financial accounts and a world in which financial transactions are made in large sums of money.'' Thomas G. Clines, 62, of Middleburg, Va., is on trial for allegedly under-reporting arms sale earnings on his 1985 and 1986 tax returns. He also is charged with failing to tell the Internal Revenue Service about overseas bank accounts. Clines and others allegedly sold arms to Iran, then used some of the profits to supply weapons to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua at a time when such aid was banned by Congress. Some of the money was kept in a foreign account code-named ``C.Tea,'' according to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in November 1987. The government contends Clines reaped about $882,000 in commissions. Clines pleaded innocent March 9 to all four counts of an indictment returned Feb. 22. If convicted of all crimes, he could be fined up to $1 million and sentenced to 16 years in prison. Clines reported gross receipts of $265,000 for the tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, prosecutors said. Abrams told jurors that Clines received 20 percent of arms sales profits in 1985 and 30 percent in 1986. ``Some of the money he sent back to banks in the United States, but not all of it,'' Abrams said. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were transferred into the Swiss account, he said. Defense attorney Paula M. Junghans told the jurors in her opening statements that Clines is looking forward to the opportunity to explain his side. ``Don't assume because the government has amassed all this paperwork that something must be wrong,'' she told the jurors. ``There is no charge in this case that says it is a crime to buy and sell arms.'' Retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord is expected to be the first government witness. Secord enlisted Clines, a 29-year CIA agent-turned-investor and consultant, as the primary broker for the arms deals in 1985 and 1986, according to the congressional report. Secord and Iranian-born businessman Albert Hakim operated the ``Enterprise,'' a maze of companies set up to carry out the arms sales to Iran and the military supply shipments to the Contras. Prosecutors said the Enterprise was formed at the request of former national security adviser John Poindexter and Oliver North, a retired Marine lieutenant colonel who was a National Security Council staff member. The Enterprise took in nearly $48 million _ $12.2 million more than its expenditures _ during its first two years of operation, the congressional report said. Secord, Hakim and Clines took commissions from the $12.2 million surplus to ``reward themselves for their work on arms deliveries,'' the report said. ``The commissions totaled approximately $4.4 million.'' Prosecutors have alleged that Secord made more than $1 million from his role, while Secord has maintained that he made no more than $250,000. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8, 1989, to one felony count of making false statements to the Iran-Contra congressional committees. He was sentenced in January to two years of probation.

DOC.HEAD: New Judge Appointed in Christian Brando Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the murder trial of actor Marlon Brando's son has been replaced at the request of prosecutors, who protested the lowering of Christian Brando's bail. Superior Court Judge David Perez was replaced Tuesday by Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas after prosecutors filed an affidavit of prejudice against Perez. Brando's trial is scheduled for Oct. 1. Prosecutors and defense attorneys are allowed to challenge a judge once without explanation. ``We were upset because of reduction of bail,'' said Deputy District Attorney William Clark, a co-prosecutor in the case. Prosecutors have argued that Christian Brando is a flight risk and should have been denied bail. Perez reduced Brando's bail from $10 million to $2 million on Aug. 10. Brando was released from jail five days later after his father posted bond with the deed to his hilltop Bel Air estate. Estimates of the home's value range from $4 million to $5.1 million. ``Christian Brando would not think twice about having (his father) lose his house,'' Clark said. ``Marlon Brando could make enough money on one film before the end of the year to buy another house.'' Christian Brando, 32, has pleaded innocent in the shooting death of his half-sister's boyfriend, Dag Drollet, 26, at the Brando estate on May 16.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

Sept. 4 The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune on the savings and loan industry: It seems that each day brings more bad news about the savings and loan mess. The latest quarterly review of the industry by the Office of Thrift Supervision documents a dramatic decline. Even the healthiest thrifts are showing an increase in losses and defaulted loans. And the number of those healthy thrifts is dwindling. In the recent survey, the OTS dropped 106 savings and loans from its list of well-capitalized and profitable institutions. Fewer than half the thrifts in the country _ excluding those taken over by the government _ can now be considered in robust financial health. An even darker portent: The rot is spreading from Texas and the Southwest into the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic states. California, long considered the safest territory for the industry, is also feeling the pinch. Washington has yet to get serious about the savings and loan scandal. Posturing and fingerpointing are the order of the day. Our national leaders may choose to whistle past the graveyard, but the data don't lie. The savings and loan industry is dying a slow and agonizing death. And the taxpayer must pay for its expensive funeral.

Aug. 29 The Sun Herald, Biloxi, Miss., on the census: Count the cats and count the dogs. Count the chickens and the hogs. Count the bathrooms in your house. Count your children and your spouse. Count each phone and plumbing pipe _ plastic, copper or other type. Who wrote these questions? Amid the jokes, census horror stories keep cropping up: a small town where 75 percent of the residents never received forms, widely publicized ``help lines'' that were either always busy or never answered. It appears that the 1990 census is full of bloopers, and nationwide, population tallies are on the low side. ... Thousands of cities are challenging the census figures and providing evidence of their own, which the Census Bureau considers, then may or may not make adjustments. This slow, complicated process may be the best we can do to rectify 1990 inaccuracies, even though it puts an extra burden on the cities and states that should not have been necessary. We must mop up the census mess as best we can and move forward. Above all, we must learn from 1990's errors. A problem-solving task force of individuals _ forget titles, pick the best brains _ from the Census Bureau, the Postal Service, key cities, minority groups, any problem areas _ should be at work right now. Ten years of planning should be plenty.

Sept. 1 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on housing problems: Once again, Congress has left to the last minute its annual renewal of two tax breaks that are needed to alleviate pressing housing problems. A mortgage revenue bond program essential to first-time homebuyers of moderate means, as well as tax credits needed to keep rental units affordable to the poor, will expire later this year unless they are extended. We believe neither program should be allowed to lapse because of the unresolved federal budget dispute. Ironically, both enjoy wide support in Congress: Some 300 lawmakers have endorsed them. ... However, there is always the danger they could fall between the boards as bigger fiscal issues monopolize attention. To avoid that, Congress should promptly pass bills to renew these programs when legislators reconvene this month.

Aug. 30 The Florence (S.C.) Morning News on scientific discoveries: Although the headlines and news shows are often dominated by the big events such as blockades, troop movements and the stock markets, very often major improvements in society are done in small ways. Microscopic ways to be exact. Scientists at the Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore have isolated a gene that prevents colonies of cancer tumors from growing. The gene, called p53, could lead to finding natural proteins to switch off cancer. P53 is one of a group of what is known as suppressor genes because they appear to act as a brake on cancer formation. Suppressor genes have been found to be either missing or mutated in the cells of several types of solid cancer tumors, researchers have noted. There is still a long way to go, and many things to study, before the experiments become a treatment for cancer patients but it is an example of genetic research and the enormous benefits it has for mankind. Last month, the genetic revolution progressed when a federal panel for the first time approved two gene therapies for tests on humans. Within a year, scientists should know whether the tests are effective against a lethal skin cancer and a rare deficiency of the immune system. It is true that genetic experimentation is fraught with dangers, but so is every human endeavor. Our ancestors probably thought fire was a great advance until they realized that they, too, could burn. Nevertheless, they kept setting fires. ... No doubt there will be abuses in the research. Not once in all of history has there not been abuses in research. But there have also been tremendous advances. In the 21st century, and perhaps before, the genetic revolution may well remake society even more than the computer revolution has changed work and leisure in the latter part of the 20th century. Obviously, careful study and planning are needed. We do not know the pitfalls that await in genetic research. But to stop would be akin to our ancestors putting out fire because someone slipped and fell in the flames.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the flames.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 29 The Record, Hackensack, N.J., on opening the Raoul Wallenberg files: Raoul Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat, saved the lives of as many as 100,000 Jews in Hungary during the closing months of World War II. Then Wallenberg vanished, an apparent victim of bloodthirsty Soviet secret police who suspected he was a spy. But reports that Wallenberg may have survived into the 1980s, and still may even be alive, have intrigued investigators of the stature of the late Andrei Sakharov. Now the Soviet Union, in one of the most dramatic acts of glasnost, has agreed to open its files on Wallenberg. Soviet officials now say that they will open the archives of the KGB and other agencies to an international commission investigating the fate of Wallenberg. It is almost certainly too late to save Wallenberg, as he saved so many others. But at least the world can learn the truth about his fate. By refusing to give up their quest for the truth, investigators have honored one of the century's authentic heroes.

Sept. 4 Topeka (Kan.) Capital-Journal on Cambodia: The United Nations' plan to end the civil war in Cambodia demonstrates the type of leadership and international cooperation the U.N. founders envisioned. The plan, which calls for the U.N. to administer a transitional government until free elections can be held, could finally bring peace to that tragic nation. So far, the Khmer Rouge have accepted the U.N. presence. Leaders of the other factions _ Hun Sen, Prince Sihanouk and Son Sann _ should follow suit.

Sept. 4 Philadelphia Inquirer on the U.S.-Soviet summit: With each passing month, it becomes increasingly clear that the Soviet Union is no longer America's chief adversary in the world. Indeed, it is coming to look more and more like an ally. The (Sept. 9 U.S.-Soviet) summit's main purpose is to intensify international pressure on Iraq's Saddam Hussein, a venture in which the United States and Soviet Union are on the same side. The United States and the Soviet Union still have thousands of nuclear warheads trained on each other's territory, and negotiations aimed at reducing those weapons have stalled. But we've reached a stage where the specter of deadlocked arms talks no longer arouses a sense of foreboding. That could change, of course, in the unlikely event that (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev is ousted in favor of someone more menacing. But, for now, a Bush-Gorbachev meeting reminds one less of the superpower summits of old than of those routine get-togethers a U.S. president has from time to time with the West German chancellor or the British prime minister.

Sept. 1 The Kansas City Star on the Persian Gulf: As the U.S. and its allies face mounting costs in the Persian Gulf and the possibility of a long standoff, some tempers are getting short over what different countries should contribute to the effort. Americans are complaining that other countries aren't doing as much as they should. Japanese officials are grousing that they aren't cash-dispensing machines. Western European politicians are waffling over what their nations' responsibilities are. ... It should be remembered that absolute justice and precision are impossible. Burden-sharing debates are hard enough at the platoon level. Where countries are concerned, allies must weigh factors that include size, interests, wealth, history, military preparedness and other commitments. ... The U.S. has the military power to make the world a little safer in situations like the current crisis. There is no getting around the fact, however, that exercising that power sometimes entails fiscal as well as substantial human costs. The fiscal costs can be better shared.

Sept. 4 Los Angeles Daily News on sex discrimination in the Saudi desert: (W)hile doing their duty, U.S. servicewomen have been forced to make some absurd concessions that male soldiers haven't been asked to make, such as wearing excessive clothing in the blistering heat. It's apparently been the military's way of making sure that American forces don't offend their Saudi hosts, whose Islamic customs are exceedingly repressive toward women. Fortunately, there are signs that relief from the heat and some forms of discrimination are on the way; Restrictive dress rules for military women have been relaxed on at least one U.S. military compound in Saudi Arabia, according to the husband of an Air Force sergeant sent to the region. Female soldiers are now being permitted to wear shorts in their off-duty hours within their living area. They also may wear bathing suits when swimming in a portable pool at the compound. ... Servicewomen whould be given that much leeway at every military installation in Saudi Arabia. ... There's a chance that any change in the rules would not sit well with the Saudis. This is a country, after all, where women must use separate beaches, cover most of their faces in public and are not permitted to drive. ... But one can be respectful (of national custom) without demeaning one's own citizens. ... In their mutual efforts to keep Iraqi troops at bay, Americans and Saudi Arabians are obliged to show understanding of the other's culture.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Strike in Seven States
With PM-Teacherless Classes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Teacher strikes in seven states extended summer vacation for more than 82,000 students. Teachers struck in at least two of 120 New Jersey school districts that are still without contracts. Pickets blocked buses from leaving the depot at Deptford High School in southern New Jersey to pick up students this morning. One striker was hit by a car, but appeared unhurt. Strikes in six Michigan districts idled 34,000 students and mediation by the governor's office failed for one striking Rhode Island district. A fourth Pennsylvania district struck today and teachers in two Illinois districts continued their walkout. In Washington state, school officials gave videotaped lessons to 12,000 students in Yakima Tuesday, but striking teachers were to vote today on a settlement. Elsewhere in that state, two other strikes kept 31,600 students away from school. College professors walked out in contract disputes at Wayne State University in Detroit and Temple University in Philadelphia, and a strike continued at the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut. Some classes were held Tuesday at Temple and Wayne State and administrators planned to open the Connecticut campus tonight. In New Jersey, classes at Union County College's four campuses were canceled today for 10,000 students as striking professors picketed. The school and professors failed to reach agreement on a contract, which expired Friday. Negotiations in the South Orange-Maplewood school system broke down early today and the union representing 572 New Jersey teachers and staff planned to picket all nine schools, union spokesman Farrell Fand said. In Deptford, teachers were on strike this morning after the 331-member Deptford Education Association voted Tuesday to set up pickets. Talks broke down early Tuesday, said association president Fred Kier. ``We're tired of being driven up against the wall,'' said Kier. ``We're getting nowhere and we've decided to take a stand.''
