Teachers in New Orleans aren't asking anything immediately for themselves, but say they'll strike Sept. 17 if the school board doesn't come up with $2 million for support staff. An estimated 3,400 to 4,000 members of the United Teachers of New Orleans overwhelmingly voted Tuesday to strike and work for the recall of the school board if the money isn't forthcoming by the Sept. 17 deadline to increase salaries of teachers' aides, secretaries and other clerical workers. The union represents 4,700 teachers and 1,000 other school workers. Teachers have received pay raises from the state for the past three years, but no extra money from the school board since 1988. Union president Nat Lacour said the proposal would give 4 to 5 percent raises to teachers' aides, who make about $10,000 a year, and to clerical workers, who make about $17,000. Tuesday's meeting on the first day of classes in the 84,000-student district caused thousands of teachers to be late for school. ``The issue is whether the school system has any more money to give them. The answer to that question is an unequivocal no,'' said Rose Drill-Peterson, spokeswoman for the school board. In Rhode Island, classes for 4,400 students in North Kingstown were postponed today for at least one more day after mediators worked until 1 a.m. trying to reach an agreement, said Edwin Nordstrom, School Committee chairman. In Washington, classes were called off through Friday for about 22,500 students in the Lake Washington School District, which covers Seattle suburbs, and through Monday for 9,100 students in Mukilteo, south of Everett. Negotiators for Yakima teachers agreed to a three-year contract offer about 2:30 a.m. today after nearly 6{ hours of talks, said Melanie Mitchell, president of the Yakima Education Association. The six striking school districts in Michigan were Saginaw, Troy, Gwinn, Cheboygan, St. Ignace and Engadine. In Illinois, talks in Mount Zion in central Illinois broke off Monday night and 1,700 students were out of class Tuesday and today. In Darien, a suburb west of Chicago, a strike closed five schools. In Pennsylvania, talks continued Tuesday in 79 school districts and strikes affected four districts with about 9,000 students.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: other's culture.
DOC.TEXT: Sept. 2 Sunday Mail, Harare, Zimbabwe, on the Persian Gulf: Once Western economies wobble, the ripple effects reach developing countries sooner rather than later. And ... the effect (of the crisis in the Persian Gulf) will be felt when many developing countries are perhaps most vulnerable. Many have adopted export-led structural adjustment programs and if a recession, however mild, is added to the growing trend in trade protectionism in the West, those programs could stumble and fall. This once again highlights the importance of developing countries to lessen their present almost total reliance on Western markets for both exports and imports. ---Aug. 30 The Statesman, Calcutta, India, on the Persian Gulf: For all the aggressive bluster and massing of troops and warships in the area, a political solution to the crisis in the Persian Gulf cannot be ruled out. ... (W)hile prone to miscalculating the consequences of his aggression, (Iraqi President Saddam) Hussein has a sensible appreciation for the mailed fist for he wields one himself after all. Militarily he cannot hope to match the West. ... He must, therefore, consider withdrawal from Kuwait.

Sept. 3 The Guardian, London, on the Persian Gulf: Because America is the greatest democracy, it cannot adequately play the part of freedom's flying squad. The bitter ghosts of the Vietnam venture are not exorcized: they are one of the dominant themes of Hollywood at the start of the '90s. The controlled experiments of Grenada and Panama _ sanitized war, with no bodies in the bag for the cameras _ have not reconciled the American voter, the human being with human rights, to a world where thousands upon thousands of lives may be put in jeopardy in foreign fields. The myth of a high-tech war fought by fighting machines at long range is just that: a myth. The mirror image of a television world which showed the citizens of the Soviet Union what economic misery they were enduring is that those same screens will show dead Americans and dead civilians caught up in a melee of bloodshed. There is no long-term reality to this role. It is not what democracies are about. It is an attempt by old minds, left bereft by the crumbling of the Cold War, to construct a new order which merely echoes the simplicities of the past. In fact there is only one global policeman. That, for its frailties, is the United Nations, because it represents the collective wisdom of a world of many nations and infinite systems of government. It is not the excuse for action in the Gulf. It is, for good or ill, the pivot of it.

Sept. 3 Straits Times, Singapore, on the Soviet Union: It is getting increasingly difficult these days to fault Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for radicalism. The man who began his career at the Kremlin as an undoubted revolutionary, though of the peaceful variety, shows signs, five years later, of transformation into an Establishment figure who lives an uneasy life between the nostalgia of revolution and the realities of power. ... He acknowledged last week that there was public scepticism over the reform program. An economic collapse of the country could not be ruled out, as could not serious tears in its political fabric. ... If his reforms are to mean anything, they must not only move forward but gather momentum. An honest and speedy transition to a market economy is a necessity, not a luxury. ... Gorbachev can take heart that there is someone who understands just how critical matters are. Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin, whose radical posture calls for privatization, the closing of inefficient industries and an end to heavy subsidies, has often differed with ... Gorbachev. It was reported, however, that the two had agreed last week on the need for urgent and drastic action. That cooperation will hopefully come about and continue. The Kremlin leader needs all the radicals he can get to put the spirit back into the Gorbachev revolution. In present Soviet circumstances, nothing less than a revolution is needed to keep reform alive.

Sept. 4 National Concord, Lagos, Nigeria, on the proposal that African nation should establish a continental defense force: It appears that an African high command has become irrelevant to the realities of African politics today. For one thing, the fact has been firmly established that African nations do not share a common ideological perspective, and the operations of the proposed defense force would only subject the Organization of African Unity to intense controversy and unnecessary acrimony. Furthermore, most of the problems plaguing various countries are so local in nature that they do not warrant the intervention of a continental force. In these circumstances, the OAU should perhaps think of a contingency arrangement whereby a peacekeeping force could be put together when the need arises. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Bush Says Drug War Remains Top Priority Despite Mideast Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Bush remarks, Bennett quotes as delivered; picks up 4th graf pvs, In an...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that even though the government is occupied with the Persian Gulf crisis, progress is being made in the fight against illegal drugs, which remains a top priority. ``I know that other subjects preoccupy all of us these days. But this one remains number one, will continue to remain number one when the international situation has calmed down,'' the president said. In remarks to a group of staff and reporters a year after he laid out his drug war strategy, Bush declared: ``I think America is making progress against drugs and will continue to do so.'' He cited a decrease in casual drug use and decreased availability of cocaine. Bush's chief lieutenant in the fight against drugs provided a more detailed assessment of the administration's contention that the war is being won. ``Last year's hopeless cause is this year's revived opportunity for victory,'' national drug policy director William J. Bennett said in remarks to the gathering marking the anniversary of Bush's drug speech. ``I think a prudent and cautious judgment on our present circumstances would be that the drug problem _ in general, nationwide _ is no longer getting worse, and in some very significant aspects it is now getting better. Not victory, but success,'' Bennett said. In an interview Tuesday, Bennett contrasted the current drug picture with the situation when he took office 18 months ago. At the time, he recalled, people said his job was ``undoable. Mission Impossible. Figurehead. Nothing can happen.'' Instead, Bennett said, ``The government actually can get some things done if it is given the right equipment, the right direction and the command of the president, and we made some progress.'' However, he said, this is no time to let up and stop pursuing the drug strategy that stresses tough enforcement of drug laws when violated by either traffickers or users as well as increased spending on treatment and education. ``There's plenty more to do,'' Bennett said. ``There are some places that are not getting better.'' The announcement of the drug strategy last Sept. 5 was Bush's first prime-time televised speech. In it, the president said he wanted ``to make our streets and neighborhoods safe.'' He referred to people being ``mugged on the way home from work by crack gangs'' and children dodging bullets as they went to school. In the past year, thanks in large part to Colombia's crackdown on the cocaine cartels that was strongly supported by the United States, the supply of cocaine to this country has decreased. But instead of making the streets of America safer, Bennett said earlier this summer, the cocaine shortage increased the violence because of greater competition among drug dealers. ``There will be the same number of dogs fighting over a smaller number of bones,'' he said. Asked Tuesday whether the American people might be wondering just what the drug war is all about if battles won cause more violence, Bennett said ``the violence fuels the national interest and the interest of citizens, but it isn't the only thing that fuels their interest.'' ``I think the largest part of the concern that people have is how it will affect their children,'' he said. The high level of violence is not always connected to the drug trade, he said. He noted that the murder rate has declined in some cities _ Detroit, Dallas, San Francisco and San Diego _ which are ``not necessarily the same cities where we're seeing the greatest progress in the war on drugs.'' Sen. Joseph R. Biden, Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, was releasing a report today citing some successes of the drug war and some failures, including an increased number of murders this year, inadequate drug education and lack of treatment for pregnant or incarcerated addicts. Rep. John Conyers, chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations, said, ``We are losing the drug war in our inner cities. ``Prevention and education efforts directed at the educated middle class appear to be having a dramatic effect,'' the Michigan Democrat said in a statement. ``Treatment programs have room for clients who can afford to pay. However, the chronically addicted cannot pay when they are poor and unemployed, as is often the case.'' Conyers urged reallocation of the federal drug budget, spending an equal amount on treatment and prevention as is spent on law enforcement. The current split is almost 70 percent for law enforcement, the rest for treatment and education. The National Institute on Drug Abuse recently reported that the number of cocaine-related emergency room visits continued to decline in the first quarter of 1990, a drop first seen in the fourth quarter of 1989. The institute, which gets its figures from the Drug Abuse Warning Network of hospital emergency rooms and coroners nationwide, also found that the number of heroin-related emergency room visits declined in early 1990. However, the number of people who died with traces of cocaine or heroin in their systems increased in 1989. As for attitudes, a survey released Tuesday found that an ever-increasing segment of the American public, including teen-agers, is rejecting illegal drugs, seeing their use as dangerous and unattractive behavior. This trend was observed in all major ethnic groups _ whites, blacks and Hispanics _ according to the survey by the Gordon S. Black Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Aquarium To Send Dolphin to Navy; Animal Rights Groups Angry
DOC.TEXT: The New England Aquarium plans to send one of its three show dolphins to a Navy program that does research on them and trains them for military work, a move that has prompted protests. Federal records indicate it will be the fourth dolphin the aquarium has sent to the U.S. Naval Ocean Systems Center in San Diego in the last 10 years, The Boston Globe said today. The curator of marine mammals at the aquarium, Kathy Krieger, worked for the Ocean Systems Center for two years. The dolphin to be sent there is Rainbow, who is about 11 years old and is being sent because he is aggressive and incompatible with the other two used in shows at the aquarium, she said. ``We feel that is the place he will get the best care,'' she said. She admitted the aquarium does not know exactly what the Navy plans to do with him. ``We know he will not be treated in an inhumane manner or be in any danger,'' she said. ``The people who work with the animals in the Navy assure us that none of the animals have been hurt.'' Thomas LaPuzza, spokesman for the Navy center, said Rainbow will be used immediately for research but he could not say whether he ever will be used for military work. The Navy's dolphin program is classified. It has been criticized for use of animals in war and for the way dolphins are treated. ``I'm very surprised they would plan on releasing animals to the Navy. I'm shocked,'' Scott Van Valkenburg of the Boston Marine Mammal Coalition, told the Globe. ``The fact that they might be sending animals to a program where they might be used in military action is amazing,'' he said. The group said it plans a protest rally Saturday. ``We're looking into how they are planning to transport this dolphin,'' said Doreene Close of the Coalition to End Animal Suffering and Exploitation. ``If we can find that out, we will do everything in our power to stop it.'' The Navy will send the aquarium an 11-year-old, partially deaf female dolphin as a replacement for Rainbow, and Ms. Krieger thought it would fit in better with the other two at the aquarium. LaPuzza said the Navy used dolphins for military work in Vietnam and in 1987 in the Persian Gulf, but he would not say what they did. A former trainer at the Navy facility said dolphins were trained to kill with .45-caliber guns attached to nose cones, the Globe said. The guns would be triggered when dolphins rammed enemy frogmen. The Navy refused to comment on those allegations.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Woman Claims North Delegate Is Long Lost Brother
With AM-Korea, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean woman claims that a North Korean delegate at this week's talks between the prime ministers of North and South Korea is her long lost brother. Lim Chun-lim, 69, appeared on television Tuesday night saying she had no doubt that Lim Chun-gil, 53, was the brother she saw last in 1947 when she left her hometown in the North for a new life in South Korea. About 10 million people living in the two Koreas were separated from family members by the division of the peninsula in 1945 and the 1950-53 Korean War. The border is sealed and there is no mail or other direct form of communication between the nations. The woman, a resident of a small town outside Seoul, gave personal and family data and described the circumstances of her separation from her family. Her hometown is the same as that of the North Korean delegate, South Korean officials said. Pictures shown of the profiles of the two Lims are strikingly similar. The official, one of the most influential in the Northern delegation, insists he is not the woman's brother. ``The claim is simply not true,'' he said in a statement issued through a South Korean spokesman. The South Korean spokesman, Kim Hyung-ki, said Lim suspected the woman's claim was ``a plot to blur the focus of the talks.'' Communist North Korea's main concern in the Seoul talks is military and political matters. Other issues such as family reunions are low on its agenda. South Korea prefers to tackle non-political and non-military matters first.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Bomb Death Toll Rises to 25
DOC.TEXT: A bomb believed set by tribal militants exploded in a bus in eastern India, killing 25 people and injuring 45, news reports said Wednesday. Police blamed Tuesday's explosion in Assam state on Bodo tribespeople, who are agitating for a separate state, The Times of India reported. The state-owned bus was parked at the town of Rangiya when the bomb exploded, the newspaper said. United News of India said 17 bodies were recovered from the bus and eight more people died on the way to a hospital. Bodos say they need their own state to protect their tribal culture from being overwhelmed by the Assamese, who are predominantly Hindus. The Bodos claim about one-third of Assam as their homeland. Tribal leaders, state government officials and members of the federal government are scheduled to conduct talks on the demands next week. The Times of India said the explosion was an attempt by Bodos to demonstrate militant capabilities and gain leverage at the talks. Assam, about 870 miles east of New Delhi, produces about 60 percent of India's tea and most of its crude oil.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Forces Man Front Line Against Iraqis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some 2,000 Egyptian soldiers, along with Kuwaitis who fought invading Iraqis a month ago, are manning the front line below the Kuwaiti border, officers said Wednesday. These are among the visible Arab units in the multinational force led by the United States to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible attack by Iraq. The total number of Arab forces has not been disclosed, and there has been confusion over the number of troops promised by various Arab countries and the number actually sent. Saudi officers say 3,000 Syrians and the same number of Moroccans are in the field. But correspondents taken to the sector by the Saudi military did not see any of them. The reported Syrian presence would mark the first time Syrian troops have stood beside the Egyptians since they fought Israel in the 1973 Yom Kippur War. Arab forces form the first line of defense along the northeastern desert and coastal approaches to Saudi Arabia's oil-rich eastern province. South of them are the U.S. forces. The desert is dotted with small encampments, anti-aircraft units, platoons of tanks and armored personnel carriers. At one of the camps, Maj. Gen. Turki Al-Nufaie said he was waiting for units to arrive to put his total force at ``a division and a little more.'' He commands Saudi Arabia's 20th Mechanized Brigade and the Rapid Deployment Force made up of troops from the six Gulf Cooperation Council states _ Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman. Al-Nufaie gave no strength figures. But judging by the size of the units described by other officers, he may be talking about 20,000 troops. Al-Nufaie said that once those troops, whom he did not identify, reached the scene, ``we await orders to deploy to defensive positions.'' He said the Syrians were deployed east of his position but were not under his command. Kuwait's defense minister told The Associated Press on Tuesday that a 7,000-man force of Kuwait's 16,000-strong army was currently ``on maneuvers'' and that half of them would soon join as regulars in northern Saudi Arabia. A short distance from Al-Nufaie's command post, troops identified as Kuwaitis were dug in with armored personnel carriers and other vehicles. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was the first Arab leader to offer soldiers for the Saudi cause, but their status has been marked by confusion. A Defense Ministry source in Cairo was quoted Aug. 16 as saying there were 3,000 Egyptians in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 more were en route to join them. On Tuesday, Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency said an unspecified number of Egyptian troops was en route to the United Arab Emirates. Military sources have said the total in Saudi Arabia is 4,000, including paratroopers, commandos, infantrymen and chemical warfare specialists. But Egyptian commanders interviewed at their desert camp Tuesday said 2,000 was the total number in the country. About 100 Egyptian soldiers could be seen at the desert encampment Tuesday. They were equipped with a handful of jeeps, AK-47 automatic rifles and light anti-tank weapons. Asked about their mission, Col. Adilan Wagdi said it was to ``defend the holy places'' of Islam _ the holy cities of Mecca and Medina. After a brief discussion with aides, he said the Egyptians were there ``to defend all of Saudi Arabia.''

DOC.HEAD: Chiles vs. Martinez in Florida, Miller vs. Gallaway in Nevada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7, bgng, `We're going ..., with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Democratic rally, Martinez quote; SUBS grafs 18-19, bgng, `With one-third ..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE with later returns from Nevada. Picks up 20th graf, `Gallaway, a ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TP1, TP2
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lawton Chiles overcame questions about his mental stability and swept to victory over Rep. Bill Nelson for Florida's Democratic nomination for governor. Gov. Bob Martinez easily captured the GOP nomination. In Nevada, Gov. Bob Miller crushed five challengers Tuesday for the Democratic nomination for a full term in the job he assumed two years ago. Businessman Jim Gallaway topped seven other Republicans for the GOP nomination. Chiles' wasn't the only political comeback in Florida: Impeached federal Judge Alcee Hastings won a slot in a Democratic runoff for secretary of state. And voters in two Florida counties rejected controversial ballot measures. In Broward, an ordinance that would have protected homosexuals against discrimination was defeated 59 percent to 41 percent. In Sarasota, voters decided by 73 percent to 27 percent not to slap a two-year moratorium on growth. Chiles and Martinez both captured 69 percent of the vote. Nelson, Chiles and other Democratic leaders held a unity rally today at the state Capitol. ``It's awfully good to be the head of a united Democratic ticket and I think that's what we have this time _ a united Democratic ticket,'' Chiles said. Martinez greeted supporters in Tampa today, then jetted to Miami, with stops in Orlando and Jacksonville also planned. ``We've reached a point where reality has to take over from rhetoric and substances over slogans,'' Martinez said, claiming he knows state issues and is more specific than Chiles. Martinez campaign manager J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich said Chiles had ``retreated into overinflated '60s liberal bull that has no place in society.'' Chiles, a 60-year-old moderate, retired two years ago, saying he was burned out from three terms in the Senate. At the time he was chairman of the Budget Committee. He was diagnosed as depressed and began using the drug Prozac. During the campaign, he was dogged by questions about his age and mental stability and was pressured into releasing his medical records. Nelson's running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, was widely criticized and finally apologized for suggesting Chiles could be suicidal. Such attacks were thought to have produced a voter backlash in Chiles' favor. Chiles received 739,916 votes to 325,448 votes, or 31 percent, for Nelson, a six-term congressman. Chiles told supporters his victory represented a mandate for his campaign's theme: an attack on big-money politics. He had limited contributions to $100 and raised $2 million. Nelson raised $6 million and spent $1 million of his own. ``We thought people should count more than money,'' Chiles said, ``and we felt like that people could join with us if we did limit our contributions, and if we trusted them they would respond.'' Nelson, a 47-year-old who went on a space shuttle mission as a member of Congress in 1986, had claimed to have more energy and vision to lead the state. Martinez, who is considered vulnerable because of his anti-abortion stance and his support three years ago of a services tax that later was repealed, had 457,952 votes to state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard's 131,782 votes, or 20 percent. Three other contenders divided the remainder. Martinez said he would focus his campaign on his administration's achievements in the environment, crime, education reform and drugs. In Nevada, Miller had moved up to governor automatically from lieutenant governor in 1988 after Gov. Dick Bryan was elected to the U.S. Senate. Nearly complete returns showed Miller with 66,998 votes, or 81 percent. ``None of the Above'' _ which appears on all Nevada ballots as a means of voter protest _ received 6,754 votes, or 8 percent. A long-shot hopeful who changed his name to Rhinestone Cowboy ran third with 2,308 votes, or 3 percent. In the GOP race, Gallaway had 35,628 votes, or 50 percent, ``None of the Above'' drew 15,637 votes, or 22 percent, and builder Charlie Brown had 14,966 votes, or 21 percent. Gallaway, a relative newcomer to the state, said Miller had shown ``a total lack of leadership'' as governor. But a poll last month of the likely matchup in November indicated Miller would trounce Gallaway 60 percent to 27 percent. Hastings, who as Florida's first black federal judge was removed by the U.S. Senate after a jury acquitted him of bribery, will face former newspaperman Jim Minter in an Oct. 2 runoff for the Democratic nomination for secretary of state. The winner will meet incumbent Jim Smith, a Republican. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Minter had 355,139 votes, or 38 percent, to 312,224 votes, or 33 percent, for Hastings. Former Ku Klux Klansman John Paul Rogers got 273,454 votes, or 29 percent. Former Gov. Claude Kirk, 64, also moved toward a political comeback, winning a three-way race for the GOP nomination for education commissioner. Kirk, governor from 1967-71, avoided a runoff with 54 percent of the vote. Kirk and Martinez are the only Republican governors in Florida since Reconstruction. The Broward referendum was opposed by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami and by critics who warned its passage would bring more homosexuals and AIDS to the county. In Sarasota, supporters of a two-year moratorium on new structures said it would give time to improve services and address other problems of growth. Opponents said a halt would put thousands out of work and damage the economy.

DOC.HEAD: National Dish Getting Better, Healthier
DOC.TEXT: Belgium's national dish _ golden-brown fried potato sticks sprinkled with salt and covered under a blob of mayonnaise _ is getting healthier again. The consumer group Test-Achat said Wednesday new legal standards for frying fats, which came in the wake of a damning 1987 report on Belgium's unhealthy ``frites,'' have done the trick. ``The statistics indicate a considerable improvement over three years ago,'' Test-Achat said in its magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Group Says Small Cars Save Gas But Not Lives
DOC.TEXT: Pressure to save fuel could increase highway deaths, an auto safety group said Wednesday in reporting new evidence that small cars are less safe than bigger models. The study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety concludes that, on average, small cars are deadlier than less fuel-efficient autos, that Japanese cars are becoming longer and safer while American cars are becoming shorter and more dangerous, and that when a manufacturer reduces the size of a given model, the model becomes more dangerous. In a broad study begun well before the Mideast crisis brought new attention to ways of decreasing U.S. dependence on foreign oil, the institute said safety too often is ignored in the debate over auto mileage standards. Carmakers already are required to produce cars with an average of 27.5 miles per gallon for 1990 models. One legislative proposal would increase fuel economy 20 percent in passenger cars by 1995 and 40 percent by 2001. ``Fuel-economy standards create safety problems if they force automakers to make cars smaller in order to increase the average miles per gallon of their fleets,'' the institute said. The organization, which is financed by auto insurance companies, researches a wide range of highway safety issues. Institute President Brian O'Neill said there are ways to save more fuel without making cars smaller, including engine changes that put less importance on power and speed and measures that relieve urban congestion. But carmakers say they eventually have to make cars smaller to meet the stringent mileage standards. ``I'm as good an environmentalist as the next guy, but I believe we have to look at the complete picture,'' O'Neill said. Smaller cars are more prone to rollovers and damage that can injure occupants, the institute said, offering the following evidence: _Based on an analysis of death rates and fuel ratings for 47 four-door cars, on average, for every one mile-per-gallon improvement in fuel economy, there is a 3.9 percent increase in the death rate. _Overall, the death rate in the smallest cars on the road is more than double the rate in the largest cars: 3 deaths per 10,000 registered cars for the smallest cars and 1.3 for the largest in 1989. _The frequency of damage claims for small, two-door cars is 35 percent higher than for large two-door cars. _Among the 29 two- and four-door cars with the highest frequency of injury claims, 27 are small and two are mid-sized. The institute said that in the 1979 model year, the average wheelbase of Toyotas and Nissans was 15 inches shorter than the wheelbases of domestic Ford and General Motors cars, and the death rate in Japanese cars was 56 percent higher. In the 1988 model year, as the average wheelbase difference was reduced to approximately eight inches, the death rates in the Japanese and U.S. cars were about the same, the institute said. The report said that fatalities in 10 of 11 GM models increased after smaller models of the cars were produced. All GM body types except the 1982 A-type cars showed increases in the number of deaths per 10,000 registered cars after the cars were made smaller, the report said. The most dramatic increase was in 1986 E-type Buick Rivieras, Cadillac Eldorados and Olds Toronados, which were compared with the larger 1984-85 models. The increase in the rate of deaths was 67 percent, from 0.9 per 10,000 cars to 1.5, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Both Sides See Hydroelectric Fight as Us vs. Them
DOC.TEXT: The eight-year battle over the Salt Caves hydroelectric project is a Western showdown reminiscent of those between free-range cattlemen and fence-building homesteaders. But this fight is between a coalition of a city, developers, a local congressman and a federal agency facing an alliance of state agencies, voters, out-of-town congressmen, fishermen, and environmentalists. At issue is an 11-mile stretch of the Klamath River 27 miles southwest of Klamath Falls in south-central Oregon. Initial proposals by the city of Klamath Falls would have drowned the river behind a dam, but the proposal now is for no dam at all _ just a series of canals and conduits bringing water from an existing dam upstream. That hasn't lessened opposition. The proposal now rests in two sets of hands: _ The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission could sweep aside most of the objections raised by state agencies simply by granting a license. _ Congress is considering a bill that would block the commission by including the Upper Klamath River in the federal wild and scenic river system. ``If the agency is going to crush state and regional decisions, we think that is another reason wild and scenic legislation should be passed to protect this river and protect the broad range of people opposed to this project,'' said Chris Orsinger, spokesman for the Oregon Rivers Council, an environmental group. Opponents say the project would destroy the last free-flowing, trout-filled stretch of a waterway already shackled by four dams. Supporters say the project can generate millions of dollars to help Klamath Falls get back on its feet after a decade of decline. No customers have yet agreed to buy the dam's electricity and opponents say the project can't make a profit. The federal energy commission says there is a need for the electricity and the project can make a profit, estimated by the city at $3 million a year. In 1985, Klamath Falls applied to the commission for a permit to build a $117 million, 130-foot-tall dam at Salt Cave, a spot named for holes in a cliff, that would generate 140 megawatts of electricity. The city even swung a deal that so far has financed planning and design without costing taxpayers a dime. It sold $250 million worth of bonds, then reinvested the money at a higher interest rate than it had to pay on the bonds. The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife protested that the original proposal would flood one of the state's premier trout streams and rafters said it would dry up a top summer white-water run. The city scaled down the dam in 1986, and tacked on a ski area to mitigate for the loss of fishing and rafting. In 1987, then-Gov. Neil Goldschmidt said Oregon's environment should be enjoyed by all, not sacrificed to economic development for one city. The state Department of Environmental Quality denied the project a crucial water quality permit. The state Department of Energy questioned the need for the power. And Reps. Peter DeFazio, Ron Wyden, and Les AuCoin, all Democrats from western Oregon, across the Cascades from Klamath Falls, introduced the first bill to grant federal protection to the river. The bill failed. In 1988, the quasi-governmental Northwest Power Planning Council _ created by Congress to plan for power needs in the Northwest _ included the upper Klamath River among 40,000 miles of Northwest waterways where it did not want hydroelectric development. Oregon voters approved an initiative putting the upper Klamath on the state scenic waterways list. Last year, the federal energy commission suggested doing away with the dam, and the reservoir, and Klamath Falls agreed. The new design would draw water directly from the tailrace of the J.C. Boyle Dam, carry it 10 miles downstream through canals and conduits built into the canyon wall, to a powerhouse where it would spin generators and be returned to the river. Michael Hartfield, spokesman for the Salt Caves project, says the no-dam proposal would improve trout habitat by taking away the periodic surges of water released from the Boyle dam, leaving a constant flow. But that would mean less water in the river, say opponents, who also object to the canals and conduits. A U.S. Supreme Court decision this year backed the city's claim that a federal energy commission license would override the state's opposition. In the meantime, DeFazio, Wyden and AuCoin introduced another bill for federal protection. The federal agency has said it will await the bill's fate in Congress before acting. ``It's up to Congress,'' said Orsinger.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Looting Kuwait Piece By Piece, Kuwaiti Claims
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: NEAR THE KUWAITI BORDER, Saudi Arabia (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops are systematically looting valuable equipment from Kuwait and mining vital oil, power and water-treatment facilities, a Kuwaiti resistance leader said Wednesday. The Kuwaiti, a former government official, said the organized destruction of Kuwait City indicates the Iraqis expect to either withdraw or be driven out of the country they invaded Aug. 2. Equipment being taken includes computers, telephones and other communications supplies, hospital beds and sophisticated medical equipment, and even window frames, the official said. He declined to be identified for security reasons. Like other Kuwaitis, including government ministers in exile, the resistance leader said he would welcome an offensive against the Iraqi occupation forces to drive them out of Kuwait. But other Kuwaitis disagree with his assessment of Iraq's intentions regarding how long it expects to remain in Kuwait, which has the third-largest oil reserves in the world. Some ministers of Kuwait's government-in-exile, based in Taif, Saudi Arabia, say Iraq has flooded Kuwait with its citizens and may settle thousands of them there. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after the invasion and last week the former emirate was declared Iraq's 19th province. The resistance leader is an articulate, English-speaking member of Kuwait's ruling al-Sabah family and an officer in Kuwait's army. He was interviewed at his headquarters not far from the Kuwaiti border. He refused to allow details of his base to be revealed. The resistance leader said it was his impression, gleaned from information he received from guerrillas moving secretly in and out of Kuwait, that the Iraqis intend to steal what they can from Kuwait because they know their days are numbered. ``They're destroying Kuwait,'' he said. ``All communications system, all telephones, even traffic lights.'' Nothing of value is left untouched, he said. His comments could not be independently verified. But some details conform with intelligence reports published elsewhere. The resistance leader runs many secret cross-border operations, smuggling ammunition, supplies and communications equipment into Kuwait for the resistance. But despite Kuwait's well-financed guerrilla campaign of armed attacks and civil disobedience, the official said ``it's obvious we can't wage guerrilla warfare for long.'' The newly formed resistance has an estimated 10,000 men, compared to the estimated 170,000 troops Iraq has in Kuwait, he said. The Kuwaitis are trying to show the world they are willing fight to regain their country, the resistance leader said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Too-Cheap Asian Sweaters Hurting Domestic Makers
DOC.TEXT: Sweaters from Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan that are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value harm U.S. industry and thus are subject to anti-dumping duties, the government ruled Wednesday. The National Knitwear & Sportswear Association in New York had filed complaints last September against sweater manufacturers in the three countries. The sweaters are made predominantly of acrylic fiber. By a 2-1 vote, the International Trade Commission determined the imports ``materially injure or threaten injury to the U.S. industry.'' The Commerce Department ruled earlier that the imports were being sold at less than fair market value. Since the Commerce decisions, the Customs Service has been requiring bonds equal to the amount of anti-dumping duties for the imports. The bonds now will be converted and actual duties will be imposed on subsequent imports. The duties are designed to make the prices of the imported sweaters comparable to those charged for domestic sweaters. Commerce had described the sweaters as knitted or crocheted outerwear garments, including jackets, vests, cardigans and pullovers. It said imported sweaters represent 72 percent of the $1.3 billion U.S. market and the three countries ship 55 percent of the imports. It said the value of sweaters imported from Hong Kong in 1989 was $208.8 million; South Korea, $476.1 million, and Taiwan, $485.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Gonzalez Proposes Limiting Government Bank Insurance
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Banking Committee on Wednesday proposed limiting the number of accounts that can be insured by the government and perhaps reducing maximum coverage below $100,000. ``Deposit insurance is at the heart of our financial and economic stability,'' said Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas. ``We ignore its problems only with the greatest peril.'' Gonzalez, in a speech to the House, noted that in the wake of the failure of the fund that insured deposits in savings and loan institutions, the bank insurance fund is facing a fifth straight year of multibillion-dollar losses. Despite doubling bank insurance deposit premiums, it will take as long as five years for the fund to reach a reasonably safe level, he said. Key elements of the plan proposed by Gonzalez would: _Limit the number of accounts protected by federal insurance and consider reducing the $100,000 maximum insurance. Under present law, about 99 percent of all deposits are insured because a wealthy person can use joint and trust accounts to avoid the $100,000 limit. Gonzalez said the changes also would prevent abuse of the insurance by pension and other investment funds. _Allow regulators to raise assessments for insurance premiums as the need arises. Institutions that engage in greater risks would have to pay more for deposit insurance. _Toughen capitalization requirements so bank owners would have more of their own money at risk. _Limit permissible investments for insured deposits. _Require a parent holding company to share responsibility for losses incurred by any insured affiliate. The 1989 law bailing out depositors in failed S&Ls created one fund to insure bank deposits, which already is in operation, and a second to insure S&L deposits starting in 1992. Although the law requires the bank fund to have a reserve of at least $1.25 for each $100 of covered deposits, huge losses have reduced the actual reserve ratio to about 60 cents per $100, Gonzalez said.

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Trickle Out, but Saddam Remains Defiant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Saddam statement, Aziz meets Gorbachev, U.S. gaining offensive capability in Saudi Arabia, Americans due home, ship released. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: More Westerners who had been stranded in Iraq flew home to freedom today, and Baghdad insisted it was speeding the departure of those who remain behind. Britain pledged funds for a U.S.-led effort to help nations suffering from U.N. sanctions on Iraq. In his latest televised message, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein said children in Iraq are dying because of the U.N. embargo. ``The children in Iraq are dying because of a foolish decision taken by certain people, the children of Iraq are dying because they are being deprived of their food and milk and medicine,'' Saddam said in a statement read by an announcer. He also sounded a defiant note, urging Arabs to rise up and overthrow leaders in countries aligned against him. He singled out Saudi Arabia and Egypt. The British commitment of funds was made today to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, one of two U.S. officials on international tours. The trips are also aimed at raising funds for the American force sent to defend Saudi Arabia. U.S. military officials said today the United States is using night convoys to move heavy firepower into the northern Saudi desert. The moves increase the offensive capabilities of U.S. forces, though officials have said the buildup is designed to defend the Saudis against any Iraqi attack. Also today, U.S. forces released a freighter they had seized in the Gulf of Oman a day earlier. The Iraqi-flagged freighter was carrying Sri Lankan tea and apparently was bound for Iraq in violation of the U.N. embargo. A Navy spokesman said the ship was allowed to proceed to an unspecified port after a 30-hour search. Though hundreds of Westerners were allowed to leave Baghdad Tuesday and today, Iraqi red tape kept many others waiting. Despite Iraqi promises to expedite departures, British officials said Iraq had intercepted 30 British women and children trying to join a convoy leaving Kuwait. Jordan's King Hussein traveled to Baghdad to try to keep diplomatic efforts alive. He was to hold talks with Saddam today or Thursday. In Moscow, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz met Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss the gulf crisis. The trip came a day after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze proposed an international conference on the Persian Gulf crisis. President Bush and Gorbachev are to hold a summit Sunday in Helsinki, Finland. In other diplomatic efforts, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was headed today for the Middle East, West Germany and Italy. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady met in London with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher promised to contribute to a U.S.-organized fund to help nations worst hit by U.N.-ordered sanctions on Iraq, British officials said. A Thatcher spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity, reported the prime minister ``said the United Kingdom would certainly contribute ... and would let the United States have detailed figures as soon as possible.'' Brady and Baker are also seeking financial commitments to help ease the burden of maintaining a U.S. expeditionary force in Saudi Arabia as part of the international effort to pressure Saddam into withdrawing from Kuwait. Baker said Tuesday that the Bush administration envisions maintaining a military presence in the Persian Gulf even if Iraq leaves oil-rich Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. He said the United States is considering creating a NATO-type alliance to deal with future security threats in the region. Meanwhile, the airlift of Westerners from Iraq, mostly women and children, continued today. Seven British and four American women arrived in Amman on the regular morning Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad. And a French-chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner also arrived in Amman with 105 Western women and children, including 10 Americans. In addition, a Virgin Atlantic Airways flight with 25 U.S. hostages from Baghdad was headed for Newark, N.J., later this afternoon. The Americans traveled via Amman and London. The Iraqi News Agency today quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying Iraq was doing its best to speed the departure of foreign women and children. ``Iraq endeavors with all possible means to ensure their departure in cooperation with concerned countries,'' the news agency reported. It said ``all border points were open for their departure, and the Iraqi Airways was ready to lease its aircraft for flying them to any capital.'' Iraq had slowed the release process by denying foreign jets landing rights and by forcing Westerners to deal with visa red tape. Saddam has said women and children can leave, but foreign men are being kept behind as human shields against any U.S. attack on strategic sites. In Baghdad, 306 British women and children who arrived in a seven-bus convoy from Kuwait on Tuesday night were awaiting exit visas today, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The group was expected to leave Baghdad on Thursday or Friday. However, Iraqis intercepted 30 British women and children trying to join the convoy Tuesday as it left Kuwait, the Foreign Office said today. They were being detained in a hotel, the officials said. They gave no further details. About 11,000 Westerners were believed still stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. In addition, tens of thousands of Asian refugees are stranded in Jordan with no way to get home. Many have gathered in desert camps, where food and water are scarce and sanitary facilities almost non-existent. On Tuesday at one of the camps, thousands of refugees pushed and scuffled next to a truck from which Jordanian officials distributed rations _ a round piece of flat Arab bread, one tomato and one small cucumber per person. Jordanian soldiers on duty stripped off their belts and started flailing the ragged refugees, yelling at them to stop fighting and get into line. At a news conference in Amman, Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan criticized the lack of attention given to the refugees and appealed for help. International relief organizations also called for more aid. Most of the more than 100,000 refugees stranded in Jordan are from Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, the Philippines and Thailand. Baker, testifying Tuesday before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, discussed ways the United States might confront future security challenges in the Persian Gulf and suggested an alliance like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``I think we will have to give consideration to working with others to create a new security structure for the region,'' Baker said. ``I think that's likely to be required even if there is a pullback (by Iraq) from Kuwait. The White House announced Tuesday that Bush had decided to ask Congress to forgive Egypt's entire $7 billion military debt in appreciation for President Hosni Mubarak's role in standing up to Iraqi aggression.

DOC.HEAD: 48 Drug Smugglers Hanged In Iran
DOC.TEXT: Forty-eight drug traffickers, most of them Afghans, were hanged Wednesday in the northeastern Iranian city of Mashhad, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Some of those executed were charged with possessing as little as 31 grams of heroin, IRNA said. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not specify how many of those executed were Afghans. Iranian officials blame neighboring Afghanistan and Pakistan for the drug problem in their country. About a million of Iran's 55 million people are involved in drug abuse, according to official Iranian estimates. Other sources put the number at twice that. The state-run Iranian media have reported more than 1,500 drug-related executions since December 1988. Iranian law stipulates the death sentence for possession of even small quantities of illicit drugs with intent to sell.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldiers Confined to Bases in Advance of Talks
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military Wednesday canceled all off-post liberty for troops at the six American bases here, citing possible danger in advance of U.S.-Philippine talks on the future of the bases. Military spokesman Lt. Col. Ron Rand said the move was taken because of ``several indications'' of an increased threat against the 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and dependents in the Philippines. He did not elaborate. In May, Communist rebels killed two American airmen at Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila, on the eve of talks on the bases' future. The United States operates six military bases in the Philippines under an agreement expiring in September 1991. The talks, expected to resume early next week, are aimed at forging a new lease. A growing number of Filipinos oppose the bases, saying they are an infringment on national sovereignty. The rebel New Peoples Army has vowed to kill more Americans until all U.S. troops leave the country.

DOC.HEAD: Ethicists: Supreme Court Ruling Doesn't Change Death Decisions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Doctors should encourage their patients to write down their wishes about whether they want life-sustaining treatment stopped if they become hopelessly ill, according to a group medical ethicists. The ``living wills'' spell out what kind of care people want if they become too sick to speak for themselves. Such directives are required in two states _ New York and Missouri _ before food, water and medical treatment can be withdrawn. In June, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld Missouri's guidelines, writing that states can require ``clear and convincing evidence'' of a patient's wishes. The patient in that case, Nancy Cruzan, had been in a vegetative state since a 1983 car accident. Her parents believed she would not want to be kept alive in such a condition and sought to have her tube feeding stopped. However, she had not made a living will, and the court refused to allow her parents to speak for her. A statement on the case was drawn up at the Annual Conference of Bioethicists in Lutsen, Minn., in July, signed by 36 ethicists and published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Besides urging doctors to learn what their patients' want, they wrote that physicians ``should also encourage patients to discuss their preferences with their families and close friends and to prepare and sign advance directives.'' Even though unnecessary in most states, such statements ``often help to resolve legally and ethically troubling cases,'' they noted. They added that the Supreme Court decision does not change the laws, ethical standards and medical practices that have evolved since the Karen Ann Quinlan case in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says U.S. Will `Review Options' if Iraq Sanctions Fail
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today told lawmakers just back from the Persian Gulf that the sanctions against Iraq must succeed or ``we will review our options.'' Bush also placed a morale-boosting call to U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, where a skeleton staff of diplomats has stayed behind to assist Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush heard ``repeated statements of support to see this mission through'' from the more than 30 representatives and senators who attended the session in the State Dining Room. Fitzwater praised the Soviet Union's role in the international effort to isolate Iraq, and said the United States is now ``even more interested'' in helping Mikhail Gorbachev's faltering economy. He quoted Bush as telling the lawmakers, ``We must keep pressure on Iraq and convince Saddam Hussein that time is against him.'' ``The president said, `The sanctions must succeed. If not, we will review our options,''' said Fitzwater. He would not elaborate. On today's statement by the Iraqi president in Baghdad that ``the children of Iraq are dying'' because of the United Nations embargo, Fitzwater said, ``We have no evidence to that effect.'' He dismissed the Iraqi president remarks as ``another rhetorical diatribe'' intended to split Arab unity, and ``a sign of desperation.'' ``For Saddam Hussein to claim moral rectitude is totally beyond belief,'' the spokesman said. The Iraqis have cut off water and electricity to the U.S. Embassy as part of their drive to shut down all foreign embassies in the land they annexed following an Aug. 2 lightning invasion. Fitzwater said Howell ``is struggling in a very difficult situation.'' Earlier, Sen. John Glenn suggested that the U.S. troops stationed in the Saudi Arabian desert be given pay and income tax incentives ``to forestall a morale problem.'' Glenn, who was part of a congressional delegation just back from th Middle East, said he told Bush such benefits as free postage stamps, ``imminent danger'' pay, and exemption from income tax should be arranged for U.S. troops on duty in Saudi Arabia. ``I just want to forestall a morale problem'' among the soldiers who have no idea how long they will be stationed in the bleak, hot desert where there are few comforts, Glenn, D-Ohio, said following the White House meeting. Glenn also suggested the sea blockade should be extended to impede air cargo to Iraq by imposing sanctions against countries where the planes originate. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said Bush should push Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to pull remaining Soviet military and technical advisers out of Iraq. He said Bush should not accept the ``figleaf excuse'' that the advisers are there on unexpired contracts. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said he urged Bush to press the Soviets for military intelligence material they could provide on the Iraqi military capability. The lawmakers also said they had received strong assurances from Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and Egypt's Presdient Hosni Mubarak that the economic sanctions against Saudi Arabia's Saddam Hussein can work if given enough time. However, some of the Kuwaitis who fled their country when Iraq invaded it Aug. 2 are more ``trigger happy,''said House Republican leader Bob Michel, R-Ill. Some other members of the congressional delegation have suggested U.S. reserve combat units should be sent to Saudi Arabia to provide a critical test of the forces' capabilities. ``We want to see ... how good the combat units are,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said at a news conference Tuesday. ``This is a test for the future.'' Rep. Bill Dickinson of Alabama, the ranking Republican on Aspin's panel, said he regretted the Pentagon's decision not to activate National Guard combat units, which comprise one-third of the combat power of the active Army divisions being sent to the Persian Gulf. Another senior member of the Armed Services Committee, Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., said the current situation provides an ideal opportunity for evaluating the reserves. ``There's no shooting war. Let's find out if you can mobilize and see how many will show up,'' said Montgomery, who toured Bahrain, Egypt and Saudi Arabia in the House delegation. The more than 9,000 reservists called to active duty following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month have been largely confined to support roles, backing up active-duty combat forces in the gulf area. More than 100,000 U.S. servicemen and women are serving on land or sea in the region. ``There's concern that we're putting all this money into combat reserves and yet they're not being called up,'' said Cohen. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams declined to say what recommendations are before Defense Secretary Dick Cheney about increasing the reservists' role. He said there has been ``a lot of discussion about what might happen down the road,'' but no decision has been made.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Children, Woman Killed by Truck
DOC.TEXT: A speeding truck crushed to death 10 schoolchildren who were waiting at a bus stop to go home Wednesday, a news agency reported. A woman at the bus stop also was killed, it said. Press Trust of India said at least 17 children were injured in the accident in Tamil Nadu state's Tiruchirapalli district, 1,200 miles south of New Delhi. It said the injured children were in serious condition. The news agency did not give details about the children but said they were in elementary school, indicating they were between five and 10 years of age.

DOC.HEAD: Most U.S. Churches Cautious on Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 2nd to UPDATE with Jemison telling convention today that he supports Bush's decision to send troops. Picks up 3rd graf, `Most religious...'
DOC.TEXT: Most of America's largest church organizations, cautious since the Vietnam War about supporting U.S. military involvement, are not sure how to respond to the buildup in the Persian Gulf. The Rev. T.J. Jemison, president of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., broke with other U.S. religious leaders during the church's annual meeting this week when he criticized the deployment. But the gathering as a whole has not yet spoken. And in an apparent policy change today, Jemison told the convention he supports President Bush's decision to send troops to the Middle East. ``As true Americans, we owe allegiance to the Stars and Stripes forever,'' Jemison said. ``We are loyal and devoted citizens.'' He had ``America the Beautiful'' played for the convention and he recited the Pledge of Allegiance. Most religious bodies condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait but are trying to figure out how to balance their opposition to Saddam Hussein with concern the U.S. response may be motivated more by oil than by humanitarianism, said Dale Bishop, director of the Middle East office of the National Council of Churches. ``I think the caution reflects different opinions, which means no one is feeling empowered to speak on behalf of the church on this issue,'' Bishop said Tuesday. The executive committee of the council, the nation's largest ecumenical body, was scheduled to meet Sept. 12 to discuss the Persian Gulf. The Baptist convention was expected to vote Thursday at its 110th annual meeting here on a resolution attacking the troop deployment. The convention is the nation's third-largest Protestant denomination with 7.8 million members and considers itself the largest organization of blacks in the world. ``There is a moral issue,'' Jemison said. ``It's over oil. We're jeopardizing our fine young men and women over oil in the Persian Gulf.'' Jemison said Tuesday that with pressing social needs in this country, ``It's really unfortunate to spend a billion dollars a month over oil.'' Other religious groups also have spoken out on the Persian Gulf crisis. Following a meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Aug. 24, 11 leaders from a broad range of American Jewish organizations issued a statement supporting President Bush's ``policies and actions in addressing Iraq's aggression.'' Robert K. Lifton, president of the American Jewish Congress, said that Hussein would have entered Saudi Arabia unless Bush acted and that the Iraqi leader is intent on trying to hold the world hostage. ``My view is the president did the only thing he could do at this time,'' he said. Other U.S. church leaders have been reluctant to take a stand. ``I think some part of our people were so burned in the Vietnam experience ... before they make a commitment to something like this, they want to be surer than sure,'' Lifton said. The Rev. Paul H. Sherry, president of the 1.6 million-member United Church of Christ, and the Rev. John O. Humbert, president of the 1.1 million-member Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), said in a joint letter to Bush last week that restraint is essential in working toward a negotiated peace. The American Friends Service Committee, an independent Quaker organization in Philadelphia, called on Tuesday for a halt to the U.S. buildup, saying American troops should be replaced by an Arab or U.N. peacekeeping force. Still, most of the nation's large church organizations have avoided judging Bush's decision to send U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia and try to force Iraq out of Kuwait. In the 53 million-member Roman Catholic Church, Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said only that he was praying for a peaceful solution so ``that the soldiers, sailors and air men of all forces now arrayed in the region may soon be restored to their families.'' Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning of the 2.5 million-member Episcopal Church, of which Bush is a member, urged the president not to allow national pride to obstruct negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Denies Complaint Against Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the Robert Mapplethorpe photo exhibit lost a bid in court Wednesday to halt the show they say violates obscenity laws. Boston Municipal Clerk Magistrate Rosemary Carr denied three complaints against the exhibit, which would have prompted an investigation by the district attorney. Carr said ``personally I wouldn't pay five cents'' for the pictures, but she moved quickly to deny the request by the American Family Association. The group had sought a ruling that the exhibit _ which includes nude photos of children _ is exploitative, constitutes dissemination of obscene materials and dissemination of matter harmful to minors. Lesley Pasquini, who filed the complaints against the Institute of Contemporary Art, said members of her group will discuss their next step. ``We're going to keep making people aware of what's going on and what's being pushed before the public,'' she said. But museum attorney Cassandra Warshowsky said the exhibit is protected. ``There is an exemption in the obscenity statutes for exhibitions in a bona fide museum, school or library,'' Warshowsky said. ``In addition to that, this exhibit is fully protected under the Constitution _ the First Amendment.'' The Mapplethorpe photos first went on display at the museum five weeks ago. Seven photographs, including one of a nude boy and another of a partially nude girl, were the subject of the complaint. Opponents objected to the juxtaposition of pictures of nude children next to pictures of nude men. ``They're the most bizarre, perverted photos I have ever seen,'' said Evelyn Dubel of Morality in Media. In Cincinnati, the Contemporary Arts Center and its director were charged with a misdemeanor count of pandering obscenity for displaying homoerotic pictures in the exhibit, which also includes portraits and still lifes of flowers. Outrage over the photos contributed to restrictions on federal funding for the arts. Mapplethorpe died last year at age 42 of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Postpones Campaign Trip to California, Colorado
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is putting off for a week a political trip to Colorado and California due to his weekend summit with Mikhail Gorbachev and ongoing budget negotiations with Congress, the White House said Wednesday. Bush, who had planned to make the western swing next Tuesday and Wednesday, instead will go to Denver, Los Angeles and San Francisco on Sept. 18-19. He will help raise funds for Rep. Hank Brown, the Republican candidate for senator in Colorado, and for Sen. Pete Wilson, the GOP gubernatorial candidate in California, in Los Angeles and San Francisco. Bush was proceeding with a planned political trip Thursday to Topeka, Kan., and Tallahassee, Fla., for Republican governors in those states. He departs Friday for Helsinki, Finland, and the hastily scheduled summit there on Sunday with the Soviet president. In his absence, White House and congressional budget negotiators are spending the weekend at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland in talks aimed at producing a deficit-reduction accord.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The White House did not announce the topic of the Tuesday night speech, but it was expected to cover the crisis in the Persian Gulf. It will follow Bush's weekend trip to Helsinki to meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``The president expressed an interst in addressing the Congress in conversations today with Speaker of the House Thomas Foley and Majority Leader of the Senate George Mitchell,'' Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a written announcement of the speech. Bush was to have made a political trip to California and Denver on Tuesday and Wednesday to raise money for Republican candidates, but the White House announced today that that trip had been postponed.

DOC.TEXT: A private funeral will be held Saturday for Irene Dunne, who delighted generations in screwball comedies such as ``My Favorite Wife'' and such dramas as ``I Remember Mama'' and ``Magnificent Obsession.'' The versatile leading lady, one of the most sought-after stars of the 1930s and 1940s, died Tuesday evening at her Holmby Hills home. She was 88 and had been in failing health for more than a year. DOC.HEAD: Call Girl Placed at Party With Thrift Executives One Day Before Her Death
DOC.TEXT: A former call girl was slain within a day after she went to a party thrown in 1985 by officials of the since-failed Vernon Savings & Loan of Texas, according to court documents. The lavish all-night party allegedly was paid for with $10,000 in bank funds. Vernon Savings officials spent more than $500,000 on rent for the house during a three-year period in the mid-1980s, according to court documents. A former call girl who has been questioned by homicide detectives told the The San Diego Union that Donna Gentile, 22, was present at the June 21, 1985, party at a northern San Diego County beach house. Gentile also was a sometime police informant. Her nude body was found at dawn on June 23. The coroner estimated she had been dead 10 to 15 hours before she was found off a rural highway eastern San Diego County. Gravel had been stuffed in her mouth, the newspaper reported. ``If the date (of the party) is close to that _ and we know Donna was a talker _ if that is what was happening, there could be all sorts of motives (for her death) other than what we are looking at now,'' a law enforcement source told the Union. Shortly before her slaying, Gentile had testified at a city Civil Service Commission hearing about alleged misconduct by some officers. Assistant Police Chief Norm Stamper has been working with the San Diego Metropolitan Homicide Task Force in its search for links among the slayings of Gentile and 42 other women, mostly prostitutes. Their bodies have been found in remote parts of San Diego County since 1985. The former call girl has been interviewed repeatedly by detectives, but had not mentioned seeing Gentile at that party. Her statements are the first disclosure of Gentile's presumed whereabouts immediately before her slaying, the newspaper said Wednesday. ``If that is the date (of the party), then it is of importance,'' Chief Deputy District Attorney Brian Michaels said. The former call girl characterized the financiers as frequent customers of Karen Wilkening, who is serving a prison sentence for operating a San Diego-area call girl ring. ``I knew that (Vernon) gang really well,'' she said. ``They spent a lot of money and had a lot of parties on yachts.'' Don R. Dixon, a former Del Mar resident who headed the Vernon institution, is accused of spending several hundred thousand dollars of Vernon funds on prostitutes, hunting trips, political contributions, yacht trips, antique cars and the beach house. He faces an Oct. 15 trial in Dallas. ``I wouldn't be surprised by anything coming up, so I wouldn't want to foreclose anything, but I don't want to suggest that the prosecution would attempt to make this part of the case'' against Dixon in Dallas, U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins said in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Perpich Leading Primary Foes in Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: A late August poll gave Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich, who has been dogged by low public approval ratings, a strong lead over his closest competitor in next week's primary, according to results released Wednesday. The copyright Pioneer Press-WCCO poll showed Perpich leading challenger Mike Hatch 52 percent to 35 percent among likely voters in Tuesday's Democratic-Farmer-Labor primary. Twelve percent were undecided and 1 percent favored other candidates. State Auditor Arne Carlson led Jon Grunseth 39 percent to 21 percent among likely voters in the Independent-Republican primary, with Doug Kelley supported by 15 percent. Twenty-three percent were undecided and 2 percent favored other candidates, according to the survey. The poll, conducted Aug. 23-30, surveyed a random sample of 705 likely primary voters. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points. For the governor, the results represented a surge in support since a Pioneer Press-WCCO Poll in July. The earlier survey showed Perpich trailing Hatch by a 33 percent to 29 percent margin, with 36 percent undecided. The latest poll came on the heels of an intensive television advertising campaign by Perpich in which the governor claimed he has made Minnesota a national leader. Carlson's strong showing in the survey represented an apparent failure by party leaders to derail his campaign and rescue Grunseth, a St. Paul businessman who is the party's endorsed candidate.
DOC.HEAD: McConnell Calls Out Bloodhounds Again
DOC.TEXT: Republican U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell has called out a familiar pair of bloodhounds to track down votes in his campaign for re-election this year. The dogs, which appear in one of McConnell's new television spots, are the same ones that were given some credit for his 1984 ouster of Democratic incumbent Walter ``Dee'' Huddleston. In the original ads, the bloodhounds were dispatched to search for Huddleston at resorts where he was paid to give speeches while the Senate was in session. This time, McConnell is using the hounds to send the message that he will be in Washington to vote on issues of concern to Kentuckians. ``Remember that ad?'' McConnell asks in the new spot, which first aired Tuesday. ``It was funny. But the point was dead serious. In the last campaign, I made a commitment to the people of Kentucky. I said I wouldn't miss a single vote to collect a speaking fee, and I've kept that pledge.'' McConnell does collect fees for making speeches, and has opposed efforts to prohibit such fees, saying a ban on that form of income would be unfair because many senators own property that generates outside income. In the ad, McConnell tells viewers his six-year voting-attendance record is 99 percent, ``one of the best in the entire Senate. Being on the job is the most important thing a senator has to do.'' The ad doesn't mention his current Democratic opponent, former Louisville mayor and Jefferson County judge-executive Harvey Sloane.
DOC.HEAD: Iowa Governor Candidates Launch Television Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: Iowa's rivals for governor launched their fall television blitz with mild commercials focusing on family and their records. GOP Gov. Terry Branstad on Tuesday began airing a 30-second spot boosting his role in developing the state's economy. His Democratic challenger, Don Avenson, began his drive last week with one commercial introducing voters to his family and another featuring Avenson talking about his efforts to push clean water legislation. Branstad campaign manager David Roederer said the television spots build on radio commercials the campaign began last month underscoring Branstad's efforts to manage the state during the economic turmoil of the 1980s. ``They'll start folding in some testimonials on economic development,'' said Roederer. House Speaker Avenson's commercials are designed to soften his image by playing on his family and connection to popular environmental programs, said spokeswoman Susy Robinette. Both camps insisted they were staying away from hard-hitting negative commercials. The governor's race is generally considered competitive, though Branstad has built a big edge in campaign finances.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Gorbachev Plans Trip to Unification Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will travel to Berlin for next month's German unification ceremonies, East German radio reported Wednesday. DDR-Rundfunk, in a report from Moscow, said Gorbachev hopes to shake President Bush's hand at the Brandenburg Gate near the former site of the Berlin Wall. The meeting Oct. 3 would signify an ``end of the postwar era,'' according to the radio report. It cited ``well-informed sources.'' Caroline Meirs-Osterling, spokeswoman for the U.S. diplomatic mission in West Berlin, said she was aware of speculation Bush would attend the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Administration: Women Soldiers May Have to Live with Saudi Culture
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American women who are part of the military buildup in Saudi Arabia may have to get used to cultural differences that put them in a subservient role, the White House said Wednesday. ``It is something our military is grappling with,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, describing it as ``just one of many similar kinds of cultural situations that our service men and women are running into there.'' The Saudi expect female soldiers to conform to such cultural practices as not allowing women to shop alone. The culture bars socializing or having personal contact _ even for business _ with a member of the opposite sex who is not a relative. The Pentagon did get a special exemption from the Saudi government to allow women to drive trucks, forklifts and other vital equipment. Saudi women are not allowed to drive. When shopping, female soldiers must be accompanied by a male who makes the purchases while the woman stands with her eyes downcast to avoid offending the male shopkeeper. ``We are working on it,'' Fitzwater said when asked whether the administration was trying to remedy the situation. ``Our commanders are working with the Saudis and trying to develop new programs and processes for living there that can accommodate both cultures.''

DOC.HEAD: Plant Extract Fights AIDS Virus in Test Tube, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: An extract from pokeweed plants can hamper reproduction of the AIDS virus within infected cells, suggesting a possible new approach to treating infected people, researchers say. In test-tube experiments, the extract worked in tiny amounts that did not disturb key functions in uninfected cells, researchers said. The work is reported in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by scientists from Oncogen in Seattle, the Veterans Administration Medical Center in San Diego and the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Pokeweed contains clusters of purplish-white flowers and reddish-purple berries. It grows in North America, and its roots and berry seeds are poisonous. Researchers purified a substance called pokeweed antiviral protein from the leaves of the plant. They mixed it with proteins called monoclonal antibodies, which targeted the dose to cells infected by the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. This mixture, called a conjugate, strongly inhibited reproduction of the AIDS virus in blood cells called T cells from infected patients, researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Agree to Plead Guilty to Bombing Charges
DOC.TEXT: Three radical leftists will plead guilty to setting off bombs at the U.S. Capitol and seven other sites, and the government has agreed to drop charges against three other people. Laura J. Whitehorn, Linda S. Evans and Marilyn J. Buck are scheduled to plead guilty Friday in U.S. District Court here to participating in a conspiracy to set off the eight bombs that damaged property but caused no injuries, according to court papers filed last week in federal court. The Nov. 7, 1983, blast at the Capitol blew a hole in a wall outside the Senate chambers, damaging five paintings and knocking the door to Democratic leader Robert Byrd's office off its hinges. As part of the deal, government prosecutors agreed to drop bombing charges against three other members of the leftist group who are serving lengthy prison sentences for possession of explosives. The six defendants are members of a radical group that variously identified itself as the Armed Resistance Unit, the Revolutionary Fighting Group and the Red Guerrilla Resistance unit. The group is linked to the $1.6 million armed robbery of a Brinks armored car near Nyack, N.Y., in 1981 in which two policemen and a guard were killed. Buck is serving a 50-year sentence for participating in the Brinks holdup and four other armed robberies. The plea agreement filed by U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said the disposition of the bombing case was ``in the interest of justice'' but gave no reason for why the government agreed to settle the case. Lawyers familiar with the case said a May Supreme Court decision in a New York case on the issue of double jeopardy figured in the government's willingness to drop the charges against Susan L. Rosenberg, Timothy A. Blunk and Alan Berkman. Rosenberg and Blunk are serving 58-year sentences for possessing more than 600 pounds of explosives. They were caught loading the explosives into a rented storage bin in Cherry Hill, N.J., in 1984. Berkman, a physician, is serving a 10-year term for possession of explosives, weapons and false identify cards when he was arrested in 1985 in Doylestown, Pa. A seventh defendant in the case, Elizabeth Duke, is a fugitive. In 1989, U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene dismissed the bombing charges against Rosenberg, Blunk and Berkman, ruling that the evidence in the case had already been used to convict them of the earlier firearms charges.
