The U.S. District Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reinstated the charges, saying the new indictment did not violate the rules against double jeopardy. But the defense renewed its double-jeopardy claims last spring after the Supreme Court said in a New York case that prosecutors cannot bring charges based on evidence that had already been used to convict the defendant of a different offense. Greene has not ruled on that motion. Whitehorn, 45, Buck, 43, and Evans, 43, agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy, and destruction of government property. Each could be sentenced to up to 15 years in prison. Whitehorn also agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with possession of false identification documents that the FBI found during a 1985 raid on her Baltimore apartment. The charge carries a five-year prison term. Prosecutors agreed to drop other Baltimore charges against Whitehorn. In addition to the explosion at the Capitol, bombs were detonated outside the National War College at Fort McNair here April 26, 1983, the Washington Navy Yard Computer Center on Aug. 18, 1983, and the Washington Navy Yard Officers Club on April 20, 1984. Bombs were also placed at the FBI's office on Staten Island, N.Y., on Jan. 28, 1983, the Israeli Aircraft Industries Building in New York on April 5, 1984, the South African consulate in New York on Sept. 26, 1984, and the New York Patrolmen's Benevolent Association on Feb. 23, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Hostages Return To United States
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four Americans held hostage in the Persian Gulf arrived in the United States on Wednesday, weary from a 20-hour flight but thrilled to be back. ``I'm happy to be home,'' said Taleb Subh, 15, of Davenport, Iowa, who had been visiting aunts and uncles in Kuwait when Iraq invaded the country Aug. 2. He said he went to the U.S. Embassy, where officials ``snuck'' him to Baghdad. ``They took care of me,'' said Taleb, who was among five men, nine women and 10 children who flew home aboard a Virgin Atlantic Airways Boeing 747. The group was among 29 Americans who began the journey to freedom in Jordan on Tuesday, said Lori Levin, an airline spokeswoman. She said she did not know why five of the Americans decided to stop in London rather than make the flight to the Newark. Norik Checkosky of Middletown, came to the airport to meet her mother, Zaroohi Babooriam, who had been in Iraq visiting relatives. ``Right now, she seems physically ill. She looks very bad,'' Ms. Checkosky said. She said she learned in a telephone call from her mother Tuesday that the freedom plane would arrive Wednesday. ``She said she was just fine, tired but fine,'' Ms. Checkosky said. The Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747 landed about 3:20 p.m. at Newark International Airport, and passengers were expected to spend at least an hour passing through U.S. Customs before they could leave the airport or catch connecting flights. ``We welcome these people home,'' Lucinda Florio, wife of Gov. Jim Florio, said in presenting yellow roses to Nithal George, who was traveling from Iraq with her three children ages 11, 7 and 2 en route to San Jose, Calif. Representatives of the American Red Cross met the former hostages at the airport to smooth their return. ``We'll make flight arrangements,'' said Jane Frotton, director of emergency services for the Red Cross' Essex County chapter. The Americans, who were among 11,000 Westerners believed to be stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, traveled through Amman, Jordan, and to London before arriving in Newark. The plane, loaded with medical supplies and food, had flown to Jordan on Monday and had clearance to land in Baghdad, but was unable to do so because such supplies would have violated the trade embargo against Iraq, Ms. Levin said. The supplies, 2{ tons of flour, 25,000 blankets, and 2{ tons of medical supplies, were requested by Jordan's King Hussein. The hostages, freed by Iraq, made their way to Jordan for the flight home. Though hundreds of Westerners were allowed to leave Baghdad on Tuesday and Wednesday, Iraqi red tape kept many others waiting. The Iraqi News Agency on Wednesday quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying Iraq was trying to speed the departure of foreign women and children. The news agency said ``all border points were open for their departure, and the Iraqi Airways was ready to lease its aircraft for flying them to any capital.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said women and children can leave, but foreign men are being kept behind as human shields against any U.S. attack on strategic sites.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Consumption, Gulf Contributions of Countries on Baker-Brady Itinerary
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas Brady are on the road in search of aid, financial and humane, for the Persian Gulf operation. Brady has been to France and Britain and is continuing to the Far East for meetings with Korean and Japanese leaders. Baker will meet with Italian, West German and Soviet leaders next week. Here is a look at the countries they will visit, with the amount of oil each consumes, imports from the Persian Gulf, and contributions thus far. Daily consumption and net imports from Persian Gulf is in millions of barrels per day.
DOC.HEAD: BRITAIN
DOC.TEXT: Consumption: 1,737. Britain is a net exporter of oil but also imports 10,248,000 barrels a year, mainly from Norway and Iran. A little comes from Kuwait and almost nothing from Iraq. Britain has sent 2,000 military personnel to Saudi Arabia, Oman and the Gulf states. Three squadrons of warplanes are divided between Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. There is a reconnaissance aircraft unit, an anti-aircraft missile unit, a field ambulance and field hospital, four warships _ two destroyers and two frigates _ and five support ships. Three minesweepers are heading for the eastern Mediterranean.
DOC.HEAD: FRANCE
DOC.TEXT: Consumption: 1,856. Persian Gulf import total: .863. Defense officials said Wednesday that France has deployed 8,950 military personnel in the Gulf, the second largest force after the United States. Nine French navy ships are in the region, or en route, including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau. One company of 180 paratroopers has been sent to the United Arab Emirates. Non-lethal government aid includes about $220 million for Jordan to help resettle refugees. The private group Medecins Sans Frontiers has sent 12 tons of medical equipment to Jordan for the same purpose.
DOC.HEAD: WEST GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: Consumption: 2,278; Persian Gulf import total .233. West Germany has sent tents and medical supplies to Jordan to help refugees. Several West German planes ferried refugees from Jordan to Cairo early in the crisis. Seven West German minesweepers are on their way to the eastern Mediterrean as reinforcement for U.S. ships being deployed to the Gulf.
DOC.HEAD: ITALY
DOC.TEXT: Consumption 1,940; Persian Gulf import total: .657. Italy has sent two frigates and a support ship to the Gulf. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean off the coast of Turkey.
DOC.HEAD: JAPAN
DOC.TEXT: Consumption: 4,981; Persian Gulf import total: 3.450. Japan has loaded a ship with 800 four-wheel-drive vehicles for the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf. The $11 million in cargo also included an unspecified number of water trucks and air conditioners. The shipment is part of the assistance package announced last week by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. It is to include 100 medical personnel and chartered civil aircraft and ships that will transport food, water and medical supplies as well as other non-military goods.
DOC.HEAD: KOREA
DOC.TEXT: Consumption: .742; Persian Gulf import total: .592. Note: latest available figures from Korea are for 1988 consumption and 1987 import.

DOC.HEAD: Another Panamanian Police Chief Fired
DOC.TEXT: The fourth person to head Panama's national police since the U.S. invasion in December has been fired after writing a letter to a newspaper in response to corruption allegations. Lt. Col. Fernando Quezada was replaced provisionally by Ebrahim Asvat, who becomes the first civilian in 40 years to head Panama's security forces. Asvat also is the public security director for the Interior and Justice Department. ``The president ... has separated Lt. Col. Fernando Quezada from his post as director-general of the Public Force because of an absolutely unacceptable public letter,'' said a communique issued late Tuesday by President Guillermo Endara's office. Quezada was fired after he sent a letter to La Prensa publisher Roberto Eisenmann and fax copies to news organizations protesting a story published Tuesday. According to the story, the former head of the Anti-Terrorist Unit, Ramon Diaz, said Quezada received $25,000 from ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega but later tried to depose the strongman. Quezada's letter recalled Noriega's charges of gross personal misconduct against Eisenmann. Asvat said Wednesday that Quezada will remain on the police force at his present rank but without specific duties. The Public Force replaces the Panama Defense Forces, which were headed by Noriega. Although many current officers are former Defense Forces personnel, the new department was converted to a civilian force and placed under the Interior Ministry after Noriega was driven from power during the U.S. invasion. Asvat told The Associated Press on Wednesday that from now on the civilian force will accept cadets only from police academies, not military schools. After Noriega was taken to Miami to face U.S. drug-trafficking charges, Col. Roberto Armijo took over the Public Force but was replaced when a bank account of more than $1 million was found in his name. A deputy, Aristides Valdonedo, took the job but was fired when he was linked to the arson of a building of which Eisenmann was part owner. He was replaced by Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan, who retired Aug. 22. Quezada was named to the post after four civilians turned it down.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Isidore Forms Off Africa
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Isidore formed off the Cape Verde Islands on Wednesday, but presented no immediate threat to land, forecasters said. Isidore, the ninth named storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season, generated winds of 40 mph and was expected to strengthen somewhat by Thursday, said National Hurricane Center forecaster Bob Ebaugh. At noon EDT Wednesday, the storm's center was located near latitude 9.9 north and longitude 34.8 west, or about 750 miles southwest of the Cape Verde Islands off the coast of Africa. Isidore was moving toward the west at 18 mph and that motion was expected to continue at least through Thursday. Storms are named when their maximum sustained winds reach 39 mph. If Isidore's winds exceed 74 mph, it would become the fourth hurricane of the season. So far, the only hurricane to reach land was Diana, which hit the Mexican coast.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Occupy Former Secret Police Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 7 `No unification' to CORRECT initials to BND. Picks up 8th pvs, `The East ...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of last fall's peaceful revolution occupied the former secret police headquarters Wednesday in a struggle over control of millions of files collected by the force. ``Herr Mielke, where are my files?'' read a message spray-painted across the street from the occupied building. That was a reference to the former East German secret police chief, Erich Mielke, who is now in jail pending investigation of criminal charges of abuse of power. There were 21 activists holed up in Block 7 of the concrete complex where the archives are kept. The activists want the East German government to demand changes in parts of the treaty merging East and West German laws that concern files on 6 million people kept by the Stasi, as the secret police force was known. ``File holders of all countries, Unite!'' read one leaflet distributed to passers-by. The treaty approved last week by the governments of the two German states limits access to the files. However, activists worry East German citizens will have little control over documents that directly concern them. They also say the files will be at the disposition of the future all-German government. ``No unification of the Stasi and the BND,'' said one banner. The BND is the West German intelligence agency. The East German Cabinet agreed Wednesday to seek modifications of the treaty with West Germany. East Berlin Mayor Tino Schwierzina expressed his solidarity with the protesters, saying that ``only citizens of East Germany as victims of Stasi terror have the right of access to their files.'' The Stasi was formed after World War II with the help of the experienced Soviet secret service. Its agents are blamed for murdering East German refugees, hiding international terrorists, and persecuting dissidents. The Hamburg-based magazine ``Stern'' this week reported that the Stasi used radiation against millions of cars that went from West Berlin to West Germany to detect East Germans trying to flee the country.

DOC.HEAD: Rejected Black Veteran Now A Legionnaire
DOC.TEXT: An American Legion post that rejected a black Vietnam veteran for membership two months ago because of his race has admitted the man after his second application. The Fred H. Sexton Post 1 approved the membership of Thurman L. Thompson, 39, durring a closed-door meeting Tuesday night. Members said the vote was 17-1. Post commander Allen Stein said he did not know who cast the dissenting vote. ``I just want to go back to being Thurman L. Thompson Jr., who happens to be a member of the American Legion,'' the U.S. Navy veteran said after the meeting. ``I just wanted to be a member and work toward helping the veterans and the community.'' He said telephone calls and letters of encouragement from around the country persuaded him to apply again. Thompson, a Naval reservist waiting to see if he will be ordered to the Middle East, said he looks forward to watching and participating in the American Legion baseball program. A nephew of Thompson and other teen-agers who live near his Florence home play for the league. Thompson said he first became interested in joining Post 1 because of its baseball team. Thompson said he is not bitter about the incident, which he called ``unfortunate.'' His initial application was rejected at a July 3 meeting in which at least three members said they did not want a black into the all-white post. After the vote became public, the state American Legion temporarily suspended the post's charter pending an investigation of the incident. The probe is continuing. The state Legion restored the charter in August after the post amended its bylaws to ban segregation and eliminate the ability to reject an applicant with just two votes. The post also promised to invite Thompson to re-apply. State American Legion Commander J. Norris Kinion welcomed Thompson to the post via telephone Tuesday night. ``I am thoroughly pleased that the events of the evening went the way they did,'' Kinion said from his Greenville home. ``Cool heads have prevailed.''

DOC.HEAD: Former SS Guard Fights to Stay in America
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for a former Nazi guard argued Wednesday that he should not be stripped of U.S. citizenship because he knew nothing about the killings at the concentration camp where he served during the Holocaust. The Justice Department has sought since 1988 to denaturalize retired janitor Michael Schmidt on charges he illegally obtained a visa to the United States shortly after World War II. The government argued before the 7th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals that Schmidt, 67, failed to meet visa requirements because he aided in the deaths of more than 100,000 people at the Sachsenhausen prison outside of Berlin. ``Therefore, his naturalization was illegally procured,'' said Ronnie Eddlman, an assistant U.S. attorney. But Schmidt's attorney, George Collins, said his client worked only as a guard at Sachsenhausen and knew nothing about the extermination of prisoners. Collins said that on his visa application, Schmidt acknowledged he had served with the Schutzstaffel, or SS, the elite military unit of the Nazi party that served as a special police force. ``This is not visa fraud,'' Collins told the three-judge panel. ``The only thing before you is whether a man at a prison should be denaturalized for things that went on inside that prison which he didn't know about.'' Collins argued that Schmidt, a native of Romania, wasn't privy to events inside the camp because he only patrolled its perimeter as an SS guard and escorted prisoners to work outside the camp. Schmidt was 20 at the time. Ms. Eddlman urged the appellate court to uphold the decision earlier this year of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, which ordered that Schmidt be denaturalized. ``It is not credible that the person did not have knowledge'' of the killings inside the prison camp, she said. Collins disagreed. ``The evidence against him, that he was there, should be no presumption of guilt,'' Collins said. Schmidt, who lives in suburban Lincolnwood, refused to comment after the hearing. His wife, son and daughter, who also refused to comment, attended the 25-minute proceedings with about 20 neighbors and friends. ``He was just at the wrong place at the wrong time,'' said a neighbor, Gerhard Taraschewsky. Schmidt would have to leave the country if the lower court's ruling is affirmed. The appellate court took the arguments under advisement and did not say when it might rule.

DOC.HEAD: Government Awards Carriers New Soviet Routes
DOC.TEXT: Alaska Airlines and Federal Express will be allowed to begin new air services to the Soviet Union, the Transportation Department said Wednesday. The department also said it will hold hearings to award passenger routes to three other carriers. Alaska Airlines had announced tentative approval of its application to fly three times a week to the Soviet Far East cities of Magadan and Khabarovsk. No other airline had applied for the route. Twelve airlines have applied for other Soviet-U.S. routes arranged in a June 1 aviation agreement between the two countries. The agreement calls for four passenger and two cargo-only services in addition to those by Pan Am, which is the only U.S. carrier now serving the Soviet Union. Flights can begin April 1, and will be authorized for two years. Federal Express would provide all-cargo service between New York and Moscow or Leningrad. The three additional routes for combination passenger and cargo service will be over the Atlantic. An all-cargo route will be assigned over the Pacific. No date was announced for the hearings, but an administrative law judge is to make a recommendation for the routes by Feb. 19. Alaska Airline officials said they plan to fly to the Soviet cities only during the summer because it would be too hard to fly into those areas during harsh winter weather. The Soviet carrier Aeroflot would have permission to fly to San Francisco and other U.S. cities, with a stopover in Anchorage. The Soviet airline frequently lands at Anchorage International Airport with goodwill and educational delegations, FAA officials said.

DOC.HEAD: No More Teachers, No More Books; Just Rakes, For Now
DOC.TEXT: Students in two school districts traded in their books for rakes to help harvest a bumber crop of wild blueberries, giving them a reprieve on the start of classes. This year's crop already exceeds the record 52.3 million pounds harvested in 1988, officials say. And it's more than double the 26 million pounds processed last year, they say. As a result, hundreds of students in the Cherryfield and Machias areas in eastern Maine, who were scheduled to return to school Wednesday, won't go back to classes until Monday. ``The crop is unusually large and the blueberry industry means a great deal to the economy of this area,'' said William Clark, superintendent of School Union 102 in Machias. The school district that serves Cherryfield and eight neighboring towns agreed in late June to a request by blueberry processors to move back the start of the school year to accommodate what was already shaping up to be a bountiful harvest. The abnormally large amount of fruit is attributed to good growing weather _ adequate rain the year before to form the flower buds, sufficient snow cover to prevent winter kill and good pollinating weather in the spring. The blueberry yield also was helped by the more than 30,000 beehives imported into Maine to bolster the native pollinators. ``The bees were out there, working real hard,'' said Edward J. McLaughlin, executive director of the Maine Blueberry Commission. Maine's ``wild blues'' are frozen and sold primarily to large food processors. They're used in such products as pancakes and muffin mixes. Although mechanical harvesters were introduced in some areas of the areas, most of the raking is still done by hand. Rakers generally earn about $150 a day, although the fastest workers have been known to make over $200. School children who work in the fields count on the cash to buy winter clothes or save for college. ``A typical kid might make $60 a day, which is pretty good if you're 13 or 14 years old,'' said Russell Libby of the state Department of Agriculture. Teachers also take part in the harvest. ``We have two who are foremen on the receiving docks,'' said Joseph White, superintendent of School Administrative District 37 in Harrington.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Success in Drug War; Lawmaker Says War Being Lost in Inner Cities ^Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Rangel criticism. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Bush and ...' ^LaserPhoto WX15
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday that the United States ``is making progress'' in the war on drugs, but two key congressmen said the year-old program isn't doing enough to help impoverished Americans. ``Drug czar (William J.) Bennett and President Bush cannot deny that we are losing the drug war in our inner cities,'' said Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations. ``Prevention and education efforts directed at the educated middle class appear to be having a dramatic effect,'' Conyers said. ``Treatment programs have room for clients who can afford to pay. However, the chronically addicted cannot pay when they are poor and unemployed, as is often the case.'' Rep. Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, agreed with Conyers' criticisms, saying the statistics showing improvement primarily pertain to the middle class. ``Unfortunately, the administration's anti-drug strategy has not been responsive to the concerns of inner city and other chronic drug abusers, whose drug abuse is fueling the crisis in our emergency rooms, in our criminal justice system and in our treatment centers,'' said Rangel, D-N.Y. Bush and Bennett, the president's chief lieutenant in the drug war, emphasized the positive in speeches and a white paper released Wednesday, the first anniversary of the president's announcement of his war on drugs. ``I think America is making progress against drugs and will continue to do so,'' Bush said, but he acknowledged that the war is far from won. ``There is still too much violence, too much destruction, too many innocent victims,'' he told a gathering of staff and reporters. ``Drugs are still an international menace.'' And he committed his administration to ``remain on the front lines until this scourge is licked for good,'' even as the government seems preoccupied with the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I know that other subjects preoccupy all of us these days. But this one remains No. 1, will continue to remain No. 1 when the international situation has calmed down,'' Bush said. The president said that signs of progress included Americans' increasing hostility toward drugs, declines in casual drug use, law enforcement successes at home and in Latin America and the reduction in cocaine supplies. Cocaine, Bush said, is ``harder to find, more expensive, less pure than it was just one year ago.'' Conyers, however, urged revising the federal drug budget to spend as much on treatment and prevention as is spent on law enforcement. The current split is almost 70 percent for law enforcement with the remainder going for treatment and prevention. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, released a report citing some successes of the drug war and some failures, including an increased number of murders this year, inadequate drug education and lack of treatment for pregnant or incarcerated addicts. ``Much progress has been made in fighting drug use, but declarations of victory in the drug war are still far away,'' Biden said. New York City police Commissioner Lee Brown, appearing before Biden's committee Wednesday, said initial enthusiasm over the war on drugs was dampened by a lack of sufficient federal funds for local lawmen. New York, he said, was designated a ``high intensity drug area'' under the program and made eligible for increased funding. But he said none of the $4 million in additional aid went directly to local police. ``The national drug control strategy needs redirecting,'' he said. Los Angeles police chief Daryl Gates told the panel that the drug strategy ``may not be perfect, but I think it is a good one.'' Bennett, director of national drug control policy, said Wednesday that he was not declaring any victories, but simply publicizing signs that the situation may not be as bleak as it once appeared. He said that when he was confirmed to his job 18 months ago, ``most commentators _ friends and critics both _ described the work ahead in almost apocalyptic terms. The drug crisis was `hopeless,' `beyond control,' `getting worse with no end in sight.''' Now, he said, ``the drug problem _ in general, nationwide _ is no longer getting worse, and in some very significant aspects it is now getting better. Not victory, but success.'' Bush made the drug strategy announcement Sept. 5, 1989, in his first prime-time televised speech.

DOC.HEAD: International Commission Accuses Soviets in Wallenberg Case
DOC.TEXT: An international commission found Wednesday that the Soviet government issued misleading statements on the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat credited with saving tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis during World War II. Wallenberg vanished after the Soviets arrested him in Budapest in 1945 in the war's final days on allegations he spied for Germany. Moscow later said he had died. Wallenberg's relatives say they received reports he is alive under detention in the Soviet Union. He would now be 77. The 25-member private commission, composed of Soviet, Swedish, U.S. and Canadian members, said its investigation of the conduct of Soviet authorities in the case ``brings into question their moral standing'' in the matter. Wallenberg, a member of a prominent family of bankers and industrialists, repeatedly risked his life by hiding Jews in houses he bought or rented, often with his own money. Shortly before Budapest was liberated, he persuaded the Nazis to cancel a plan to kill 70,000 Jews still living in the city's ghetto. In 1981, the United States made Wallenberg an honorary citizen. Swedish authorities presented the Kremlin with witnesses' reports in the 1950s and 1960s that Wallenberg was alive and was seen by non-Soviets at Vladimir Prison, 12 miles outside Moscow. The Soviets responded with ``The Gromyko Memorandum'' of Feb. 6, 1957, saying they investigated reports from Vladimir Prison and concluded Wallenberg died of a heart attack in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison in 1947. This year, the Soviets opened some archives to foreign investigators for the first time and let the commission hold interviews and search files at Vladimir Prison. ``We have found that the Soviet Union never conducted any investigation at Vladimir Prison,'' said the report, issued at a news conference by the newly formed Soviet-International Joint Commission on the Fate and Whereabouts of Raoul Wallenberg. It found that despite Soviet claims of having investigated the case, ``prison archives were not examined, prison officials were not interviewed, and witnesses whose testimony was relevant were not examined.'' ``This finding is particularly disturbing _ and painful _ as the Soviet Union continued to receive testimony from the Swedish government in the 1950s, based largely on witness testimony from imprisoned foreign nationals at Vladimir Prison who had left the Soviet Union, that Raoul Wallenberg was alive in the 1950s. ``Yet for 12 years, from 1945-57, the Soviet Union insisted that `Raoul Wallenberg is not in the Soviet Union and he is not known to us.''' Quoting from the Gromyko Memorandum, named after the late Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Kremlin authorities looked into the matter and could not find ``any information whatsoever about Wallenberg being in the Soviet Union. . . . None of those interrogated knew anything about Wallenberg.'' ``Accordingly the Commission's finding that no investigation had ever been conducted by the Soviet Union at Vladimir Prison not only discredits the Gromyko Memorandum and the Soviet position that Wallenberg died in 1947, but brings into question their moral standing to make any claim whatever in the absence of any investigation by them,'' it said The commission also found that the KGB secret police kept its own files on incarcerated foreigners. ``Accordingly, the commission finds it rather incredulous that the KGB claimed to have discovered `by accident' in October 1989 items belonging to Raoul Wallenberg (prison registration card, passport, money, personal belongings) and which it turned over to the Wallenberg family during their visit . . .. ``Indeed, the former director of archives at Vladimir . . . found this KGB claim to be rather ludicrous. ``Moreover, the KGB had previously claimed for 32 years that it had no information or materials whatsoever relating to Raoul Wallenberg.'' Members of the commission include Wallenberg's brother, Guy von Dardel of Sweden; Irwin Cotler of Canada; Marvin W. Markinen, an American professor who formerly was incarcerated at Vladimir Prison; Cronid Lubarsky, another former Vladmir inmate; and Rolf Bjornerstedt, a former United Nations assistant secretary. It also included five Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Aquarium's Plan to Trade Dolphin to Navy Launches Protest Wave
DOC.TEXT: An aquarium director was reconsidering plans to trade an aggressive, unsociable show dolphin to the Navy after news of the deal set off a wave of protests from animal-rights activists. The New England Aquarium and the Navy worked out the swap, which would have enlisted Rainbow, an 11-year-old male, in the secret underwater mammal program at the Naval Ocean Systems Center in San Diego. Aquarium director John H. Prescott said Wednesday that the angry public reaction prompted him to rethink the trade. ``I think the decision is good for the animals concerned,'' Prescott said. ``(But) if it's causing public concern, I must pay attention. It's not a closed issue.'' Rainbow, 8-foot-2 and 450 pounds, is a blue-gray bottlenose dolphin. One of three show dolphins at the aquarium, it became cantankerous as it matured. Prescott sought a swap: Rainbow for a female. Other aquariums refused. But the Navy center, which looks after, studies and trains 142 marine mammals including 109 dolphins, eventually agreed to take Rainbow in exchange for a partly deaf female. The center trains dolphins in underwater surveillance and detecting, locating and marking objects for recovery. Other details are are classified, said Tom LaPuzza, a spokesman at the San Diego center. The trade was delayed because the military buildup in the Persian Gulf took Navy planes that could have been used to transport Rainbow. News of the deal got out Thursday, and animal rights activists raised an outcry. ``We have been attempting to persuade the aquarium not to capture wild dolphins and whales ... Our efforts are more urgent now that we learn that the aquarium is acting as a clearinghouse for animals for the military,'' the Boston Marine Mammal Coalition said in a statement. A protest at the aquarium was set for Saturday. The aquarium got so many calls it recorded a message to intercept them, inviting anyone concerned about Rainbow to send a letter. National interest in the Navy dolphins was galvanized by reports in 1988 that 13 dolphins in Navy training had died between 1986 and 1988. Nearly half the animals suffered from lack of appetite or stomach ulcers before their deaths, the report said. Other causes were hepatitis and pneumonia. A federal Marine Mammal Commission probe found no major problems in the program. No Navy animals have died in the past 13 months, LaPuzza said. Then in May, a former trainer told the media that bottlenose dolphins with .45-caliber guns mounted on their snouts were being trained by the Navy to kill enemy frogmen. LaPuzza denies such claims. The Navy has ``never trained marine mammals to kill people and will never do so,'' LaPuzza said. ``We do not train mammals to perform operations that will put them in danger.'' The Navy did use dolphins for military work in Vietnam and in 1986 and 1987 in the Persian Gulf, however, LaPuzza said. He refused to say what the mammals did. There aren't any immediate plans to use dolphins in the gulf crisis, he said. The aquarium has given the Navy three dolphins since 1980, all animals it couldn't take for various reasons, Prescott said, praising the care the military gives the animals. The Boston controversy coincides with a similar one in Washington state. In Silverdale, Wash., Wednesday night the Navy planned to hear public concerns about the Navy's intention to use dolphins to guard Trident submarines at Bangor, Wash. The hearing is part of a settlement reached after 15 animal rights groups sued the Navy in April 1989, claiming that bringing the warm-water dolphins to the colder waters of Hood Canal required an environmental assessment under the National Environmental Policy Act. The suit was dropped when the Navy agreed to make that assessment.

DOC.HEAD: White House Taking Pre-Summit New Look at Aid to Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS lead to delete reference to direct aid; aid proposed for Soviets had not been direct cash grants but various other forms of assistance
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Wednesday, four days before the U.S.-Soviet summit, that it would take a fresh look at economic aid for the Soviet Union in light of Moscow's ``real and very helpful support'' in the Persian Gulf. The administration had previously rejected the idea, but presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The Soviet cooperation in the gulf has impressed us to the point where we are even more interested in being supportive economically if we can be.'' Meanwhile, the White House announced that President Bush would address a joint session of Congress next Tuesday night after returning from his weekend summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush's topics, aides said, would include the summit and the gulf crisis. According to a White House statement, Bush had brought up the idea of the joint session appearance earlier in the day in conversations with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``Speaker Foley extended an invitation to the president on behalf of both chambers,'' the statement said. White House aides said that the speech would deal primarily with the Persian Gulf crisis but that Bush would also give lawmakers a rundown on his session in Helsinki with Gorbachev. In pre-summit comments, White House officials seemed to be going out of their way to praise the Soviets. Fitzwater said he was certain the issue of Western economic aid to Moscow would come up at Sunday's summit. The administration opposed direct economic aid as recently as last July at the economic summit of seven industrial nations in Houston. But, Fitzwater said of the Soviets, ``They have sent ships to the gulf. They have been supportive. President Gorbachev has made some strong public statements'' of support for the U.N.-backed trade embargo against Iraq. He said Gorbachev's words ``have a political impact in the world of countries that have formally been aligned with the Soviet Union that is very hard to measure, but one which we know is real and has been very helpful'' Furthermore, Fitzwater said, the United States is ``willing to talk'' with the Soviet Union about a longstanding Soviet proposal _ revived on Tuesday by Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze _ for a Middle East peace conference. The conference, which the United States long has opposed, would seek to resolve all conflicts in the region, including the Arab-Israeli dispute. In the past, Moscow has been Iraq's principal arms supplier. However, after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Kremlin cut off arms sales although several hundred Soviet military advisers remained in Iraq. Some lawmakers, back from visits to the Middle East, urged Bush at the White House on Wednesday to press Gorbachev to pull Russian military advisers out of Iraq and to provide the United States with intelligence information on Iraq's military capability. But, as to the military advisers, Fitzwater said: ``There is no sense in getting argumentative with the Soviets on this issue.'' Fitzwater portrayed the continued presence of the Soviet advisers as a ``marginal'' problem, and not one that threatened the effectiveness of the embargo against Iraq. The spokesman said that Bush wants to discuss with Gorbachev the status of an International Monetary Fund review of Soviet economic needs. The study was commissioned at the Houston summit as a compromise between the United States, which opposed direct economic aid to the Soviets, and West Germany and France, which favored it. Noting reports of bread shortages and other economic deprivations in the Soviet Union, Fitzwater said: ``We'll be very interested in President Gorbachev's analysis of what his problems are and whether or not the West can be helpful and in what areas.'' Fitzwater said he did not expect a final resolution of the economic aid issue at Helsinki. Meanwhile, administration officials said it now seems unlikely that Bush will stop in Brussels on his way home from Helsinki to brief allies on the Gorbachev summit _ as had been discussed earlier. The White House said Bush had decided to postpone until later in the month a political trip to Colorado and California that had been scheduled for next Tuesday and Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Chiles, Nelson Pledge Unity Against Martinez
DOC.TEXT: Democrats rallied Wednesday around their landslide gubernatorial primary winner, Lawton Chiles, who launched what's expected to be a tough general election campaign against Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. In Nevada, political newcomer Jim Galloway opened his Republican gubernatorial campaign by trying to draw Democratic incumbent Gov. Bob Miller into a debate. Florida's first-term governor was spoiling for a fight, saying in Tampa that he'd leave the rallies to the Democrats. ``We've had the unity. We don't need the rally,'' said Martinez, who got 69 percent of the vote in Tuesday's GOP primary. Democratic officeholders ranging from Sen. Bob Graham to county commissioners joined about 250 people Wednesday on the steps of the Capitol to celebrate the victory by the man nicknamed ``Walkin' Lawton.'' Chiles and running mate Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay of Ocala, a former congressman, got 69 percent of the vote and carried 65 of 67 counties in defeating Bill Nelson, a six-term congressman from Melbourne. Nelson criticized Chiles sharply during the campaign for accepting what he called ``sweetheart'' financial deals. He also suggested that Chiles wasn't healthy enough to handle the governor's office; Chiles had said he was burned out when he decided in 1988 against re-election to the U.S. Senate and later revealed he'd been taking antidepressant drugs. On Wednesday, Nelson called that a ``family fight'' and said he and his running mate, House Speaker Tom Gustafson, were committed to supporting the Chiles-MacKay ticket. ``I decided to come here today not just to say pretty words, but to suggest some things I could do,'' Nelson said. Later, he went to the Chiles headquarters to telephone supporters about contributing to the party nominee. Chiles said he held no grudges: ``The enduring friendship that we have, and have had over the years, did endure.'' According to complete but unofficial vote totals, Chiles got 739,916 votes, or 69 percent, to Nelson's 325,448 votes, or 31 percent. In the GOP race, Martinez got 457,952 votes, also 69 percent, to state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard's 131,782 votes, or 20 percent. Three other candidates split the rest of the Republican vote. Chiles has run well ahead of Martinez in most polls, but the governor has begun to close the gap recently. Martinez has a huge campaign war chest ready for the campaign and plans a new television ad blitz beginning this week. Martinez called for debates before journalists, which Chiles has said he doesn't like. He said he did not intend to bring up questions of Chiles' health but hinted that voters should watch the Democratic nominee closely. ``People will make that judgment _ how healthy he is by the vigor he may show, how he addresses debates or does he stay vague, does he speak on the issues?'' Martinez said. In Nevada, it was the challenger, Gallaway, who said he wanted to get the governor ``out from behind his desk'' to debate. Final results of the voting were delayed by massive computer failures in the Las Vegas area, where most of the state's voters live. Clark County election officials blamed computer glitches, poorly trained volunteers and soggy ballots for a vote count fiasco that left some local candidates guessing their fate the day after the election. But nearly complete returns showed Miller, who is seeking a full term in the job he inherited two years ago, winning the Democratic primary with 66,998 votes, or 81 percent. He was followed by ``None of the Above'' _ a protest option on all Nevada ballots that tallied 6,754 votes, or 8 percent; and a long-shot hopeful named Rhinestone Cowboy with 2,308 votes, or 3 percent. Gallaway, a businessman and newcomer to Nevada politics, had 35,628 votes, or 50 percent, in his eight-way GOP race. ``None of the Above'' drew 15,637 votes, or 22 percent, and builder Charlie Brown had 14,966 votes, or 21 percent.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Seeks Wide-Ranging Constitutional Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with ANC saying Thursday meeting with government still scheduled, comments by defense minister, Inkatha leader, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Calling South Africa's anti-apartheid course ``irreversible,'' President F.W. de Klerk on Wednesday invited groups of all races to join negotiations on a new constitution. ``Now is the time to wipe out petty differences,'' he said. The government and African National Congress were scheduled to continue talks Thursday, despite tension over the army's involvement in a township shooting that killed 11 people. An ANC spokeswoman said she knew of no change in the plans for Thursday's meeting. ANC leader Nelson Mandela visited black townships near Johannesburg wracked by fighting that has killed more than 550 people since Aug. 12. Mandela repeated accusations that police fueled the fighting by siding with Zulu backers of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC. Police deny the charges and say they have prevented the violence from escalating. Defense Minister Gen. Magnus Malan said black leaders appeared unable to control their followers and should stop blaming police and soldiers for the unrest. Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said a meeting with Mandela could help curb the violence, but Mandela has refused such a meeting. The ANC blames Inkatha for starting the recent fighting, but an Inkatha youth leader accused the ANC on Wednesday of trying to wipe out his group's members. The townships were reported quiet Wednesday after a day in which 40 people were killed. ``A momentum has begun which is making the negotiation process irreversible,'' de Klerk told a governing National Party congress in the central city of Bloemfontain. ``We will not turn back, nor will we be stopped at giving every South African a say in decision-making.'' He said all parties were welcome in talks on power-sharing between the black majority and the ruling whites. De Klerk has proposed the National Party accept non-whites as members, and he says he wants a new constitution within five years that will bring blacks into the national government. However, he has stated opposition to black majority rule and a one-person, one-vote system. The government opened talks this year with the ANC, the main black opposition group, on halting anti-government violence and removing other obstacles toward constitutional negotiations. Government and ANC committees were scheduled to meet Thursday to discuss the ANC's decision last month to suspend its armed struggle. The talks were expected to focus on the status of ANC guerrillas, both inside and outside South Africa, as well as what to do with existing arms caches in the country, several newspapers reported. Meanwhile, violence has raged in black townships near Johannesburg. In Sebokeng, south of the city, soldiers opened fire Tuesday on a crowd outside a migrant workers' hostel, leaving 11 dead. Many in the crowd were ANC supporters. Police and army officials said they would investigate the shooting. The Congress of South African Trade Unions, the nation's largest labor federation, and a group of Anglican bishops led by Archbishop Desmond Tutu echoed Mandela's call for a judicial inquiry of the Sebokeng shootings. In March, police opened fire on black protesters, killing at least five and wounding 150. A judicial inquiry last week concluded the gunfire was not necessary. The ANC suspended talks with the government after the March shooting. Also Wednesday, police said they will bar the news media from areas of unrest when they believe demonstrators are acting up for journalists. Police spokesman Capt. Eugene Opperman said the final decision on whether to order journalists away from an area would be left to the commanding officer. Opperman said police could order journalists to leave unrest areas under emergency regulations in the townships.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to include that ceremony is Roman Catholic and clarify marital status of parents
DOC.TEXT: Kara Kennedy, the 30-year-old daughter of Massachusetts Sen. Edward Kennedy and ex-wife Joan, will marry Washington, D.C., architect Michael Allen to the tune of gospel music this weekend. Singers from Boston's Twelfth Baptist Church will croon hymns and spirituals during Saturday's Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville, Cape Cod. The wedding reception will be held at the house of Kara's grandmother, Rose Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrat Wants Japan To Pay More For U.S. Defense
With AM-Gulf-US Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A member of the House Democratic leadership, angered by Japan's slow response to aid the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis, on Wednesday called for forcing the Asian nation to pay for U.S. troops stationed in Japan. Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., the fourth ranking Democrat in the House, said he wrote his measure, which will be offered when the House considers the fiscal 1991 defense bill, before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month. But the chief deputy majority whip said the amendment is ``needed now more than ever.'' Japan has announced that it would supply the United States with a $1 billion assistance package, but Bonior said it seems now that the aid will be delayed. ``Everyone is bellying up and doing their part, and they're hanging back. I think that's grossly unfair,'' Bonior told a news conference. The Michigan Democrat complained that U.S. forces in the gulf region are protecting the oil interests of American allies, including Japan which can afford to pay for its defense as well as the defense of oil supplies. ``Too often we have seen Japanese promises and no action. They should pay a greater share in the Persian Gulf and they should pay for our troops protecting Japan,'' Bonior said. According to Bonior's estimates, the United States spends $4.5 billion annually to station about 50,000 U.S. troops in Japan while the Asian nation contributes $2.9 billion. Under the amendment, President Bush would have one year to negotiate with Japan on having them foot the bill. If Japan refuses, 5,000 troops would be withdrawn at the end of September 1991 and each year afterward. While calling for increased Japanese aid in the gulf region, Bonior dismissed suggestions that Japan should share in the leadership as the United States undertakes Operation Desert Shield. ``I am not for them calling any military shots. I would strongly argue against the deployment of Japanese defense forces beyond what has already been agreed to,'' Bonior said. The Democratic leader said he expects the House to take up the defense authorization bill next week.

DOC.HEAD: Widely Spread Rain And High Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Rain and thunderstorms were scattered across broad sections of the nation Wednesday, and hot weather continued from the central Plains into the Ohio Valley. Kansas City, Mo., hit a record high of 95. Several schools in Nebraska scheduled early class dismissals for a second day this week because of the heat and lack of air conditioning in classrooms. Showers and thunderstorms extended from western New York state across northern and western Pennsylvania during the afternoon, and across eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia and Maryland, with a threat of heavy rain. Showers and storms also reached over Florida, southeastern Louisiana, and along the lower Texas Gulf Coast. Late Tuesday, wind up to 78 mph ripped the roof from at least one building and knocked out power to 46,000 homes and businesses during a brief but heavy thunderstorm that hit the New Orleans area. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over western Upper Michigan, northwestern Wisconsin, east-central through northwestern Minnesota and eastern North Dakota. Showers and storms extended over the southern half of New Mexico, north-central Colorado, southwestern Montana, northeastern Wyoming, eastern Idaho, southern Nevada and southeastern California. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.48 inches at West Palm Beach, Fla., and 0.86 of an inch at the Naval air station near Jacksonville, Fla. Tropical Storm Isidore formed over the Atlantic but was not a threat to any major land area. Its center was 750 miles southwest of the Cape Verde islands off the coast of Africa. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 57 at San Simeon, Calif., to 102 at Longview, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Lord Caradon, Former British Ambassador to United Nations, Dead
DOC.TEXT: Lord Caradon, the former British permanent representative to the United Nations, died Wednesday in a Plymouth nursing home. Caradon was 82, said his son, Paul Foot. No cause of death was given for Caradon, who spent more than 30 years in Britain's former Colonial Office, and helped four colonies gain independence. He was not afraid to differ with the governments he served and once resigned rather than defend a policy he did not support. Caradon was born Hugh Foot on Oct. 8, 1907, the son of a distinguished political family. His brother, Michael, was leader of the Labor Party opposition from 1980 to 1983 and remains a Labor member of parliament. Caradon was educated at Leighton Park, a Quaker school at Reading and at Cambridge University. He was president of the Cambridge Union, a student body, in 1929. Later that year he entered the old Colonial Office, which was responsible for administering Britain's colonies. In 1943, he was appointed Colonial Secretary in Cyprus, acting as governor in 1944. The next 13 years he held a variety of Colonial Office posts, including the Chief Secretary in Nigeria and Governor-in-Chief of Jamaica. He was knighted in 1951. From 1957-60, Caradon was Governor and Commander-in-Chief in Cyprus. He is credited with bringing the rival Greek and Turkish leaders together and he left the island having completed his mission to forge a new independent republic. A government citation praises his ``wisdom, courage and humanity, and his unwearying efforts in the Cyprus negotiations.'' In 1961, Caradon went to the United Nations as British Representative on the Trusteeship Council. But he did not agree with what he considered the British government's lenient attitude toward the white minority in the colony of Rhodesia and resigned rather than speak for a policy he did not support. In 1963, he was appointed consultant to the U.N. Special Fund, dealing with the governments of newly independent countries on matters of economic development. The British government made him a life peer in 1964 and sent him to the United Nations as Permanent Representative, a post he held until 1970. During this time he gathered support for sanctions against Ian Smith's Rhodesia after Smith made his Unilateral Declaration of Independence. He also served on the U.N. Expert Group on South Africa. He retired in 1970, but continued with some of his United Nations activities, becoming a consultant on the U.N. Development Programme. In a television interview, Caradon admitted he never smiled when journalists were nearby. ``It was one of the first lessons I learned in the diplomatic service,'' he confided. ``You never know when there may be a stray photographer near and in the newspapers the next morning, alongside the headlines saying `100,000 people dead,' there is a picture of you smiling all over your face.'' Caradon married Florence Tod in 1936. She died in 1985. He is survived by three sons and a daughter. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Government Extends State of Emergency in Capital, Rebels Kill Boy
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday extended the state of emergency in the nation's capital by 30 days and limited freedoms to help the military fight leftist guerrillas. Meanwhile, police said rebels of the Maoist Shining Path group killed a 9-year-old boy in a highland village attack Tuesday. The boy was shot once with a rifle when he tried to run from Nueva Florida after about 15 rebels invaded the village 45 miles northeast of Ayacucho, police said. Ayacucho, a stronghold of the Shining Path, is 230 miles southeast of Lima. The state of emergency was first imposed in Lima and its nearby port of Callao in early August. A military decree issued Wednesday replaced the police state of emergency that had been in effect. The decree suspends freedom of travel and assembly and allows authorities to detain people without court hearings and to search homes without warrants. All or part of 10 other states, representing more than one-third of Peru's territory, also are under emergency rule. More than half the country's 22 million people live in these areas. Almost 20,000 Peruvians have died in political violence in the 10 years since the Shining Path first took up arms against the government.

DOC.HEAD: Decade-Long Study Says Acid Rain Isn't an Environmental Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A $537 million, decade-long study ordered by Congress concluded Thursday that acid rain should be ``viewed as a long-term problem'' requiring pollution controls but is not the environmental crisis some scientists have suggested. The report by the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program was embraced both by those who support steep cuts in sulfur dioxide emissions and by critics of such cuts. The critics have long claimed that severe pollution controls, costing as much as $5 billion a year, are an overreaction to the acid rain problem. In its final draft report, the scientific group, known as NAPAP, reiterated that pollution-control measures are needed to return hundreds of lakes and streams _ especially in the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states _ to healthy conditions. The report also acknowledged that acid rain is affecting visibility across much of the East; causes damage to some forests, particularly red spruce at higher elevations; reduces soil nutrients; kills some aquatic life; erodes buildings and statutes, and poses health problems to some humans exposed to acidic aerosols. James Mahoney, director of NAPA, outlined the draft report to a final meeting of the group and said its findings have ``reduced the scientific uncertainties'' about acid rain. ``Acid rain is correctly viewed as a long-term problem which should be resolved by permanent measures,'' he concluded, summarizing the findings. Mahoney said that while the study supports many of the scientific views expressed over the years on acid rain it also rejected other, ``more extreme views'' such as those that consider it ``a flat-out crisis'' or those ``who would say there's no problem at all.'' NAPAP was established by Congress in 1980 to improve the understanding of acid rain. During its decade of work it spent $537 million. The report stopped short of endorsing specific control requirements, including the 10-million-ton cut in sulfur dioxide emissions required by legislation nearing approval in Congress. The study said, however, that if annual sulfur dioxide emissions were cut by 10 million tons the damaging trends would be reversed. Such emission controls would lead to the ``chemical recovery'' of lakes in the Adirondacks, where the acid rain problem is said to be most severe, and protect lakes in the higher elevations of the mid-Atlantic states. It also would reduce other damages caused by acid rain and improve visibility. But the pollution controls would not be cheap, with the expense increasing sharply as steeper emission reductions are put in place. An 8-million-ton reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions would cost $1.7 billion to $2.7 billion a year, while cuts of 10 million tons would cost as much as $4 billion a year, the study estimated. The most severe pollution control requirements would have to be imposed on electric utilities, especially those burning high-sulfur coal in the Midwest, for the results to be effective, the study said. The National Coal Association issued a statement urging that Congress ease its acid rain pollution controls in light of the NAPAP study. ``The report provides strong evidence that there is time to implement more cost-effective ways in which to mitigate the limited environmental impacts of acid rain,'' said Richard Lawson, the association's president. But Eileen Claussen, a senior director involved with air pollution issues at the EPA, said the NAPAP report ``clearly establishes the link between (sulfur) emissions and environmental damage'' and supports the Bush administration's call for tough pollution controls by coal-burning electric utilities. President Bush has supported legislation calling for utilities to reduce annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the end of the decade. Clean air legislation approved by the House and Senate and awaiting action by a conference committee would require such reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Expands Dialogue with Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT that U.S. will open talks with Cambodia, sted expand talks with Vietnam. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The United States will open talks with Cambodia in an effort to reach an agreement that could end that country's nearly 20 years of civil war, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Wednesday. ``We don't suggest for one minute that we're home on Cambodia, but we think things are moving in the right direction,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He said the United States would hold talks in Laos with representatives of Hun Sen, prime minister of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian government. The United States said in July that it would begin talks with Vietnam on the Cambodian civil war. The Bush administration has withdrawn its diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which included the Communist Khmer Rouge. Last month, the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council announced an agreement on the main elements of a settlement. But Sunday, Cambodian President Heng Samrin said his intention was ``to maintain the status quo _ both politically and militarily.'' Still, Baker told the committee the administration was pleased with the action taken by the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. ``We think that offers the greatest prospect for a stable outcome to the conflict,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Wiretap Scandal Shakes Israeli Government, Divides Jews
DOC.TEXT: A scandal dubbed Israel's Watergate eclipsed news of the Persian Gulf crisis here Wednesday, featuring accusations of high-level political fraud and questions on the propriety of wiretapping under Jewish law. It rattled nerves in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's narrow-based coalition Cabinet and renewed tension between Israel's two main communities _ Sephardic Jews from Africa and the Middle East and Ashkanazim of European origin. National Police Commissioner Yaacov Turner, under fire for investigating Interior Minister Ariyeh Deri, defended himself against charges by Deri's supporters that the probe began because Deri is a Sephardic Jew born in Morocco. ``It's crazy,'' Turner said. ``To prevent an investigation they are willing to break up an entire people. Whoever helps this along is worse than a criminal.'' Police Minister Roni Milo, of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc, said he will summon Turner on Thursday to discuss that comment. A statement from Milo's office, carried by Israel television, said Turner's comments ``dealt with issues . . . not related to proper functioning of the police force and its national tasks.'' The scandal began last week with reports that five people were held on suspicion of bugging the telephone of investigative reporter Mordechai Gilat of the newspaper Yediot Ahronot. A recorder was found on a motorcycle outside Gilat's home, with wires running through his phone box and into his Tel Aviv apartment. Gilat wrote articles in June that led to police investigation of Deri, 31, a leading member of the ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians Party, known by the Hebrew acronym Shas. Deri is suspected of misappropriating millions of shekels in government money by diverting funds from local councils to religious institutions after taking office in December 1988. A shekel is worth just over 50 cents. Deri denied the charges on national TV. Both he and police have refused to comment on his interrogation by investigators Tuesday. Israeli reports said Wednesday police also suspected Deri had advance knowledge about Gilat's being wiretapped. Deri has not commented. Deri's supporters seek to use the tapes as a possible way to exonerate him. Some Israeli reports said the recordings contained conversations between Gilat and Turner, coordinating their moves. The issue led to radio discussions by religious experts on what Jewish law has to say about admitting a wiretap as evidence. Some rabbis argued that 13th-century sage Gershon Ben Solomon of Arles, France, ordered a man punished for reading someone else's mail without consent. The same principle could be applied to a wiretap, they reasoned. Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef of Shas, a former chief Sephardic rabbi, said nobody could hide his words or deeds from God. ``The Almighty has a tape with television pictures,'' he was quoted as telling followers. ``Nobody can go to heaven and claim to the creator, `I never said such things.''' Deri's supporters demand the tapes be declared legal evidence and that Turner be ousted if found to be in the wrong. Gilat won a Supreme Court injunction Monday barring use of the tapes. Questions over Turner's role also motivated Shas leaders to charge Deri was being persecuted because of his North African origins. ``It is all a plot against the Sephardic community,'' Israel radio quoted Rabbi Shabtai Atun, a Shas supporter, as saying. The Sephardim comprise about 60 percent of Jewish Israelis. The Ashkanazim, who gained political power in pre-state Israel, still dominate the government, however. Cabinet members from Shas raised the Deri issue at Sunday's Cabinet meeting. News reports said Communications Minister Raphael Pinchasi of Shas won Shamir's promise that the fraud probe against Deri would be carried out quickly before it could upset the political balance. Shas has five seats in the 120-member Parliament, but is a key player among the 10 parties in Shamir's government. It brought down Shamir's coalition with the Labor Party on March 15 by abstaining in a vote of no confidence. Wiretaps also were featured in the Watergate scandal that drove Richard Nixon from the presidency in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Party Chief Threatens to Quit Politburo
DOC.TEXT: Armenia's Communist Party chief has threatened to quit the Soviet Politburo unless President Mikhail S. Gorbachev can restore order in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, news reports said Wednesday. Meanwhile, the Armenian parliament passed a resolution complaining that citizens of the predominantly Armenian territory located inside the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan are having their rights trampled upon, the Tass news agency reported. ``The Armenian population of Nagorno-Karabakh continues to be subject to terror on the part of Azerbaijani authorities, assisted by units of the Soviet army and Interior Ministry troops,'' Tass quoted the resolution as saying. A state of emergency is in effect in the mountainous region, part of Azerbaijan since 1923. Ethnic battles between residents of the two Caucasus republics over who should control the area have left more than 200 people dead the past two years. Vladimir Movsisyan, the Communist Party leader of Armenia, said in an appeal published in the republic's newspapers Wednesday that indifference and indecision on the part of the Soviet leadership have given Azerbaijan's leaders ``a free hand to pursue an anti-Armenian policy,'' according to the independent Interfax news service. It quoted him as saying misinformation circulated about Armenians' ``aggressive activity'' in Azerbaijan has put the two republics on the verge of war. Movsisyan, who as the republic's Communist Party leader is a member of the Soviet Politburo, threatened to resign unless the Nagorno-Karabakh issue is solved as soon as possible so that Armenian lives in the region are protected, Tass and Interfax reported. The president of Azerbaijan, Ayaz Mutalibov, also has accused the Soviet authorities of inaction in the dispute, and he has issued a different kind of threat _ that his republic may secede from the Soviet Union if the Kremlin does not act to ``normalize the situation'' in Nagorno-Karabakh. Mutalibov made the threat in an interview published Tuesday in the newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya. Movsisyan said a natural gas pipeline to Yerevan, Armenia's capital, has been shut off, and freight trains have stopped arriving in the city of Idzhevan, costing the republic tens of millions of rubles. In addition, Azerbaijani authorities are forcing Armenians to leave their homes in Nagorno-Karabakh, in order to change the demography of the region, the Armenian parliament's resolution was quoted by Tass as saying. The parliament urged that Interior Ministry and Soviet army troops be deployed immediately along the borders of Nagorno-Karabakh and adjacent areas to restore Soviet authority and self-government in the area, Tass reported. Last week, the Armenian parliament banned the Armenian National Army, created last winter as a vigilante group to protect the mostly Christian population of Armenia from the mostly Moslem population of Azerbaijan. Lawmakers acted after the militant nationalist group was blamed for the shooting deaths of a member of parliament and another man. Gorbachev has demanded that militants in the republic disarm and disband paramilitary groups, but Armenian leaders say they can police their own population.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Denies Newspaper's Right to Use Union Logo
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leaders decided Wednesday to bar Poland's biggest daily newspaper from displaying the union's logo in another move that reflects the deepening split in the labor movement's ranks. The trade union's National Commission at its weekly meeting in Gdansk voted 26-21 with 12 abstentions to take away the union logo from the Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper. A newspaper spokeswoman later said it would comply with the decision. Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa was not present for the vote. Walesa in June questioned the use of the logo by Gazeta Wyborcza, which is published by a private company. The newspaper was the first independent daily to be published legally in Poland after decades of Communist rule. The editor-in-chief, Adam Michnik, defended the daily's right to use the logo at that time. Michnik, a historian and longtime adviser to Walesa, stressed in a June 6 editorial that the daily was a direct continuation of the union's underground press. After Wednesday's vote, Solidarity's national spokeswoman Barbara Malak announced she was resigning to protest the leadership's decision. ``The logo was treated as a censorship tool directed against the press and other media. I had to decide whether or not to accept my job as spokeswoman when it comes to using censorship,'' Ms. Malak told the PAP news agency. Alina Bialkowska, a senior editor reached at Gazeta's office, said the newspaper would remove the Solidarity logo and publish a statement by the editorial staff on Thursday. ``The newspaper will remain the same _ independent _ like it has been all the time,'' she said. Gazeta Wyborcza was founded in May 1989 as a result of the round-table agreements that restored Solidarity's legal status. The union was banned by Communist authorities after the December 1981 martial law crackdown. Early editions of the newspaper focused on elections to parliament in which Solidarity scored easy victories. Although generally supportive of Solidarity, the daily has ceased to be a union mouthpiece since the creation of a non-Communist government a year ago. It has defended the policies of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and taken a lukewarm attitude toward Walesa's ambitions to become Poland's president. Michnik is a leader of the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, a recently formed Solidarity-related political group that supports Mazowiecki. The staff of Gazeta Wyborcza denies it is aligned with the group.

DOC.HEAD: Parents of Son Slain on Subway Goes Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a tourist from Utah who was stabbed to death in a subway mugging testified to a grand jury Wednesday before heading home for the funeral. Sherwin and Karen Watkins looked tired and pained as they entered Manhattan Criminal Court shortly before noon to testify about how their son, Brian, was stabbed to death chasing youths who robbed his father. The couple, escorted by detectives from the district attorney's office, did not speak to reporters. Mrs. Watkins left the courtroom about 90 minutes later and bought a newspaper to read while her husband testified. Reporters who tried to speak with her were blocked by a burly man who said, ``They don't want to talk to the press.'' The family plans to hold a news conference Thursday afternoon after their return to Provo, Utah, according to David G. Hansen, the family's Mormon bishop. Funeral services for Brian Watkins were scheduled for Saturday in Provo. On Sunday, the 22-year-old tennis buff, his parents, his brother, Todd, and Todd's wife, Michelle, had been at the U.S. Open in Queens and were waiting for a train in a midtown subway station at around 10:20 p.m. when they were attacked. The family was approached by a group of youths who sliced open Sherwin Watkins' pants and took a money clip containing about $200 and some credit cards. One punched Mrs. Watkins in the face. The brothers interceded and Brian was stabbed, but started to give chase before collapsing. He died 40 minutes later. The youths robbed the Watkinses because they wanted money to go dancing at the nearby Roseland Ballroom, police said. The grand jury was considering charges of second-degree murder and first-degree assault against eight youths, including Yull Garry Morales, 18, who police accuse of stabbing Watkins. The eight, who pleaded not guilty at their arraignment, were ordered held without bail. A return court date was set for Friday, said Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for the Manhattan district attorney. Besides Morales, the suspects were identified by police as Anthony Anderson, Pascal E. Carpenter, Emiliano Fernandez, Ricardo Lopez, Johnny Hincapie and Ricardo Nova, all 18, and Luis Fernando Montero, 22. A double-edged ``butterfly'' knife, believed to have been the murder weapon, was recovered. The Queens youths belonged to a gang known as FTS _ an abbreviation for an obscene phrase _ which required would-be members to mug someone as an initiation rite, the New York Times reported. Quoting former members of the gang, the Times said the gang liked to rob people ``for the hell of it'' and had two passions: graffiti and dancing. A city police spokesman, Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, said however that the group was not known to the department's Youth Gang Intelligence Unit. ``We never knew of them as being an organized group. They may have been involved in graffiti in Queens.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Picks Head Of State's Office on Aging as Running Mate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 12th graf might offend some readers.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LJ3
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard chose Olivia Maynard, head of the state's office on aging, as his running mate in a move that could placate women and senior citizens angered when he dumped 78-year-old Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths. The governor denied picking Maynard, 54, to mollify those interest groups. The senior citizens' and women's groups told him they supported his initial decision, Blanchard said. But he added that picking Maynard will bring a ``new sense of enthusiasm'' about his Democratic ticket. Amid the controversy, Blanchard's Republican opponent, Senate Majority Leader John Engler, last week chose a state Sen. Connie Binsfeld, 66, as his running mate. Her selection was expected to be ratified at the GOP convention, which begins Friday in Detroit. Blanchard had a double-digit lead over Engler in a poll conducted in late July. Blanchard, seeking his third four-year term, described Maynard as a fighter for senior citizens and people living on fixed incomes. ``I trust her with power, I trust her with decisions, I trust her ability to work and select good people and I trust her with the future of this state,'' he said. Maynard was head of the Michigan Democratic Party from 1979 to 1983 and has been director of the state's Office of Services to the Aging since March 1983. Blanchard, 48, announced Aug. 24 that he was replacing Griffiths on the Democratic ticket after two terms because he didn't feel she was ready to step in at any moment to take over as governor. The naming of his new running mate came one day after the crusty former congresswoman and long-time fighter for women's rights said she wouldn't oppose his decision at the state Democratic convention this weekend in Flint. The convention, which begins Friday, must ratify Blanchard's choice. Griffiths _ originally furious about Blanchard's decision _ also denied a published report she called the governor a ``son of a bitch'' last week. She said the reference was to politicans in general who dump someone after getting what they want. She dodged a question about whether he falls into the same category as other politicians, saying: ``You be the judge.'' Griffiths is widely credited with helping Blanchard first gain the governor's office in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Former Lottery Winner Found Crushed, Dead in Dump
DOC.TEXT: A man who won $188,000 in Florida's lottery last year will get a pauper's burial after he apparently was crushed to death in a trash bin following a night of drinking. Police say Roy Clark may have spent all the money he won in a Fantasy Five drawing, but on Wednesday they were looking for any relatives in case some cash or property remained. ``Poof!'' said Orange County sheriff's detective Tom McCann. ``I guess he just blew it.'' When Clark's body _ compacted by a garbage truck _ was found Friday at the Orange County dump, there was less than $10 in his pocket. It was the last of $40 he made the previous day working for a labor pool. Police said they didn't know whether Clark had anything left to show from his winnings. Detectives know that Clark, 39, spent at least some of his money buying rounds of drinks for friends and riding around in limousines. They traced much of the money through several bank accounts. He wrote checks for most of it from an account with Barnett Bank in Tallahassee. They said they had heard he invested in several businesses and that he bought a condominium in Hawaii and land in California. If true, those holdings would go to any heirs, but after nearly a week of looking for his next of kin, police haven't found anyone. Friends said he carried a picture of a young girl he said was his daughter, Brandy, whom he described as a student at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. But when detectives checked, they were told that no one named Brandy Clark was registered there. When he hit the lottery last September, Clark had been working for a sod company and living in an apartment building in Winter Park. He had become friends with the family across the hall, Chuck and Sandy Herbert. He moved away after hitting the lottery, and detectives said they believe he was living with another man in a rented trailer in east Orange County. In April, the Herberts said, Clark came to see them at their new home. He told them he was having some legal problems getting his winnings from the lottery and needed a place to stay. Until the week before he disappeared, Clark lived with the Herberts and their three children. They find it hard to believe he lied about not getting his winnings. ``He was a good man. He was always watching the kids for me. He loved them,'' said Sandy Herbert. ``Every time I look here or there, I can picture him holding the baby.'' He enjoyed snorkeling and watching National Geographic nature programs, she said. He didn't drink, carouse or take drugs, she said. Clark told the Herberts he would be gone for a few days on a business trip with his lawyer to try to get his lottery winnings. ``I can't see him leaving like that knowing he wasn't going to come back,'' Sandy Herbert said. ``He had a home here. Whatever happened to him in that week is the answer.''

DOC.HEAD: `Most Difficult Crime Scene'; Memorial Service Scheduled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with forensic specialist's quotes about crime scences, quotes from school officials at memorial services. Picks up 5th graf, `As the grisly ...'
DOC.TEXT: A forensic specialist said Wednesday the three apartments where the bodies of five college students were found ``the most difficult'' crime scenes he has ever seen. Dr. Michael West made the comment after hunting for fingerprints at the apartments with high-tech equipment.
