West, a dentist and deputy medical examiner from Hattiesburg, Miss., said the apartments gave clues of a careful, cautious killer. ``I've never been associated with a crime scene that had so many violent attacks and so litle evidence left behind,'' West said. ``This individual that perpetrated these crimes is not your average criminal. He's very methodical, and very neat. He doesn't leave any traces of his presence in the crime scenes.'' Students in Gainesville remembered their dead classmates at a memorial service in a 10,000-seat sports center. Also Wednesday, the University of Florida announced scholarships in memory of the students. Three of the victims were students at the University of Florida and two were from Santa Fe Community College. One of the two later enrolled in the university but hadn't attended classes. Their bodies were found late last month. ``We are struggling with the conflicting emotions of grief, anger and fear,'' college President John Lombardi told about 600 people attending the memorial service. Dr. Larry W. Tyree, president of Santa Fe Community College, said: ``With each horrible tragedy ... the sense of helplessness has grown in each of us.'' As the grisly job of examining evidence and looking for a killer continued, investigators divulged more brief glimpses into what they have learned about the crimes. West used an experimental reflective ultraviolet imaging system that intensifies light 70,000 times to examine two of the three crime scenes Tuesday for fingerprints; he returned Wednesday to look at the final apartment. The Miami Herald on Wednesday quoted sources as saying the killer cruelly posed his victims for maximum shock value. The killer placed Santa Fe Community College student Christa Hoyt's severed head in the direct line of vision of anyone entering the apartment and positioned a mirror in one of the apartments to show a victim's body to any passerby who happened to look in the window, the Herald reported. The killer also reportedly poured bleach onto the genitals of the four female victims in an apparent attempt to confuse investigators about whether the women were sexually assaulted, the newspaper said. Police would not confirm the report. Fluids removed from the murder scenes are being subjected to sophisticated DNA testing. Those tests are to be completed in a few days. The bodies of Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26. The body of Miss Hoyt, 19, was found the next day; the bodies of Tracy Paules, 23, and Manuel Taboada, 23, were found Aug. 28. ``This is the most difficult crime scene I've ever seen,'' said West, who has been a medical examiner for 13 years. He said he's been able to turn up some fingerprints ``but the odds are they belonged to the residents'' of the apartments. He said he hasn't been able to find any prints ``on the areas we believe the perpetrator to have touched, moved or manipulated.'' Despite the filing of unrelated new charges in Indian River County against Edward Lewis Humphrey for armed burglary and attempted sexual battery, police said it has not affected his position on their pool of eight suspects. ``An arrest is not imminent'' in the slayings, said Lt. Spencer Mann, a spokesman with the Alachua County Sheriff's Office. ``We still have no timetable on arrests or legal options.'' Only Humphrey and Stephen Michael Bates, a 30-year-old Lakeland short-order cook, have been publicly mentioned as being on the list. Bates has been held in the Polk County Jail on $100,500 bond since his Aug. 29 arrest in an unrelated assault case. Police in Dothan, Ala., also have contacted Gainesville police about the May stabbing death of Marilyn Mitchell, a nursing graduate from the University of Alabama, to see if that case is related. Polk County authorities have said they doubt Bates is the killer, but his fingerprints have been sent to the task force investigating the slayings. Humphrey faces the new charges after he was identified by a 27-year-old woman as the man who attacked her at knifepoint in 1988. She called police after seeing Humphrey's picture in a newspaper. ``He said something or did something in this case that is very similar to characteristics of the suspect in Gainesville,'' said Lt. Mary Lenz of the Indian River County Sheriff's Office.

DOC.HEAD: Bronze Age Sword Found in Irish Bog
DOC.TEXT: A Bronze Age sword nearly 3,000 years old has been found in an Irish bog by a workman, the National Museum in Dublin said Wednesday. Jim Kelly was working at the Littleton Bog in County Tipperary when he saw something sticking out of what had been the timbers of an ancient roadway, said Michael Ryan, the museum's expert. When Kelly tapped it with his boot the sword fell out, Ryan said. He said the sword was made of cast bronze and dates to the Bronze Age about 2,700 or 2,800 years ago. ``It's quite small but beautifully made and still very sharp and in very good condition, except for a little bit of surface corrosion,'' Ryan said. A team from the museum is now exploring the site. Ryan said bronze objects preserve well in bogs and several spearheads were found earlier in Littleton Bog.

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Asians' Pleas for Help Beginning to be Heard
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cries for help by tens of thousands of hungry Asians stranded in Jordan after fleeing Kuwait are finally being heard by other nations, but there still were concerns Wednesday that the aid could come too late. The multitudes, now living in makeshift desert camps, are fighting for food and water, and many are on the verge of starvation. Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan chided the international community earlier this week for its slow response to his government's pleas for aid. The International Organiztion for Migration announced Wednesday it would begin an airlift Thursday to evacuate 19,000 people over the next two weeks. It said it planned 72 flights at a cost of about $12 million. Foreign correspondents visiting the stinking camp at Salwa, near Ruweishid on the Jordanian-Iraqi border, were surrounded by hordes of bedraggled Bangladeshis and other Asian nationals pleading for deliverance from the blazing desert. ``Tell the world we will die here if we are not helped,'' was one of the anguished cries heard over and over in the camp on an expanse of stony desert. About 40,000 Asians are packed into the Salwa camp, which lacks basic sanitary and other amenities. Some are crammed into tents, but shelter for most is a woman's sari spread overhead to provide some shade from the fierce sun. The severe food shortage has forced people to fight over scraps of bread. The official Jordanian news agency Petra said Wednesday 605,277 evacuees had crossed into Jordan since Aug. 2, when the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sparked the exodus of foreigners from the two countries. The vast majority of evacuees have left Jordan, but 105,000 Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Indians, Sri Lankans, Thais and Filipinos are stranded in camps scattered throughout Jordan, waiting for transportation home, Petra said. Nearly 20,000 more cross into Jordan every day, but only half that number leave daily, the agency said. The West German government announced Tuesday it had dispatched an 167-seat aircraft that over the past 10 days evacuated 6,000 Egyptian nationals stranded at Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. Sweden, Denmark and Norway on Wednesday together pledged $14 million in aid; Finland pledged $2.5 million and Italy $3.4 million. The United Nations already has sent more than 3,000 metric tons of food and other supplies to Jordan, and received $19 million in aid, mainly from Japan and Sweden, said Robert Souria, a relief official with the agency. But he added, ``The international community needs to send more.'' Jordan's American-born Queen Noor hugged and kissed British tycoon Richard Branson when he flew into the Amman airport Tuesday night aboard a jumbo jet of his Virgin Atlantic Airline laden with 40 tons of supplies for the 100,000 stranded Asians on the verge of starvation. ``We are so grateful, we desperately needed this,'' the queen told Branson. Branson flew back to London with a planeload of Western women and children hostages who had been allowed to leave Iraq. ``There is a tremendous amount of concentration on a few British and a few American people coming out'' of Iraq, Branson told reporters. ``I feel it is slightly embarrassing being there with a big plane and there is a refugee camp 10 minutes away with thousands and thousands of people from India and Bangladesh, who may be waiting for months to get out.'' He said relief efforts should be coordinated by European nations to ensure that all aircraft arrive full of provisions and tents, and return full of Westerners.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Business Leaders to Help Soviets With Transportation, Housing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to include that delegation plans to meet with Gorbachev and Yeltsin.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. business leaders picked to go to the Soviet Union with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher this weekend represent some of the areas where the Soviets need the most help, such as housing and transportation. Mosbacher and 15 chief executive officers of U.S. companies are scheduled to leave for Moscow on Saturday for a week-long visit to discuss what kind of ``technical assistance'' the United States can give the Soviet Union. During the trip, they plan to meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Republic, said an administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Bush administration, while balking at providing the Soviet Union with cash grants or loans, agreed at the economic summit of industrial nations in Houston in July to provide the technical assistance. About 80 other nations receive American technical assistance, which can range from developing a fly-resistant wheat in Morocco to bringing down Bangladesh's fertility rate. The Soviets need help with improving their transportation infrastructure and housing, said business leaders who will make the trip. ``Big chunks of money are not what they want. They want to have the exposure to the management techniques and construction techniques and operating techniques that we take for granted,'' said Mark Hungerford, chairman and chief executive officer of Tanscisco Industries Inc. of San Francisco, a rail car company. Hungerford's company, for example, is engaged in a joint venture with the Soviets to help them with a heating system for tank rail cars that performs well in cold climates. His firm also is helping the Soviets to better transport petrochemical products. Another transportation firm _ Sea-Land Service Inc., of Edison, N.J. _ will be represented by its chief officer, Alex J. Mandl. Sea-Land specializes in ``global distribution networks,'' or establishing a way for goods to be transported by land and sea. The trip, Mandl said, gives him a chance to help both President Bush and his company. ``That part of the world is opening up. As long as the Iron Curtain was up, our distribution network did not participate in that part of the world. As that wall comes down, we have a chance to be in there,'' Mandl said. Leonard Sylk, chairman and chief executive officer of Shelter Systems Group of Hainesport, N.J., said the Soviets have been interested in his firm's expertise because it makes manufactured housing components, or the roofs, floors and walls that large-scale builders use in putting up houses. U.S. business leaders stand to gain if the Soviet economy improves, Sylk said. Other companies to be represented on the trip are, according to government sources: the Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. of Decatur, Ill.; Atlantic Richfield Co. of Los Angeles; the Chevron Corp., of San Francisco; Dresser Industries of Dallas; Fortune Magazine of New York; Glenair International of Del Mar, Calif.; The Louisiana Land and Exploration Co. of New Orleans; PaineWebber of New York; Pepsico Inc. of Purchase, N.Y.; Pruet Oil Co., of El Dorado, Ark.; Texaco Inc., of White Plains N.Y., and United Telecommunications of Westwood, Kan.

DOC.HEAD: An Irene Dunne Remembrance: Champagne Charm and Screwball Style
With AM-Obit-Dunne; also moved for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Irene Dunne filled the screen like a good vintage champagne in a Baccarat crystal goblet. She was bubbly, of course. But like that fine champagne, hers were small, neat bubbles compacted with years of flavor and refined ever so to explode not all at once but slowly and smoothly and surely. Dunne, who died Tuesday night in her Los Angeles home at 88, was one of the last of that great breed of film actors who delighted generations with those romantic frolics known as screwball comedies. Her portrayals were spontaneous, unexpected, flirty and winsome. They were tantalizing, frothy and intelligent. Above all, they were downright funny. She may have liked her dramatic roles more (``I Remember Mama,'' ``Magnificent Obsession''), but comedy made her a legend. She had an offhanded but charming way of delivering lines in a voice that sounded like sable brushing diamonds. Hers was not the clipped, patrician charm of Katharine Hepburn, or the coquettish zaniness of Carole Lombard. Her timing was better in a way. Ask her a question and she could say more with a turn of her head and a simple, ``Ahh,'' than with a long answer or even a ``yes'' or ``no.'' ``Cary (Grant) paid me one of the loveliest compliments of my life,'' she once remarked. ``He said I had the best timing of anyone he ever worked with. It must be something that comes naturally to you. My father had a keen sense of humor, which I think is different from having a sense of humor.'' Timing _ and attitude. ``It's not that I'm prudish. It's just that my mother told me never to enter any man's room in months ending in `r,' '' she tells Charles Boyer in ``Love Affair,'' a 1939 movie later made into ``An Affair to Remember,'' with Deborah Kerr and Cary Grant. In ``The Awful Truth,'' Leo McCarey's Academy Award-nominated crazy romp about a divorcing couple who scheme to get back together, Dunne (Lucy Warriner) turns the table on co-star Cary Grant (Jerry Warriner) in the classic Lola scene. She shows up as Jerry's alleged stripper-sister, Lola, at a formal dinner party given by his terribly proper fiancee and her terribly proper family. With an outfit that would make a streetwalker proud, Dunne swings into a stripper number she had seen Jerry's girlfriend of the moment, Dixiebelle, perform in a nightclub. Dixiebelle had a fan blow her skirts above her head during certain lyrics in the song. Lucy sings ``My Dreams Have Gone With the Wind'' _ and Dunne, who had a trained lyric soprano voice, butchers her singing talents in the most vulgar but funny ways: ``I used to dream about a cottage small A cottage small by the waterfall But I wound up with no dreams at all My dreams have gone with the wind.'' There is no fan as Lucy performs the embarrassing number. Instead, she makes the wind sounds herself and spreads her legs apart. ``This song has some wind effects in it, but you'll just have to use your imagination about them,'' she coos. Earlier in the movie, Lucy and Jerry have a courtroom custody battle for their wire-haired terrier, Mr. Smith. Dunne, with an all-knowing and alluring smile at the judge, hides the dog's favorite squeaky toy in her fur muff. He runs to her to prove whom he prefers. Love wins out, as it always does in these situations, despite Dunne's chilling promise to Grant: ``I wouldn't go on living with you if you were dipped in platinum.'' Dunne and Grant have another wonderful romp in Garson Kanin's ``My Favorite Wife,'' in which Dunne returns home after being shipwrecked and presumed dead for a number of years. She's spent the time with Randolph Scott, and Grant has remarried. ``How long does it take to tell a woman, `My wife's come back?' I can say it in two seconds. `My wife's come back.' You've had two days,'' she snaps at him. She also asks, ``Oh, by the way, how was my funeral?'' But the urbane charms drop ever so slightly in ``Life With Father.'' Here, Dunne is understanding, loving and the all-knowing wife to William Powell's irascible husband. ``You know,'' Dunne tells Zasu Pitts in the movie, ``I don't believe Clare has come right out and told me he loves me since we've been married. 'Course, I know he does because I keep reminding him of it. You have to keep reminding them.'' Grant loved working with Dunne and once summed up the delightful effects of her performance: He called it a lovely flirtation.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Tells Czech Descendants They Are Like ``Family''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with remarks at lunch. Picks up 9th graf, `Dubcek, now 68, ...' New Prague is pronounced new prayg. A longer version moved on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP5
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakian leader Alexander Dubcek feasted on sausages and potato dumplings Wednesday and told residents of a town founded by Czech immigrants they were like ``members of my family.'' ``I am glad that many of you have found a new mother country in the United States,'' the president of the Czechoslovakian parliament told a crowd of about 1,200 _ half the population of the southern Minnesota farming community. Children chanted ``Dubcek, Dubcek!'' and waved Czechoslovakian and American flags. ``I am especially glad that the new generation that is here does not forget the old country,'' he said through a translator. In an effort to inject life into Czechoslovakia's sagging economy, a six-member delegation including top ministers of industry and science is visiting Minnesota to learn about medical and computer technology. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a one-day visit to the state in June for similar reasons. Dubcek met with about 100 health care executives Tuesday at Medtronic Inc., the world's largest maker of cardiac pacemakers, in the Minneapolis suburb of Fridley. Dubcek said at a luncheon address Wednesday that the shift from a planned economy to a free market system will progress slowly and painfully over several years. ``Destruction of the totalitarian power is not enough,'' he said. ``It is necessary to rebuild the economic structure from scratch. We want to avoid the danger of excess inflation that has so badly hit our neighbors in Poland and Hungary.'' That can be spurred by foreign investment and joint ventures with American entrepreneurs, the Czechoslovakian leader said. ``Our industry is considerably sound, even if some of our industrial branches may be obsolete,'' he said. ``We have qualified workers and technicians who are experienced. We have a relatively low foreign debt.'' Earlier, Dubcek joined local and state officials for breakfast at Schumacher's New Prague Hotel. They ate the Czech sausage Jiternice with horseradish, along with biscuits, potato dumplings and scrambled eggs. Dubcek, now 68, was led the 1968 Prague Spring liberalization movement that was crushed by Warsaw Pact forces. Last year, he regained his post as head of parliament following two decades of political exile and relative obscurity. He told a crowd gathered on the steps of the St. Wenceslaus Church in New Prague that his years of struggle were worth the ultimate freedoms gained by his countrymen when they forced out the communist government. ``As the lessons of history say, `violence can never last forever,' '' he said. ``Truth and justice will come _ sometimes later _ but it will always come. ... the best witness of that is my good mood as I talk to you here. ``I can tell you frankly that to be here, I feel I am among members of my family,'' he said. New Prague was founded by Czech immigrants in the 1870s. More than 500,000 people with Eastern Europe roots live in Minnesota. State House Speaker Robert Vanasek, of New Prague, called Dubcek ``the greatest Slovak of the 20th century.''

DOC.HEAD: Secord Testifes That Ex-CIA Agent Shared In Arms Sale Profits
DOC.TEXT: Richard V. Secord testified Wednesday that a former CIA agent shared in Iran-Contra arms sale profits, but that records of the weapons deals ``were cooked'' after the scandal became public. The retired Air Force major general was the lead-off witness in the government's tax case against Thomas G. Clines, the retired CIA agent who is accused of under-reporting some of his arms sale earnings on his 1985 and 1986 tax returns. The trial in U.S. District Court focuses on profits during the Iran-Contra affair, which involved the sale of arms to Iran and efforts to supply weapons to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua at a time when Congress banned such assistance. Clines, 62, of Middleburg, Va., also is charged with failing to tell the Internal Revenue Service about overseas financial accounts. If convicted, he faces up to 16 years in prison and fines of up to $1 million. Secord pleaded guilty last year to a felony count of making false statements to the Iran-Contra congressional committees. He was sentenced in January to two years' probation. Secord said he asked Clines in early 1985 to help obtain weapons for the rebels fighting the Sandinista government in Nicaragua. Secord said Clines agreed. ``He managed the procurement,'' he said. ``He used his contacts in the Communist East Bloc of Europe and western part of Europe to procure the infantry weapons that were needed.'' Clines often worked out of a ``closet office'' in Lisbon, Portugal, he said. Clines initially received 20 percent of the profits, and began receiving 30 percent in 1986, Secord said. The remaining shares went to Secord, Iranian-born businessman Albert Hakim and various companies, the general testified. Prosecutors claim Clines received about $882,000 in commissions in the arms deals. Some of the money was kept in a Swiss bank account code-named ``C. Tea,'' the prosecutors said. Clines reported gross earnings of $265,000 for the tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, according to a four-count indictment returned Feb. 22 in Baltimore. Secord said he couldn't remember much about the C. Tea account. ``I have a vague recollection that he (Clines) said there was such an account,'' Secord testified. ``I'm not sure Clines said anything to me about its purpose. According to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in 1987, the account was managed at a Geneva-based firm called Compagnie de Services Fiduciare, or CSF. Secord said he believed the CSF records were altered sometime after Congress began investigating the Iran-Contra affair. ``I believe the CSF ledgers were cooked,'' Secord said. ``I believe they were falsified in some respects.'' But when asked whether he had ever seen a forged document relating to Clines' profits, Secord said, ``I don't believe so.'' Under questioning from defense attorney Paula M. Junghans, Secord testified that Clines was not a shareholder, officer or director of any of the companies set up to channel Iran-Contra arms money. Rafael ``Chi Chi'' Quintero, a former contract agent for the CIA who began working for the Iran-Contra operation in early 1985, testified for the government under a grant of immunity. Quintero said Clines once told him that he had earned roughly $700,000 during the affair. He said he later overheard Clines tell his lawyer on the telephone that he had earned $750,000. Under cross-examination, however, Quintero testified that he did not know if the figures referred to gross earnings or what Clines had made after expenses or taxes. In her opening remarks, Junghans said Clines got involved in the affair because he was sympathetic to the Contras and it was an opportunity to make some money. ``There is no charge in this case that says it's a crime to buy and sell arms,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Forgiveness for Tribal Warfare, Repression
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with pope's comments on AIDS. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Now the...'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Wednesday urged forgiveness and reconciliation in this central African nation with a history of tribal warfare and repression of Roman Catholics. He also said the AIDS virus, which has ravaged Africa, was a moral issue that calls for changes in sexual behavior. The church condemns the use of condoms to check the spread of the deadly disease. The pope said the church has a duty to assist AIDS sufferers with health care and moral support. ``These people often tend to close themselves in an anguished silence,'' he said. The pope, who flew to the predominantly Catholic country from Tanzania, spoke on his arrival of the nation's tribal wars, ``trials that have scarred your people, dragged into conflicts which have torn your communities and wounded too many families.'' ``Now the path of reconciliation and harmony has opened before you,'' he said. ``You have made a beginning. Speed up the pace, and may no one hesitate to rediscover the fraternal path so that your hills never again experience division and violence.'' Burundi, a small mountainous nation of 6 million people which gained independence from Belgium in 1962, has suffered from a conflict between the Tutsi and Hutu tribes. Some 300,000 people, most of them Hutus, were killed in ethnic massacres 18 years ago. Violence exploded again in 1988, with at least 5,000 people killed in tribal fighting. In May, President Pierre Buyoya unveiled a charter saying his minority Tutsi tribe was preparing to share power with the majority Hutus. ``Hear my appeal,'' the pope said in French at the Bujumbura airport, where he was greeted by Buyoya. ``Consolidate your unity, not with resignation or fear, but rooting it solidly with reconciliation and forgiveness...your total reconciliation does not mean forgetting the past. You must look at it with truth. You must rediscover and overcome together that which divided you so that you can build a new life.'' The pope also hailed the ``cordial relations of mutual respect'' between church and state in Burundi, where about two-thirds of the people are Catholics. Under the previous regime of Col. Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, overthrown in a coup three years ago, missionaries were expelled, Catholic schools closed and weekday church services banned. Buyoya has restored full freedom for the church. Earlier in Moshi, Tanzania, John Paul celebrated Mass at the foot of Mount Kilimanjaro and implored rich countries to forge a ``new era of solidarity with Africa.'' ``Let the world not forget the urgent needs of Africa,'' he said. About 40,000 people attended the pope's Mass in Kilimanjaro Stadium, the former cricket and polo grounds of British rulers. As John Paul arrived in the popemobile, clouds that had obscured the 19,300-foot snowy peak of Africa's tallest mountain cleared. Gifts for the pope included a stuffed lion brought to the altar by a Masai Moran, or warrior, dressed in the tribe's traditional toga-like robe of red and blue. The pope, on his seventh visit to Africa, will also travel to Rwanda and the Ivory Coast, where he ends his tour Monday by consecrating the massive basilica of Our Lady of Peace.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage: Concern for Arabs is Misunderstood
DOC.TEXT: A teacher who was held hostage for six days in Iraq says her concern for Arabs is being misinterpreted as anti-American sentiment. Elizabeth Krekeler, a former Peace Corps volunteer who arrived at her home in Webster Groves late Sunday, said she has received two telephone calls from people angry about her statements on the Persian Gulf crisis. Krekeler has said she feels no bitterness toward Iraq or its leader, President Saddam Hussein, and that she opposes an embargo on shipments of food to Iraq. Krekeler, 50, said Tuesday she was expressing her concern for the welfare of the average Iraqi citizen. She added that she opposes Saddam's Aug 2 invasion of Kuwait, which touched off the U.S. military buildup in neighboring Saudi Arabia. ``I'm not a political person. I was over there to teach English and to build bridges for peace,'' Krekeler said. In Iraq, ``the average person on the street likes the United States. They're not political either.'' Krekeler was among 47 American hostages released on Sunday by Iraq and flown to the United States. Regarding her six-day stint as a hostage, Krekeler said she ``felt like a political pawn.'' Krekeler arrived in Baghdad on July 22 to take a job teaching English to Iraqi adults at the American Cultural Center, set up by the federally financed U.S. Information Service. She had just finished a two-year stint with the Peace Corps in Morocco. She said she plans to spend a few months visiting friends and family, and probably will look for work as a substitute teacher until she makes more permanent plans. Her goal is to find another teaching job overseas. ``I would like to go back there and build bridges,'' Krekeler said. ``I want to teach English and bring people closer together.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Senator's Widow In Wrongful Death Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf with two grafs to UPDATE with comment from Mrs. East's attorney. Picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Wednesday denied a $3.5 million wrongful death claim by the widow of Sen. John East, who contended that government doctors' failure to diagnose a thyroid disorder drove her husband to suicide. The first-term Republican killed himself June 19, 1986, by running his car in the closed garage of his Greenville, N.C., home. He left a suicide note blaming his doctors, saying, ``they ruined my life.'' Priscilla East, contended in her wrongful death lawsuit that Navy doctors, who provide care for members of Congress, were slow to detect her 55-year-old husband's thyroid condition. The suit said the delay triggered severe depression that led to the senator's suicide. U.S. District Judge Walter Black, who heard the case without a jury, ruled against Mrs. East. ``This is a truly tragic case,'' Black wrote in his opinion. ``However, the court has determined ... that the medical care rendered by the government doctors, while clearly not perfect, does not establish liability in this case.'' Ira Oring, the assistant U.S. Attorney who represented the government, said: ``The physicians have had to live with a cloud over their careers for some period of time. Essentially they have been vindicated and we're very happy for them.'' Terri Steinhaus, an attorney representing Mrs. East, said the lawyers believe ``the court's decision is unsupported by the evidence.'' Ms. Steinhaus said Mrs. East had no comment on the decision. She also said no decision has been reached on whether an appeal will be filed. The case was heard in Baltimore because that is the seat of the judicial district that includes Bethesda Naval Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Fund-Raising for $10 Million Headquarters Stirs Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES reference to ``arm-twisting'' in 2nd graf; SUBS 5th graf pvs, `It is ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT spelling to Cain sted Kane, and add title of his latest book
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: His late father's dream of a headquarters for the nation's largest black church is the jewel in the crown in the reign of the Rev. T.J. Jemison as president of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. ``That must be our Vatican. That must be our center of strength,'' Jemison said as he cajoled, pleaded for funds at the denomination's 110th annual meeting for the $10 million World Baptist Center some critics say is a monument to one man's ego. The center, with its 162-foot spire, 3,000-seat auditorium and 300-seat choir loft, was dedicated with great fanfare in June 1989 in Nashville, Tenn. With the Rev. Jesse Jackson at his side, Jemison said he was the ``instrument called by God'' to build the headquarters envisioned by his father, D.V. Jemison. For others, it revives the age-old controversy of whether church money should be spent on buildings or people. ``It is a travesty when we see the problems of drug abuse, teen-age parenting'' and other social ills, said Cain Felder, professor of New Testament at Howard Divinity School at Howard University and the author of ``Troubling Biblical Waters: Race, Class and Family.'' Even critics concede the headquarters _ the first one of its kind ever for a black church body _ is a tribute to the remarkable charismatic powers of Jemison. His father, elected president of the Baptist convention in 1941, was not able to realize his dream of giving the denomination an architectural monument of its own. Blind and in failing health, the Rev. D.V. Jemison was forced out of office by the Rev. Joseph H. Jackson in 1953, but not before he ensured his son was installed as general secretary of the denomination. T.J. Jemison had to wait 29 years before Jackson would be ousted from office, but he almost immediately set out to build a headquarters that would rival the buildings long taken for granted by most predominantly white denominations. In so doing, he may have permanently altered the way the denomination's 32,000 churches give financial support to the 7.8 million-member Baptist convention, which refers to itself as the largest black organization in the world. Jemison has made it clear annual contributions as low as $50 would no longer be acceptable, and has tried to recruit 100,000 ``Baptist builders'' to give at least $10 a month to pay off the $7 million still owed on the building. On Tuesday, Jemison devoted half of the denomination's board of directors meeting to taking up a collection for the center, raising half of the $1 million fund-raising goal he set for the annual meeting. Jemison continued fund-raising at the general convention Wednesday. ``Don't walk around with the money in your pocket,'' Jemison told the delegates. ``Don't get too happy and keep it to Friday.'' Felder said the center, with its ``palatial'' offices and prominently displayed portraits of Jemison, is a symbol of how the denomination has not fulfilled its potential for social change as the nation's largest black institution. ``It is a sleeping giant that tends to remain asleep. When it tends to wake up, it is filled with gross overindulgence,'' Felder said. Forrest Harris, director of the Kelly Miller Smith Institute on the Black Church at Vanderbilt Divinity School, said Jemison has a clear agenda for addressing social problems. But he said the jury is still out on Jemison's administration ``because so much energy has been invested in the building of the World Baptist Center.'' Even while raising funds, Jemison concedes he has his detractors. But he contends the center will be a catalyst for social action, including being a place where the homeless, drug abusers and people afflicted with AIDS will be cared for. The headquarters is a symbol of new independence for National Baptists, Jemison said. ``It's not for Jemison. It's not my ploy,'' he said Tuesday as a steady stream of delegates brought up checks from their congregations. ``It's something we should have had a long time ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Ruling Blocking Execution of Convicted Murderer
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld a state ruling blocking the execution of a convicted murderer who contends his confession was coerced by a sheriff who is now a congressman. Barry Lee Fairchild, 36, had been scheduled to die Wednesday night by injection, but the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals voted 3-0 Tuesday to send the case to U.S. District Court for a hearing on the allegations he was beaten by the sheriff and his deputies. That hearing was scheduled for Nov. 13. U.S. Rep. Tommy Robinson has denied that, as sheriff, he and his Pulaski County deputies beat Fairchild and five other black suspects and urged them to confess to the 1983 abduction, rape and murder of Air Force nurse Marjorie ``Greta'' Mason. On Wednesday he released a statement criticizing the justice system and the defense: ``These legal maneuvers could go on for years. The time has come for Congress to limit the number of appeals that can be filed by those on death rows across the country. ... ``The rights of Barry Lee Fairchild were never violated,'' the statement continued. ``He abducted, raped and murdered a young lady who had been in our state for only 10 days. He has had appeal after appeal. At some point, all of us must step back and say `enough.''' The congressman was elected as a Democrat but switched to the Republican party. He lost the GOP primary for governor this year and isn't seeking re-election to the House. The high court ruling to uphold the stay of execution was unanimous, said Supreme Court press officer Toni House. Fairchild's attorneys say he is mildly retarded, with an IQ between the 60s and 80s, and contend he was easy prey for authorities seeking to force a confession. He confessed twice but later said the statements were coerced. His lawyers also contend that someone else confessed to the murder and that police dropped the man as a suspect because he provided few details about the crime. Defense attorneys say they have interviewed four men who say they, too, were beaten and threatened with racial epithets by deputies investigating the case. On Wednesday, Assistant Attorney General Jack Gillean confirmed that three of the four men who submitted affidavits about the alleged beatings were suspects in the murder. He said they were questioned by police days before Fairchild was arrested and questioned. Defense attorney John Wesley Hall said the fact that police had other suspects wasn't revealed to his client's trial counsel. The information could have helped convince the jury that ``police rounded up blacks and beat on them until they elected which one was the best one to be charged,'' Hall said. Gillean said he had no reason to believe the information was withheld.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Leader Calls Anew for Holy War, Says Embargo Imperils Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT that Saddam said Iraqi children were in peril because of the embargo, not actually dying. ADDS quotes from text as issued in Arabic by the Iraqi News Agency. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Wednesday renewed his call for a holy war against the huge Western military presence, and said U.N. sanctions could kill Iraqi children. He also urged Arabs to rise up and overthrow leaders aligned against him, singling out Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, formerly close allies. Saddam has previously called for a holy war, or jihad, but his speech read by a spokesman over Baghdad television Wednesday was his most virulent attack on Arab leaders who sided with Western powers after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. An earlier translation from Saddam's Arabic speech, carried by The Associated Press, incorrectly stated that Saddam said some children were dying because of the sanctions. ``The children of Iraq are dying,'' that translation said. However, the Arabic text carried by the official Iraqi News Agency did not contain that quote. In the broadcast speech, monitored in Cyprus, Saddam appeared to reject foreign help to circumvent the U.N. embargo, assistance for which his government had previously appealed on humanitarian grounds. ``Have you, O brothers, known throughout the history that you have come across that anyone tried to starve a nation to death by depriving it of food?'' said Saddam. ``And have you witnessed in the history that is known to you that some children should die because of a premeditated decision to deprive them of milk? ``The children of Iraq, before the rest of the nation, refuse that we beg for the milk which they need from the infidels and shameless.'' Saddam reiterated that Iraq would defy the boycott and would be victorious, even against the advanced military technology arrayed against it. He said the people are ``ready to sacrifice'' and do without. Saddam is holding an estimated 20,000 Westerners and has deployed some Western men as human shields to deter attack on vital military and civilian installations within Iraq. He has warned that any shortages among Iraq's civilian population caused by the U.N.-imposed embargo would be applied equally to foreign children and elderly persons being detained. In the past, Saddam has bragged that his nation could withstand the sanctions, a claim made in tandem with Iraqi attempts to convince some embargo nations to wink at the sanctions and resume trade with Iraq. Jordan, a close ally of Iraq, has agreed to go along with sanctions, but has so far rejected full-scale compliance on the grounds that international law might forbid blocking food and medicine from Iraq. Referring to the Egyptian and Saudi people, Saddam said ``We call on them to revolt against the traitors . . . and fight the presence in the Holy Land (of the Western multinational force). ``We call upon all Arabs, within the teachings of Allah and according to the Moslem Holy War of Jihad, to fight this U.S. presence of non-believers and to fight the stance taken by Arab agents who have followed these foreigners,'' said Saddam in the broadcast. The Western force in the gulf now totals about 65,000 troops and 30 to 40 warships. Arab nations such as Egypt, Morrocco and Syria have sent contingents to fight in the U.S.-led multinational force, while the five-nation Gulf Cooperation Council has fielded its rapid deployment force against him. The GCC members include the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and before the invasion, Kuwait. Saddam's speech on Baghdad television was read by Miqdad Morad, a veteran radio and television announcer who was the only spokesman authorized to announce military communiques during the eight-year Iran-Iraq War. Saddam charged the Saudis were agents of foreign forces who were backed by the ``Zionist money'' and the ``Zionist media,'' a reference to domestic U.S. support for Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins For State Lawmaker's Son Charged With Killing Mother
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with jurors chosen, taken back to Juneau Wednesday afternoon. Picks up 5th graf, `Authorities say ...'
DOC.TEXT: A jury was selected Wednesday in the trial of a state lawmaker's 19-year-old son, who is charged with shooting and killing his mother with a hunting arrow during a dispute at the family's farmhouse. Chad Goetsch, the son of Rep. Robert Goetsch of Juneau, is charged with first-degree intentional homicide in the Nov. 8 killing of his mother, Carolyn, 51. The charge carries a mandatory sentence of life in prison. Although the trial will be held in Dodge County Circuit Court in Juneau, lawyers selected jurors in Balsam Lake in Polk County _ about 300 miles northwest of Juneau. Judge Daniel Klossner ordered the jury to be chosen there to ensure that the panelists weren't influenced by news reports on the case. The jurors were impaneled and taken back to Juneau on Wednesday afternoon. Opening arguments were set for Thursday morning. The trial is expected to last two weeks and include a trip to the home where the killing occurred. Authorities say the killing took place after Chad Goetsch had returned home from Marquette University in Milwaukee, where he was a freshman, at about 4 a.m. After his mother answered the door and let him in, the two began arguing. A short time later, authorities say, Mrs. Goetsch was shot with the arrow in the doorway of her son's bedroom. Goetsch is also charged with recklessly endangering his father's safety during a struggle that allegedly ensued seconds after Mrs. Goetsch's death. Goetsch has pleaded innocent to both charges. He has told police he was practicing with a hunting bow when the arrow accidentally was shot and struck his mother in the heart.

DOC.HEAD: Baptist Leader Supports President Bush on Troop Deployment
DOC.TEXT: After earlier charging that sending U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf lacked any moral principle, the leader of the nation's largest black church body on Wednesday said he supported President Bush's decision. ``As true Americans, we owe allegiance to the Stars and Stripes forever,'' said the Rev. T.J. Jemison. He told about 10,000 delegates at the annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. that he stood behind the president's decision to send tens of thousands of U.S. troops to the Middle East in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We are loyal and devoted citizens.'' Jemison then recited the Pledge of Allegiance at the first general business meeting of the convention. In welcoming ceremonies Monday, Jemison said the U.S. military deployment was over oil. ``We are not fighting over any principal or ideal,'' he said. He also said if more time was spent at the negotiating table, the nation wouldn't have to spend $1 billion a month on the military action. ``Think of the good that billion dollars could do for black America and poor white America,'' he said. On Wednesday, Jemison changed his focus to the ``immoral'' regime of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. In remarks after the business meeting, Jemison said he regretted that the military struggle was over oil, but he said Bush did what he had to do to preserve the American way of life. He also urged Bush to pursue greater diplomatic efforts to end the struggle.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
State Department Says It Told of American Shot by Iraqi Soldier
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Wednesday night it had received a report that an American citizen was shot by an Iraqi soldier in Kuwait while trying to avoid capture. ``We have no information on how serious his injuries might be,'' the department said in a statement. Diplomats at the blockaded U.S. Embassy in Kuwait city spoke with officials at the hospital where they were told the American had been taken, but ``hospital officials said they had no knowledge of the incident,'' the statement said. ``The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad has been instructed to contact the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to demand consular access to this citizen,'' said the statement read by Tom Dougherty, a spokesman. Dougherty said the family of the man believed to have been shot had been told of the report but he was not at liberty to identify him. ``Attempts by our embassy in Kuwait to obtain more information from Iraqi officials in Kuwait have been in vain. We will continue to press this case,'' Dougherty said. Though the statement spoke only of ``a report'' of a shooting, Dougherty said the department believed it was a well-founded report. Iraqi soldiers have been rounding up westerners in Kuwait ever since their Aug. 2 takeover of the country. Embassies have been ordered closed and diplomats transferred to Baghdad. The United States and several other countries have refused to recognize the closure order. Iraq has cut off access to the embassies, stopped water and power service, and has told diplomats there they have lost their diplomatic immunity. Diplomats have stayed in the U.S. embassy, which has not been invaded, and have not tested their diplomatic status in the streets.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Get Life Sentences as Uprising Marks 1,000th Day
DOC.TEXT: A military court sentenced four Palestinians to life in prison for murdering an Arab village leader, the army said Wednesday, the 1,000th day of the uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied lands. Arab reporters said the men, all from the West Bank village of Kfar Bidiya, killed the village leader on suspicion he sold land to Israelis. Underground leaders of the uprising had called for protest marches to mark the anniversary of the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, but no demonstrations were reported. Instead, thousands of Palestinian children marched off to the first day of elementary school classes in the West Bank. One stone-throwing incident was reported in a schoolyard. The army said the four men sentenced on Tuesday were Hassan Id-Alkum, Ahmed Salah, Salah Abu-Safia and Hasan El-Kara. They were convicted of gunning down Mustafa Salim Abu Bakr, 41, the muhktar, or traditional leader, of Kfar Bidiya in October 1988, the army said. The gunmen set Abu Bakr's body afire after killing him. The muhktar's two young sons were wounded in the incident. About 255 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs in the 33-month-old uprising, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israeli authorities. In addition, 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 47 Israelis have died in the violence. Repeated orders from the Palestine Liberation Organization urging moderation in collaborator interrogations have not reduced the collaborator killings. Meanwhile, the Israeli military government allowed 195,000 elementary students in the West Bank to begin their 1990-91 school year. Intermediate and senior high schools will be allowed to open in the next several weeks if there are no problems at elementary schools, the government said. About 100,000 students attend these schools. Gaza schools opened Tuesday, and no incidents were reported, according to Israeli radio reports. Most elementary and secondary schools in the West Bank were closed for at least six months during the 1988-89 school year after the army charged they were hotbeds of anti-Israeli activity. Human rights groups and Palestinian educators said the closures constituted collective punishment. Israeli authorities warned that schools would be closed again if violence breaks out. ``We are assuming that parents, teachers and students will be aware of the fact that we will not agree to suffer violence or incitement from within the schools,'' said Brig. Gen. Freddie Zach, deputy coordinator for the territories. ``We hope that they will try to do all they can in order to keep violence out of the schools.''

DOC.HEAD: Monrovia Residents Flock to Areas Under Control of West Africans
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Monrovia residents seeking food and safety flocked Wednesday to areas of the capital under the control of a West African military force. Monrovia has been virtually cut off from the outside world for more than two months, partly because of heavy street fighting between troops loyal to President Samuel Doe and two rival rebel factions. Maj. Chris Otulana, a spokesman for the five-nation West African force, said Wednesday that ``everywhere in Monrovia is calm at the moment.'' He said some rebels loyal to Charles Taylor were cooperating in efforts to restore peace to the capital. But Taylor, who has vowed to destroy the task force, continued broadcasts from a captured government radio transmitter. They accused the West African soldiers of abuses ranging from murdering civilians to selling cocaine to children. Both Doe and Prince Johnson, the leader of a splinter rebel group, have welcomed the West African troops. Their forces appeared to be observing a truce that began Aug. 24, the day the West Africans landed. The West Africans were sent to Liberia under orders to end the civil war, which has left at least 5,000 people, mostly civilians, dead since December. Taylor contends that the West African intervention is just a ploy to keep Doe in power. He has expressed concern that the force includes soldiers from Nigeria and Guinea, whose leaders in the past supported Doe. Thousands of Monrovia residents poured into areas of the capital controlled by the 3,000 troops from those nations and Ghana, Sierra Leone and Gambia. They apparently felt safer there than in the areas held by Doe or Johnson. The influx was especially heavy at night. In the areas controlled by the West Africans, there was more commerce than at any time since the fighting hit the capital, with food the most highly sought after item. The West Africans control the port area, but efforts to use Spriggs Payne Airfield to bring in supplies has been hampered by the threat of mortar fire from Taylor's troops. The airport is controlled by Doe's forces, but Taylor's rebels have staged occasional attacks. Diplomats said that if the African force can open the airport, it will deny Taylor any hold on the city and also restore an air link with the outside world. Once in firm control of the capital, the West Africans could then move to restore electricity and water, and bring in desperately needed food and medicine. When the task force arrived, Monrovia had been isolated and without water and electricity for two months. There was almost no food. The task force was not expected to make any major push against Taylor's forces until its commander, Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana, returns from consultations with West African leaders later this week. Taylor's rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, branding Doe's government as corrupt and saying they would overthrow it. A rebel faction led by Johnson broke with Taylor in February. Taylor since has declared himself president of Liberia. His forces hold most of the country outside Monrovia, but their advance in the capital's eastern suburbs was held up by Doe's troops. Doe remains holed up in his fortified seaside mansion, and Johnson's rebel group controls part of the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch Scrubbed Because of Fuel Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with comments from NASA briefing, adds detail. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The line ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2
DOC.TEXT: NASA scrubbed the launch of space shuttle Columbia for the third time after discovering a leak as liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were being poured into the fuel tank on Wednesday. The decision was made after 10 times the normal amount of hydrogen was found in the shuttle's aft compartment, said shuttle director Robert Crippen. The launch crew immediately began trying to trace the leak. No new launch date was set. NASA canceled the first launch attempt in May after sensors detected an unusual buildup of liquid hydrogen during fueling in the aft compartment and around a valve in plumbing between the orbiter and external tank. The second scrub was last week because mission control had trouble communicating with one of the four telescopes in Columbia's cargo bay. ``I think we got fooled by the fact we had two leaks,'' Crippen said. ``I think this leak has been there all along.'' Crippen said there was no leak this time in the connecting link between shuttle and tank. The aft compartment, where the explosive hydrogen was found, contains the shuttle's main engines. Thursday's attempt would have been the 36th shuttle flight and the first in four months. Wednesday's troubles were the latest blow to NASA's image. The highly touted Hubble Space Telescope failed to operate as advertised because its mirrors were ground wrong; the shuttle Atlantis developed a hydrogen leak similar to Columbia's and NASA controllers had intermittent problems contacting the Magellan space probe which is orbiting Venus. ``The shuttle's business is flying, and we're sitting on the ground,'' Crippen said. ``I guess all I can say is that the shuttle is a very complicated vehicle. It flies in environments that are very strenuous and we have to be able to assure that the vehicle is safe to fly.'' In the three months since the first leak was discovered, NASA has tested and retested the lines between the fuel tank and its three shuttles, but never with a tankload of fuel. Crippen said he didn't regret his decision against a tanking test. Such a test would have required five or six days. ``It wouldn't have given me that much lead time,'' Crippen said. The line being used on Columbia is new, having been taken from the orbiter Endeavour, which is under construction in California. The leak Wednesday wasn't in the area of that line, NASA said. But the space agency offered no clue where else it might be. Space shuttles rely on two sources of power to get into orbit. Two solid fuel rockets burn for two minutes to get the vehicle off the ground. At the same time _ and continuing for eight minutes _ the orbiter engines burn a combination of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen. The shuttle's 154-foot-long tank holds 385,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen which is cooled to 423 degrees Fahrenheit below zero, and 144,000 gallons of liquid oxygen at 297 degrees below zero. The leak was revealed as the hydrogen was pumped in at the rate of 8,400 gallons a minute _ in the so-called ``fast-fill'' mode. It didn't show in the early minutes of fueling when the hydrogen was loaded at the rate of 1,000 gallons a minute. Columbia was to have carried an array of four telescopes into orbit. Four astronomers in the crew of seven would have operated the instruments, which would remain in the shuttle's cargo bay. The launch, with the $150 million Astro observatory aboard, had been scheduled for 1:20 a.m. EDT. ``Dozens of us are dying to see this thing get launched,'' said Arthur Davidsen, principal investigator of one of Astro's four telescopes. It was only the fifth time NASA scheduled a shuttle launch at night and the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. The night launch was planned because of the demands of the astronomy mission. Speaking to NASA employees via closed-circuit television from the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Vice President Dan Quayle called the mission ``cutting-edge space activity.'' He said that despite its recent problems, NASA is up to doing the job it was assigned to do. ``Take it from a guy who knows a lot about unwarranted criticism,'' he said. ``Once they pile it on, they just don't know when to stop.'' Standing about 1{ miles away was Discovery, which was moved to NASA's other shuttle launch pad Tuesday night to await an October flight with the Ulysses satellite that will study the sun. The Astro, designed to study highly energetic stars, galaxies and other hot objects, has been waiting for a shuttle ride since March 1986, NASA's original target date for the mission. The flight was postponed indefinitely because of the Challenger disaster earlier that year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives Besieged Envoy Pep Talk, Talks of Options to Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 5 grafs new or rewritten on report of American shot; suppresses incorrect dying babies report to new last graf in light of correction embodied in a0730; picks up 4th graf pvs: ``Bush, who;'' Bulet matter edited to trim
DOC.TEXT: AM-Gulf-Finances

An Iraqi soldier shot an American citizen trying to avoid capture in Kuwait, according to a reported reaching the State Department revealed by the department Wednesday night. The reported shooting happened during a day in which President Bush telephoned the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait to encourage the ambassador and his skeleton staff to hang on under ``most difficult circumstances.'' Separately, Bush told lawmakers he would consider further moves if economic pressure fails to push Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The State Department said attempts by U.S. diplomats ``to obtain more information from Iraqi officials in Kuwait have been in vain. We will continue to press this case.'' The department declined to identify the American and said it did not know the seriousness of his injuries. Bush, who met privately with more than 30 senators and House members, will address a public joint session of Congress next Tuesday night after returning from his weekend summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Senior administration aides, meanwhile, disclosed that the United States wants its allies to pay the entire cost, either in cash or contributions of material, of the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The aides said the administration estimated those costs as $6 billion to the end of the year and $1 billion a month after that, plus $10.5 billion a year for nearby states hurt by the trade embargo and an unspecified sum for developing countries battered by oil price increases. At the Capitol on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III wound up a second day of congressional questioning _ repeating his proposal for planning of a new ``regional security structure'' for the Middle East _ and was leaving Wednesday night for Saudi Arabia. He said anew that Americans should not expect any quick resolution of the standoff which has brought tens of thousands of U.S. troops to the Saudi desert, across the Kuwaiti border from an even larger force of Iraqis. Current U.S. efforts, aimed at weakening Saddam's resolve through the economic embargo, ``are going to take some time, and that is what we ask most of the American people: Stand firm, be patient and remain united so that together we can show that aggression does not pay,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. However the current situation plays out, he said, ``this is not the last crisis of this nature we are likely to face in this region. ... It is worthwhile to begin considering regional security structures ... that would guarantee an equilibrium in this region that will produce peace'' and ``create a more durable order.'' He gave no details and said such planning was in a very early stage. Meanwhile, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi ambassador to the United States, sent letters to each member of Congress expressing his country's gratitude for lawmakers' support of Operation Desert Shield. ``I want to convey our regard and respect for the individual men and women of the American air, naval and ground units now temporarily in Saudi Arabia and the adjoining waters, side by side with our own defense forces and those from a number of important Arab, European and other countries vigilantly there,'' he said. In one military development, the Navy said it had authorized the battleship USS Wisconsin in the Persian Gulf to fire its 16-inch guns, which had been silenced in May after an investigation was reopened into the deadly explosion aboard the Wisconsin's sister ship, the USS Iowa. Navy spokesman Cmdr. Jim Mitchell said additional tests had ``determined that the 16-inch guns may safely fire specified lots of powder, which are now loaded on the Wisconsin.'' Baker's overseas trip, which will also include the weekend U.S.-Soviet summit in Helsinki and later stops in Europe, will be partly focused on soliciting major contributions to help pay for the Mideast effort opposing Saddam. Another Cabinet member, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, was on his way to South Korea Wednesday after winning a pledge of support from Margaret Thatcher in London. At the White House, Fitzwater said Bush called the embassy in Kuwait City to express his appreciation to Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and the few other staff members who stayed behind to assist Americans trapped in the region. Iraq has cut off water and electricity to the embassy as part of its effort to shut down all foreign embassies in the land they annexed following an Aug. 2 lightning invasion. Bush told his envoy ``to keep up the good work under these most difficult circumstances,'' Fitzwater said. ``Ambassador Howell is struggling with a very difficult situation in terms of the physical conditions there. They have fast-diminishing supplies of water and electricity. But as you all know and have seen on the television reports, the embassy staff there has been actively working with U.S. citizens in helping to facilitate these flights out of Kuwait and out of Iraq,'' the spokesman said. Later on Wednesday, Bush met with more 30 members of Congress concerning the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush told them that ``we must keep pressure on Iraq and convince Saddam Hussein that time is against him,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president said, `The sanctions must succeed. If not, we will review our options.''' The spokesman would not elaborate. The lawmakers gave Bush ``repeated statements of support to see this mission through,'' Fitzwater said. They also had suggestions, they indicated in comments after the meeting. In some of them: _Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said the U.S. troops stationed in the Saudi Arabian desert might be given pay and income tax incentives ``to forestall a morale problem.'' Glenn, part of a congressional delegation just back from the Middle East, said he also suggested such benefits as free stamps. _Glenn suggested sanctions against countries letting planes depart for Iraq. _Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said Bush should push Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during this weekend's summit meeting to pull remaining Soviet military and technical advisers out of Iraq. _Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said he urged Bush to press the Soviets for intelligence on the Iraqi military capability. Fitzwater praised the Soviet Union's role in the international effort to isolate Iraq. During the day, the White House brushed off Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's incorrectly reported statement that ``the children of Iraq are dying'' because of the U.N.-supported economic embargo, dismising it as a ``rhetorical diatribe.'' The statement later was determined to be an incorrect translation from the Arabic.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Bomb Main Oil Pipeline
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas bombed the country's main oil pipeline Wednesday, forcing the state-run oil company Ecopetrol to suspend pumping. Ecopetrol said it has stopped pumping 235,000 barrels of crude oil a day _ almost half its daily output. Guerrillas of the National Liberation Army, known as the ELN, blew up a section of the Cano Limon oil pipeline in northeastern Colombia, Ecopetrol said. The explosion caused an oil spill, but the company did not give any details. The 500-mile-long pipeline transports most of the country's petroleum destined for export. The pro-Cuban National Liberation Army has bombed the pipeline scores of times since 1986, causing losses estimated at $520 million. The guerrilla group is seeking to reduce the presence of foreign oil companies in Colombia. It is the only leftist rebel group that has refused to join peace talks with the government. Colombia is currently producing at maximum capacity _ around 465,000 barrels a day. Around 200,000 barrels a day are earmarked for the international market where prices have risen sharply because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Last month, President Cesar Gaviria announced that Colombia was raising its oil production by about 15,000 barrels per day to join other oil producers in helping make up for the shortfall resulting from the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. U.N. economic sanctions have caused the withdrawal of more than 4 million barrels a day of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil from the world market. Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela have boosted production to cover most of the shortfall.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Authors, Poets, Profs Plead To Save Yale Review
DOC.TEXT: George Plimpton, Joyce Carol Oates and Susan Sontag are among the literary chorus pleading with the president of Yale University to save the prestigious Yale Review. The literary quarterly, which introduced the works of Eudora Welty, Robert Frost, Robert Penn Warren, Virginia Woolf, Eugene O'Neill, among others, is to be shelved after issuing its 79th volume in November. More than 50 novelists, critics, professors and poets have signed a petition opposing the decision to halt publication of the magazine, the oldest literary quarterly in the country. The petition was delivered Tuesday to Yale President Benno C. Schmidt Jr.. Schmidt announced in June that Yale would shelve the quarterly after its 79th volume, citing financial difficulty, limited readership and the absence of any direct tie to Yale's academic programs. Annie Dillard, author of ``Pilgrim at Tinker Creek''; Plimpton, editor of The Paris Review; Charles McGrath, deputy editor of The New Yorker magazine; Robert Giroux, editor of Farrar, Straus and Giroux publishers in New York; and James Laughlin, the founding editor of New Directions, a literary magazine, were among those to sign the petition. Other signatories from the literary world included novelist Iris Murdoch, author Oates, poet Adrienne Rich, critic Sontag, Pulitzer Prize-winning poets William Meredith and Richard Wilbur, and Lord Noel Annan, former provost of Kings College at Cambridge University and the University of London. Schmidt said a list of names would not, taken alone, make a difference in his decision, though ``they are serious people and ought to be paid attention to.'' The Yale Review has a paid circulation of only about 4,200. Schmidt said he wasn't confident he could raise the $1 million or so needed for an endowment to fund the the magazine's annual cost of $60,000 to $80,000 at a time the university faces other financial pressures. Several potential donors have expressed interest in helping fund various sorts of publications, he said, some ``along the lines of The Yale Review and some not.'' However, he said ``there is no clear sense as yet whether they will ripen into actual commitments.'' Penelope Laurans, the magazine's acting editor, said Wednesday she was encouraged by the show of support. But she added, ``it would be wrong of me to say I felt that this particular attention meant the review was necessarily going to be saved.''

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Company Recalls Aerosol Streamer
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Consumers with questions may call the company collect at 203-233-8709 during business hours.

A Connecticut company is recalling its ``Streamer Spray,'' an aerosol product that could catch fire if sprayed near an open flame, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. Streamer Spray, manufactured by Cotracto Inc. of Hartford, is used at parties and other festive occasion to throw a stringy substance like confetti. Since the spray is intended for use by children, it is banned under the Hazardous Substances Act, the commission said. Tests prompted by consumer complaints confirmed the propellant in the can is flammable, the commission said. Streamer Spray comes in aerosol cans with orange, pink, yellow and green plastic caps corresponding to the color of the string. Cans are labelled in part, ``Streamer Spray.'' About 5,500 cans were sold between November 1989 and January 1990. The commission said consumers should not use any cans on hand and should return them to the stores where purchased for a refund.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Forces Evacuation of Prudhoe Bay Workers
DOC.TEXT: A toxic plume from a fire that gutted a chemical-filled warehouse near the Prudhoe Bay oil field prompted the evacuation of more than 1,000 workers, state officials said. But there were no reports Wednesday of injuries, nor that chemicals had spilled onto the tundra, the delicate arctic layer of plants that can take years to regenerate. The fire at the Dowell Schlumberger Inc. warehouse at an oil-field service camp in Deadhorse was contained within four hours Tuesday night, said Louis Steinke, Alaska manager for Dowell Schlumberger. Brad Fristoe, North Slope district manager for the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation, said the nature of the fire made it difficult to fight and the building essentially was left to burn. Fristoe said the DEC would investigate whether chemicals spilled on the tundra. Steinke said there was no evidence of a spill. Fristoe said at least 1,000 oil-field workers were evacuated, but Steinke said there were wide fluctuations in estimates and he did not have a figure. Workers returned Wednesday morning. ``The plume was caused by a number of the chemicals they had within the building,'' Fristoe said. The warehouse contents included lubricants, acid and solvent, he said. Steinke said a list of the building's inventory was being drawn up. The fire did not interrupt the flow of oil from Prudhoe Bay, which supplies 20 percent of the nation's crude. Dowell Schlumberger's work includes keeping oil wells in working order.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says Space Tomatoes Taste Home Grown
DOC.TEXT: Tomatoes grown from seeds that spent years in space don't seem much different from their home-grown cousins, NASA researchers say. ``I've noticed that the space seeds germinate earlier,'' James Poindexter, an education specialist at Johnson Space Center, said Tuesday. ``After that, there's no difference in the growth rate. They all flowered at the same time. I didn't see any noticeable differences.'' Some 12.5 million seeds were retrieved from the bus-size Long Duration Exposure Facility by the crew of the shuttle Columbia in January. Some of the seeds that were planted at the Houston space center have yielded juicy red tomatoes. Millions of the seeds were sent to schools nationwide, and student growers later this month will submit growth data to Oklahoma State University's aerospace education services program. The OSU program will analyze and summarize the results.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Calls for Holy War; American Reported Shot in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATING with American reported shot, Iraqi reserve officers called up, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Wednesday urged Arabs to rise up in a holy war against the West and former allies who turned against him, and said world trade sanctions are imperiling the lives of Iraqi children. An American citizen, meanwhile, was reported shot in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait but details were sketchy. The State Department said Wednesday night in Washington that it received a report an Iraqi soldier fired on an American who was trying to avoid capture, adding, ``We have no information on how serious his injuries might be.'' Iraqi troops have been rounding up Westerners in Kuwait since Iraq invaded and seized the small oil state on Aug. 2. Embassies in Kuwait have been ordered closed and diplomats transferred to Baghdad. Western women and children detained in Kuwait and Iraq trickled out in small groups Wednesday, leaving behind hundreds who lack permission to depart. Iraq, criticized for blocking releases with red tape, said it was doing everything it could to expedite departures. On Thursday, an Air France jet flew into Paris from Jordan carrying 153 Westerners allowed to leave Iraq, including three pregnant women. Those aboard included 105 French women and children, 28 Britons and at least nine Americans. The American women had Arabic names, indicating they had married Arabs. Japan and the Soviet Union asked Iraq on Wednesday to withdraw at once from Kuwait and free all foreigners held in Iraq and Kuwait. A joint statement issued in Tokyo by Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama and visiting Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze was the first ever by the two nations on an international issue, Foreign Ministry officials there said. As a multinational armada grew in the Persian Gulf, U.S. Army officials in Saudi Arabia said the military was using night convoys to move heavy firepower _ including ground-to-air missiles and rocket launchers _ into the northern Saudi desert. Although Washington says its troops are deployed to defend the Saudis, the recent moves increase the offensive capabilities of U.S. forces. President Bush indicated Wednesday the United States has not ruled out an offensive role, telling lawmakers back from the gulf that if sanctions do not succeed, ``we will review our options.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III was headed for the Middle East, where he said he planned to discuss with U.S. allies a proposed new regional security structure for the Persian Gulf. In the Gulf of Oman, U.S. forces released an Iraqi-flagged freighter they intercepted and boarded Tuesday as it headed for Iraq with a cargo of tea. The Navy said the ship was allowed to proceed to an unspecified port after a 30-hour search. Shipping sources said it headed for Yemen. Saddam has promised to free all foreign women and children but to keep the men as human shields against attack at strategic sites. In another attempt to play on Western anxiety about the captives, he released messages Tuesday purported to be from seven such hostages, including an American. Also, London-based Kurdish dissidents from Iraq pinpointed six installations where they said hostages were held. They included a chemical weapons factory, an air force training college and other military bases. In other developments: _ Iraq called up its reserve officers Wednesday, the Iraqi News Agency reported. A statement issued by the Defense Ministry said reserve officers in all specialties except chemical warfare would be subject to the call-up. The statement was broadcast on Iraqi radio, according to the INA dispatch monitored in Cyprus. _ Britain pledged funds to a U.S.-led effort to help nations suffering from the U.N.-ordered sanctions against Iraq. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made the commitment at a meeting with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. _ Diplomatic efforts continued, with King Hussein of Jordan conferring in Baghdad with Saddam and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz meeting in Moscow with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Soviet President Gorbachev meets Bush on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, to discuss the crisis. Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas, who met Gorbachev on Wednesday, said later he thought Aziz may pass a message to Gorbachev to relay to Bush at the summit. _ Britons paid nearly $40 million in purchase taxes on gasoline in August because of higher pump prices triggered by the crisis, Britain's Automobile Association said Wednesday. _ Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the exiled emir of Kuwait, reassured Kuwaitis on Saudi television Wednesday of worldwide support for an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and restoration of his family's rule. _ Bush placed a morale-boosting call to U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, where a skeleton staff remains. Saddam, in his televised statement Wednesday, said the U.N. embargo imposed on Iraq on Aug. 6 may be imperiling the lives of Iraqi children. He also called upon ``all Arabs, within the teachings of Allah and according to the Moslem Holy War of Jihad, to fight this U.S. presence of non-believers and to fight the stance taken by Arab agents who have followed these foreigners.'' He was referring to Saudi Arabia, which allowed U.S. troops onto its soil, and countries such as Egypt and Morocco, which sent contingents to fight in the multinational force. Addressing the people of those countries, he said: ``We call on them to revolt against the traitors . . . and fight the presence in the Holy Land (of the Western force.) He said in his speech, ``Have you, O brothers, known throughout the history that you have come across that anyone tried to starve a nation to death by depriving it of food? ``And have you witnessed in the history that is known to you that some children should die because of a premeditated decision to deprive them of milk? ``The children of Iraq, before the rest of the nation, refuse that we beg for the milk which they need from the infidels and shameless.'' An earlier translation from Saddam's Arabic speech, which was carried by The Associated Press, incorrectly quoted Saddam as saying some children were dying as a result of the sanctions. Saddam reiterated that his people would defy the boycott and emerge victorious. A group of Americans who reached Jordan on Tuesday were treated to a free ride home by British tycoon Richard Branson, who flew them to London and then Newark, N.J., on his Virgin Atlantic Airways. Of the 29 Americans, 24 flew on to Newark and five stopped over in London. The plane that took them to London carried 40 tons of supplies for tens of thousands of desperate Asian evacuees from Kuwait and Iraq, now stranded in the desert just inside Jordan as they await transport home. AmeriCares, a non-profit world relief organization, said Wednesday its first emergency airlift to Jordan for suffering refugees will take off from Bradley International Airport at Windsor Locks, Conn., on Saturday with 42{ tons of relief supplies.
