DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Four teen-agers who attended the first Bolshoi Academy dance school at Colorado Mountain College have been invited to study at the prestigious academy's facilities in Moscow. Sophia Golovkina, artistic director of the academy, extended the invitations last weekend to Stacey Uster, 13, of Wheat Ridge; Jesse Roderick, 14, Arvada; Tammy Gargas, 11, Tabernacle, N.J.; and Kara Jehle, 12, Pensacola, Fla. The four were among 44 students between 11 and 18 years who spent a month studying with Bolshoi Academy instructors Alexandr ``Sasha'' Bondarenko and Galina Solovyeva. The Soviets set up the school _ the first in North America _ after making a stop in Vail during a U.S. tour last year. They also operate a satellite school in Japan. The four would-be ballerinas have been asked to spend six months at the Moscow school early next year, with the average cost expected to run about $1,500 a month, officials said. The financing details haven't been set yet.

Columbia Records' bottomless vault has coughed up yet another treasure chest of jazz reissues. This time around, the salute is to the best of the big bands, with digitally remastered and annotated volumes by Artie Shaw, Harry James, Kay Kyser, Claude Thornhill and others. Issued on compact disc are: ``Will Bradley-Ray McKinley,'' ``Doris Day With Les Brown,'' ``Eddy Duchin,'' ``Hal Kemp,'' ``Harry James,'' ``Kay Kyser,'' ``Lester Lanin,'' ``Artie Shaw'' and ``Claude Thornhill.''

Red Skelton will perform at Carnegie Hall on Sept. 12 _ the first time in two decades he has appeared on the famed concert stage. Skelton will perform pantomines and skits utilizing characters he's developed during six decades of show business, including ``The Old Man Watching a Parade,'' and ``Thje Newlyweds and the Same Couple 50 Years Later.'' ``An Evening With Red Skelton'' will be signed for the hearing impaired. Frank Leone is musical director.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.TEXT: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in more than a year, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.5 percent, the government said. The rise in non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ was the first increase since productivity climbed 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1988, the Labor Department said Tuesday. The rebound was a departure from productivity's poor performance in recent months.

Construction spending edged up 0.4 percent in July for its first gain in four months, the government said. Analysts said they expect the industry to remain weak through the end of the year. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that spending on residential, non-residential and government buildings totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $442.2 billion.

The nation's purchasing managers said manufacturing slowed in August, providing more evidence of a looming recession and signs that the Persian Gulf crisis is taking a toll on the economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks the manufacturing economy through a monthly poll of its members, said Tuesday its overall index of business activity at 300 industrial companies fell to 47.0 percent from 47.4 percent in July. When the index registers below 50 percent, it indicates the economy is weakening.

Chrysler Corp., struggling with sagging sales and high incentive costs, has increased its target for a cost-cutting program to $2.5 billion. In July 1989, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca announced plans to trim $1 billion from the automaker's $26 billion yearly budget by the end of 1990. Chrysler has cut about 2,500 of its 28,700 white-collar jobs since last October, spokesman Steve Harris said Tuesday. Since the cost-cutting plans were announced, executives have raised the target twice, first to $1.5 billion by the end of this year, and now to $2.5 billion by next June, Iacocca said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal.

Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, announced a powerful new mainframe computer it says is the fastest in the world. The news Tuesday came a day before rival IBM is expected to announce its new top-of-the-line models. Both companies are depending on their new-generation mainframes to maintain their technological and competitive leadership in high-end computers. International Business Machines Corp. has refused to release details of its new computer line before its announcement scheduled for Wednesday.

A subsidiary of a Scottish banking group agreed to acquire most of Bank of New England Corp.'s Rhode Island operation for $75 million, buying a little hope for the troubled bank's prospects. The deal Tuesday will sell most of the best of Bank of New England-Old Colony assets to the Citizens Financial Group of Providence, R.I. Citizens is a subsidiary of The Royal Bank of Scotland Group, a financial services holding company.

The Texas Health Department placed an embargo on Kellogg Co.'s Heartwise cereal, accusing the company of deceptive labeling on the psyllium-based cereal. The embargo Tuesday prohibits warehouses from distributing the cereal but does not require grocers to pull the product from store shelves, said Dan Sowards, chief of the food branch for the Texas Department of Health. Texas is the only state that has sought to ban sales of Heartwise, which was introduced last year by the Battle Creek, Mich.-based cereal maker and has prompted a federal inquiry into the safety of the whole grain, psyllium.

The federal Environmental Protection Agency charged United Technologies Corp. with failing to comply with federal laws on the management of hazardous waste at six production plants. The EPA said Tuesday inspections of five Pratt & Whitney Aircraft manufacturing plants and one Hamilton Standard plant revealed more than 100 violations of the federal law that mandates management of hazardous waste.

The Greyhound drivers' union said it has to cut off $50-a-week strike benefit payments to drivers because the 6-month-old dispute has already cost it more than $6 million. In a letter to local officers, Amalgamated Transit Union President Jim La Sala said Tuesday that strike benefits to the union's 6,000 drivers would be discontinued starting Sept. 13.

Stock prices ended mixed in extremely light trading Tuesday as oil prices continued to climb and a report indicated further erosion in the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.99 point to 2,613.37. Bond prices were mostly lower and the dollar was mixed in domestic trading after rising overseas. Oil futures prices surged as fading hopes for a settlement to the Middle East crisis helped turn traders' attention to the prospects for tight supplies in the last three months of the year. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures were widely mixed; orange juice futures fell sharply; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: A Myth Is A Manufactured Belief
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: Anyone who has seen pictures of military equipment assembled in the Mideast or who observes the millions of automobiles on U.S. roads knows immediately that America can still manufacture. Despite this visual evidence, stories abound about the decline of American manufacturing, about the abandonment of still another plant, about the so-called de-industrialization of the nation. ``Modern mythology,'' snaps Murrary Weidenbaum. American manufacturing not only is well, he says, but has improved in several ways that bode well for the future. He observes that the decline that led to a rash of doomsday books, articles and extremist forecasts, ended nearly a decade ago. As often happens, however, the belief lingers, erroneous though it might be. There is, some say, a vested interest in the myth: research, books, consultancies, academic grants. But, says Weidenbaum, ``The manufacturing sector today contributes just about the same proportion of the total output of the American economy as it did three decades ago.'' And in that period the economy grew more than four times. Weidenbaum has a longtime involvement with issues of industrial myth vs. fact, having been chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan administration, and since then as director of the Center for the Study of American Business, a think tank based at Washington University in St. Louis. Contrary to the doom-and-gloomers, he says, the longest U.S. peacetime expansion didn't bypass the industrial sector. By year-end 1988, he points out, industrial production was 40 percent above the 1982 low. Perhaps of even greater importance, that rate was 24 percent above the previous cyclical high. Now, he states, three key forces are at work which strongly suggest the industrial sector will continue strong in the 1990s: _ American companies have been reducing the cost of producing goods and services. In 1980, the average private-sector worker received a 9 percent wage boost. By mid-1989, the rate was half that. For all 1988, the number of work stoppages involving 1,000 or more employees was 43, compared to 300 a decade earlier. _ Workers and managers are showing a new awareness of their personal responsibility for quality. At some manufacturers, Weidenbaum states, employees receive as much as 40 hours of training in quality measurements. And responsibility for quality control is gradually moving from inspectors to workers themselves. _ Private investment in research and development continues to grow. For the first time since data was assembled, business R&D outlays in the 1980s exceeded government spending, by $445 billion to $430 billion. The number of R&D scientists and engineers grew to 595,000 in 1987 from 469,000 in 1980. These three factors have made a difference and will continue to do so, says Weidenbaum. From 1973 to 1981, he points out, domestic manufacturers increased productivity by only 1.5 percent a year, but from 1981 to 1988 the average more than doubled to 3.8 percent, higher even than in the period 1948-1973. In short, says Weidenbaum, the American manufacturing sector is stronger today than it was a decade or so ago, in spite of the persistent declaration by public officials, academics and others that it is in decline. Weidenbaum believes American competetiveness will continue strong, assuming the country doesn't adopt counterproductive public policies. Protectionism would be one such policy. A spate of social mandates _ higher minimum wages, compulsory health insurance, parental leave _ that raise the cost of doing business would be another. In contrast, he says, a reduction of federal budget deficits through spending cuts, especially if the cuts focus on consumption, could lead to additional improvements in the manufacturing sector. He concludes: ``Enhancing the competitiveness of American industry is not fundamentally a question of how to get government to do more for manufacturing, but how to get it to do less to manufacturing.''

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom's Northeast Debut Comes at Tough Time in Retailing
Also in Wednesday AMs report.
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: As the trademark piano received a final tuning, sales help scurried around the new Nordstrom Inc. department store unpacking the remaining boxes, rearranging clothes racks and getting to know the inventory. The opening of the Nordstrom store at the Garden State Plaza shopping mall in Paramus, N.J., marks the retailer's first foray into the fiercely competitive Northeast. The official debut occurs Friday when the 245,000-square-foot store opens for business. Members of the media were given a preview tour of the store Tuesday. Operating in this area might pose the biggest challenge yet for the West Coast chain that has been migrating eastward as part of an ambitious expansion. A struggling regional economy has shaken consumer confidence and crimped spending. Crisis in the Middle East could further curb retail spending as the critical holiday season approaches. Nonetheless, Nordstrom executives seem optimistic about entering the market and private analysts say the retailer stands a good chance to thrive here. Its service-oriented brand of retailing, combined with broad assortments of reliable quality merchandise, will give it an edge over rivals with less favorable reputations, analysts say. ``I think it's probably one of the best _ if not the best _ department stores in the country,'' said Carl Steidtmann, chief economist at Management Horizons, the retail management and market research division of the accounting firm Price Waterhouse. ``The fact that the competition is in such a state of disarray might make it a good time to go into the Northeast.'' Richard Pyle, a retail analyst at Piper Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., said Nordstrom, which focuses on women's, men's and children's fashions, shoes and accessories, is in far better financial shape than its competitors. Some department stores, such as Macy's _ which is a Nordstrom neighbor at the Garden State Plaza _ are courting customers aggressively to boost business and pay off debts. Others, such as Saks Fith Avenue, are adjusting to life under new owners who are closely monitoring bottom lines. The 61-store Nordstrom chain dates back to 1901 when Swedish immigrant John W. Nordstrom founded a Seattle shoe shop with money made mining gold in Alaska. Nordstrom still emphasizes shoes; the Paramus store boasts an inventory of some 70,000 ladies' shoes and 30,000 men's. The chain has historically prided itself on top-notch service and stories abound about its sales associates going to unusual lengths to please people. ``Nordies'' have been known to personally deliver merchandise to customers' homes and to write thank-you notes to customers _ typically on their own time. The legendary service has been a key to landing customers in new markets. As elsewhere, the Paramus store employs personal shoppers who will help customers select apparel, assemble outfits and accessorize. A concierge stationed near the entrance will steer customers in the right direction and handle special requests. Shoppers have three restaurants to choose from on the store's three levels and a spa offering massages, facials, manicures, pedicures and waxing. James F. Nordstrom, one of three descendents of the founder who currently bear the title co-chairman, said shoppers appreciate being treated well no matter what part of the country they live in. Apart from minor adjustments in merchandise mix, he said there have been no special adaptations made in bringing the Seattle-based retailer east. The chain already operates two stores in the Virginia suburbs of Washington and intends to open two more in New Jersey over the next two years, plus one in New York in 1993. Its growth strategy calls for about four openings a year. ``We just think customers like a lot of selection, good quality and to be treated nicely,'' he said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters. One blot on the Nordstrom name appeared earlier this year when the Washington state Department of Labor and Industries, acting after a union complaint, ruled that the company has failed to pay employees for some of the extras they provide. The agency ordered Nordstrom to properly compensate employees for work and to pay back wages. Industry analysts say Nordstrom has weathered the bad publicity without much damage to its reputation. A $15 million reserve the company set aside to pay back wage claims should be adequate. James Nordstrom said the labor problems, which have been confined mostly to the Seattle area, haven't impaired the retailer's results. Many employees have proven their commitment to the company, he said, by paying their own way to transfer to new stores. The Paramus store will have about 100 sales associates who have previously worked elsewhere for Nordstrom. An additional 100 managers were transferred by the company, which has a policy of promoting from within. About 900 employees overall will work at the Garden State Plaza store. Nordstrom's sales and profits haven't been as impressive lately as they had been in the recent past. Earnings slid 20 percent in the first half of this year to $49 million on sales of $1.36 billion. That deterioration came after a 7 percent income drop last year to $115 million despite a 14.7 percent sales gain to $2.7 billion. Nordstrom also has felt the pinch of the currently sluggish retail climate. Co-chairman Nordstrom said, ``It's fair to say that our planned increase in sales is greater than the increase we're experiencing.'' He said the retailer is taking a conservative approach to the coming season and will tighten inventory slightly. If business doesn't measure up chainwide for a prolonged period, Nordstrom may scale back its expansion plans. ``We're not going to leverage ourselves and grow for growth sake,'' Nordstrom said, noting that some openings may be delayed if necessary. At the Paramus store, retail analysts say the company is hoping sales will exceed $100 million in the first year. Nordstrom executives declined to disclose projections.

DOC.HEAD: Revamping Milk Price System Begins In City Where Price is Based
DOC.TEXT: This western Wisconsin community _ in many ways the center of the dairy industry _ is the first battleground over proposed changes in the government's decades-old milk pricing system. It hosts the first hearing today in a rare U.S. Department of Agriculture investigation into whether the federal milk marketing system should be altered to eliminate price disparities from one region to another. The formula partially pays farmers based on how far they live from Eau Claire, a city of about 50,000 located 120 miles east of Minneapolis in the heart of Wisconsin's dairy farm region. Dairy farmers close to Eau Claire argue the milk-pricing system is unfair, outdated and provides artificially high subsidies for producers in the South and West who live farthest from here. The milk marketing order system, created in the 1930s, is designed to insure an adequate supply of milk, move milk from high-production areas and stabilize the market, said Bob Cropp, a dairy marketing specialist at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. But while milk production in the South and West _ traditionally non-dairy producing states that have received higher prices for their milk _ has increased markedly, the current system continues to pay farmers in those regions more than the Midwest, Cropp said. ``I don't mind competing against farmers from the South and West as long as we are competing by the same rules,'' said Wisconsin dairy farmer Pete Knigge, the chairman of the National Commission on Agriculture and Rural Development Policy. Officials expect the hearings to manifest the strong regional splits over the issue. ``Certainly, there is a great divergence of opinion among producers in various parts of the country on changes needed in the order program,'' said Jim Barr, chief executive officer of the National Milk Producers Federation in Virginia. The Federation represents about 100,000 dairy farmers who produce 70 percent of the nation's milk, Barr said. The group's membership is about evenly split over whether the current system should be changed, he said. An administrative law judge will conduct the Agriculture Department hearings, which will explore about 60 different proposals to alter the system, U.S. Rep. Steven Gunderson, R-Wis., said. The administrative law judge will make recommendations to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who observers predict will take two to three years to institute changes. Three days of testimony are planned in Eau Claire. The remaining hearings will be Sept. 10-19 in Minneapolis; Sept. 20 in St. Cloud, Minn.; Oct. 1-5 in Syracuse, N.Y.; Oct. 10-12 in Tallahassee, Fla., and Oct. 15 in Dallas. The present system includes a transportation factor in determining what farmers are paid for milk. The farther a farmer lives from Eau Claire, the more the producer receives. While Wisconsin remains the No. 1 milk producing state with about 17.5 percent of the nation's milk supply _ a title it has held for the last century _ California has moved into second place with a 13-percent share of the market. Eau Claire became the measuring spot for the transportation differential in 1961 because the bulk of U.S. was produced in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and Eau Claire was center of that production. ``When you look at the kind of increases in production in the South and West, there simply is no rhyme or reason for providing incentives based on how far you live away from Eau Claire,'' Gunderson said. For example, in June, a Wisconsin dairy farmer, on the average, earned $14.20 for every eight gallons of milk he produced, based on the federal milk orders, Barr said. The same farmer in Florida got $17.30.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchange Seat Price at Lowest Since December 1984
DOC.TEXT: It's getting a little easier to get into one of business's more exclusive clubs. Two New York Stock Exchange seats in the past two months have each sold for $301,000 each, the lowest level in more than 5{ years. Prices of seats _ which entitle members to trade directly on the stock exchange floor _ tend to reflect the level of trading volume on the NYSE, the nation's largest stock exchange. The latest sale, on Tuesday, matched the price paid on Aug. 23, continues a decline that has driven down prices from the all-time high of $1.15 million in September 1987, a month before the stock market crashed. A seat last sold for $300,000 on Dec. 17, 1984. Brokerage firms in the last year have reduced personnel and operations, individual investors have shied away from stocks and commission rates have fallen _ reducing the desirability of owning a seat. Less trading means lower commissions and less revenue for brokerage firms. The price of an NYSE membership has fallen steadily since the 1987 market crash after a steady rise that took seats from a low of $35,000 in 1977 to $105,000 in 1978, $425,000 in 1983 and $600,000 in 1986. The high seat price this year was $430,000 on June 7, according to stock exchange records. There have been 24 seat sales so far in 1990 _ including seven in August _ compared with 26 in all of 1989. The most recent seat sales have been $370,000 on July 17, $330,000 on Aug. 3, $325,000 on Aug. 14, $320,000 on Aug. 15, $310,000 on Aug. 20, $301,000 on Aug. 23, $309,000 on Aug. 28 and $305,000 on Aug. 31. Following the latest sale, the quoted price for a seat was $350,000 with a bid of $280,000. The quoted price is the asking price and the bid is what a buyer is willing to pay. Seat prices also have fallen at the American Stock Exchange to 10-year lows, but the sharp rise in oil prices since Iraq seized Kuwait last month has driven up seats on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil futures are traded. The seat system dates to 1868, when stock exchange membership was made saleable. Before that, each member had a lifetime seat reserved in one place. Physically, there haven't been seats on the floor for years, and the name dates to a time when brokers literally sat around trading a roster of stocks. The number of seats has been limited to 1,366 since 1953.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's: Real Estate Loans Continue To Threaten Banks
DOC.TEXT: Troubled loans for real estate and leveraged buyouts are adding to the burdens of the nation's biggest banks, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said. The problems are hindering the banks' recoveries from past mistakes in lending to developing nations, the credit rating agency said. In a pessimistic annual review, Moody's said Tuesday the 1990s may be the decade in which some powerful regional institutions challenge the supremacy of the nationwide ``money-center'' banks. While the creditworthiness of most of the nine money-center banks has steadily declined since the 1970s, problems have accelerated in recent years with credit rating reductions. Moody's said in a 37-page report that major trouble spots for banks are $55 billion in commercial real estate loans, inadequate reserves to cover nonperforming loans to developing countries and a large exposure to buyouts and other high-risk transactions. The nine money center banks are BankAmerica Corp., Bankers Trust New York Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp., Chemical Bank Corp., Citicorp, Continental Bank Corp., First Chicago Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp. and J.P. Morgan & Co. The report said that all the money centers except J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust are undercapitalized because of ``the sharp deterioration in domestic asset quality and low domestic reserves.'' Moody's said it was not clear the banks could rebuild capital quickly enough to absorb additional provisions against domestic and developing country loans, which might be required. The report mentioned Security Pacific Corp. of Los Angeles, Wells Fargo & Co. of San Francisco, NCNB Corp. of Charlotte, N.C., and Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, as key ``superregionals'' for the 1990s. The most recent round of credit-rating downgrades affecting Citicorp and other giants were prompted by the real estate slump, and Moody's offered no promises that further downgrades could be avoided. Moody's said vacancy rates remain high in big cities, which appear to be overbuilt, and that construction loans of all types are ``potentially troublesome, particularly for hotels and strip shopping centers.'' Market psychology has deteriorated, as the savings and loan scandal has forced many regional and money-center banks to reduce new real estate lending. That has put developers under pressure and made existing properties tough to sell, Moody's said. The credit agency listed Texas, Arizona, New England, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Colorado as ``highly distressed'' markets. It said ``significant risk elements'' exist in New Jersey, Georgia, Maryland, Virginia, Pennsylvania, California, New York and Florida. Chemical Bank had the largest percentage of nonperforming commercial real estate loans _ on which no interest is being paid _ at 15.5 percent, followed by Citicorp at 13.9 percent and First Chicago at 12.6 percent. J.P. Morgan had by far the lowest rate, 0.4 percent. Overall, 11.4 percent of the banks' $54.9 billion in commercial real estate loans outstanding in March were described as nonperforming, the report said. Moody's also said banks' still need to increase their reserves to account for a larger slice of outstanding loans to Latin American countries. Moody's said average coverage by banks increased to 50 percent in the first quarter of 1990 from 37 percent in 1988, but the level remains below the 75 percent to 100 percent established by most regional and international banks. Further clouding the future of national banks is exposure to high-risk transactions, mostly leveraged buyouts initiated in the mid to late 1980s. In a leveraged buyout, an investor or investors borrow a large amount of money to purchase a corporation and then sell assets to make interest payments. Moody's said the nation's money-center banks had $54 billion in exposure to highly leveraged transaction at the end of 1989, up from $32 billion in 1988, in part because of a broader regulatory definition. But the report pegged ``HLT'' exposure as a major coming problem area, with nonperforming assets expected to rise substantially. Compounding the problems is the collapse of the junk bond market, which was envisioned as a place to refinance some leveraged buyouts. ``Problem borrowers may go bankrupt, resulting in a lengthy workout process before the banks can recover their principal,'' Moody's said. ``In several instances, asset sales have fetched prices below expectations,'' the report said. ``As a consequence, those LBO structures that rely upon asset sales or refinancing to meet maturing principal . . . may encounter difficulty in the next few years.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING f0013, adds Bjt designator.
IMF Study of Soviet Economy to be on Helsinki Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, which has prescribed financial austerity and free-market capitalism for countries from Mexico to Mozambique, may be about to issue the same prescription to the capital of world communism. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday that an IMF-led study of the Soviet economy will be on the agenda when President Bush meets with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday. Industrialized nations meeting at the economic summit in Houston in July ordered the IMF and three other international financial institutions to study the Soviet Union's needs and the opportunities for western help. ``President Bush will be interested in the progress that has been made in that assessment, and President Gorbachev's views of the reform effort,'' Fitzwater said. The IMF, founded in a New Hampshire village 46 years ago to stabilize the exchange of money among nations, is coordinating the study. Also taking part are the Washington-based World Bank, which makes loans for projects in Third World countries; the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; and the newly formed European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Graham Newman, deputy chief of the IMF information office, said a team representing the four organizations has been in the Soviet Union conducting interviews and collecting data for the study, which is due to be completed by the end of the year. Newman said the IMF will not have a representative in Helsinki, but it ``could well be'' that the team will submit to the president a memo on its progress. Of the four agencies, the IMF is perhaps the most controversial, partly because of policies that its critics say have imposed stringent economic rules on developing nations to the detriment of the poor. ``The standard prescription for countries suffering from inflation to get an IMF loan is dismissal of workers from public employment, deflation of the currency and removal of subsidies on basic staples,'' said Laurence Birns, president of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs. ``There is no question that the group that bears the heaviest burden in these restructuring efforts are the poor and the rural middle class.'' IMF spokesman Newman conceded that ``in any economy, when adjustments need to be made, there are some short-term problems.'' But Newman said the fund encourages the countries to develop ``a safety net to protect the most disadvantaged.'' ``I suppose one has to look at the alternatives,'' Newman said. ``If countries do not put their economies back in order again, things are only going to go from bad to worse, and the poor are going to suffer even more.'' In addition to barbs from liberals such as Birns and his group, the IMF has faced opposition from economic conservatives. ``I think the problem is that they have essentially become a dole,'' said Doug Bandow, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute. ``We have seen throughout Latin America that as a practical matter countries will get money year after year even if they don't live up to their conditions.'' Newman took issue, saying, ``If performance criteria have not been attained and a country wants to continue with the program, that triggers an automatic consultation to find out what went wrong and why it went wrong.'' He said IMF loans have been stopped in ``many, many cases.'' Bandow also argued that IMF conditions encourage countries to adopt protectionist measures which hurt their economies, and to raise taxes rather than reduce spending to curb budget deficits. ``My guess is that the study (of the Soviet economy) may not be a bad thing,'' Bandow said. ``The problem is that the policy of the IMF suggests that whatever the study is the outcome isn't going to be terribly helpful.'' The five-month deadline for the Soviet study came as a shock to some in organizations accustomed to more leisurely studies. ``We did a study of the Chinese economy many years ago,'' said Peter Riddleberger, press manager for the World Bank. ``It took several years, of course.'' Hernan Puentes, a Chilean economist who is Riddleberger's counterpart at the IMF, said, ``I tell you people are scared to death of being asked to do it in five months. It's going to mean sleepless nights for a lot of people.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Cutting Ax Out Again at Chrysler
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca is telling his executives to cut the budget, again. For the second time since June 1989, Chrysler has boosted its target for cost-cutting _ this time to $2.5 billion by the end of June. It had been $1.5 billion by the end of this year which, in turn, was up from the original $1 billion. Chrysler's cost-cutting program comes as its profits and sales sink. Iacocca disclosed the latest target in an interview in Tuesday's editions of The Wall Street Journal. Spokesman Steve Harris said the means for removing the additional expenditures haven't been worked out yet. ``Some tentative targets were being talked about,'' Harris said Tuesday. ``We haven't formalized that yet or put the program in place. That is a tentative target that he (Iacocca) is looking at.'' Harris said product-development plans would be exempt from any new round of cuts. ``Anything having to do with the product or customer satisfaction is intact,'' he said. Industry observers generally agree that Chrysler badly needs to introduce a new mid-size sedan as soon as possible to freshen its lineup. The next such car is code-named ``LH'' and is due in dealerships in late 1992 as a 1993 model. Also on Tuesday, Chrysler tacked seven months onto the life of its St. Louis car plant, which employs about 2,300 workers. Chrysler had initially planned to close the plant Sept. 21, then delayed it until Nov. 9. Company spokesman Alan Miller said the factory now is due to close May 24, at the end of production for the 1991-model Dodge Daytona and Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible cars. Daytona production will be moved to Sterling Heights, Mich., and LeBaron production is to transfer to Newark, Del. Chrysler's sales this year have been slumping. Through the first seven months of 1990, the company sold about 1.04 million cars and light trucks, down 15.5 percent from last year. Iacocca said in the Journal interview that the cost cutting prevented Chrysler from going into the red during the first half of this year. The company made $251 million during the first six months of 1990, 64 percent less than it made during the same period last year. Part of the reason for the decline in profits has been Chrysler's continued heavy use of incentives to prop up sales. Company officials have said incentives cost Chrysler more than $1,000 for every vehicle sold. Wall Street analysts and Chrysler executives expect the company will lose a substantial amount of money in the third quarter, mainly because of production interruptions at its two profitable minivan plants. The two factories were shut down for four weeks apiece for retooling for 1991 models. Chrysler has eliminated about 2,500 of its 28,700 white-collar jobs since last October, Harris said. The cost-cutting program was announced in July 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Cars and Other Vehicles Recalled for Too Much Pollution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was included in PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motors Corp. is recalling about 92,000 cars and 75,000 trucks and utility vehicles that fail to meet federal exhaust pollution standards. The Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that the cars are 1987 Mitsubishi Mirage and Dodge Colt and Plymouth Colt models equipped with 1.5-liter engines. The other vehicles are 1986 and 1987 models equipped with the 2-liter engine _ 1986 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive and two-wheel-drive Dodge Ram 50 and Mitsubishi trucks, and 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive. The Dodge and Plymouth models concerned are manufactured by Mitsubishi. The agency said routine testing discovered that the cars emit more than the permitted about of carbon monoxide, and the trucks and utility vehicles emit too much carbon monoxide and unburned fuel. Owners will be asked to schedule appointments at Mitsubishi or Dodge and Plymouth dealers for modifications _ installation of a new valve in the pollution control system of the cars and changes in the fuel systems of the trucks and utility vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Backs Greater Business Role in Improving Education
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was included in PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Businesses should play a greater role in improving schools by investing more dollars and personnel to boost quality and prepare students for the workforce, according to a nationwide poll. The Roper Organization poll was released Tuesday. Commissioned by an affiliate of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, it found 96 percent of Americans with children in public school, as well as 91 percent of all Americans, are concerned about the quality of education in their communities. Three-quarters of those polled agreed that public schools are failing to prepare students for jobs now available. Sixty-three percent said most students will lack skills for jobs in the future. Most of the 1,003 adult Americans polled by telephone last month were receptive to the involvement of business in local public education. Ninety-one percent said it is a good idea for business to provide equipment to schools, while 6 percent thought it was a bad idea and 2 percent didn't know.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Slaps Embargo on Kellogg's Heartwise Cereal
DOC.TEXT: Texas officials have imposed a distribution embargo on Kellogg Co.'s Heartwise cereal in Texas in a dispute over labeling. On Tuesday, the Texas Health Department ordered warehouses to halt distribution of the cereal. It accused Kellogg of deceptive labeling and of failing to warn consumers about potential allergic reactions to psyllium, a whole grain touted by Kellogg as a cholesterol fighter. Texas is the only state that has sought to ban sales of Heartwise, which was introduced last year by the Battle Creek, Mich.-based cereal maker and has prompted a federal inquiry into the safety of psyllium. Last week, Kellogg filed a federal lawsuit in Dallas against the Texas Health Department and the attorney general's office to try to ward off the embargo and allow the company to retain its current labeling on the product. ``For the state of Texas to detain Heartwise on the basis of their belief that it's an unapproved drug is totally ridiculous and a total disregard for the science behind psyllium,'' Kellogg spokesman Joseph Stewart said. Kellogg maintains that psyllium, a grain grown mainly in India, has been scientifically shown to help reduce cholesterol when used as part of a complete nutritional diet. The soluble fiber is used in laxatives and its inclusion in Heartwise has led to a controversy in the food industry about whether the cereal should be considered a drug or food. The Food and Drug Administration is currently reviewing data on psyllium's safety and the company's cholesterol-fighting claims. ``I think this goes back to the labeling of foods with drug-like claims,'' said Dan Sowards, chief of the food branch for the Texas Department of Health. ``The FDA ... has said products that continued to make health claims would be subject to scrutiny.'' Sowards said his department has asked Kellogg to change the product's name and remove heart symbols from the box as well as references to hospital endorsements. It also has asked for inclusion of warnings about potential allergic reactions to psyllium. Sowards said data given to the FDA by Kellogg include at least 50 cases of allergic reactions to the grain and some of them required hospitalization. Kellogg maintains Heartwise has been shown to be safe. Most grains, including wheat, cause allergic reactions in a very small percentage of people, Stewart said. Three independent university studies released in April found psyllium to be more effective in fighting cholesterol than wheat or oat bran cereals. Stewart said the embargo's timing _ less than a week after the lawsuit was filed _ shows that it is ``politically motivated and not out of any concern for public safety.'' He said the company is worried about the controversy's affect on the cereal's sales, which have been disappointing. John McMillin, a food analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities of New York, said those worries are justified. ``This just might be the nail in the coffin for Heartwise,'' McMillin said. ``It is my own feeling that the state of Texas has no business doing this ... but consumers, and the state of Texas, seem to perceive this as a drug and not as a food.'' General Mills Inc. pulled its psyllium-based cereal, Benefit, in January, citing poor sales.

DOC.HEAD: Penney Pulls Clothes after Protests
DOC.TEXT: Boys clothes with an anti-hunting message have been pulled from J.C. Penney Co. Inc. store shelves due to hunter complaints, one of them from Michigan's largest conservation and sportsmen's group. Duncan Muir, public relations manager for the Dallas-based retailer, said the decision was made Tuesday after complaints from across the nation. ``It is our company policy not to take a position one way or the other on these sorts of issues. This is taking a position and an anti- position,'' he said. ``Obviously, this was pointed out to us and frankly we feel we've made a mistake. All we can do is just withdraw it from the stores,'' he said. Michigan's largest conservation and sportsmen's group, Michigan United Conservation Clubs, took aim at Penney on Friday. Conservation Clubs Executive Director Thomas Washington said the clothes were a slap in the face to Michigan's million hunters. He said the clothing's message that ``anyone who enjoys hunting is somehow dangerous and evil, is simply outrageous.'' A card attached to each shirt in the clothing line shows a sketch of a bird hunter aiming a shotgun over which a large red ``X'' has been marked. Under that are the words: ``Absolutely No Hunting of Wild and Free Animals While Wearing This Garment.'' A similar message is stitched into an inside panel of the garment. Pants have a larger card with the message: ``Wild life protected by man surround the world with pure thoughts.'' Tags in the clothes indicate it was made in Hong Kong. Penney bought the ``Environmental Protection Department'' line of clothing from a New York company, H. Cotler Co. The head of the company, Howard Cotler, was in a meeting Tuesday and didn't return telephone calls seeking comment. In a letter to the National Rifle Association last week, Cotler said the anti-hunting message was a marketing tool that had been discontinued. He wrote that his company ``neither condemns nor supports anti-gun or anti-hunting legislation'' and it was trying to appeal to the environmental awareness of young people. Muir said he didn't know how many pieces of clothing were being taken off Penney store shelves. ``It's in various stages of shipment. A lot of it is still on its way and stores order on their own, so it's hard to say how many pieces are out there.'' He declined to place a dollar figure on the Penney order to Cotler, saying that was an internal inventory matter. Muir also said the retailer hadn't decided what to do with the clothes. Penney is the nation's largest department store chain with 1,330 stores.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges, Stocks Touch 1990 Low
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS one new graf after 4th graf pvs, At one . . . to include reference to lowest close of the year. Picks up 5th graf pvs, A light . . .
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plummeted today to its lowest close against the Japanese yen in Tokyo this year, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index also fell to a 1990 low before recovering somewhat. Analysts said the dollar and Tokyo stock prices suffered from economic uncertainties arising from higher oil prices and expectations of a possible easing of U.S. interest rates. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 829.30 points, or 3.33 percent, closing at 24,078.34. This followed plunges of 557.94 points on Monday and 512.79 points on Tuesday. At one point in Wednesday's trading, the index fell to 23,640.52, down 1,267.12 points from Tuesday's close and its lowest level this year. The lowest closing level for the Nikkei was 23,737.63 set on Aug. 23. A light 380 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from Tuesday's 330 million shares. ``With the Mideast situation remaining in stalemate, uncertainties over the world economy are making investors reluctant to buy,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities. Nishiguchi said selling of futures by some institutional investors to prepare for midterm account settlements this month accelerated the index's decline. ``There were almost no buyers as most institutional investors took a wait-and-see position in thin trading,'' said a dealer at a major Japanese securities firm, speaking on condition of anonymity. Declining issues included large-capital steel, shipbuilding, heavy electrical machinery and paper pulp. The dollar closed at 142.30 yen, down 1.75 yen from Tuesday's finish of 144.05 yen and its lowest close since 142.15 yen on Dec. 28. It opened at 143.08 yen and ranged between 142.17 yen and 143.25 yen. Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar was hit by speculation that U.S. monetary authorities might ease credit. Many economists say the U.S. economy is headed into a recession and the Federal Reserve Board, the nation's central bank, will move to encourage lower interest rates. Lower interest rates tend to make a nation's currency less attractive to foreign investors. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond edged up to 8.180 percent from Tuesday's close of 8.130 percent. The price stood at 82.76 points, down from 82.96 on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Sikorsky, Korean Air Announce Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Sikorsky Aircraft and Korean Air say they will work together to make Black Hawk helicopters for the Korean government. Under terms of the agreement announced Tuesday, the number of helicopters to be produced and the value of the deal were not released. ``Sikorsky is proud to be associated with a company with the worldwide reputation and prestige of Korean Air, and we are particularly pleased to be part of a program that will provide Black Hawk helicopters to one of America's staunchest allies, the Republic of Korea,'' Sikorsky President Eugene Buckley said in a prepared statement. The Black Hawk is the United States Army's standard transport helicopter. Korean Air has made light helicopters and jet fighters. It is one of three Korean companies designated by the Korean government to produce aircraft as part of a consolidation of that nation's aerospace industry.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Data Puts Heath Business Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Data Systems, a division of Groupe Bull, says its Heath electronics business is for sale. The Heath Co., based in St. Joseph, Mich., manufactures and markets home-security products, educational systems and home electronics, including the Heathkit line of build-it-yourself electronic kits. The announcement does not affect the Heath-Zenith Business Centers, which are operated separately from the Heath Co., ZDS said Tuesday in a statement. John P. Frank, ZDS president and chief executive, said ZDS was selling Heath to focus its activities on the personal computer market. Groupe Bull, a French computer company, completed its purchase of Zenith Data Systems from Zenith Electronics Corp. in April.

DOC.HEAD: Austria's Laudia Air Orders Three Boeing Jetliners
DOC.TEXT: Laudia Air of Austria has ordered three Boeing jetliners worth about $180 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group announced. The order for one 767-300 extended-range jet and two 737-400s was signed Tuesday at the Farnborough Air Show in Farnborough, England. Laudia Air founder and president Nicki Lauda also confirmed another 737-400 on order which had not been announced previously. That aircraft is valued at about $37 million. The 737-400, the largest of the 737 twinjet series, can carry 146 to 170 passengers in a variety of configurations. The extended-range 767-300 can carry 269 passengers on non-stop trips of up to 7,000 miles, Boeing said in a release. The announcement brought firm orders for the Boeing 737-400 to 240, and orders for the 767-300ER to 151.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's Trade Surplus Up 8.6 Percent in August
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan's trade surplus grew 8.6 percent to $1.59 billion in August from a year earlier, the government said Wednesday. Exports slipped 1.3 percent to $5.87 billion from a year ago, while imports dropped 4.5 percent to $4.28 billion, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics. In August, Taiwan had a trade surplus with the U.S. totalling $1.06 billion, down 10 percent from a year earlier. Taiwan exports to the U.S. were $2.01 billion, while imports from the U.S. totaled $950 million. The agency said Taiwan's overall trade surplus for January through August was $8.01 billion, down 15.1 percent from the same period 1989. Exports in the first eight months of this year fell 1 percent to $44.03 billion, while imports rose 2.8 percent to $36.02 billion.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Unveils Next-Generation Mainframe Computers
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with IBM announcement. Edits throughout to tighten. May be led after 11 a.m. EDT news conference.
DOC.TEXT: IBM today announced its next generation of mainframe computers as part of a strategy designed to ensure the large machines' place at the center of corporate information systems. The world's largest computer company also announced replacement models for several lower-level computer lines in what the company said was its most sweeping announcement in 25 years. International Business Machines Corp. announced 18 new computers, including a top-of-the-line model that provides twice the power of its current high-end model. The new machines are part of what IBM calls its System-390 line, replacing its current System-370. This is only the third mainframe system line from IBM since the early 1960s. The new machines, which are called the Enterprise System-9000 family, range in price from $70,480 to $22.8 million. IBM says its new top-end model will be the most powerful computer on the market, however, this model won't be available until the third quarter of 1991. Many of the lower level models will be available later this year or early next year. As part of its announcement today, IBM also disclosed new ways to link various size computers in a network and new operating system software for the new computer line. Despite the increasing popularity of smaller computers, mainframes account for about half of IBM's profits when associated software and equipment are included. That makes acceptance of the new models crucial. The introduction of the new machines, which has been rumored for more than a year, also is important to IBM because its competitors are stepping up the pressure. The major makers of IBM-compatible mainframes, Hitachi Data Systems Corp., Fujitsu and Amdahl Corp., all are planning major upgrades to their machines. On Tuesday, Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, beat IBM to the punch. It announced a powerful new mainframe that it says is the fastest in the world. Fujitsu officials said the top model in their new M-1800 series is capable of executing up to 600 million instructions per second, or mips, in scientific calculations. However, the Fujitsu machine would not be capable of achieving that speed in commercial applications. Analysts say the new top-of-the-line IBM computer will run at a maximum speed of about 230 mips. IBM's current most-powerful mainframe can handle about 112 mips. IBM does not disclose its mips ratings of computers. IBM also said that customers will be able to link eight of the next top-end models to operate as one machine, boosting power dramatically. Fujitsu's new technology is likely to appear in mainframes produced by Amdahl, a U.S. maker of IBM-compatible mainfames that is 45 percent owned by Fujitsu. Hitachi and Amdahl traditionally undercut IBM's prices, and their share of the U.S. mainframe market has been growing while IBM's slipped in recent years. But IBM still holds about 87 percent of the U.S. high-end mainframe market, according to Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., research firm. IBM compared the importance of today's announcement to the 1964 disclosure of its System-360 line, considered a milestone in the computer industry. The company even rented a special Amtrak train to take reporters from New York City to the announcement site at its Poughkeepsie mainframe plant. Mainframes typically are used by large corporations such as airlines and insurance companies to hold vast amounts of data, such as information on millions of customer accounts. The new IBM machines feature fiber-optic lines to link the computers to data-storage devices. Fiber-optic lines, which transmit information in beams of laser light, can move data to the computer's processor at about twice the rate of the standard electrical lines used on the 3090s, IBM's current top machines, helping speed processing. While the System-390 represents a major improvement, some analysts say it doesn't appear to be the breakthrough they earlier expected. ``It is not a qualitatively different type of technology. The 3090 is being extended,'' said Tom Willmott, a vice president of Aberdeen Group, a Boston-based research firm. He doesn't think the doubling of processing power will do much to improve the operation of data-base programs that are among the most popular uses for high-end mainframes. Analysts also expressed concern that some of the new models won't be available until the second half of 1991. That lag could cause customers to defect to competitiors or postpone orders that would have gone to 3090s, hurting IBM's revenues.

DOC.HEAD: Major Japanese Banks May Face Credit Downgrading
DOC.TEXT: A handful of major Japanese banks may face a downgrading in their credit ratings following the recent dramatic fall in the Tokyo stock market and amid pressure to improve their profitability, an international credit rating agency said Wednesday. Among the banks put on ``rating watch'' by the ratings agency IBCA are the so-called big five city banks _ Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Fuji Bank, Mitsubishi Bank, Sanwa Bank and Sumitomo Bank _ and the Industrial Bank of Japan. These institutions currently carry a AAA rating, the highest credit rating available. But IBCA noted that their results in recent years ``have been increasingly dominated by the stock market,'' which has declined sharply this year. That decline, coupled with the weakness of the Japanese yen, ``have brought to an end the virtuous circle whereby Japanese banks could finance at insignificant costs virtually any level of growth,'' the agency's report said. IBCA predicted life for Japanese banks ``is going to be more difficult for here on.'' The big-five banks have increased their equity base by more than 300 percent over the past five years, or roughly $40 billion, the agency said. But those gains were possible because Japanese investors have been willing to ``put up with minimal dividends.'' IBCA said once-pliant investors may ``go on strike'' as capital losses mount. Further, IBCA noted that Japanese banks have been slower than their international peers in setting aside reserves to cover problem foreign loans, and those losses are expected to mount. But the agency said its overall concerns center on high monetary growth and the current international tensions rather than the performance of individual banks. IBCA said that other Japanese banks also may be put on a ratings watch.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Tribune Names `Public Editor'
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Kneeland has been named to the new position of public editor of the Chicago Tribune, the newspaper has announced. As public editor, Kneeland will ensure that ``legitimate complaints about the newspaper's behavior are heard and redressed,'' Tribune editor Jack Fuller said in announcing the appointment Tuesday. Kneeland, 61, had served as associate editor@editorial pages. Kneeland will see to it in his post ``that errors of fact and taste are aggressively corrected and that the Tribune lives up to the high standards of behavior the public rightly expects,'' Fuller said. Kneeland has been a Tribune staffer since 1981. He has worked as national-foreign editor and as an associate managing editor. Replacing Kneeland as second in command on the editorial page is N. Don Wycliff, 43, whose title will be deputy editorial page editor, the paper said. Wycliff joins the paper from The New York Times, where he served as a member of the editorial board. Before joining the Tribune, Kneeland worked for the New York Times from 1959 to 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Borden Buys Astro Industries
DOC.TEXT: Consumer and industrial products giant Borden Inc. said Wednesday it has acquired the assets of Astro Industries Inc., a North Carolina-based producer of specialty resins. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Astro Industries, based in Morgantown, N.C., makes thermosetting specialty resins for use in making decorative laminates, treating and coating textile and paper products and surface coating. Its sales amount to about $9 million a year, and it employs about 20 people. Astro will be operated as part of Borden's worldwide packaging and industrial products division, Borden said, and its co-founder Ernest St. Louis will continue as president and general manager of the unit. Borden is a worldwide producer of foods, non-food consumer products and packaging and industrial products with sales of $7.6 billion in 1989.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 382.85 up 1.18 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Up Slightly in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose this morning, and most gasoline futures traded higher in response to the uncertainties of the Middle East standoff and increased consumer demand. ``As the situation keeps dragging on, the market is nervous,'' said Hartley Connett, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``People are topping off their tanks and it's creating some very, very good demand right now.'' Crude oil futures were trading 13 cents higher at $29.25 per barrel for October delivery late this morning on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Unleaded regular gasoline was down 1.32 cents to 93.20 cents per gallon on October contracts. But gasoline futures contracts for later months were all higher, by as much as 2.6 cents per gallon on the contract for November delivery. Traders who speculate on petroleum futures have kept gasoline prices higher in response to fears that refining capacity lost in the embargo of Iraq and Kuwait cannot be made up, even if increased OPEC oil production is able offset the crude shortfall. Service stations and consumers have also been keeping their tanks fuller than usual. ``Gasoline is the one that's leading us to the upside,'' Connett said. On the crude futures, traders were maintaining the momentum of higher prices reached in the European and Far East markets, Connett said. There was no specific news from the Persian Gulf that was affecting the oil prices, he said. Home heating oil prices were also higher, rising .71 cent to 83.10 cents per gallon for October delivery. Natural gas was trading at $1.505 per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts, down from Tuesday's close of $1.510.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Lead Crop Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government reported a slight deterioration in the condition of the U.S. soybean crop. The share of the soybean crop in good to excellent condition slipped to 58 percent last week from 59 percent a week earlier, mainly reflecting hot, dry weather in the Mississippi Delta region, analysts said. The Agriculture Department's weekly crop-progress report also showed corn and soybean development continuing to lag behind the normal pace, leaving the crops unusually vulnerable to an early frost. Today's early, across-the-board advance in grain prices followed a powerful rally in soybean prices Tuesday that was attributed largely to bargain hunting and chart-based speculation after last week's sharp drop in the market. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the crop markets also drew strength from speculation the U.S. may offer the Soviet Union credit to buy agricultural products when President Bush meets Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev this weekend. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.58{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2\ cents higher with September at $2.43 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with September at $1.08{ a bushel; and soybeans were \ cent lower to 3 cents higher with September at $6.09 a bushel. Cattle futures were lower and pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .15 cent lower to .15 cent higher with October at 76.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .32 cent lower to .05 cent higher with September at 87 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .48 cent higher with October at 49.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .68 cent to .70 cent higher with February at 50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures advanced on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Auto Workers Target Ford
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union will focus its national contract bargaining on Ford of Canada Ltd., the Canadian subsidiary of the world's second-largest automaker, union officials said Wednesday. CAW President Bob White announced the decision after meeting for several days with union leaders bargaining with subsidiaries of Ford Motor Co., General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. Ford of Canada's chief negotiator, Don McKenzie, said the company welcomed the decision and said although there are a lot of issues on the bargaining table, they could be resolved in 10 days. The CAW represents about 63,000 auto workers in Canada. Union contracts with the three companies expire Sept. 14, the same as United Auto Workers union contracts with the Big Three in the United States. Those contracts cover more than 450,000 active auto workers. The UAW has chosen GM, the industry's largest, as its bargaining target. Traditionally, the UAW and the CAW bargain with the target company and use a contract ratified with it as a pattern for the other two.

DOC.HEAD: Boise Cascade Agrees to Sell Washington Paper Mill
DOC.TEXT: Boise Cascade Corp. said Wednesday it has agreed to sell its Vancouver, Wash., paper mill in the first major step toward dramatically reducing its Pacific Northwest pulp and paper operations. Appleton Papers Inc., based in Appleton, Wis., will pay about $60 million for the mill and another $12 million for its finished goods inventories in the deal that should be completed by year's end. The mill, employing some 450 workers, has a papermaking capacity of 100,000 tons. The Boise-based wood products company has produced carbonless paper and other business communications papers at the facility. ``The sale of the Vancouver mill will be the first major step toward Boise Cascade's stated objective of reducing its pulp and paper presence in the Pacific Northwest,'' Chairman John B. Fery said. ``The sale also supports a second objective of focusing on white paper grades other than carbonless.'' The company, buffeted by reduced earnings in recent quarters, announced earlier this summer it would take steps to increase shareholder value in the 1990s. Appleton Papers, a subsidiary of Wiggins Teape Appleton PLC of London, is the world's leading producer of carbonless paper and the top U.S. producer of thermal paper. It also makes colored enamels and other specialty coated papers at facilities in Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Want Ads for Jobs Stagnant
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT - time set by source
DOC.TEXT: An index measuring changes in help-wanted advertising in major U.S. newspapers stayed the same in July and was 17 points lower than a year earlier, the Conference Board said Wednesday. The business research group said its Help-Wanted Index registered 132 in July, unchanged from June's reading and down from 149 in July of last year. Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist, said events in the Middle East could cause businesses, including exporters, to put some hiring plans on hold. Prior to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the economy, and the labor market in particular, appeared poised for modest improvement, he said. ``Now it is more likely that exporters, business investors, and consumers will put some plans on hold until the economic and political situation in the Persian Gulf becomes more clear,'' Goldstein said. ``For the labor market, that probably means no big staff expansions over the next few months and little chance of want-ad volume quickly turning around,'' he said. Parts of the country in which oil plays an economic role could experience job gains if the recent spike in oil prices encourages growth in oil exploration, the board said in a news release. The Conference Board, based in New York, collects information for its Help-Wanted Index from 51 big newspapers around the country each month. Ad volume is sensitive to labor market conditions and considered to be a gauge of changes in the supply of jobs at the local, regional and national levels.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Merc Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 new grafs to update with jury selection beginning; Picks up 4th graf pvs, ``A 15th...
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began today in what promised to be a lengthy and complicated trial of 14 currency traders charged in a wide-ranging probe of corruption in the city's commodities pits. The defendants, all traders of Japanese yen futures contracts, face 393 counts stemming from allegedly illegal trading practices at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Jury selection began before U.S. District Court Judge William T. Hart, said a clerk in Hart's chambers who declined to be identified by name. Hart has set opening statements for next Tuesday in the trial, which is expected to last four months. A 15th defendant, Martin Riley Jr., pleaded no contest during pretrial motions Tuesday to one count of mail fraud and two counts of violating the Commodities Exchange Act, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Gillogly. Riley, a trader in the Japanese Yen pit, listed financial and health reasons when entering the plea. Hart accepted the plea conditionally until he reviewed Riley's financial and health records, Gillogly said. The trial is the second major trial stemming from an undercover FBI investigation at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. The 14 defendants are accused of violating the Commodities Exchange Act by executing trades outside the open-outcry system at the futures exchanges. In all, 48 people have been indicted in the probe. FBI agents posed as traders and secretly tape recorded conversations that prosecutors said revealed fraud among traders at the Merc and the CBOT. In the first trial, a federal jury convicted two Swiss franc traders on relatively minor trading violations. A third trader was acquitted. The jury in that trial failed to reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one of the defendants and mail and wire-fraud charges against all three. The scandal prompted the Merc, the CBOT and their regulators to adopt tougher anti-fraud measures. And Congress is considering regulatory changes to strengthen the markets' integrity. Yen trader Aric March pleaded guilty Aug. 24 to two counts of mail and commodities fraud. As part of a plea agreement, the government agreed to drop fraud charges against him. According to court documents, the government had accused March of prearranging trades of S&P 500 futures with another broker. March is expected to testify in the other yen traders' trial. Six of those traders are charged with racketeering conspiracy, and all are charged with wire and commodities fraud. The trial of 12 CBOT soybean futures traders is scheduled to begin Monday before U.S. District Judge George Marovich. One soybean trader who was to go on trial before Marovich pleaded guilty in late August to racketeering and tax fraud. The trader, James D. Nowak, was charged last year with two counts of racketeering, more than 200 counts of fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher on the London Stock Exchange Wednesday, although off the day's best levels in low-volume trading. The release of disappointing interim results for several companies caused a nervous start to the session, dealers said. But a positive opening on Wall Street boosted enthusiasm. ``London was looking for a lead, and Wall Street was as good as anything,'' one trader said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 4.2 points to 2, British officials said 30 British women and children trying to join that convoy in Kuwait were detained, but there were no details on why they had been stopped. The Iraqi News Agency on Wednesday quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying Iraq was doing its best to speed up the departure of foreign women and children. ``Iraq endeavors with all possible means to ensure their departure in cooperation with concerned countries,'' the news agency reported. It said ``all border points were open for their departure, and the Iraqi Airways was ready to lease its aircraft for flying them to any capital.'' More than 700 Western detainees _ women, children and a few ailing men _ left aboard two Iraqi Airways flights on Saturday in the first major airlift since Saddam announced they could go. Some evacuees also have traveled across the desert to neighboring countries. But the departures of others have been complicated by Iraq's refusal to allow foreign airlines to land in Baghdad and by long delays in processing exit permits. About 11,000 Westerners are now believed stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Most of the evacuees were women, young children and teen-agers, but some elderly and ailing men were also aboard the flights. On Tuesday, 135 foreigners, mostly West Germans, flew into Amman on a charter from Baghdad and then transferred to a Lufthansa flight. British millionaire Branson, owner of Virgin Atlantic, arrived in Amman with one of six jumbo jets he lent at the request of Jordan's American-born Queen Noor. He said he was worried more by the plight of stranded Asian refugees in Jordan than by Westerners, who are coming home. ``What we are doing is only a pittance,'' he said. ``Children and old people are dying. We need a massive airlift and ships. This is something the United Nations should do.'' He urged that all flights coming in to repatriate Asian refugees carry supplies for the more than 100,000 people housed in squalid camps in Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Big Loss in Fourth Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said Wednesday the costs of a previously-disclosed corporate restructuring left it with a loss of $238.4 million in its fourth fiscal quarter despite an 11 percent increase in sales. The loss for the quarter ended July 29 amounted to $1.84 per share. The foods company lost $194.7 million, or $1.51 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Its fourth-quarter sales rose to $1.44 billion from $1.3 billion in 1989. For the fiscal year, the company reported a profit of $4.4 million, or 3 cents per share, down 66 percent from $13.1 million, or 10 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 8.8 percent to $6.2 billion from $5.7 billion a year ago. Results were depressed by a charge for divestitures and restructuring of $301.6 million in the latest fiscal year, and by a restructuring charge of $260.8 million in the previous fiscal year. The company had announced in late June that it would take a $247 million charge for the year to cover the sale of several North American businesses, including most of its fresh and refrigerated products, and the closing of three facilities in Fremont, Neb., Grand Prarie, Texas, and Moorestown, N.J. That was in addition to planned charges for the year of about $55 million for the sale of five European operations. ``We have reorganized and restructured to eliminate the inefficient and unprofitable,'' said David Johnson, Campbell president and chief executive. ``This will improve earnings, returns and cash by reducing overheads and increasing manufacturing capacity utilization and by refocusing the company on its core businesses,'' Johnson said. Timothy S. Ramey, an analyst for County NatWest USA, said the earnings came as no surprise. ``It's really on line with expectations,'' Ramey said. ``What this company is trying to do is present a lean and meaner structure. ``We'll see after this restructuring how lean and mean it is,'' said Ramey.
