DOC.HEAD: BAT Industries Reports First-Half Earnings
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC, a tobacco and financial services conglomerate, on Wednesday reported a 17 percent increase in net profits in the first half of the year. The increase, however, came on an extraordinary gain, and the company's pre-tax profit was down 11 percent from the same period a year ago. BAT said net profit for the six months ended June 30 came to 773 million pounds, or $1.47 billion, compared to 660 million pounds, or $1.25 billion, in the previous six months. Earnings per share fell 20 percent, to 20.7 pence (39 cents) from 25.5 pence (48.5 cents) a year earlier. Pre-tax profit was 592 million pounds ($1.125 billion) compared to 668 million pounds ($1.27 billion). Sales rose 12 percent to 9.49 billion pounds ($18.03 billion), compared to 8.48 billion pounds ($16.11 billion) in the year-earlier period. The earnings report included 468 million pounds in extraordinary gains, largely from BAT's restructuring program. The program included the disposal of assets and spinoff of Wiggins Teape Appleton, a paper and pulp manufacturer, and the Argos retail chain. A year earlier the group had an extraordinary gain of 270 million pounds. ``I am pleased with the growth trends in both our tobacco and financial services activities,'' said BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy. However, he said, the weakness of the dollar and declines in world stock markets could affect earnings from the company's core businesses for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Beverage Company Posts 3 Percent Profit Increase in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The beverage giant Seagram Co. Ltd. said Wednesday a strong performance in its business outside North Amrica helped lift its earnings by 3 percent in the second quarter compared with a year ago. The Montreal-based Seagram said its results rose despite a charge for a previously announced staff reduction in its U.S. spirits business and continued higher fruit costs for its Tropicana beverages. Seagram said it earned $205 million, or $2.18 a share, in the three months ended July 31 compared with $199 million, or $2.07 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 8.7 percent to $1.42 billion from $1.30 billion a year earlier. Operating income rose 8.6 percent for the quarter to $152 million from $140 million a year earlier. Edgar Bronfman, president and chief operating officer, said the improvement in operating income and revenue ``are due primarily to the continued strong business performance of Seagram International in all regions.'' Seagram International covers Seagram's business outside North America. He said the company's Brazilian affiliate outperformed expectations, but the company is cautious about its prospects for the full year. Seagram announced July 17 that it was eliminating 177 positions in sales and marketing in its U.S. spirits business, called The House of Seagram. Only about 140 of those positions were filled at the time. The company has never disclosed the magnitude of the charge but said it expects to save about $15 million annually as a result of the cutbacks. The results included $65 million in dividends and $99 million in unremitted earnings on its 24.3 percent stake in E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Co., up from $57 million in dividends and $105 million in unremitted earnings a year ago. For the first six months, Seagram earned $392 million, or $4.15 a share, down slightly from $395 million, or $4.07 a share, a year earlier. Sales for the first half rose 7.1 percent to $2.71 billion from $2.53 billion a year earlier. Earnings per share rose for the six months despite the decline in earnings because there were fewer shares outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Zapata Sells Rigs to Bermuda-Based Arethusa Ltd
DOC.TEXT: Zapata Corp. said Wednesday it has signed a definitive agreement to sell its offshore drilling rig fleet to Bermuda-based Arethusa Ltd. for $298 million. The Houston-based corporation will own 8.75 percent of the new company and continue to manage the 12 rigs, Zapata officials said. ``The rig sale agreement is a major milestone in Zapata's comprehensive restructuring,'' said R.C. Lassiter, Zapata's chairman and chief executive officer. ``The company can now focus its attention on a tender offer for its outstanding subordinated debentures and on obtaining necessary stockholder approval.'' Company officials announced Aug. 23 Zapata had reached an agreement with bankers to restructure $560 million of debt. The cash tender offer for subordinated debentures will be the final step in the restructuring. The tender offer is expected to begin in early October when a proxy statement and offer documents are ready for distribution, company officials said. The sales transaction is expected to close Oct. 31 with Zapata investing $17.5 million of the $298 million in gross sales proceeds in an 8.75 percent interest in Arethusa Ltd. Of the remaining $280.5 million, $7.7 million will be used to pay commissions related to the rig sale and $53.6 million will be used to repay rig-specific debt. Besides operating Fitzwater said.

The questions asked Secretary of State James A. Baker III in two days on Capitol Hill reveal that lawmakers are worried about America's Persian Gulf commitment even if it succeeds in forcing Iraq's Saddam Hussein to withdraw behind his borders. Even then, congressmen wanted to know, what would keep Saddam's chemical and nuclear warfare potential _ not to mention his million-man army _ from again threatening the region? And _ an underlying question that poked through the accolades for Baker and President Bush _ they asked how the United States ultimately will extract itself from the region. Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., said even if Bush's goals are met and the emir of Kuwait is restored to rule, ``we are left with an Iraq to deal with afterwards.''

North Korea demanded Wednesday that South Korea release jailed dissidents and stop joint military exercises with the United States as a step toward easing tensions between the rival nations. During the historic meeting between the prime ministers of North and South Korea, the North also demanded that South Korea stop efforts to enter the United Nations separately, saying that to do so would perpetuate national division. ``We view these as very urgent, very serious matters ... directly connected with the future fate of this conference,'' North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk said. Yon stopped short of calling the demands a precondition for future talks, but he indicated North Korea might stall progress of the premiers' talks, the highest-level contact between the hostile nations since 1945. The prime ministers met Tuesday and opened formal talks Wednesday. They are to continue until Friday.

President Bush said Wednesday that the United States ``is making progress'' in the war on drugs, but one congressman said the year-old program isn't doing enough to help impoverished Americans. ``Drug czar (William J.) Bennett and President Bush cannot deny that we are losing the drug war in our inner cities,'' said Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations. ``Prevention and education efforts directed at the educated middle class appear to be having a dramatic effect,'' Conyers said. ``Treatment programs have room for clients who can afford to pay. However, the chronically addicted cannot pay when they are poor and unemployed, as is often the case.'' Bush and Bennett, the president's chief lieutenant in the drug war, emphasized the positive in speeches and a white paper released Wednesday, the first anniversary of the president's announcement of his war on drugs.

The eight-year battle over the Salt Caves hydroelectric project is a Western showdown reminiscent of those between free-range cattlemen and fence-building homesteaders. But this fight is between a coalition of a city, developers, a local congressman and a federal agency facing an alliance of state agencies, voters, out-of-town congressmen, fishermen, and environmentalists. At issue is an 11-mile stretch of the Klamath River 27 miles southwest of Klamath Falls in south-central Oregon. Initial proposals by the city of Klamath Falls would have drowned the river behind a dam, but the proposal now is for no dam at all _ just a series of canals and conduits bringing water from an existing dam upstream. That hasn't lessened opposition. Opponents say the project would destroy the last free-flowing, trout-filled stretch of a waterway already shackled by four dams. Supporters say the project can generate millions of dollars to help Klamath Falls get back on its feet after a decade of decline.

Before she died in January, Dorothea Allen destroyed family papers and letters and tore the date and place of birth from her passport. She left more than $2.8 million in cash, no traceable next of kin, no will, no birth certificate, no marriage certificate, and a growing list of claimants to her fortune. So far, 31 people have come forward, claiming to be heirs of the woman known in British newspapers as ``the vanishing lady.'' By law, claimants have 12 years to prove they are blood relatives. If they fail, the fortune goes to the state treasury. Treasury lawyers ordered the sale of her effects, including mink coats, a 1972 Rolls-Royce Corniche and a 1964 Daimler, jewelry, paintings, furniture, silver and other trappings from a glamorous past that by some accounts included a trip across the dance floor with Fred Astaire. The sale, conducted Tuesday by Sotheby's at her 300-year-old home, added $1.08 million cash to the estate. The home itself, in the village of Sutton-under-Brailes 90 miles northwest of London, is expected to fetch another $1.3 million when it is sold.

Sex may be on the minds of nearly everybody, but a new Kinsey Institute survey finds that most Americans don't know much about it. Fifty-five percent of those surveyed flunked a test of basic sexual knowledge, Kinsey director June Reinisch said Wednesday. Only about 25 percent knew that the typical American has first intercourse at age 16 to 17, or that an estimated 30 percent to 40 percent of married men have had an extramarital affair, the report said. Only 21 percent knew that more than a quarter of American men have had a sexual experience with another male as an adolescent or adult. Half incorrectly thought that rectal intercourse itself can cause AIDS, even if neither partner was infected by the AIDS virus. The poll's 18 questions were drawn from those most often asked of the Kinsey Institute, and represent facts that ``people need to know for both their physical health and their mental health,'' Reinisch said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Otis Elevator Establishing Presence in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Otis Elevator Co.'s German operation has signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in an East German elevator maker, the Farmington-based company announced Wednesday. The East German company, Berliner Aufzugs-und Fahrtreppenbau GmbH, or BAF, is a subsidiary of a government-owned conglomerate and employs 1,000 workers. The agreement is subject to approval by government agencies in West Germany and East Germany. Terms were not disclosed. BAF, which supplies and services electric passenger and freight elevators in East Germany, operates two manufacturing facilities in East Berlin and several small branch offices. The joint operations will manufacture, install and maintain elevator equipment using Otis designs, technology and installation and maintenance methods. ``With Germany moving rapidly toward full unification, this acquisition positions Otis to capitalize on emerging growth opportunities in the region,'' said J.P. Van Rooy, Otis executive vice president and chief operating officer. In recent weeks, Otis announced separate agreements to establish manufacturing joint ventures in the Soviet Union and Hungary. Otis, the world's largest elevator manufacturer, had 1989 revenues of $3.3 billion, of which 70 percent came from outside the U.S. The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of Ha ordered a trial for two men and a woman accused of trying to illegally export nuclear detonating triggers to Iraq. The three defendants, who were released on bail, did not enter a plea with the magistrates in Brent, a borough in northwest London. The accused are Toufic Fouad Amyuni, 37, a Lebanese engineer; Ali Ashour Daghir, 49, an executive with dual Iraqi and British nationality; and Jeanine Celestine Speckman, 41, a Frenchwomen employed by Daghir. Daghir's company, Euromac Ltd., was order to face trial on the same charge. No trial date was set. The accusations relate to an attempt to export 40 electrical capacitors through London's Heathrow airport and other places in Britain. A consignment of U.S.-made capacitors was seized at Heathrow in March by British authorities working with the United States. At the time, U.S. prosecutors said the devices could be used for detonating nuclear warheads. Britain later expelled an Iraqi Airways executive in connection with an alleged plot to smuggle the devices. In 1981, Israeli warplanes destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor believed capable of producing nuclear arms. Israeli officials say Iraq is now trying to restore its program.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Announces Three-Year Replacement Guarantee
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Wednesday began offering a ``Total Satisfaction Guarantee'' that promises a free replacement to customers dissatisfied with any of the company's products. The guarantee covers all Xerox products delivered from now on for three years, or for the full term of financing through Xerox, whichever is longer. A customer not totally satisfied with a product, for whatever reason, can have it replaced with the same or comparable product, entirely at Xerox expense, company officials said at a news conference. ``We believe this is clearly different from anything that's out there today,'' said Paul V. Cahn, vice president of reprographics and customer service marketing. ``The customer is the sole arbiter and decision-maker. With virtually every other guarantee or warranty, the company decides whether a replacement is needed.'' David Schofield, an industry analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago, said the guarantee ``might help ease a little buyer fear,'' and is probably more psychological than anything else. ``I don't know that it's going to be a huge boost to sales,'' he said. ``I agree with them that it probably won't cost a whole lot, either.'' James J. Miller, Xerox's manager of reprographic product marketing, said the company does not expect the guarantee to be a major expense. ``We don't think that we're going to get a lot of machines back,'' he said. For the past two years, Xerox has offered three-year warranties covering repairs on most of its low-volume consumer products. Under those warranties, the company decided whether or not to replace a machine, Cahn said. The new guarantee supplements existing warranties and applies to machines bought, rented or leased from Xerox or an authorized dealer. Customers must have a Xerox service contract. Cahn said Xerox expects the guarantee to increase sales in all areas. The pledge will be extensively advertised over the next few weeks, he said. ``Standing behind Xerox equipment to the point of replacement is good for the customer and it's good for Xerox,'' he said. Xerox also announced the introduction of two new small copiers, the Xerox 5034 and the 5011 R-E.

DOC.HEAD: Announce Plan for Electronic Trading of Unregistered Securities
DOC.TEXT: The American Stock Exchange on Wednesday announced plans to develop an electronic system with Reuters Holdings PLC for trading securities in the $170 billion private placement market. The announcement follows a recent rule change by the Securities and Exchange Commission making it easier for securities firms to sell unregistered stocks and bonds to big institutions. Amex said the new electronic marketplace for trading the securities is expected to be implemented in the first half of 1991 and will be called the System for Institutional Trading of Unregistered Securities, of SITUS. Amex Chairman James R. Jones said in a statement the new system would ``help companies from any country to gain access to a rich and largely untapped source of capital liquidity.'' The SEC's new rule 144a exempts U.S. and foreign institutions from registration requirements for the sale of stocks and bonds to big institutions. The market is used largely to sell corporate debt. The rule was expected to give a boost to the securities industry during a slump in trading of stocks and bonds on the public market and other business areas. But activity there has slumped as well. U.S. private placement financings fell by one third in the first half of 1990 to $55.3 billion from $82.1 billion a year earlier, IDD Information Services said Tuesday. The drop occurred despite the SEC rule change and a drying up in the junk bond market as a source for corporate financing, IDD said. Under the agreement for private placement electronic trading, SITUS owuld be a division or subsidiary of the exchange. The exchange would be responsible for regulating and administering the system, which would be developed, operated, owned and maintained by Reuters, a worldwide business news-gathering and information-distribution organization.

DOC.HEAD: Some Figures on the S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With BC-S&Ls on Main Street III. The $50 figure in ``actually paid'' section is cq. Also moving on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Here is a scorecard on the savings and loan situation as of Aug. 1. Information was supplied by the Justice Department, Resolution Trust Corp. and various sources:

COST: $500 billion or more over 30 years. SCOPE: 468 thrifts taken over in 39 states as of July 30. Of these, 211 were either sold or closed. The other 257 are in conservatorship. CHARGED: 328 defendants indicted. CONVICTED: 231 defendants; 5 others acquitted. JAIL TERMS: 1.9 years on average. The average term for a bank robber is 9.4 years. PENALTIES: $56.6 million ordered in restitution, including $25 million in civil settlements. FINES IMPOSED: $1 million. ACTUALLY PAID: Of the $2.5 million ordered in restitution this year in cases prosecuted by the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force, the only one for which statistics were available, $50 has been paid. In the previous two years, $23,700 of $8.9 million ordered in restitution has been paid. PENDING: 84 civil lawsuits against 48 thrifts in an attempt to recover lost money. Also pending, about 40,000 lawsuits in an attempt to recover money from thrift officers.

DOC.HEAD: Four Years After Merger, Unisys Struggles To Return To Profitability
With Graphic, LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: All's not happy here on Jolly Road, home of the nation's third-largest computer company. Unisys Corp., the behemoth created by Burroughs Corp.'s 1986 purchase of Sperry Corp., is struggling mightily to make money once again after reporting a staggering $639 million loss last year. Since last October, it has slashed more than 8,000 jobs, closed plants and refocused its mishmash of inherited product lines. Still, the red ink keeps flowing. In July, Unisys reported a $45.1 million loss in the year's first half after paying preferred-stock dividends. Two weeks ago, the company's stock price plunged to a 52-week low after several industry analysts reduced their earnings forecasts. The cutbacks, losses and a Pentagon bribery scandal at the Unisys defense division are said to have taken their toll on morale among the company's 78,000 employees. But the payback from the belt-tightening should appear later this year, analysts say, when they expect Unisys to report a profit in the fourth quarter. ``Once those plants are closed and the benefits start flowing through, it's virtually impossible to build a scenario where they're not in the black,'' said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The situation wasn't always bleak. Most observers agree Burroughs' $4.8 billion merger with Sperry initially was a success. The consolidation of the two old-line computer companies led to a streamlining that cut costs and improved profits. In a burst of optimism, W. Michael Blumenthal, the Burroughs chairman who engineered the merger, launched the renamed company on an ambitious plan to double annual sales to $20 billion by 1993. He predicted Unisys would rival International Business Machines Corp., the world's largest computer maker. But the scheme of the former U.S. Treasury secretary flopped. The computer industry's breakneck growth slowed to a trot in the late 1980s and major corporations began to move away from large mainframe computers _ Unisys' mainstay product _ to smaller models. That left Unisys with warehouses full of unsold computers and unneeded production lines, analysts say. ``You don't take two slow-growing companies and turn them into one fast growing company,'' said Martin. With profits strangled, Unisys was forced to borrow up to $1.5 billion to pay shareholder dividends, analysts say, pumping up its debt to a high of $4.1 billion last year. Unisys also saw its important government business drop last year when its defense unit was barred from bidding on contracts for three months as part of the ``Ill Winds'' probe of Pentagon fraud. Several Unisys executives pleaded guilty to bribery and Unisys still faces a possible fine. To help fix the problems, Blumental in October announced the sweeping restructuring, taking a $231 million charge against earnings to pay for it. In April, he relinquished day-to-day control and his chief executive title to James A. Unruh, a longtime Burroughs executive. In a recent interview, Unruh spoke frankly about the company's troubles. ``We had a very difficult 1989. It seemed like whatever could go wrong did go wrong,'' he said at the company's sprawling headquarters complex in this Philadelphia suburb. Unruh admitted Unisys misjudged the U.S. computer industry slowdown, but noted the company's plight wasn't unique. Digitial Equipment Corp., the world's second-largest computer company, reported its first-ever quarterly loss earlier this year and has eliminated thousands of jobs. IBM also has been cutting costs. The industry is undergoing a painful transition as large computers are losing favor to cheaper _ and less profitable _ midsize and desktop models that often are linked in networks. In addition, companies increasingly want computers that use industry-standard operating systems, the base layer of software that controls internal computer functions. With the move to these ``open'' systems, which Unisys has joined, profits have been squeezed as computers become more like interchangeable commodities. Unruh said the cutbacks have been painful both to him and employees. ``Closing plants is not a pleasant process. Reducing employment is not a pleasant process at all,'' said the soft-spoken North Dakota native, whose team-oriented management style is said to differ markedly from that of the more demonstrative Blumenthal. Unruh, 49, said no more major cutbacks are planned, but he wouldn't rule them out if the economy continues to sour. Unisys also could be hurt by a steeper-than-expected scaleback in U.S. defense spending, which accounts for about 22 percent of its revenue, he said. Unisys, which traces its history to the first successful electronic computer, the giant ENIAC machine built at the University of Pennsylvania in the mid-1940s, has reorganized its operations around customer lines of business instead of the size of its computers. For example, it has targeted the airline, health care, insurance, banking and phone companies, among others, as areas where it can offer specialized software and services, along with Unisys computers. The strategy is a contrast from past practice, Unruh said, when Unisys would tell its customers, `` `We've got the next bigger, faster box for you. Here it is. Good luck.' Because that's where we stopped.'' By becoming an expert in particular businesses, and providing specialized software, Unisys can differentiate itself from competitors who also are promoting industry-standard computers, Unruh said. Sensing that hooking computers in a network was a growing trend, Unisys made two major acquistions in 1988: Timeplex Inc., a maker of networking equipment, which it acquired in a $300 million stock swap, and Convergent Technologies Inc., a maker of networked desktop computers, which it bought for $350 million. Unisys says it will provide ways to use mainframe computers as the ``information hub'' of computer networks that adhere to industry standards at the desktop level. A strategy based on networked, industry-standard computers is not foolproof, said Wendy Abramowitz, an analyst at Argus Research Corp., a New York investment research firm. Almost every computer company is singing the same song, making it a very competitive market, she said. Also, the company must not alienate its many longtime mainframe customers, analysts say. These machines will be based on the old Burroughs and Sperry proprietary systems for the foreseeable future. Debt reduction is another area Unruh has targeted. The company announced in June it would sell $150 million in convertible preferred stock to Mitsui & Co., Unisys' longtime Japanese business partner, to reduce Unisys' debt by that amount. That also could help boost Unisys' stock price, which sank to around $8 a share in recent weeks from a high of $30.25 last year. ``I can understand why the stock price has gone down. People want to see results,'' said Unruh. ``The actions to be taken are just the basic actions of turning the business around.''

DOC.HEAD: Spain Seeking Fiat Again to Buy State's Truckmaker
DOC.TEXT: The government is seeking to get Italy's Fiat group back in the bidding for its ailing state truckmaker Empresa Nacional de Autocamiones SA (Enasa), because its earlier deal with Germany's Daimler-Benz AG has collapsed, a newspaper said. Spain's leading daily El Pais Wednesday reported that Spanish Industry Ministry officials opened talks with Fiat after an agreement for a joint buyout by Daimler-Benz and Man AG fell apart. In a decision last November, the Spanish government gave the nod to a joint bid for Enasa by Daimler-Man over offers by Fiat SpA, Anglo-Dutch truckmaker DAF NV, and AB Volvo of Sweden. Daimler-Man had offered to pay 36 billion pesetas, or about $380 million, for a total 80 percent stake. Enasa's state owner, the National Industrial Institute, would hold the rest. But in July, the West German Federal Cartel office stunned Spain by blocking the purchase on antitrust grounds, even though the West German government had strongly lobbied Spain for the deal. El Pais said Industry Ministry Claudio Aranzadi traveled to Turin, Italy, in early August to meet with Fiat managing director Cesare Romiti. On Wednesday, an Industry spokesman said talks with Daimler-Benz continued, but he declined to confirm or deny contacts had been made with Fiat officials. A Fiat spokesman said he had no knowledge of meetings with Spanish officials. Enasa posted profits last year of 240 million pesetas, or $2.47 million, ending years of losses.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Off Sharply, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar sank against all major foreign currencies Wednesday in trading punctuated by widespread talk of lower U.S. interest rates. Gold prices moved higher in most world trading centers. Heavy dollar selling began in Asia and carried over into later European and U.S. dealing. The sales were triggered by speculation that the Federal Reserve soon might seek to foster a U.S. economic rebound by pushing interest rates down. Falling U.S. rates would reduce returns on dollar holdings and lessen investment interest in dollars. Currency dealers said the dollar also was hampered by speculation that West Germany and Japan soon may raise their interest rates. Higher rates in those countries, especially if U.S. rates go down, would tend to spur demand for marks and yen. Commenting on the dollar's selloff, analyst David Marshall of MMS International said, ``I think on the whole it was a lot of speculation about the Fed easing. There was speculation about U.S. rates moving down and other rates moving up.'' Financial markets are awaiting the government's monthly unemployment report, due Friday, for indications of the economy's condition in August. Evidence of new softening in the labor market would bolster the case for the central bank to loosen its monetary policy. Remarks Wednesday by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that the United States will regret involvement in the Middle East appeared to have only a minor impact on the dollar. If the Persian Gulf situation stokes inflation and stalls the U.S. economy, the dollar would suffer. One of the most pronounced moves of the day was the dollar's drop against the yen. It was quoted at 141.65 yen late in New York trading, down from 143.40 on Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 142.30 Japanese yen from 144.05 yen at Tuesday's close and in London it fell to 141.75 yen. The British pound gained against the dollar. Sterling strengthened in New York with a pound fetching $1.9055 in late trading, compared to $1.8810 Tuesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8990 from $1.8750 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5580 German marks, down from 1.58115; 1.2945 Swiss francs, down from 1.3135; 5.2180 French francs, down from 5.2965; 1,162.00 Italian lire, down from 1,179.00; and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16075. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with levels late Tuesday were: 1.5630 West German marks, down from 1.5843; 1.2963 Swiss francs, down from 1.3170; 5.2375 French francs, down from 5.3105; 1.7607 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7860; 1,166.00 Italian lire, down from 1,182.25; and 1.1532 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1623. Bullion dealers said gold prices rose in reaction to the weaker dollar. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for September delivery added $2.40 to settle at $386.10. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $387.20 for a ounce of gold, up $2.60 from Tuesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold moved to a late bid of $387.75 a troy ounce in London, up from $382.50 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $385.75 from Tuesday's late bid of $382.25. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.33 to close at a bid of $384.02. Silver rose in New York and London. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of silver for September delivery rose to $4.735 from Tuesday's settlement of $4.719. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.78 a troy ounce from $4.75 late Tuesday.

Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 144.64 million shares. Traders appeared to find little cause in the economic and financial news to make many big changes in their positions. Oil prices were moderately higher Wednesday as they continued to respond to events in the month-old showdown in the Middle East. But interest rates declined a bit in the credit markets. Analysts said stock-market investors were awaiting Friday's monthly report from the Labor Department on the employment situation. DOC.HEAD: Wheat Rebounds on Hopes U.S. Will Give Soviets Food Credit
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rebounded strongly Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, ending a six-day decline amid speculation the United States will offer food credits to the Soviet Union. Other grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher after the Agriculture Department reported a slight deterioration in the condition of the U.S. soybean crop. On other commodity markets, oil and precious metal futures advanced and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Wheat futures settled 3{ cents to 6} cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.63 a bushel; corn futures were 1\ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with September at $2.43\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with September at $1.08} a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents lower to 5 cents higher with September at $6.11} a bushel. Wheat's rally represented the market's first upward move since Aug. 24, when the September contract settled at $2.84} a bushel. The September price fell 28{ cents, or about 10 percent, in the interim, reflecting an abundance of wheat on the world market due to favorable growing conditions in much of the Northern Hemisphere. Analysts said speculation that the United States will offer the Soviets food credits mounted after Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday that deteriorating Soviet food supplies could warrant a technical exemption from a law prohibiting such credits to countries that are not among America's most-favored trading partners. ``I think they're going to get credit,'' said Katharina Zimmer, grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. ``Considering how the Soviet Union has supported the U.S. position in the Persian Gulf, I'd be willing to bet you five bucks they will get it,'' she said. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said rumors circulated that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev would strike a deal on food credits at their meeting this weekend. But Frick said she doubted the process would move that quickly. Oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange as tensions rose in the Persian Gulf. The higher prices extended Tuesday's sharp gains and reignited inflation fears, which prompted a runup in precious metal futures prices on New York's Commodity Exchange. Among other developments in the Gulf, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said Wednesday that ``the children in Iraq are dying'' because of U.N.-supported economic sanctions, but he appeared to retract an earlier appeal for foreign help to circumvent the embargo. Saddam also renewed his call for an Islamic holy war to defeat Western forces and overthrow Arab leaders aligned against him, singling out Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. On the New York Merc, light sweet crude oil futures finished 33 cents to 76 cents higher with October at $29.77 a barrel; heating oil was .98 cent to 2.74 cents higher with October at 83.37 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.25 cents lower to 2.71 cents higher with October at 92.27 cents a gallon. On the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $2.40 to $2.70 higher with September at $386.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.8 cent to 1.6 cents higher with September at $4.735 a troy ounce. Cattle futures ended narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with support provided by higher-than-expected top steer prices paid in the Southern Plains. Pork futures were mostly higher, reflecting higher cash markets and expectations for stronger pork demand. Live cattle futures settled .07 cent lower to .25 cent higher with October at 77.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .08 cent higher with September at 87.02 cents a pound; hogs were .03 cent lower to .35 cent higher with October at 49.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent to .90 cent higher with February at 51.10 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Call for Holy War Boosts Oil Prices
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose to nearly $30 per barrel Wednesday as traders began buying in response to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's televised call for an Arab holy war against the West. Light sweet crude for October delivery rose 65 cents to close at $29.77 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The price rose as high as $29.89 before falling back. ``It was full of religious fanaticism, and I think people kind of got nervous and started bidding the market back up,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``We're getting close to that $30 mark, and it looks like people might want to get up there and test that $30 area,'' he said. Traders also said prices were partially keeping pace with a bullish oil market in Europe. Other petroleum futures were mixed. Unleaded gasoline dropped 2.25 cents to 92.27 cents per gallon for October delivery. Speculators were either taking profits from the previous day's jump or selling gasoline so they could buy more crude, said Randall Rothenberg, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Later contract months for gasoline were up. Home heating oil for October rose .98 cent to 83.37 cents per gallon, while later months were also up. Natural gas was up to $1.514 per 1,000 cubic feet, compared with Tuesday's close of $1.510. Traders said Wednesday's rise in oil prices was also partly attributable to speculation on Wall Street that the American Petroleum Institute on Wednesday would report a decline in the nation's stockpiles of crude. The API report, which is released after the markets close, said crude stocks for the week ending Aug. 31 were at 372.2 million barrels, down from 376.6 million barrels a week earlier but up from 335.8 million barrels a year earlier. Crude imports were up to 6.8 million barrels a day, compared with imports of 6.6 million barrels a week earlier and 6.4 million barrels a year earlier, API said. Crude stocks were down because companies were drawing on their supplies, Tagler said. The stockpile of gasoline was virtually unchanged for the week at 210.5 million barrels. Imports stood at 192,000 barrels, compared with 287,000 barrels a week earlier and 221,000 barrels a year earlier. Analysts have attributed the drop in gasoline imports to supplies that were diverted to other buyers after the boycott of Iraq and Kuwait cut into the world's refining capacity. Companies also traditionally try to avoid holding onto too much gasoline after Labor Day, considered to be the end of the peak summer driving season, an API spokesman said. The price of gasoline dropped at the pump, the American Automobile Association reported Wednesday. The nationwide average price for a gallon of self-serve unleaded regular was $1.273, down 3.4 cents from a week earlier, the AAA said. The retail pump price remained about 19.8 cents higher than on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the AAA said. A spokesman for the Service Station Dealers of America said the decrease was attributable to lower prices charged by gasoline suppliers.

DOC.HEAD: Next Generation Is Plugged In At IBM
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: IBM unveiled a new generation of mainframe computers Wednesday that it said would double the power of its most profitable machines and cement their position at the center of office computing. The announcement, made at the company's U.S. mainframe factory, was billed as the most important rollout for International Business Machines Corp. in 25 years. The success of the new machines is crucial to the world's largest computer company because it derives about half its income from mainframes and associated equipment and software. The move was well publicized in advance, but industry experts were still impressed with the scope of the company's new strategy. The announcement crystallized a new vision for how IBM believes mainframe computers should fit into today's decentralized computer systems, where desktop machines are almost as common as telephones. ``You saw it piecemeal before,'' said industry consultant Sam Albert. The new machines show that IBM intends the mainframe to be the ``traffic cop'' of computer networks, said Albert, a former IBM executive. In addition to annoucing 18 new machines, IBM said it would provide systems that will allow mainframes to manage information on all sorts of computers throughout a company. Such systems would address the growing concern of companies that too much information is spread among desktop computers that don't communicate well with each other. The company said it also will provide products that will make it easier to connect non-IBM computers to a network of IBM machines. IBM's new mainframes provide about twice the processing power of the three mainframe lines they replace and are priced from $70,480 to $22.8 million. The line is IBM's response to several Japanese mainframe makers that recently announced new high-end models. On Tuesday, Fujitsu Ltd. announced a new mainframe it said would be the world's fastest. IBM dismissed that claim, saying it has provided the most powerful machines for years and will continue to do so. The new computers are part of a model line IBM calls System-390. It is intended to be the successor to IBM's original mainframe line, the System-360, which was introduced in 1964, and the System-370, introduced in 1970. Among the machines' advances are fiber-optic lines that, compared with the copper lines they replace, more than double the rate at which information can be transferred to the computers from the huge data-storage devices used with mainframes. The fiber-optic lines, which transmit data as flashes of laser light, also allow the data-storage devices to be located several miles from the computers themselves, instead of several hundred feet with copper cable. IBM said that would give customers more flexibility in locating computer rooms. IBM also will provide the means to link together up to eight of the new models to vastly increase processing power. This is the first time IBM has provided such a linkup. In addition, IBM announced the first encryption device that can built into a computer. The optional coding device would be useful to protect the security of transactions such as electronic funds tranfers between banks, the company said. It also said the Central Intelligence Agency has expressed interest in the device. IBM also said it will sell devices that can boost the power of the most powerful model of the new line to supercomputer status. Supercomputers are used for such calculation-intensive tasks as weather forecasting. The so-called ``price-performance'' measure of the new computers, which compares the price with the machines' processing power, is 15 percent to 25 percent greater than the models they replace, said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. IBM said the System-390 represents the first generational change in its mainframes in which owners of most existing machines can easily upgrade to the new line. The two high-end models of the new line won't be available until the third quarter of 1991, IBM said. That could provoke some customers who need that level of power to consider competing machines, analysts said. IBM said the delay was due to normal testing procedures on the advanced processors that will drive the new high-end models. The processors in the models that are available immediately or in coming months are based on IBM's existing high-end mainframes, the 3090 series, said Carl J. Conti, the IBM senior vice president in charge of mainframes. Conti said he expected customers who need the power of the new high-end machines will buy the models that are available, then upgrade the computers with the new processors. IBM has come under increasing pressure in recent years from makers of IBM-compatible mainframes, principally Fujitsu, Hitachi Data Systems Corp. and Amdahl Corp. Amdahl is 45 percent owned by Fujitsu, while Hitachi Data Systems is partially owned by Hitachi of Japan. These three companies often undercut IBM's prices, and their share of the mainframe market has been growing as IBM's has slipped. However, IBM still holds about 87 percent of the U.S. high-end mainframe market, says Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., research firm. Because Wednesday' announcement had been expected, the stock market reaction was muted. IBM shares finished off 12{ cents for the day at $102.37{.

DOC.HEAD: Subcommittee Chairman to Seek Subpoenas For Good, Walters
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee chairman said Wednesday he will ask that two former Denver developers be subpoenaed to answer questions about their finances and failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan. Kenneth Good and Bill Walters defaulted on $132 million in loans from the former Denver thrift. They had been scheduled to appear Thursday before the House Banking Committee's subcommittee on financial institutions supervision, regulation and insurance. Members of Congress want the two to explain how they can maintain affluent lifestyles after claiming in earlier congressional testimony to have a ``negative net worth.'' This week, Good and Walters both refused to appear before the financial institutions subcommittee, so it cancelled the hearing. Subcommittee chairman Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., said Wednesday in a statement from his Washington office that he will seek a subpoena to force the two to testify. ``I am appalled by their actions,'' Annunzio said. ``Originally, they said they would testify voluntarily and I took their word in good faith. Now, at the last minute they say they will not attend. They falsely led the subcommittee to believe they would be in Washington on Thursday. ``I will not be deterred,'' he said. ``I will ask for a subpoena to compel them to testify.'' Good and Walters are two key figures in the investigation of Silverado's demise. Both invested in Silverado board member Neil Bush's Denver oil company and then Bush, as a board member of the thrift, voted in favor of big loans for the two. Good and Walters subsequently defaulted on the loans. Federal regulators closed Silverado in December 1988. The thrift failure is expected to cost taxpayers up to $1 billion. Walters and Good have both said they are broke and cannot repay the loans they obtained from Silverado. But officials were concerned about evidence to the contrary that surfaced in recent months. Walters, through a trust benefiting his wife, owns a $1.9 million home in Newport Beach, Calif.; a $1 million Palm Springs, Calif. home; and expensive cars and memberships in exclusive country clubs across the country. Good has a $700,000 home in Tampa, Fla., and a New York condominium. Good also stands to recover a $1.5 million Eagle-Vail golf course home he once owned. Annunzio said George Manning, Walters' attorney, reported that his client's life had been disrupted by his requested appearance before the subcommittee and that he would only appear if the panel met in a closed session. ``The American people have the right to hear everything involving the savings and loan scandal, and I will not be a party to any closed meetings to hear testimony from those who are responsible for this multi-billion scandal,'' Annunzio said. Gil Thurm, Good's lawyer in Washington, said Good could not attend the hearing because of a scheduling conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Economists Tell Congress of Dangers, Benefits of Foreign Investment
DOC.TEXT: Three economists told Congress Wednesday that foreign investment in the United States can be good, but must be closely watched by the government. The danger, they said, is predatory investment by foreign companies that buy their American competitors and shut them down. They also said business practices of other nations can conflict with American philosophies _ even to the point of running against U.S. law. ``We must reject the assertion that corporate nationality does not matter,'' said Steven Cohen, director of the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy at the University of California. For example, ``Japan's behavior is determined by rules that are very different from the United States,'' said Clyde Prestowitz, director of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. ``Most traditional business practices of Japan are contrary to anti-trust laws,'' he said. Prestowitz, Cohen and Robert Reich of Harvard University expressed their views to a congressional panel studying the government's role in a world economy dominated by multi-national corporations. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, asked the economists if a federal law should be passed limiting government subsidies to American-owned companies. Cohen said the ownership of the firm wasn't as important as its behavior in the United States. For example, a foreign-owned company that is creating employment, bringing in new technology and developing technology in the United States is benefiting this country, he said. Problems occur when foreign ownership starts changing the politics of the United States, the economists warned. Reich criticized the government's enforcement of anti-trust laws. He said lack of enforcement has caused monopolistic and predatory practices.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Trade Commission Approves Chemical Plant Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday approved the sale of a French-owned chemical plant in Thorofare, N.J., to a Dutch-owned firm to avoid potential price-fixing in the vinyl manufacturing industry. Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine of Paris will sell the plant to Ausimont U.S.A., Inc., for an undisclosed price, said Daniel Ducore of the FTC's Bureau of Competition. Atochem Inc., an Elf subsidiary in Glen Rock, N.J., last year acquired the Thorofare plant as part of a $1 billion purchase of Philadelphia-based Pennwalt Corp., Ducore said. After receiving a complaint, the commission became concerned that Elf's acquisition could reduce competition in the production and sale of two chemicals used to make vinyl-type plastics like wire insulation, Ducore said. ``To settle the commission concern, they agreed they'd sell off the Thorofare plant,'' he said. Ausimont, based in Morristown, N.J., is a subsidiary of Ausimont NV of the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: Saffels Orders Government to Give Up Control of Franklin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with further reax from OTC, minor editing; PICKUP 7th graf, Harris Weinstein . . .
DOC.TEXT: In apparently the first reversal of its kind for the Office of Thrift Supervision, a federal judge ruled Wednesday that the government must return control of the state's largest thrift to its management. U.S. District Judge Dale Saffels ordered the federal OTS to release the Franklin Savings Association from receivership by 10 a.m. Thursday. Saffels said decision to place Franklin under control of the federal Resolution Trust Corp. in February was ``arbitrary and capricious.'' Further, Saffels found the OTS decision ``lacked any basis in fact.'' Saffels also retained jurisdiction in the case for the next 90 days, meaning the OTS cannot appoint another conservator or attempt to place Franklin in receivership during that time without his approval. Saffels told reporters that after 90 days, the OTS could move against Franklin again. That could mean more court hearings, he said. ``And we'd probably start over again,'' he said. In Washington, OTS spokesman William Fulwider said he believes it is the first time a court has returned control of an S&L from the agency to private management. The OTS was set up about a year ago as part of the savings and loan bailout legislation. Harris Weinstein, chief counsel of the OTS, said in a statement that the thrift agency regretted Saffels' decision. ``We firmly believe the government acted in a timely and proper manner in taking over Franklin, an institution that was being operated with insufficient capital and in an unsafe and unsound manner,'' said the statement released in Washington. ``OTS continues to believe that the takeover of Franklin was fully justified and in the best interests of taxpayers, the (deposit) insurance fund and the institution's depositors.'' Weinstein's statement said the OTS plans to appeal the decision ``vigorously.'' He said the agency will ask the District Court to stay its order while the appeal is pending. If that motion is denied, the OTS will immediately seek a stay from the federal court of appeals in Denver, Weinstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Carries Campaign Against Koito To U.S. Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: T. Boone Pickens is taking his battle against a Japanese auto parts manufacturer to U.S. newspapers Thursday with a advertising campaign proclaiming ``America, You Lost the Economic War.'' In full-page ads appearing in the New York Times and Washington Post, Pickens says his fight with Koito Manufacturing Co. Ltd. is an example of how Japan is closed to foreign investors. The ads also claim the Japanese economy is being protected by the U.S. military in the Middle East and providing little in return. With 26 percent, Pickens is the largest shareholder of Koito but has been rejected in repeated attempts to gain seats on the board of directors. Koito claims Pickens is a stalking horse for another Japanese corporate raider. Pickens accuses Toyota Motor Co., Koito's largest customer and second largest shareholder, of controlling Koito and blocking him in order to keep hidden its amount of control. ``The Japanese refuse to play on a level playing field, causing the loss of American jobs and a growing U.S. trade imbalance,'' the ads say. ``Now Japan is even refusing to fully support America's military efforts in the Middle East where Japan gets all of its oil to fuel its economic machine.'' ``Japan's cartels are taking us to the cleaners, and laughing all the way to the bank,'' Pickens said. ``Now they are evening doing it under the protection of our aircraft in the Middle East. Earlier this week, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced an aid package of $1 billion for the U.S.-led force arrayed against Iraq and further assistance for Middle East countries hurt by the embargo on Baghdad. The government also asked the country's private industry to help support the multinational force in the Persian Gulf by providing jeeps, car-carrying ships and other products and services. Readers are asked to write President Bush, Trade Representative Carla Hills, Japanese U.S. Ambassador Ryohei Murata and others to complain about ``Toyota and other Japanese cartels taking advantage of America's fairness.'' Pickens plans to spend several hundred thousand dollars on the campaign, said associate Andrew Littlefair. The ads will also appear later in USA Today, plus large regional newspapers and special interest magazines. The ads also repeat taunts such as ``Yankee go home'' and ``Remember Pearl Harbor'' Pickens heard at Koito's annual meeting earlier this summer. ``I think (the ad) appears to be blatant Japan-bashing,'' said Koito spokesman Richard Wolf. ``And I think it is attempting to appeal to the lowest common denominator and I don't think that tack is going to be successful.'' ``What the ads are designed to do is camouflage the fact that he is pursuing his own personal financial agenda, and that is to obtain a greenmail payment for Koito stock that he is stuck with,'' Wolf said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf: ``He said,'' to CORRECT ``reaching'' to ``reducing'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The United States wants its allies to pay the entire cost of its military buildup in the Persian Gulf, an estimated $1 billion a month, senior administration officials said Wednesday. The officials provided some of the first specific figures on what President Bush had in mind when he called last week for America's allies to pay their fair share of the campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bush directed two of his closest Cabinet aides, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, on global fund-raising missions. Baker was scheduled to tour the oil-rich capitals of the Middle East while Brady was in the middle of a whirlwind tour of four capitals in four days. After meetings with French officials and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Brady's delegation made a refueling stop in Anchorage before flying on to meetings Friday with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. In London, Baker pronounced Mrs. Thatcher ``enormously supportive.'' Aides said she promised detailed figures soon. The secretary also said his French visit was a success. The senior administration officials, briefing reporters on condition that they not be named, said that Brady's mission was focusing on two types of assistance. One is emergency aid for countries especially hard hit by the trade embargo against Iraq and the other is cash and contributions to defray the costs incurred by the United States in its big buildup of troops and ships in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. The officials put the total cost of the buildup at $6 billion through the end of 1990 and estimated it would average $1 billion a month after that. A request to allies to meet the entire U.S. cost is reasonable, one official said, because ``they couldn't buy this (military) capability anywhere else in the world.'' The officials indicated that the administration hoped for many contributions such as oil, air and sea transportation and medical supplies, in part to blunt the criticism that cash donations effectively turn the U.S. military into a mercenary force. One official said the worldwide search for donations was linked in part to the U.S. budget deficit. Brady told reporters traveling aboard his plane Wednesday that the administration remained opposed to any efforts to reduce the targets for deficit reduction next year. He said the president strongly favored reducing the deficit, projected at $231 billion for the 12 months beginning Oct. 1, by $50 billion next year and reducing cumulative deficits by $500 billion over five years. Egypt, Jordan and Turkey would be the principal candidates for trade asssistance, estimated as needing $3.5 billion through the end of this year and another $7 billion next year. The officials said that the conversations with Thatcher and the French centered primarily on this issue and involved a dicusssion of a possible $3 billion in aid that the 12-nation European Community was scheduled to take up Friday at a meeting of European finance ministers in Rome. In addition to aid to the so-called front line states of Egypt, Turkey and Jordan and the military payments to the United States, the administration also wants to raise an unspecified amount to be used to alleviate economic damage from rising oil prices in countries such as the Philippines, Brazil and the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. The officials would not discuss an overall price tag but the various elements could well add up to more than $25 billion. The Paris and London stopovers were seen as a way for the United States to gain endorsements for Bush's call for burden-sharing before the administration solicits Japan and West Germany, two economic superpowers who have been accused, especially by many members of Congress, of not doing enough so far in the Persian Gulf crisis. The officials on Brady's plane said that Japan's pledge of $1 billion in aid was a good beginning but they did not dispute reports that the administration will press for more. One officials said that Taiwan, a country that is not on the travel agenda of either Brady or Baker, would be approached by a third-party emissary and asked for support. Because of diplomatic relations with mainland China, the United States is limited in the types of official contact it can have with Taiwan. Before leaving London, Brady rejected a suggestion that foreign leaders might resent being leaned on by the United States for economic help. ``Quite the contrary, Mrs. Thatcher thought it was exactly the right thing to do,'' Brady said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Injunction in Music-Cable Fight
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday refused to stop Home Box Office Inc. from showing films containing songs copyrighted by Broadcast Music Inc., in a licensing dispute involving nearly all of HBO's programming schedule. But U.S. District Judge John Sprizzo ordered HBO to pay BMI an interim fee for broadcasting films containing songs by BMI composers. BMI sued HBO in January as HBO's license was about to expire and the two sides couldn't agree on a new fee. The broad licensing dispute, which involves several lawsuits, focuses on who and how much should be paid to music syndicates for the songs heard during movies. Sprizzo refused to slap an injunction on HBO that would have prevented the pay-television service from showing about 80 movies on its September schedule that contain BMI songs, including ``Batman.'' Since its license expired Jan. 1, HBO has continued to broadcast such films without paying a fee. ``We would have no schedule without BMI music,'' HBO general counsel John Redpath Jr. said. ``And without a schedule we don't have a business.'' BMI attorney Robert Sisk could not be reached for comment. The lawsuit was filed amid efforts by BMI to boost its cable television levies. Beyond raising basic rates, BMI wants to collect from local cable systems as well as from cable programmers. It now charges just programmers. That aspect of the case still is in litigation, Redpath said. BMI represents more than 100,000 composers and publishers of more than 1.5 million songs, collecting a contracted fee whenever one of its songs is played. It licenses radio and television stations, hotel and restaurant chains, even discotheques. HBO, owned by Time Warner Inc., has more than 23 million subscribers, making it the largest pay-television service in the nation. Redpath said HBO has paid for music rights for more than a decade and was willing to negotiate a new fee. He said Sprizzo suggested HBO pay BMI 15 cents per subscriber, which Redpath called too high. Redpath said the two sides would negotiate. HBO's fees amounted to about 27 cents per subscriber to BMI and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which has about 45,000 members. BMI demanded a split license from HBO in which the cable service would buy performance rights for programs only until they are transmitted to the local oeprator. The operator, which transmits to the home viewer, would have to negotiate licenses separately. BMI has named Manhattan Cable Television Inc., a local operator and a unit of Time Warner, in the same lawsuit. HBO contends that split licenses violate antitrust laws, and says local operators with dozens of channels would be hard-pressed to negotiate individual licenses for each program. BMI lawyers have maintained that HBO has not proven that operators cannot negotiate individual licenses.

DOC.HEAD: LA Times President to Run Eastern Dailies; Fox to be Newsday President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands as writethru to BC-Newsday Appointment, f0057, incorporating information from that story.
DOC.TEXT: Richard T. Schlosberg III, the Los Angeles Times' president since 1988, has been appointed Times Mirror Corp. group vice president for newspapers. He'll run the media company's Eastern dailies. Schlosberg, 46, had been responsible for circulation, advertising, production, operations and other business functions at the Times. The newspaper this year became the nation's largest metropolitan daily, with a circulation of more than 1.2 million daily and 1.5 million Sunday. His appointment was nnounced Tuesday. In addition to the flagship Los Angeles Times, Times Mirror publishes Newsday on New York's Long Island, New York Newsday, the Baltimore Sun newspapers, The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, The (Allentown, Pa.) Morning Call, The (Stamford, Conn.) Advocate and Greenwich (Conn.) Time. On Wednesday, Newsday and New York Newsday announced that Douglas B. Fox, senior vice president for marketing, had been appointed president and chief operating officer. Fox, who joined Newsday in 1987 as a vice president of marketing, will be responsible for the day-to-day management of the newspaper, Publisher and Chief Executive Officer Robert M. Johnson said. The appointment ``will allow me to concentrate more on broad issues of policy, strategy, employee concerns and outside community relations,'' Johnson said. Advertising revenue at Times Mirror's eastern papers has fallen sharply this year, largely because of the weak Northeastern economy, Times Mirror Chief Executive Robert F. Erburu said July 24. He said that was a major reason that Times Mirror's first-half profits dropped 40 percent, to $93 million. Times Mirror also announced that the duties of Donald F. Wright, senior vice president, will be expanded to include supervision of budget and planning processes, public policy issues and multimedia efforts. He currently is responsible for the company's broadcast and cable-television groups. ``These changes will enhance Times Mirror's management strength at a critical time to meet the ongoing challenges of the media environment of the '90s,'' Erburu said in a statement. In announcing Schlosberg's appointment, Times Mirror said it was too early to say when or whether he will be replaced as president of the Times. Schlosberg will assume his new duties by the end of September, when he also will become chairman of Times Mirror's newspaper management committee. Schlosberg joined Times Mirror in 1983. He served as publisher and chief executive of the Denver Post for four years. Then he moved to the Los Angeles Times. From 1980 to 1983, he was senior vice president of Harte-Hanks Communications and president of Harte-Hanks' newspaper operations.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Says ABC-CFA Television Contracts Are Anti-Competitive
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Updates with ABC comment, details of contracts, other information; A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission filed an administrative complaint against the College Football Association and Capital Cities-ABC Inc. on Wednesday, saying their national television contracts are anti-competitive. The five-page complaint, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, said competition among schools and networks for college football games has been hindered and that ``consumers have been deprived of the selection of college football games that would otherwise have been televised in a competitive environment.'' The FTC asked that the CFA and Cap Cities appear before an administrative law judge on Nov. 13 in Washington. The FTC could void the national television contracts and prohibit the CFA from negotiating new deals for all its members. ABC currently televises games under a contract with the Big Ten and Pacific-10 conferences. The CFA's $64 million four-year contract with CBS expires after this season and it is scheduled to begin a $210 million, five-year deal with ABC in 1991. In addition, the CFA has a deal with ESPN that expires after this season and a $125 million, five-year renewal with ESPN that begins in 1991. Cap Cities owns 80 percent of ESPN and the other 20 percent is owned by RJR Nabisco Inc. The CFA is comprised of 64 schools from all major conferences except the Big Ten and Pac-10. The association announced the filing of the complaint at its Boulder, Colo., office after Lew Engman, its Washington lawyer, received the papers. ``We are disappointed that the FTC has decided to file a complaint against the CFA,'' the association said in a statement. ``Such action, however, should not be construed as a finding that the CFA has acted unlawfully, but rather as an initiation of the formal hearing process.'' ABC Sports spokesman Mark Mandel said the network did not have a comment since it had not yet seen the complaint. Engman said the FTC did not take the more drastic step of going to federal district court for an injunction against the contracts. Mary L. Azcuenaga, one of the commissioners, dissented from the complaint. Another commissioner, Deborah K. Owen, dissented in part. After the administrative law judge makes his ruling, either side can appeal to the five commissioners of the FTC. If the full commission rules against the CFA, the association can appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals. The FTC scheduled a news conference for Thursday to discuss the complaint. The papers say that, ``Competition among schools in the marketing of college football telecasts has been hindered, restrained, foreclosed and frustrated; and competition among telecasters of college football games has been hindered, restrained, foreclosed and frustrated.'' The FTC said these acts ``constitute unfair methods of competition in or affecting commerce.'' The CFA began marketing football games in 1984. In June of that year, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the NCAA violated antitrust law by selling national TV contracts.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Dollar Declines, Share Prices Inch Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar approached its lowest opening level in almost a year against the Japanese yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange inched up. The dollar opened at 141.48 yen, down 0.82 yen from its Wednesday close. The dollar was quoted at 141.65 yen, late during New York's Wednesday session. The dollar opened at 140.97 yen on Oct. 19, 1989. A trader with Fuji Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the lower opening was in part due to a rumor that life insurance companies had sold dollars in Sydney, prior to the opening of the Tokyo market. Buy orders for the dollar appeared on the Tokyo market shortly after it opened, he said. ``Dealers are adjusting positions ahead of possible credit easing (by the U.S. Federal Reserve) and employment statistics due to come out'' Friday, he said. Many economists say the U.S. economy is headed into a recession and the Fed will move to lower interest rates to spark economic activity. Lower interest rates tend to make a nation's currency less attractive to foreign investors. In stock trading, the closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 32.30 points, or 0.13 percent, in the first 30 minutes of trading. On Wednesday the index fell 829.30 points. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond declined to 82.62 points, from 82.76 Wednesday. Its yield was 8.210 percent, up from 8.180 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc Tightens Stock-Index Circuit Breaker
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said Wednesday it wants to tighten up the so-called ``circuit breakers'' in its stock-index futures market in a further attempt to prevent a runaway stock-market collapse. The Merc said it had applied to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to reduce the maximum daily price limit for Standard & Poor's 500 index futures to 20 points from 30 points. The new limit would be equivalent to about 150 points on the Dow Jones industrial average. The current limit of 30 points is equal to more than 250 Dow points. The Merc's board of governors approved the lower limit after studying the workings of circuit breakers during recent periods of extreme market volatility that occurred during the week after Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August. ``On the whole, the circuit breakers have been given high marks and have been cited as having a stabilizing effect on the market,'' the exchange said in a statement. ``After consultations with futures and securities industry market participants, the board concluded it would be beneficial to further reduce the maximum daily price limit for S&P futures,'' the Merc said. S&P 500 futures are the most widely traded stock-index futures, which are contracts to buy and sell baskets of stocks. The contracts enable investors to hedge against stock-market losses or speculate on stock prices without actually owning stocks. Some critics contend computer-driven trading strategies involving huge blocks of stocks and futures can cause violent price swings in the stock market. Limits on the price movement of the futures contracts are intended to act as brakes on a runaway stock market.
